HEADLINE: Weeklong Wonders: Quickly Qualifying to Drive a Bus

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
As Janet Lucci steered a 27,000-pound city bus down Bay Parkway in Bensonhurst, a passenger started yelling that she was driving too slowly.
"I'm gonna be late for work!" he shouted. "Speed it up, will you, honey!"
Ms. Lucci did not speed it up. It was her first day ferrying passengers and a 40-foot vehicle through the mean and unpredictable streets of New York, and she was taking no chances. 
 Before last week, Ms. Lucci, a 41-year-old former delicatessen owner, had never driven anything larger than a delivery van. But in just two days of classroom training and five days of driving an empty bus with an instructor, Ms. Lucci and the 37 other students in her class had gone from crashing into curbs and hitting telephone poles to picking up passengers and stopping on a dime.
Unlike airplane pilots, subway motormen and railroad engineers -- all of whom must train for months or even years before they are allowed take the controls with real people aboard -- New York City bus drivers are expected to master the fine points of the trade in less than a week.
 
A Horn and a Brake
 Despite the apparent pitfalls, the decades-old system seems to work pretty well: the Transit Authority reports very few accidents involving first-time bus drivers. Experienced drivers ride along with rookies for their first few weeks, and transit officials said that new drivers who have problems receive additional training.
But for a rookie, driving a bus for the first time is still a little scary. "I was really nervous at first because things happen that are beyond your control, like a car darting out or a person running into the street," Ms. Lucci said. "More than anything else you have to drive defensively."
Calvin Worrell, a 23-year-old college student who drove a B-60 bus from Williamsburg to Canarsie last week, greeted passengers on his maiden trip with a friendly hello but found his best friends to be his horn and his brake. He used both frequently. He honked his horn at pedestrians, and he honked at cars that came too close to the bus.
"Whenever I'm unsure what someone will do, I hit my horn to warn them I'm coming," Mr. Worrell said. "You can never be too careful." At the corner of Himrod and Wilson Streets, a truck stopped suddenly in front of the bus, and Mr. Worrell stamped on the brakes, sending passengers flying around the bus. A woman screamed. Another gasped.
William Bennett, a 22-year veteran driver who was on the bus to supervise Mr. Worrell, told him not to worry because "sudden stops sometimes happen." "Overall, he's a good driver because he's very conscientious," Mr. Bennett said.
Not everyone who applies to become a city bus driver makes it through the training. Applicants must first take a civil service test, pass a medical exam and drug test, obtain a learner's permit to drive a commercial vehicle and have a good driving record.
Last year, the Transit Authority was sharply criticized for hiring bus drivers with poor driving records and for failing to monitor drivers who may be medically unfit to operate buses.
As a result, the investigation by the inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority found, people who should have been disqualified as drivers under state regulations were hired and were later involved in serious bus accidents.
State regulations require that a bus driver applicant must not have more than three moving violations and no suspensions within three years of the application date.
 
Fear of Flying
 Transit Authority officials said the agency had now installed a computer link with the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles' data base to insure that they have up-to-date records of applicants' driving histories.
Transit officials said that an average of two to three people in every 30- to 40-member class do not become drivers, often because they are physically incapable of operating the bus -- like one woman who was too short to reach the pedals.
"Some people are just too afraid, and they never get the hang of it and end up dropping out before we tell them they are not cut out to be drivers," said Michael Donovan, a Transit Authority bus instructor. "But I am happy that we have this," Mr. Donovan said, pointing to a hand brake. "Otherwise, I'd have a very upset stomach with the way some students drive."
On an isolated Soundview Avenue in the Clasons Point section of the Bronx, Mr. Donovan teaches students to drive a city bus by having them make "zigzags" -- alternating from one side of the street to the other. At the end of the street the students turn the bus around and head back the other way. "This is a little boring at first but it will help you get a feel for how to handle it," he said, holding tight to the hand brake that he uses to stop the bus if a student goes too close to the curb.
 
300,000 Miles a Day
 Driving a city bus is not like driving a car. Obviously. Getting that across is easy -- getting the students to operate a bus correctly is not always so. For example, Mr. Donovan tells them that the proper way to steer a bus is to "push and pull" the steering wheel instead of using the "hand over hand" method that most people use to steer a car.
The demand for drivers has waned in the last year because service has been scaled back. But New York City's bus system remains the nation's largest, with more than 3,600 buses driven by 8,000 drivers on 220 bus routes in five boroughs. The buses carry 1.5 million passengers and travel about 300,000 miles on a typical day.
Transit officials said that in recent years the authority has received a record number of applicants for bus driving jobs, which they attribute to the weak local economy. In the first seven months of 1991, the Transit Authority hired 335 new bus operators, compared with 664 in all of last year. Beginning bus operators earn about $24,000 a year, with drivers reaching the maximum, $34,000 a year, after three years at the wheel.
Ms. Lucci said she tries to ignore passengers like the man who wanted her to drive faster and cars that try to outrun the bus. She recalled the advice of another instructor, John Grass: "Don't get mad at people who try to race you or cut you off. You and you alone are in charge of the bus.
"Those cars are like ants to you. You can crush them with your big bus, but you better not."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Publisher Turns Its Final Page

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Battered by debts and the most severe advertising slump in years, Family Media Inc., the publisher of Discover, Health and five other magazines, announced yesterday that it would close its doors immediately. The shutdown is considered the largest failure of a media enterprise since the recession began a year ago.
The closing ends more than a year of speculation in the media and advertising industries over the fate of the New York publisher, whose magazines covered health, science, sports and home improvement. 
 While the closing underscores the severity of the publishing recession, which has claimed a newsstand full of victims like 7 Days, Fame and California, it also provides fresh evidence that American business is coming back to earth after the debt-amassing 1980's.
 
'Returning to Reality'
 "Like real estate, like banking, like retailing, we are returning to reality after a hyped-up decade," said Myrna Blyth, the publishing director and editor in chief of The Ladies' Home Journal, which was owned by Family Media from 1982 to 1986.
But "magazines with a strong franchise, that deliver to their readers and deliver for their advertisers, should remain strong," she said. "The weak ones will fall by the wayside."
Especially weak, industry executives say, are publishers in the same predicament as Family Media: competing against bigger companies with deeper pockets and wider holdings.
Family Media's closing will put 209 people out of work, most, if not all, in New York City. In addition to Discover and Health, the closing affects Golf Illustrated, Homeowner, 1,001 Home Ideas and Tennis Illustrated, formerly known as World Tennis, as well as Your Family, a magazine distributed through doctors' waiting rooms.
In a memo read to surprised employees yesterday morning at the company's headquarters at 3 Park Avenue, Robert E. Riordan, the chairman, wrote, "Due to the continual downturn in advertising, and an economy which hinders the ability to borrow new money, we are unable to continue our operations effective today."
While discussions are continuing to sell the company's holdings, Mr. Riordan wrote, "We have come to the conclusion that even if any of these negotiations were to reach fruition, it would still not allow us to continue."
A spokeswoman for Family Media, Leslie Jay, said neither Mr. Riordan nor Bruce Barnet, the president, would respond to questions. An interview with Mr. Riordan, scheduled for yesterday, was canceled.
Mr. Riordan's other media holdings are believed to be unaffected. These holdings include FM Business Publications, New York, a publisher of four trade magazines; a printing plant in Atlanta, and a direct-marketing operation in Florida.
 
Steep Level of Debt
 A front-page article in this week's issue of Advertising Age reignited speculation that Family Media would go out of business. The trade publication reported that the privately held company had an overall debt of $60 million to $70 million. The debt, considered steep for a publisher whose advertising revenues last year totaled an estimated $60 million, was taken on as Mr. Riordan bought titles like Discover and spent lavishly to introduce and reintroduce titles like Model and Savvy Woman, both of which have already succumbed.
"The problem was not just the magazines," said James R. Guthrie, executive vice president of the Magazine Publishers of America, the industry's trade association. "On balance, the magazines are doing as well as, or slightly above, the average."
Mr. Guthrie attributed part of Family Media's problem to timing. "Timing is everything, and the times changed too quickly for some," he said. "What we are looking at here is the residual effect of someone trying to do so many things at once in the halcyon days of magazine advertising, which ended in 1989."
 
A Frenzy of Activities
 After selling The Ladies' Home Journal to the Meredith Corporation for a profit estimated at $84 million, Mr. Riordan, who founded Family Media in 1976, became engaged in a frenzy of activities: buying Discover from Time Inc., seeking to become a power in women's fashion publishing with Model and Taxi, and even buying a yacht, which he rechristened the Savvy Lady and sent plying the waters around Manhattan to entertain potential advertisers and their agencies.
"If the bank is knocking at your door, you don't have a chance," said Paul DuCharme, vice president and director of print media for the Grey Advertising agency in New York. That is especially true, he added, for "stand-alone and small publishing companies with secondary or tertiary titles."
"They're in a lot of trouble right now," he said.
Among the stronger companies that industry executives said could gain advertising and circulation in the wake of Family Media's misfortunes are Rodale Press and the Reader's Digest Association, whose Prevention and American Health magazines, respectively, compete with Health.
The executives also mentioned the Times Mirror Company, whose Golf magazine competes with Family Media's Golf Illustrated, and The New York Times Company Magazine Group, whose Golf Digest and Tennis magazines compete with Golf Illustrated and Tennis Illustrated.
 
Speculation About Buyers
 Mr. DuCharme expects other publishers to buy some of Family Media's titles, but perhaps only on a circulation liability basis -- that is, subscribers to the Family Media magazines would start receiving copies of the buyer's magazines.
One industry executive, who asked not to be identified, said Discover might already have been sold to a long-rumored suitor, the Disney Publishing unit of the Walt Disney Company. A telephone call to Disney Publishing was not returned.
At Family Media's offices yesterday, the scene was "awful," said one employee, describing how colleagues were crying and struggling to learn the details of their severance and benefits packages.
"The human toll of a story like this is never told," said the employee, who asked not to be identified, "but people gave up a lot to work here. It was a sweatshop at times, but we created some great magazines." Health, for instance, recently won an award from the American Pyschiatric Association -- due to be presented next week.
The sweatshop reference spoke to Mr. Riordan's well-established reputation in the industry as a publisher whom admirers called lean and mean, but whose detractors contended skimped on expenses that other publishers deemed necessary. One former employee, who asked not to be identified, said that in producing Model, Mr. Riordan asked staff members to use "girls from your neighborhood" for photo layouts instead of hiring professional models.
"We have to be out of the offices by Friday," the employee said, "but it's bring-your-own-boxes."

HEADLINE: New York City Embraces Notion Of Selling Cheaply Priced Bonds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
On Monday, a Wall Street bond broker suggested to Mayor David N. Dinkins that New York City sell municipal bonds in denominations as small as $250.
A good idea, city officials said. So good, in fact, that the city was already working on a similar plan. 
 "We have been talking at the staff level about a payroll-deduction plan for city employees," said Michael W. Geffrard, deputy executive director in the city's Office for Economic Development. "But for the fact that we had other fires to fight, we would have implemented some sort of plan by now."
Mr. Geffrard expects that sales of so-called mini-bonds through payroll deduction will start within a year. In addition to the city's 250,000 employees, Mr. Geffrard said, the base of potential buyers could be enlarged if big corporations joined the program.
 
Reaching Smaller Investors
 City officials and analysts said the bonds, which would be free of city, state and Federal taxes, would help the city borrow the money it needs, perhaps at a lower cost. In traditional bond sales, the minimum purchase is $5,000, and securities firms concentrate on selling to large institutions and wealthy individuals.
"The mini-bonds are a way for the city to reach a group of investors who are not being reached by the Wall Street firms," said Robert C. Apfel, an adviser to local governments and president of the Fiduciary Communications Company. "Sometimes government officials become so concerned about keeping the Wall Street firms happy that they forget all about the little people who would also buy their bonds."
The proposal for mini-bonds offered to Mayor Dinkins on Monday, in a day of meetings with the public, came from James A. Lebenthal, chairman of Lebenthal & Company, who had previously discussed the idea with city officials.
Unlike the pending city plan, his idea does not involve payroll deductions, but calls for the city to hire securities firms to sell non-interest-bearing bonds at low prices, which would be worth much more when they mature. For example, a bond sold now for $232.63 could be worth $500 when it matures in 10 years, equaling a yield of 7.8 percent over that period.
"The idea depends on mass marketing," Mr. Lebenthal said. Because the profit margin in small-sized bonds would be so small, he said "it's not economical to use traditional brokers."

HEADLINE: Ex-Head of Peru Denies Charges in B.C.C.I. Case

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Indignant, scornful and plaintive, Alan Garcia, the former President of Peru, rejected accusations today of any personal wrongdoing in his country's dealings with the Bank of Credit and Commerce International.
Mr. Garcia, who returned on Monday from a month's stay in Paris and Brussels, called a news conference today to formally denounce Peruvian legislators who have accused him of profiting illegally while he was in office from mid-1985 to mid-1990. While Mr. Garcia was President, Peru placed more than $250 million of its reserves with the Panamanian office of B.C.C.I. in return for relatively little, investigators say, referring to a modest interest rate and line of credit. 
 Last week in New York, a state grand jury indicted B.C.C.I. on money laundering and bribery charges, including one count that said the bank paid $3 million in bribes to two former Peruvian central bank officials in return for the country's cash reserves. The funds were eventually withdrawn and no money was lost when the bank's offices were seized last month.
Mr. Garcia left Peru on July 3, two days before regulators around the world shut down the B.C.C.I. offices. He said he spent the month abroad trying to get more documentation to refute charges of accounts in foreign banks. His remarks today were his first since the indictment, which has reignited one investigation of corruption and spurred new ones.
 
Accusers Called 'Delinquents'
 Mr. Garcia said today that he had made no decisions on placing the money. He characterized those making allegations against him as "delinquents," "liars," "scandal mongers," "purveyors of calumnies" and "frauds," and predicted that he and his party would emerge victorious.
"The insinuations about the involvement of ex-President Alan Garcia with the reserves of Peru, I want to say to everyone that this is a new lie that comes from the same falsifiers and delinquents who have already demonstrated to the entire country to what point they have no scruples and are willing to invent documents and change testimony," Mr. Garcia said.
Mr. Garcia said he had successfully rebutted accusations that he had hidden $50 million in foreign bank accounts by producing letters from officials at each bank that said he had no accounts there. He said the attack on him was really an effort by members of smaller political parties in Peru to weaken his American Popular Revolutionary Alliance, called Apra, Peru's largest political party.
 
'One Gunshot'
 "This has nothing to do with the ex-President of Peru," Mr. Garcia said. "Apra continues to be the political alternative to the current Government. I have always told people that one gunshot is much cheaper than all of this scandal." In other words, if his political opponents want to debilitate his party, Mr. Garcia said with his characteristic bravado, eliminating him is the easiest way.
The banking accusations against the 42-year-old Mr. Garcia come as he fights for his political life. In April, a special commission of Peru's House of Delegates released reports by two private American investigators that listed bank accounts they said Mr. Garcia held, totaling $50 million.
Commission members said that there was more evidence in the United States but that it was available only if the Peruvian Congress lifted Mr. Garcia's immunity from prosecution, which is bestowed on all former Presidents here.
 
A Malpractice Charge
 Within weeks Mr. Garcia and his Apra allies had effectively discredited those reports by producing the letters he mentioned today. He also succeeded in getting the State of Florida to charge one of the investigators with malpractice.
Indeed, members of the Peruvian Congress began talking about a return of Mr. Garcia to power in 1995 and the demise of his political nemisis and head of the investigative commission, Fernando Olivera.
The only issue that hung over Mr. Garcia's head at that point was that Peru had maintained large deposits in B.C.C.I.'s Panama office at a time when the office was experiencing difficulties. And even there Mr. Garcia's aide, Jorge del Castillo, was able to effectively argue that such decisions were made by the autonomous central bank and that Mr. Garcia had nothing to do with them.
There are three investigations under way into Peru's ties to B.C.C.I. Panama and they will inevitably encompass Mr. Garcia's actions.
The investigation by the House of Delegates is likely to continue for a while. Members of that commission testified last week before a United States Senate subcommitee about Peru's central bank deposits with B.C.C.I.
On Tuesday evening, the Peruvian Senate also voted to form a commission to look into the Peruvian central bank's dealings with B.C.C.I. Panama. Mr. Garcia, who as a former President is a member of the Senate for life, said today that he told his colleagues, "Do what you have to do, and do it quickly," a reference to what Jesus told Judas before he was betrayed.
Finally, the Peruvian Attorney General, Pedro Mendez, said he was conducting an investigation of the two Peruvian officials accused by the New York grand jury of receiving bribes from B.C.C.I. -- the former central bank president, Leonel Figueroa, and the former general manager, Hector Neyra. The indictment named the bank, not the former Peruvian officials.
Mr. Garcia denied having any contact with B.C.C.I. and said he had never put pressure on the central bank to put the country's reserves there. He reiterated that the reserves were placed in B.C.C.I. Panama to avoid retribution by multinational banks after Peru declared a moratorium on almost all of its debt payments several years ago.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Fell in June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Consumer credit fell 3.0 percent in June, the sixth decline in seven months and the largest drop since January, the Government said today. At the same time, automobile loans were down for the sixth straight month and credit card spending slowed.
"People are more cautious," said Michael K. Evans, who heads an economic forecasting firm in Washington.
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit fell by a seasonally adjusted $1.83 billion in June after a revised $1.33 billion drop in May. That decrease, 2.2 percent, was more than twice as large as the $626 million decline first estimated a month ago.
The June drop was the largest since installment loans fell 3.5 percent, or $2.14 billion, in January. Installment loans this year grew only in April, when they posted a 1.9 percent gain.
 
Delaying Big Purchases
 Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It helps finance much of overall consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Michael P. Niemira, an economist with Mitsubishi Bank in New York, said the recent declines in installment loans "reflect the recession's impact on spending patterns more than a desire to pay down credit outstanding."
Except for the brief spurt in April, installment loans have fallen every month since December, when they dropped for the first time since February 1989.
 
Fewer Loans for Cars
 Loans for automobiles continued to provide a drag in June, declining 10.2 percent after a 13.9 percent decrease in May.
The recession has been especially difficult for the automobile industry, with the last increase in borrowing for new vehicles in December, when it advanced 3.6 percent. Still, automobile sales rose in June, indicating that customers were buying less expensive cars and making bigger down payments.
The growth in revolving credit, which includes credit cards, slowed to 2.2 percent, from a 6.9 percent gain the previous month. Mr. Evans, the economic forecaster, said the decrease reflected lower retail sales in June.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
California regulators received a $3 billion French offer for Executive Life and agreed to turn the seized insurer over to groups backed by the giant bank, Credit Lyonnais, unless a better deal is forthcoming. The deal was welcomed as good for policyholders, who generally would get 81 cents on the dollar. Executive Life gambled on high-risk junk bonds and lost. [Page A1.] 
 Chrysler plans to issue 56 million common shares worth $714 million at current market prices to increase its liquidity. [D1.]
Family Media announced it would close immediately, costing 209 people their jobs. The publisher of Discover, Health and five other magazines has been saddled with debts and the most severe advertising slump in years. [D1.]
Ford will build a small pickup truck in Edison, N.J., for Mazda Motor, of which it is a 25 percent owner. [D4.]
Braniff International Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection barely five weeks after it began commercial flights. [D4.]
 
The Economy
A Federal judge ruled that 12 million airline passengers may be represented in a class-action lawsuit charging nine big domestic carriers with price-fixing. A lawyer representing passengers said the airlines could be forced to refund "hundreds of millions of dollars" to people who bought tickets after Jan. 1, 1988. [D1.]
The St. Louis area is emerging as a national laboratory for the post-cold-war economy. It is one of the first regions to confront weapons cutbacks and develop plans for dealing with them. [D1.]
The Federal Reserve said the economic recovery had been slow and uneven with prospects dimmed by weak retail sales, lackluster factory demand and rising layoffs of municipal employees. [D2.]
Consumer credit fell 3.0 percent in June, the sixth decline in seven months and the largest drop since January. Automobile loans were down for the sixth straight month. [D2.]
 
International
The Justice Department is urging Federal prosecutors to speed their investigations of suspected tax fraud and money laundering at Bank of Credit and Commerce International. [D1.]
Alan Garcia, Peru's former president, rejected all accusations of any wrongdoing in his country's B.C.C.I. dealings. [D6.]
Indian Government investigators uncovered fraud by the bank's Bombay branch years ago, but no illegal payments to Government officials, Finance Minister Manmohan Singh said. [D6.]
 
Markets
Note and bond prices were little changed as the credit market readily digested a heavy supply of new issues, including $12 billion of new 10-year Treausry notes, sold at an average yield of 7.94 percent. HEADLINE: VETO BY WEICKER BLOCKS 3D BUDGET

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. vetoed a budget for the third time today, but in a scornful veto message he offered legislators no clear options except to override it or give up their opposition to an income tax.
"The whole Coalition III is a gimmick," he said, referring to the name given to the third budget without an income tax passed by a coalition of Republicans and Democrats. "Actually, gimmick is the kind word for what is the shame and scandal of our generation." 
 Legislative leaders said they were hopeful that the State Senate and the House would vote to override the veto and force upon Mr. Weicker his first budget as Governor. With Mr. Weicker's veto speech hardly calculated to win over opponents, legislators said some who had voted against the budget would now vote against the veto to put at least a temporary end to the five-week stalemate.
 
'Doesn't Hurt Anymore'
 "There is a point at which people have bashed their heads against a wall so long that it doesn't hurt anymore," said Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a Democrat from West Hartford who has supported an income tax. That point, he said, had been reached.
The State Senate and the House can override the Governor's veto with two-thirds majority votes. The latest budget was approved by a 19-to-17 vote in the Senate and a 77-to-70 vote in the House.
There appeared to be little chance that the veto risked a shutdown of state offices like that in the first week of July, when Mr. Weicker furloughed 20,000 employees because his second veto left Connecticut without a budget at the start of the fiscal year.
This time the Governor said he was open to adopting another temporary spending measure to keep the government going, if the legislature failed to override his veto. Legislators said that lacking such a measure, he could continue to keep offices open by executive order, as he has this week.
Mr. Weicker, in a speech broadcast live at noon, said he was vetoing the $7.6 billion plan before him because it was $623 million out of balance, hurt the poor and middle class by expanding the 8 percent sales tax, raised business taxes amid a recession, and did not start paying off a billion-dollar deficit from the last fiscal year.
He accused some legislators of voting for the patchwork plan for political gain, and others of voting for it out of exhaustion, to end a deadlock that has left Connecticut the only state without a budget, more than five weeks into the fiscal year.
 
'The Wink of an Eye'
"Yes, it would be easy for me to sign this budget, devised in the wink of an eye on scrap paper and cocktail napkins, and then stand back to watch it crash and burn," he said. "I do not wish that ill on its proponents. I will not visit that ill upon the state."
Mr. Weicker's veto message was aimed at the public, rather than legislators. With a large chart behind him, he described how the budget's more than $800 million in higher taxes and fees would affect a family with a $43,500 annual income, taking more from them in sales taxes, gasoline taxes, a fee on a home-equity loan used for college expenses and a higher tax rate on a grandmother's dividends and interest income.
The choice, he said, was not between an income tax and no tax increase at all, but between a tax plan that worked and one like this that not only struck at those already paying high taxes but also would require more taxes to balance it later this year.
"I came to this office because the people of Connecticut broke the political mold at election time," concluded Mr. Weicker, who was elected last November as an independent governor without a political party. "I will not accept the old creative-accounting mold at budget time. We have the honest numbers. On with the honest job."
 
No Long-Term Solutions
 But the Governor's harsh gibes at the General Assembly won votes only for an overriding of his veto, if any votes at all. "It wasn't a real friendly type speech," Representative Richard J. Balducci, the House Speaker, said with a grimace.
After working with Mr. Weicker on several income-tax plans, Mr. Balducci said, he would vote for a second time to override a veto.
But unlike the last time, he said, if he voted against the veto, he would also actively lobby other House Democrats to vote with him.
This budget offered no long-term solutions, he said, but it had passed the legislature three times and would slow the state's slide into debt until legislators, cooled off, could return in the fall to repair it.
Representative Edward C. Krawiecki, the Republican minority leader in the House, said, "The issue is clearly in the lap of the Speaker."
Legislators have long lost patience with Mr. Weicker's criticisms of their plans. The income-tax proposals that the Governor has supported would be $600 million out of balance by now and require higher taxes because the state's finances have worsened without a budget, Mr. Krawiecki said, adding that the Governor's insistence on quickly paying off the debt was a ruse to justify the need for an income tax. It was time for the Governor to offer a solution rather than sit judgment on them.
 
Eroding Tax Revenues
 "If the Governor has a better way of doing business, I would ask him to put his proposal on the table," Mr. Krawiecki said.
After all, he continued, "a budget could have been adopted in June, one could have been adopted in July, and now one could have been adopted in August."
Connecticut accumulated a $937 million deficit in the last fiscal year as spending continued to increase while the recession ate away at sales-tax and corporate-profits tax revenues. What has been clear for months is that a billion dollars in new and replacement revenues had to be found, in any budget, to avoid a similar deficit this fiscal year.
In February, Governor Weicker proposed a first-ever tax on wages as the solution, and by May positions had hardened into nearly their final form. The Democratic leadership in the House had supported his plan, but Democratic leaders in the Senate joined with Republicans in an anti-income-tax majority.
Today, Mr. Weicker said a budget that worked, not an income tax, was the issue.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut explaining in a televised speech yesterday his reasons for vetoing a budget for the third time. (Steve Miller for The New York Times) (pg.B4)

HEADLINE: Jim Crow's Ghost; Savannah and Civil Rights -- A Special Report;
Ways of Older South Linger In City of Thomas's Boyhood

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB with PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAVANNAH, Ga.

 BODY:
In January 1964, a half-year after this seductive, unhurried river city banished its segregated lunch counters and water fountains, a triumphant Martin Luther King Jr. arrived here to hail the passing of Jim Crow.
The moment, later captured in a local photo exhibition proudly entitled "We Ain't What We Used to Be," is still remembered as one of the purest and sweetest in the often sorrowful 250-year history of blacks in Savannah. 
 Blacks here today clearly are not what they were when Clarence Thomas, President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, grew up in the city 30 years ago -- second-class citizens in a world where segregation had the force of law.
But in place of the clarity of Dr. King's visit, there are sobering ambiguities these days that underscore how long and hard the black struggle for equality has been in Savannah and how resistant the problems have been to solution.
The civil rights movement and the Great Society have changed aspects of life here forever, banishing the humiliating dual society and leading to advances in health, literacy and political representation.
There have also been tragic disappointments -- alarming increases in violence, teen-age pregnancy and drug abuse; an unforeseen collapse of black business activity after integration; a failure to convert political gains to economic ones that has left the black unemployment rate exactly where it was in 1960 -- twice that of whites.
But the most striking reality may be other aspects of Savannah's institutional life that have remained unchanged -- the absence of blacks from the city's financial leadership and the de facto segregation, which still determines where people live, socialize and pray. It often leaves prosperous parts of Savannah, like the successfully rebuilt tourist Mecca of River Street, full of white faces, and the shabbiest parts of town peopled by blacks.
The solutions offered by Judge Thomas, who now sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, are starkly different from those of traditional civil rights groups. A conservative Republican, Judge Thomas calls for a renewed up-by-the-bootstraps ethic and opposes many Government programs, including various forms of affirmative action. While the civil rights groups have been supportive of black self-help efforts, they have long pushed for government initiatives that the judge considers destructive.
"Those who attempt to capture the daily counseling, oversight, common sense, and vision of my grandparents in a governmental program are engaging in sheer folly," he said in an address before the Heritage Foundation four years ago.
To some outsiders, Judge Thomas's views and standing as a black Republican mark him as a turncoat to the gains of the past three decades; to others, they offer a refreshing sense of clarity.
 
Between Past and Present
 But the world he grew up in this city of twisted oaks, elegant brownstones and mean hovels -- a world that for blacks as well as whites tends to be more conservative than that of other cities -- suggests something else. His views reflect a piece of the subtle interplay between past and present, resistance and accommodation, and integration and self-reliance that have played out in the black community here over centuries like a symphony's recurring themes.
Judge Thomas's bootstrap conservatism is appealing to some blacks at a time when the social fabric is so threatened that they think life may in many ways be harder now than it was in the 1950's.
"When I first moved to Savannah 10 years ago, I thought it was the nicest place in the world to live," said Jacquelyn Cleveland, a black high school teacher who grew up in a Brooklyn housing project. "But as I've lived here, the city has begun to fall apart -- there's such a big gap between the haves and have-nots. There's more opportunity, but less acceptance of authority." Referring to the Court nominee's call for self-reliance, she said, "I have no problem with Thomas."
For others, like Howard Alls, a 32-year-old lawyer who ran for mayor unsuccessfully this year, Judge Thomas offers no solutions, just an insidious call to forget the legacy of more than 200 years of racism.
"People complain about the lack of success that black males have, but it's like crippling someone and then complaining about the way they walk," he said.
Still, for those of either view, Judge Thomas has crystallized the degree to which blacks are looking back on the civil rights revolution of the 1960's and assessing why the gains have not been greater.
Reflecting on the days of segregation, Otis Johnson, a civil rights veteran and former alderman, said: "For the average black in Savannah, they are doing the same kind of work they would have done. They may be economically worse off. They haven't received the education where they can advance. Politically, there are elected officials in all areas, but they are in the minority. Socially, this community is still basically segregated. I think we need a period of reassessment."
 
Beginnings
Slavery Yields To Jim Crow
 James Oglethorpe founded Savannah in 1733 as a humane farming community built around symmetrical urban squares where slave labor was outlawed. Twenty distinctive shaded squares remain, but the prohibition against slavery lasted only until 1750, and the slave trade became one of Savannah's leading businesses.
For Savannah's blacks, who now make up more than half the population of 140,000, history in different ways has repeated this story of inflated expectations and dashed hopes in which almost every opened door has led to a brick wall.
A month after he completed his March to the Sea here in December 1864, for example, Gen. William T. Sherman issued Field Order 15, giving confiscated plantation land to newly freed blacks. Six months later, after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated, President Andrew Johnson rescinded the order. Jobs that went to blacks after the Civil War were soon taken by whites, and by the end of the century Jim Crow reigned.
For years, the blacks in Savannah held themselves together through self-reliance and racial solidarity.
Early in the century, Savannah had active chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and Booker T. Washington's National Negro Business League. Until the Depression, there were seven black banks and a thriving business district with two movie theaters, variety stores, confectionery shops and other businesses. Of the black banks, only one survives.
When Clarence Thomas came to Savannah in 1955, he was 7 years old. He was sent to live here with his grandparents after a fire destroyed the family's wooden shack in Pin Point, a lush tract of ramshackle homes on the marshy banks of what is now called Moon River. The unincorporated community, seven miles from town, remains a caricature of a self-reliant -- or underserviced -- enclave, where the county first provided running water about four years ago, according to residents, and still does not provide street lights, household garbage pickup or even fire-protection service.
Judge Thomas's grandfather, Myers Anderson, a bull-necked man who worked seven days a week as a purveyor of ice, wood, cinderblocks and real estate, became the judge's role model.
Through another black entrepreneur, Sam Williams, Mr. Anderson became involved in St. Benedict the Moor Roman Catholic Church, where Clarence Thomas attended grade school and came under the influence of Irish nuns, whom he still venerates, and the N.A.A.C.P.
Myers Anderson regularly attended the organization's Sunday afternoon meetings. Otis Johnson recalls them as a deep ritual through most of the 60's and remembers Clarence Thomas accompanying his grandfather on occasion. Besides the meetings, huge voter-registration drives and sit-ins at lunch counters, the city was consumed by a 16-month boycott by black people of its main shopping boulevard and daily marches.
The Establishment in Savannah had always been tightly knit. Trying to avoid bloodshed, it formed a group of 100 -- which some pointedly called "The House of Lords" -- and entered into negotiations with black representatives that minimized violence and in 1963 led to the relatively quiet desegregation of restaurants, theaters, hotels and public facilities. Litigation later forced a more contentious desegregation of the county's schools.

 
Progress
Federal Money Changes Lives
 The changes wrought by this upheaval and an era of Federal programs are indisputable. The Hill-Burton Act subsidized the financing in the mid-1950's of Memorial Hospital, Savannah's first regional hospital, and led to an eventual overhaul of the antiquated and segregated health system. With the passage of Medicare and Medicaid in 1965, infant mortality rates, particularly among blacks, began to plummet.
Peter Scardino, a urologist and former Savannah Medical Society president, said the Federal programs led to an increase in his patient load of one-third within a year and, with all his patients able to pay for the first time, a doubling of his gross income.
There were improvements in education, although the public schools have some of the lowest achievement levels in Georgia. In 1960, blacks attended school an average of only seven years in Chatham County. By 1980, the figure had increased to 11.1 years, nearly the same as the average for whites.
There were other breakthroughs. Perhaps the one that achieved the greatest national attention was the use of Federal housing funds by a local organization to extend efforts to rehabilitate the city's beautiful stock of old housing to include black neighborhoods.
On a personal level, the city is filled with people, from the higher reaches of government to the hard-pressed residents of the housing projects, whose lives have been helped by the sorts of programs that might draw Judge Thomas's suspicion. Henry J. Moore, an assistant city manager who got his first administrative experience under a government job-training program in Maryland, is now in charge of all the Federal funds coming into the city. Carolyn Coleman, a resident of the Yamacraw Village housing project, recently saw her daughter graduate from college. She was the first member of the family to go to college, thanks partly to the Federal Upward Bound program.
Most pointedly, there is Emma Mae Martin, Judge Thomas's sister, who was the subject of some of the most exasperated statements he was quoted as making at a conference of black conservatives in 1980: "She gets mad when the mailman is late with her welfare check. That is how dependent she is. What's worse is that now her kids feel entitled to the check, too.
In an interview in her weather-battered yellow frame house in Pin Point, Mrs. Martin said that she had been forced onto welfare periodically after her husband abandoned her and her small children and she became too sick to work. But, she said, she had only remained on the program once for a sustained period. This was between 1977 and 1981, when an aunt asked her to care for her when she became sick. She said the aunt had taken in her family, including Clarence, in the early 50's after their house burned down.
"It was one of the things I promised her because she didn't want to live in a nursing home," Mrs. Martin said.
When the aunt died, Mrs. Martin inherited her house in Pin Point and, rather than become dependent on welfare, returned to work. She now is a cook at Candler General Hospital, which had been for whites only until the early 60's.
Notwithstanding the seeming harshness of his quotes about her welfare involvement, Mrs. Martin said she and her brother are close. "He understood why I had to be on it," she said.
But there are bleaker stories in Savannah as well, stories of despair, stories of drugs -- crack use is at epidemic proportions -- and stories that end in death: the murder rate this year is on a record-breaking pace.
The economic statistics are sobering. All indications are that income for blacks remains as little as 60 percent of that for whites. At best, a handful of blacks are on the board's of local corporations or partners in major law firms.
Politically, blacks hold three of eight City Council seats, but have never come close to electing a mayor or controlling City Hall, something that many politicians say is a result of an inability to put aside differences and unite behind a single candidate.
While three of the five candidates in this year's Democratic mayoral primary were black, none made the runoff, in which Mayor John Rousakis came from behind to win by carrying virtually every black precinct.
Socially, more than 60 percent of black children are born to unwed mothers, three times the rate of a generation ago. The rate for whites has skyrocketed, too, but still does not reach 15 percent. Meanwhile, in many neighborhoods residents are afraid to be on the streets. On the block of 32d Street where Clarence Thomas grew up and where his mother still lives in a neat lime-green house, there are four abandoned buildings. Neighbors say they keep their distance because of late-night drug dealing.
The city has attempted to combat the problems with a variety of programs, many aimed at helping black neighborhoods and businesses, but the effectiveness of these is a matter of bitter contention.
Some whites, looking at the slow pace of black progress, blame a local paternalism. "I think there is a fear on the part of the powers that be -- they don't want any change because it would change their lives," said Betti M. Sands, former head of a now-defunct Savannah urban research institute who now heads the United Way in Fresno, Calif.
More common is a view that the black experience mirrors the slow pace of change here in general. Arnold Tenenbaum, president of Chatham Steel Company, said: "One of the big gaps here is that there is not a substantial black business middle class. He says it is naive to think self-help is an adequate remedy for Savannah's blacks.
"Absolutely, there is a role for whites," he said. "I would not want to be a young black person trying to escape from poverty and all the other conditions associated with that on my own."

 
Lessons
Winding Road, Hard Journey
 No black person in Savannah would want to go all the way back. Still, for many who grew up or live in Savannah, Judge Thomas's views strike a responsive chord, not necessarily as a rejection of the civil rights agenda but more as a voice for deeply rooted values often left out of the public discourse.
Of course, not everyone is impressed. "How you going to pull up by the bootstraps when you don't have any boots?" asked Sam Williams, the entrepreneur who was the friend of Judge Thomas's grandfather.
City officials and community leaders complain that Reagan-era Federal cutbacks, rather than Federal programs, are exacerbating social problems. City officials say that community development and job-training funds have been cut nearly in half over the past decade.
"It's very discouraging," said Lee Adler, a Savannah banker and leading preservationist. Speaking of a severely cut-back Federal housing program, he said, "The Section 8 funds are very hard to come by, and without them you can't really do anything for low-income people."
But Judge Thomas's views resonate with those of many black Savannahians who share a social conservatism, a belief in self-help and a frustration with the loss of black businesses and local role models.
"I think the old giveaway programs from the Federal Government have not made us strong enough to go ahead on our own," said Willie Brown, an alderman and unsuccessful mayoral candidate this year.
Veronica Mars, who heads the tenants' association at the Yamacraw Village housing project, does not share Judge Thomas's hostility toward government programs, but she likes what she hears about his religious background and what she believes is his opposition to abortion.
"The biggest mistake they made was when they took God out of the schools," said Ms. Mars. "If you ask me where the answers are, I'd say they're in prayer."
Even for many veterans of the civil rights movement, there is a sense that blacks have come to rely too much on government.
"I share a lot of his views," said Otis Johnson, the former civil rights leader and alderman who now heads the Chatham-Savannah Youth Futures Authority, which works with troubled youths. "In a large segment of the community, we have developed a dependency syndrome. You can't keep blaming someone else for all your problems."
Carlton Stewart, who attended Catholic school with Clarence Thomas in Savannah, followed him to Holy Cross and Washington, reflected: "His grandfather had his business, mine had a bakery. Most of those black businesses have gone. It's like our communities have been taken over by others, and those not taken over have been left to decay."
 
On Doors and Bootstraps
 To some, that view of the problems may be accurate, but the prescription -- a vague call for self-help -- fails to take into account the systemic racism that still blocks opportunities for blacks. Similarly, the notion that the son of a crack-addicted 14-year-old mother simply needs to find a way to pull himself up by his bootstraps strikes others as hoplessly naive.
"It's fine to say affirmative action and desegregation and those kind of things are not the answer to solving the problems of the black community, but what does Judge Thomas suggest instead?" asked Diane Harvey Johnson, a former state representative who owns a marketing and consulting firm. "I can't say that just because I'm making it, all other black people ought to do the same thing. That's very unrealistic."
There is little new about Savannah's doors opening partway to blacks and then, in important ways, closing tight again. What is new is the degree to which what is happening in this old port city, serenely emblematic of the Old South, is happening everywhere.
There are the stores and jobs that have fled from moribund Broughton Street downtown for the outlying malls. There are the sweaty manual jobs like those in Pin Point's abandoned crab-packing plant giving way to those that are out of reach for high school dropouts. There is the flow of drugs and the disastrous increase in teen-age pregnancy.
Back in the civil rights era, some cynics in the South used to say that the Mason-Dixon line really begins at the Canadian border. True or not, more than ever Savannah's quandary mirrors the nation's.
"You would have thought things would have progressed more than they have," Myers Anderson's old friend Sam Williams said the other day. "I really didn't think it would go on like this."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Democrats' Distress Grows As Presidential Field Shrinks

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug 7

 BODY:
Democrats struggled today to adjust to the last thing they needed six months before the Iowa caucuses: an already tiny Presidential field that keeps shrinking.
As expected, Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th announced in Charleston, W.Va., today that he would not seek the 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination. That announcement, just three weeks after Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, took himself out of the race, combined with the demurrals of other Democratic heavyweights to create a frustrating, embarrassing pattern for the party. 
 While the West Virginia Democrat struggled to cast his decision as a personal one, it left a clear public perception that one leading Democrat after another was looking at the 1992 campaign and deciding that George Bush could not be beaten.
"Am I frustrated?" asked Phil Angelides, chairman of the California Democratic Party. "Absolutely."
"The role of an opposition party is to offer alternatives," said Mr. Angelides, who argued that the Bush Administration had real vulnerabilities.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, said, "This is no longer an entertaining situation. This is becoming a serious problem."
Senator Rockefeller's withdrawal is expected to open new opportunities for those who seem eager to run, like Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa. It is also expected to heighten the pressure on Senator Al Gore of Tennessee and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York to enter the race.
In the modern world of nominating politics, this is remarkably late for a novice to mount a Presidential campaign, particularly one against a popular President. Both Mr. Gore, who ran in 1988, and Mr. Cuomo are widely considered to have the name recognition, political base and fund-raising potential to jump into the race late and mount a formidable campaign.
"In previous Presidential campaigns, people were now dispatching their state campaign managers with well-defined plans," Mr. Torricelli said. "I'm not certain there's anyone now considering a race other than Mario Cuomo who could make up for the lost time."
While Mr. Gore is considering a race, Mr. Cuomo has repeatedly said he had neither plans nor plans to make plans for a Presidential campaign.
Still, the New York State Democratic Chairman, John Marino, suggested today that Mr. Cuomo had time. "An Al Gore, a Lloyd Bentsen, a Cuomo, people who have recognition and some base, that kind of person can wait longer than most people say is traditional," Mr. Marino said. "I didn't think the process was so bad in 1960, when it was much more confined."
 
The Price of Delay
 The party has an enormous stake in these collective personal decisions. In the South and elsewhere, Democratic leaders worry about the impact of a weak Presidential ticket on House and Senate candidates. And they worry about the party's image in general.
"If we don't have folks attracting folks to their campaign and therefore to the party, we pay a long-term price," said James Ruvolo, a member of the Democratic National Committee from Ohio.
Mr. Ruvolo and others have argued that candidates interested in 1996 should be out running in 1992, and there is an undercurrent of annoyance about those who choose to sit this race out.
"I don't put Jay in this category," Mr. Angelides said, referring to Mr. Rockefeller, "because I think he wrestled with it. But I would say that for those people who would lead us in 1996: now is when we need leaders."
Still, the Democrats have a recent history of repudiating their failed nominees, a fact that weighs heavily with many potential candidates.
Mr. Rockefeller, who began actively exploring a Presidential candidacy in May, asserted that he believed that President Bush was beatable. But he said he lacked the time to both mount a campaign and plan a Presidency. But Mr. Rockefeller's effort to cast his decision as purely personal was greeted with some scorn by the Republicans. "It's another big-name Democrat who got all prepared, got up to the starting gate, blinked and backed out," said Charles Black, a top Republican strategist strategist, "which certainly speaks to what they think their prospects of winning are."
 
Some Signs of Life
 Despite Mr. Rockefeller's withdrawal, there is some stirring in the party. Mr. Harkin has been rousing the party faithful, while Mr. Clinton seems to be moving ever closer to candidacy. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia is testing the waters, and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts is carrying the banner as the party's only announced candidate. The Rev. Jesse Jackson is also still thought to be considering a race.
Some Democrats had felt in recent weeks that they were finally drawing some blood from the White House over domestic issues; the President himself seemed slightly rattled by it last week. And today, Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared, "One less candidate in the primaries will not erase the fact that this country and our economy is drifting from bad to worse and George Bush doesn't have a clue how to fix it."
Still, it is shaping up as a strangely spare field for the Democrats. And as the clock winds down, the heavyweights -- Bentsen, Cuomo, Gephardt -- are demurring, and a promising newcomer, Mr. Rockefeller, is now joining them on the sidelines.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:
It's getting harder to find a good $25 movie these days -- a new one, that is. Prices of $90 and more for new titles do not bother video store customers who only rent films. But for those who occasionally like to buy a hit film at a low price when it is first released on video, the supply has dried up.
With the exception of "Home Alone," which is to be released Aug. 22 at $24.98, big hits in the $25-to-$30 range are not being released the way they used to when "Pretty Woman," "Batman," "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids," "Lethal Weapon 2" and "Total Recall" came out 
 In fact, all the hits in theaters this summer -- "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," "Robin Hood, Prince of Thieves," "Naked Gun 2 1/2: The Smell of Fear" and "City Slickers" among them -- will probably be released early next year at about $95.
Some dealers see a shift in studio strategy. "They're backing off on titles they should be selling," said Ken Dorrance, owner of three Video Station stores in Alameda, Calif., and a board member of the Video Software Dealers Association. " 'Terminator 2' will do $200 million at the box office by the time it goes on video," he said. "When it does go on video, it should also be on sale. A couple of years ago it would have been."
Mr. Dorrance also said that the two-stage pricing schedule used by the studios has been accelerated. In the first stage, the movie does its turn as a rental. "From a cost standpoint, it should be released for sale then at $59 or $69," Mr. Dorrance said, "but because the studios want to make the most from rental, they add an extra $20 or $30." The effect is to increase rentals and inhibit sales until the film's best renting days are over.
Three or four months later the sale price is lowered, he said. "In the past that usually has come six months or a year later. Now we see the gap narrowing."
Customers don't want to buy everything, he said, giving "Misery" and "L.A. Story" as examples of films that he thought would not sell well. But he said that if the price had been lower, many of his rental customers would have bought "Kindergarten Cop," "Look Who's Talking Too" and "Edward Scissorhands." Mr. Dorrance also reported strong demand for a moderately priced "Dances With Wolves," which is to be released as a rental on Aug. 28. "If they just came out with one sales title a month, it would whet the buying appetite," he said.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES

 
New Jack City
1991. Warner. $92.99. Laser disk, $29.98. 1 hour 41 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
The flamboyant and very cool crack kingpin Nino Brown (Wesley Snipes) tries to hold things together while staying just out of range of rivals and the police. Mario Van Peebles's film hauls out every gimmick of the drug-film genre, but he directs "with as much flash and energy as this weary formula will allow" (Janet Maslin).
 
Scenes From a Mall
1991. Touchstone. $89.95. LD, $39.99. CC. PG-13.
Perhaps only Southern California could produce a couple like Nick (Woody Allen) and Deborah (Bette Midler). She's an exuberant, prominent psychiatrist; he's a neurotic lawyer who represents sports stars who endorse sneakers. In one afternoon together at a shopping mall they manage to run through personal confessions, life crises, a breakup and a reconciliation. Though awfully thin at times, Paul Mazursky's film is redeemed by the performances, which rescue a "peculiar but, finally, very engaging comedy" (Vincent Canby).
 
The Rock and Roll Collection: Dick Clark's Golden Greats
1991. MPI. Four tapes, $99.95. 4:00. No rating.
Fifty-six performances strong, here is a history of rock-and-roll from the 1950's to the 80's. Numbers by the Beach Boys, Buffalo Springfield, Steppenwolf, Jim Croce, Jackie Wilson, Otis Redding, the Mamas and Papas, the Everly Brothers, Three Dog Night and James Brown are among the memorable renditions, all introduced by the neatly tailored Mr. Clark.
 
28 Up
1984. Fox Lorber. $79.95. 2:16. No rating.
In 1963 the British director Michael Apted worked on a documentary about the aspirations of a group of 7-year-olds from various racial, social and economic backgrounds. Since then he has visited the same group every seven years to see if their lives have lived up to the dreams they had as children. Here they are at 28 and relatively upbeat, if not altogether pleased with themselves, in a vivid film that is "alternately hugely funny and extremely moving and, even more remarkable, comparatively optimistic about the human condition" (Canby).
 
Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead
1990. Buena Vista. $92.95. LD, $39.99. 1:59. CC. PG.
Tom Stoppard's hit play of 1968, adapted for the screen, looks at "Hamlet" through the eyes of a couple of fall guys, played by Gary Oldman (Rosencrantz) and Tim Roth (Guildenstern), brought to Elsinore to cheer up their old school chum, the Prince of Denmark. They specialize in windy philosophizing well above their station. On stage that's fun, but on screen "so many words can numb the eardrums and weigh upon the eyelids like old coins" (Canby).
 
PLAYING IT STRAIGHT
 Film documentaries aren't the best-represented genre in video stores, but many fine tapes are available. Here are some examples.
COMMON THREADS: STORIES FROM THE QUILT -- AIDS victims tell their stories, narrated by Dustin Hoffman. 1989. HBO. $39.95. 1:19. CC. No rating.
GATES OF HEAVEN -- Errol Morris's study of questionable doings in a California pet cemetery. 1978. RCA/Columbia. $79.95. 1:25. No rating.
GREY GARDENS -- A reclusive mother and daughter, relatives of Jacqueline Onassis, hide out in the Hamptons in a film by David and Albert Maysles. 1975. Maysles Films. $79.99. 1:34. No rating.
HARLAN COUNTY, U.S.A. -- Coal miners and their families battle management through a 13-month strike. 1976. RCA/Columbia. $29.95. 1:43. No rating.
HEARTS AND MINDS -- Peter Davis's hard-hitting film about the Vietnam War won an Oscar. 1974. MPI. $19.95. 1:52. No rating.
NANOOK OF THE NORTH -- With spectacular photography Robert J. Flaherty's silent film classic chronicles the perils of Eskimo life on Hudson Bay. 1922. Home Vision. $29.95. 1:09. No rating.
SHOAH -- Claude Lanzmann's exhaustive examination of the Holocaust is told through the memories of survivors, former Nazis who ran the death camps and other witnesses. 1985. Paramount. $299.95, five cassettes. 9:30. No rating.
STREETWISE -- Seattle street kids grub and battle and love one another amid danger and extreme deprivation. 1985. Starmaker. $59. 1:32. No rating.
THE THIN BLUE LINE -- The murder of a Texas policeman gets a long second look in another harrowing film by Errol Morris. 1988. HBO. $89.99. 1:46. CC. No rating.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Cuba Moves Forward On 2 Wheels

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
THE first thing a visitor notices in Cuba is that there are no traffic jams. This makes it very easy to get to the venues of the Pan American Games.
The reason there are no traffic jams is that there are very few private cars. Because of the economic blockade imposed by the United States, the last generation of American cars is 32 years old now, and showing it. 
 During the eternal quest for truth in sport, I have seen every car I ever owned, wobbling along the streets of Havana:
The 1951 Plymouth my mother used to teach me to shift. That 1955 Pontiac that broke down while I was covering a football game in Pennsylvania. The red 1953 Studebaker I used to park with a girlfriend at the edge of La Guardia, to watch the propeller planes. Saw all those cars.
Driving down the back streets, one can see old Fords and Chevies up on cinder blocks outside boarded-up buildings, a dozen years of dust and cobwebs on them. Their owners probably live near Calle Ocho in Miami now.
Most cabs are Soviet-built Ladas. Today's driver, Gustavo Mesa, told me his Lada is "muy fuerte," very strong, but when I asked him where he will obtain parts in the future, he gave an expressive shrug. The Soviets have problems of their own these days.
But Cuba will keep moving. On all the main roads are signs that say: Atencion! Ciclos en la Via" (Careful! Cycles on the Road.) Bicycle lanes are being marked.
At first, I thought this was mostly a device for recreation. Cubans, who proudly talk about their medical care and the relative health of children, have been urged to take exercise, led by Fidel Castro himself.
Also, nobody can miss the significance of Cubans winning gold medals, not just in track and field and boxing but also in canoeing and kayaking, two sports not normally associated with a Caribbean island.
But the bicycle signs are not for sport. Cuba is getting back to basics, commuting to work on the humble bicycle. Soviet cars are out. Chinese bicycles are in.
I became fascinated with the concept of bicycles the other afternoon, when my driver took it as a personal affront that cyclists were in the road. It is true they showed as little regard for the right-of-way as any messenger in my beloved hometown of New York.
"They don't respect the law!" roared my driver, swerving to try to hit a cyclist, unsuccessfully, I am glad to report.
Sensing that the sheepherder vs. cattle rancher border war was just as spirited as anything in the Pan American Games themselves, I visited a bicycle assembly station yesterday morning, on a quiet street far from downtown.
At the Technological Institute they have a rudimentary assembly line, students working for wages during a two-week vacation, but as part of their training the rest of the year.
The parts came from wooden boxes with English and Chinese markings on them, straight by ship from China.
The bikes for men, named "Forever" and "Flying Pigeon," weigh around 60 pounds. The bikes for women, named "Phoenix," weigh around 36 pounds, and cost 130 pesos, roughly $25-$30. There are no gears, and they have hand brakes and thick tires.
"We assemble them here, but they are sold at the place of work," said Floro Queseda Urria, the director. "The managers decide who can use them. This guarantees they will get to work."
Since the Chinese bikes began arriving in early January, Urria said his school alone had assembled and distributed 36,400 of them.
When asked about the reasons for stressing bicycles, he said in Spanish: "We are a small country. We have 2 million people in the city and they have to get to work. We do not want to depend on others for gasoline, so we are in a position to be independent. Also, we have to think about air pollution."
One of the students was Alain Villazon, age 17, who recently bought one of the bikes he had assembled, paying the 50 percent workers' discount. ("I got a good one," he said with a smile.)
Villazon is now able to cycle about six miles each way to work, and on the weekends he cycles 20 miles from his home to the beach. He also attended the Cuba-United States basketball game last weekend, another long haul.
"It's better than taking the wa-wa," he said, using the Cuban word for the laborious, fume-spewing buses.
Pedaling a heavy bicycle for long distances is the near future for the workers of Cuba. But from all this hard work will come muscles, and perhaps new members of elite Cuban cycling programs, and soon, who knows, more gold medals for Cuba. As if they need more.

HEADLINE: Barbara Ewing Ylvisaker, Nurse and Nutritionist, 66

 BODY:
Barbara Ewing Ylvisaker, a registered nurse who in the 1960's helped to create one of the nation's first federally financed neighborhood health centers, in Trenton, died Sunday at New England Baptist Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. She was 66 years old.
Her husband, Paul, said she died of cancer. 
 Mrs. Ylvisaker, who lived in Cambridge, became a consultant on nutrition after working for several years at the Trenton Neighborhood Health Center, which was financed by the Office of Economic Opportunity.
Besides her husband she is survived by a daughter, Elizabeth of Meredith, N.H.; three sons, Mark of Fort Meyers, Fla., Peter of Hightstown, N.J., and David of Washington; her father, Walkley Ewing of Greenwich, Conn.; a brother, David Ewing of Winchester, Mass,; a sister, Elizabeth Purves of the Westchester town of Larchmont, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: 5 POWERS AT U.N. DECIDE TO ALLOW IRAQIS TO SELL OIL

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have decided to continue sanctions against Iraq, but agreed today to allow Baghdad a one-time exception to sell up to $1.6 billion worth of petroleum, with part of the money to be used to buy food and medical supplies.
Along with the permission to sell the oil comes a tough set of restrictions that would keep the revenue out of Iraqi hands and make sure that others, including the United Nations and countries with war-related claims against Iraq, are paid first. 
 "The United Nations has Iraq spread-eagled against the car and is going through its pockets," a Western diplomat said. "Iraq will never touch any of this money."
 
Iraqi Leaves in Anger
 The head of Iraq's mission to the United Nations, Abdul Amir A. al-Anbari, sat in on the deliberations by the permanent members today but left the meeting in anger after a short while and told reporters that Iraq would denounce the decision.
"Iraq won't accept it both as a matter of principle and as a matter of practice," Mr. Anbari said.
He said the proposed oil sale had become so time-consuming and complicated that "it is simply not going to help us."
 
'It Benefits Non-Iraqis'
 "It benefits non-Iraqis rather than Iraqis," he said. "For all practical purposes, it allows Iraq to buy not one sack of rice or one sack of grain."
There could be room for negotiation on how the rest of the oil money is divided between United Nations expenses and what would go toward food and medicine.
But Western diplomats said there would be no negotiation on the 30 percent chunk for compensation -- which already represents a compromise United States -- or on giving any of the money directly to Iraq.
 
Extent of Need Questioned
 Security Council members including the United States say they are certain Iraq needs some help, but they question how much. Baghdad had asked to sell $2 billion worth of oil solely to pay for humanitarian aid, but refused demands for a detailed acounting of its gold and foreign currency reserves.
Western diplomats, noting the continued Iraqi importation of goods such as liquor and American-brand soft drinks since the Persian Gulf war ended, have questioned just how desperate Iraqi needs are.
After a week of discussions, the permanent members agreed on a resolution drafted by France that would allow Iraq to pump and sell -- in three installments -- $1.6 billion worth of oil over the next six months.
One demand in the draft resolution is that the Government of Iraq on the first of each month provide the Secretary General with a statement of its gold and foreign currency reserves.
How much oil Iraq can sell is to be determined by the Security Council after the Secretary General submits a report on the level of Iraq's humanitarian requirements, but the total for the six months cannot exceed $1.6 billion. At current oil prices, that would be about half a million barrels a day, about a sixth of what Iraq produced before the war.
The draft resolution must still be voted on by the full 15 members of the Security Council, and officials said the vote would occur Friday or early next week. Although some members had favored easing the sanctions further, it is unlikely that the vote will go counter to the decision of the five permanent members -- the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France.
A diplomat who sat in on the Security Council deliberations and spoke on condition that he not be identified said any chances of Iraq's getting easier terms were dashed this week with revelations that Baghdad had secretly extracted small amounts of plutonium and had lied about a biological weapons research plant.
 
U.S. Threatens Iraq
 President Bush and Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney have repeatedly threatened to use military force against Iraq if it did not make full disclosure of its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs.
Under the draft resolution, Baghdad would be allowed to sell its oil directly on the open spot market for six months from the date of passage of the resolution. But proceeds from the oil would go into an escrow account controlled by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar.
Officials said 30 percent of the oil revenue would be placed into a compensation account to pay governments and individuals who have filed claims against Iraq over war-related losses.
The draft resolution said some of the money would go to meet United Nations costs in Iraq. Those costs include inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Special Commission that was established to check for weapons of mass destruction, the transfer of all Kuwaiti property seized by Iraq and half the expenses for redrawing the border between Iraq and Kuwait. The United Nations would use the balance of the revenue, expected to be a least half, to buy food and medicine and would monitor the distribution of the goods.
 
Figures Are Unspecified
 But the resolution does not specify a dollar figure or the percentage of revenue that is to go toward compensating the United Nations or to be spent on the humanitarian aid. Diplomats said those expenditures would have to be determined after they get some feeling for how much work has been done and needs to be done.
Iraq, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, had a prewar daily oil quota of 3.1 million barrels.
Persian Gulf crude was selling at $16.50 a barrel at the end of July, but the price varied according to the field that produced the crude.
The reaffirmation of the sanctions -- contained in the so-called cease-fire resolution, number 687 -- means that an international ban will continue on the sale of weapons to Iraq and that United Nations observers and inspectors will remain there. The Security Council's permanent members decided Monday at a private meeting to keep the sanctions in place, but that decision was not made public until today.
Under Resolution 687, adopted April 3, the Security Council must meet at least every 60 days to reconsider the sanctions against Iraq. At its first meeting on June 3, the Security Council also refused to remove the sanctions.
The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reported in July that "Iraq's population is facing a massive famine as a result of the war and a poor harvest."
The F.A.O. said Iraq needed $2.64 billion over the next year to purchase food and $500 million more to rebuild the agricultural sector, replacing machinery, irrigation and drainage systems, fertilizers and animal feed damaged or destroyed during the war.
Even in normal years, the agency said, Iraq produces only about a third of its food needs, with the remainder coming from imports of more than $2 billion annually.

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about United Nations Security Council decisions on Iraq misstated the Iraqi delegate's whereabouts during the deliberations. The delegate, Abdul Amir A. al-Anbari, was in a lounge within the Council chambers and stormed out after getting a copy of a draft resolution; he did not sit in on the closed meeting of the five permanent Council members.
