HEADLINE: THE CITY GARDENER;
Rural Retreats (In New York) To Better Enjoy the Summer

BYLINE: By LINDA YANG

 BODY:
NOT everyone in town bolts to greener pastures when summer's hot winds blow. There are city gardeners who devote their all to an urban patch.
Susan Rowland's jungle-like rooftop terrace is in Brooklyn, more or less in the shadow of the Williamsburgh Bank tower. Michael Straus's English-style backyard is in lower Manhattan, more or less in strolling distance of Chinatown. And neither gardener hankers for the hinterlands. 
 "This is our country retreat," said Ms. Rowland, a painter and sculptor. "We like summer in New York."
Ms. Rowland and her husband, Tony Sifton, moved to their loft in downtown Brooklyn five years ago in the middle of a June heat wave, so an awning seemed essential. Along with providing respite from summer's sun, she said, the awning "keeps us away from other people's eyes."
It also marks an area for al fresco dining and living.
Her original idea was to cover the 30-by-40-foot expanse of black tar roofing with soil and make a field. "I fantasized that birds would plant seeds and we'd have a meadow," she said. Which, of course, was impossible. Especially when she realized that the roof might collapse.
A more practical solution was the wood deck that now obscures the tar and helps distribute the weight of dozens of plant containers, including some she sculptured. The deck was built in sections that theoretically are removable, and in low steps, "to keep the area from looking too flat," she said.
To the Italianate backdrop of the Williamsburgh tower, the couple added some spidery, Italianate landscaping of their own. The first species planted were distinctly vertical in outline: narrow white birches, skyrocket junipers and a crab apple and viburnum pruned to an upright shape.
These were followed by small areas with themes. The subtle distinctions are now blurred, but still there is a "plaza center" (a black terra-cotta pot filled with water that reflects bromeliads and papyrus), a "prairie" (with rustling stands of zebra grass and maiden grass), and a 4-foot wide, 10-foot-long perennial border (two dozen species, including monarda, coneflower, Montauk daisies, lambs' ears and helianthus, which flourish in beds with 8 to 12 inches of soil).
"I have an inability to let nature have her way," Ms. Rowland said, "and I love pruning to alter a plant's normal look."
The urge to prune led her to carve a field juniper into a lollipop topiary, to strip leaves off a viburnum to create a "garden window," and to manipulate a five-foot-tall black pine "like a bonsai."
"But I really go for fragrance," she said. Favorites include heirloom roses like Marchioness of Londonderry, a light pink hybrid perpetual that dates from 1893 and flowers sporadically from spring through frost, and Bishop Darlington, a 1926 hybrid musk whose single pale apricot flowers add aroma all summer.
Lilies, white Madonnas and crimson and white Rubrums, add their scents too. They are grown in small pots and moved into view as they start to bloom. In autumn, the pots are buried in soil and covered with hay to protect against frost.
Vines insure privacy. The brick parapet walls and a trellis are covered with a mix of yellow honeysuckles, white moon flowers, clematises and climbing roses like America, Zephirine and New Dawn.
Across the East River, Michael Straus's backyard is a small, sunny space behind a Federal period house. "I wanted a four-season garden that looked like it could be at the edge of a meadow," said Mr. Straus, a lawyer. He was standing in the center of a mix of coreopsis, phlox, bell flowers, black-eyed daisies and rosemary.
"You can see that my goal was English cottage style," he said.
The combination of perennials, herbs and shrubs is a creation of Phillip Watson, a landscape designer he hired three years ago. Mr. Watson, the owner of Washington Gardens, a Fredericksburg, Va., nursery, commuted six hours each way by truck.
"It's hard to believe," Mr. Straus said, "but after Phil designed the garden plan, I realized it would actually be more economical to have him also bring all the soil materials and plants from Virginia -- and do the planting, too."
Mr. Watson said, "Retail prices in Virginia are cheaper than wholesale prices in New York."
"Since I knew this client intended to do all future maintenance chores himself, it was important to choose easily cared-for plants," he continued. "My idea was to arrange them so they looked like they'd always been growing here. They also had to be species that would survive his business trips away."
The first order of business was coping with the steep slope around a bedroom addition that occupies nearly half of the 60-foot-long yard. Designed by Andrew MacNair, an architect, it was also planned to be a sitting room and office. "So what is seen from inside is important," Mr. Watson said.
Multiple levels now temper the nearly four-foot change of grade and insure a smooth transition from indoors to out. Two retaining walls, built of bluestone and brownstone found on the site, divide the 23-foot-wide garden into three broadly rectangular terraces.
Wide steps and a gently curved stone path link the three levels. "The steps, terraces and curving path not only solve the grade problem," Mr. Watson said, "but add a sense of depth and dimension. They keep this long, narrow site from feeling like a railroad car and make it possible to have a bit of mystery. I think it's good when you can't see everything in a garden at one glance."
The lowest level, a shady stone patio, is brightened early in spring by the scores of small flowering bulbs that appear between the stones. Among these diminutive daffodils are Tipit, Baby Moon and Jenny. Tulips include Waterlily, Tarda, Sweet Harmony and New Design, with its variegated foliage.
The uppermost level, the furthest from the house, is the sunniest portion. A green wall of fastigiate yews adds a year-round backdrop for masses of colorful summer bloomers as well as a specimen weeping mulberry, which flowers but does not bear messy fruit.
The mulberry is surrounded by an evergreen ring of dwarf Hicks yews. In summer, hostas and golden lamium add another circle of color.
The cracks between the winding stone path on the upper levels are filled with fragrant herbs -- a mix of creeping gold oregano and the creeping thymes Pink Chintz and Elfin.
These tiny crack fillers keep the weeds under control and also perfume the summer air around a stroller who crushes them.
"Sequence and timing are the secret of the color in this garden," Mr. Straus said. "Just like a good comedy."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Fed's Worry Over Money

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
PEOPLE often talk about monetary policy as if Alan Greenspan were punching buttons on the electronic control panel of a Boeing 747. In truth, however, the Federal Reserve chairman is doing something more akin to guiding a hang-glider by shifting body weight -- skilled improvisation at the mercy of the elements.
Mr. Greenspan is trying to nudge down inflation and keep the recovery going by controlling the money supply. But steering the nation's money supply has rarely been harder. And even gauging its present course is tricky. 
 Judging whether money is easy or tight is always tough when the economy is emerging from recession. Inflation often looks better than it really is, while, thanks to trailing data, business and consumers often look worse. That leads to the classic mistake of providing too much stimulus long after, in retrospect, the recovery has taken off.
Nowadays, there are two additional circumstances that compound the problem of reliably gauging whether the Fed is on course: the fact that savers have more alternatives to banks and the restructuring of the savings and banking industries. Consider M-2, the Fed's current favorite measure of money. It lumps together assets that are ready to spend, like currency and checking accounts, with savings: passbook savings, small certificates of deposits and bank money market funds.
Money, of course, can be used to buy additional goods and services or to bid up prices.
Money has been growing at a worryingly meager rate since last fall: 2.6 percent, right at the bottom end of the target range the Fed announced last February. "It is unusual for money to grow so slowly during a recovery," said Anatole Balbach, research director at the St. Louis Fed. "It says essentially that the recovery is going to be a slow one." In fact, the Fed decided to nudge interest rates down further this week for the first time since April, the month many economists believe the economy bottomed out.One explanation -- favored by the Treasury and the White House -- is that monetary policy has not been as easy as is suggested by the sharp decline in short-term interest rates since last fall. Short-term rates are the lowest they have been in 14 years and the lowest of any industrialized country.
There are strong reasons for thinking, however, that there is a different explanation for a good deal of the sluggishness. Looking at the different components of the money supply, the weakness is concentrated in bank and savings deposits and in types of deposits that are highly sensitive to interest rates.
Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, argues that virtually all of the money's unusually slow growth stems from the fact that consumers aren't rolling over their certificates of deposit. "Nearly all the other components of M-2 are behaving normally for this stage of the business cycle," Mr. Steinberg said.
Since the end of June, the money supply has fallen by around $11 billion. As it happens, consumers have cashed in, on a net basis, some $11 billion worth of C.D.'s. It is not hard to figure out why, either. Rates on C.D.'s, above 8 percent last winter, have plunged to around 5.5 percent. These days they are even lower than passbook savings rates.
What are consumers doing with their money? They mostly are pouring it into mutual funds that offer higher returns. In recent months, bond mutual funds have swelled by $7 billion a month and stock mutual funds have grown by roughly $4 billion a month. Funds outside the banks, of course, are not counted in the money supply. "While M-2 stalled, the public's financial assets have continued to expand," said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
The question is why money growth has not stalled in other recoveries, since short-term rates have typically fallen far more in recessions than long-term rates. Consumers today have both a greater incentive and more opportunity to move their savings out of banks and savings institutions. In contrast to today's rock-bottom short-term interest rates, such rates were around 8 to 9 percent when the last recession ended, producing impressive returns -- at least in terms not adjusted for inflation.
Besides, alternatives to C.D.'s and NOW accounts were simply not as abundant. Back then, according to Mr. Steinberg, bond mutual funds amounted to a puny 1 percent of the consumer savings that are counted in the money supply. Today they equal a respectable 15 percent.
Moreover, banks and savings and loans have not been willing to raise rates to keep the business. In addition, when healthy institutions buy sick savings and loans they are acquiring additional deposits, tamping their appetite for other funds. And commercial banks as a whole are more anxious to shore up their capital/asset ratios than to expand their liabilities, which include deposits.
More critical, the part of money that is most closely tied to spending, M-1, has been growing at a brisk 8.5 percent clip in the past six months -- about in line with increases in past recoveries.
Nonetheless, the Fed was not inclined to dismiss the possibility that the economy was softer than expected, even though the evidence on that score, including a weak job market, is mixed. "We know some of the sluggishness of money growth is a signal of the weak economy, said Art Rolnick, research director of the Minneapolis Fed. "We can't know how much. We just have to make a guess."
Fortunately, the Fed's inflation-fighting credentials are such that it can afford to err on the side of ease. The bond market, a critical barometer of inflation fears, greeted the Fed's easing move warmly, pushing long-term rates down.

HEADLINE: Retailers Say July Sales Were Generally Listless

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
With the notable exception of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the industry leader, most United States store chains yesterday reported listless sales for July, a transitional month when summer goods typically are cleared out for back-to-school items.
Other than Wal-Mart and the specialty retailer the Gap Inc., sales were "pretty meager," said Walter Loeb, a New York-based industry consultant. 
 Bruce Missett, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, said, "You go from gargantuan numbers for the Gap and Wal-Mart to a sluggish trend for all the other retailers."
 
40% Gain for Wal-Mart
 Wal-Mart, which also reported record profits and revenues for its fiscal second quarter, posted a 40 percent rise in July sales, to $3.36 billion from $2.40 billion in July 1990. At stores open at least one year, sales were up 13 percent.
The Gap said it sold $153 million of merchandise at its clothing stores, an increase of 34.2 percent from the $114 million sold a year earlier. Same-store sales, considered the best comparison of year-to-year performance for the industry, were up 14 percent.
But at most other major chains, the news was disheartening.
Sears, Roebuck & Company said overall sales fell 1.4 percent in July, to $2.49 billion, while sales at stores open a year or more were down 2.1 percent. The J. C. Penney Company said July sales fell 2.2 percent, to $984 million, and sales were off 3 percent on a same-store basis.
 
Sales Up at May and K Mart
 The K Mart Corporation and the May Department Stores Company each posted July sales increases of four-tenths of a percent at stores open at least one year. Over all, K Mart's sales were up 4.7 percent, to $2.36 billion, while May's were up 8.6 percent, to $657 million.
Analysts said one reason for the subdued July business was that the weather was hot in May, so that consumers started their summer shopping early and had bought most of their summer merchandise by June.
Analysts also noted that buying picked up at the end of July and in the first few days of August as fall merchandise began to arrive for the back-to-school season. "In the last week there's been a pickup, particularly evident in specialty apparel and department stores," Mr. Missett of Morgan Stanley said.
 
Back-to-School Business Expected
 Analysts predicted back-to-school business this fall would be brisker than last year, when consumers, gripped by uncertainty in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, battened down spending.
"Business should look better in August and September and for the rest of the year compared with last year's results, which were depressed by the gulf crisis," said Edward Johnson of Jones & Ryan's Johnson Redbook Service.
Kurt Barnard, publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, added: "The July data clearly indicate a bottoming out of the retail recession. We can look forward to a gradual, modest upturn."
 
Quarterly Report by Wal-Mart
 Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., and took over the title this year as the nation's biggest retailer, said its profits for the second quarter had surged 26.7 percent, to $345.9 million, or 30 cents a share, from $272.9 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales jumped 37.1 percent, to $10.34 billion from $7.54 billion.
Wal-Mart's share price rose 75 cents yesterday, to $48.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
K Mart, which said its second-quarter earnings would exceed last year's level, saw its share price gain 25 cents, to $46.125, after it announced the slim rise in sales.
Among other retailing stocks, the Gap jumped $3 a share, to $39.25; Sears was down 62.5 cents, to $41, and J. C. Penney gained $1.625, to $51.875.
 Following is a list of the July sales of the other largest retailers. The dollar figures are not listed for the same-store sales because some retailers do not report them.
Dayton Hudson Corp.: Up 7.3 percent, to $1.06 billion; same-store sales up 2.7 percent.
Melville Corp.: Up 20.0 percent, to $665 million; same-store sales up four-tenths of 1 percent.
Woolworth Corp.: Down 3.2 percent, to $691 million; same-domestic-store sales down 1.5 percent.
The Limited Inc.: Up 14.0 percent, to $398 million; same-store sales up 1.0 percent.
Mercantile Stores Co.: Up 3.0 percent, to $155 million; same store sales up 1.6 percent.
Neiman Marcus Group: Up 3.4 percent, to $120 million; same-store sales down 1.6 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Prices Lose $7.50; Gasoline at Summer High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The platinum market took another downward spin yesterday. Prices of platinum futures are now poised to drop below $350 an ounce for the first time in more than five years.
Gasoline futures soared to their highest level of the summer on the New York Mercantile Exchange, lifting the energy market amid scattered reports of refinery problems. 
 As pessimism grows about industrial demand for platinum, prices settled $7.50 lower on the New York Merc. The contract for delivery in October ended at $350.90, the lowest settlement of a near-term platinum contract since Feb. 4, 1986.
Silver also fell. Silver for September delivery ended 4.3 cents lower, at $3.927 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The August gold contract rose 60 cents, to $357.20, on the Commodity Exchange.
Platinum traded as low as $350 in a thin market dominated by trade selling, analysts said. The selloff partly reflected fears that the Japanese, who are big investors in platinum, would continue to liquidate precious metals, analysts said.
Although there was no market-moving news yesterday, platinum traders have grown wary of developments indicating lower demand. Those include the development of automobile catalytic converters that substitute other metals for platinum. The auto industry accounts for about 40 percent of world consumption.
The United States' sluggish economic recovery is also a drag on platinum because a slow economy implies slack demand for industrial materials.
The platinum market has also been shocked recently by signals that the Soviet Union is positioned to sell large amounts, if necessary, for hard currency and by proposals that the United States sell some of its strategic metal reserves.
Among energy futures, wholesale unleaded gasoline for delivery in September settled at 68.70 cents a gallon, up 1.89 cents; crude oil for delivery in September settled at $21.58 a barrel, up 22 cents; September home heating oil rose 0.54 cent, to 59.53 cents a gallon, and September natural gas finished at $1.285 per 1,000 cubic feet, down 0.1 cent.
Live cattle futures reached new three-year lows on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting ample supplies of fattened cattle and slack demand by packers and retail buyers.
Live cattle for August settled 1.38 cents lower, at 65.62 cents a pound, the lowest near-term cattle price since Aug. 2, 1988; August feeder cattle fell the 1.5-cents-a-pound daily limit, to 82.62 cents; August live hogs dropped 90 cents, to 51.25 cents a pound, and August frozen pork bellies rose 0.70 cent, to 42.75 cents a pound.
Grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade as the effect of beneficial rainfall in the Midwest began to fade.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Concerns Over Mideast and Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced today in light trading dominated by concerns over interest rates and strife in the Middle East.
Analysts said there was little news to influence currency trading, and most investors were adjusting their holdings in advance of today's release of producer price figures for July. 
 There was a flurry of buying on news that Turkey had begun new raids against Turkish Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq, but "it turned out to be not that big an event," said Walter Simon, a vice president with Bank Julius Baer & Company.
The dollar tends to rise when fighting breaks out in other countries because the currency is viewed as a relatively safe investment.
Traders were waiting for the producer price numbers to see if inflation moderated enough last month for the Federal Reserve to push interest rates lower again. The Fed already took steps to nudge rates downward earlier this week.
A drop in rates likely would prompt traders to sell the dollar because it, like all currencies, is supported by higher interest rates.
Mr. Simon said the market expected the producer prices report to show that prices rose by one-tenth of 1 percent in July.
"Most people are thinking that if it's anything like that, it's better to own marks than dollars at this moment," he said.
The dollar rose to 136.15 Japanese yen in New York from late Wednesday's 136.00. In overnight trading in Tokyo, the United States currency fell 0.55 yen, to 135.45 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 136.45 yen.
The British pound lost ground against the dollar. Sterling fell to $1.7065 in New York, from $1.7130 late Wednesday, and to $1.7005 in London from $1.7125.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.7140 German marks, up from 1.7105; 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.4985; 5.8330 French francs, up from 5.8180; 1,284.00 Italian lire, up from 1,280.00, and 1.1465 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14705.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Investors Deal a Costly Blow to Maxwell

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Just as Robert Maxwell is planning to try to sell common stock in the United States, there are signs that investors may be getting nervous about at least one branch of his far-flung publishing empire.
A preferred stock issue of Official Airline Guides Inc., a subsidiary of the Maxwell Communication Corporation, failed to find buyers in an auction last week. As a result, the company will pay an extraordinarily high interest rate on the issue, and some stockholders who want to sell are being forced to hold on to it. 
 In an interview last night, Mr. Maxwell said the company had no financial problems, asserting that the auction failed because of a lack of communications about expected bids. "All my people say it was a snafu between us and Merrill," he said. Merrill Lynch & Company co-managed the original offering with Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Mr. Maxwell said he had no problems with Goldman, Sachs, but added that it was pointless to try to fix blame for the failed auction. "It really is, to our knowledge, nobody's fault," he said. He forecast that when the next auction is held, on Sept. 20, "it will be successful."
The failed auction came at an unfortunate time for Maxwell Communication, which said last month that it was considering spinning off its American operations, including Official Airline Guides and the book publisher Macmillan Inc., and selling stock in them. Mr. Maxwell said last night that he expected to announce firm plans about the American operations "very shortly."
Mr. Maxwell said there was "no possibility about being scared about the credit" of Official Airline Guides. He said that the company had no debt and that there was no reason to be concerned about the $2.15 billion debt of its corporate parent, Maxwell Communication.
But there were at least some indications that nervousness over the Maxwell empire played a role in the failed auction, which took place last Friday but received little attention until this week. The issue is a private placement, and the results of the auction were not widely disseminated.
The security in question is a $75 million issue of auction-rate preferred stock, which is set up to allow holders to sell out every seven weeks as a new auction is held to establish the dividend rate. It is the practical responsibility of the original underwriters to round up bids, but they have no obligation to bid if buyers cannot be found.
In past auctions of similar issues, when unusually high rates resulted from an auction problem, buyers have rushed to snap up the securities in after-market trading. But two traders said they were aware of no such trading in this case. That could indicate investor hesitation to buy the Maxwell paper.
Officials of both Goldman, Sachs and Merrill Lynch declined to comment on the auction. But Robert Kantowitz, a managing director of Merrill Lynch, said, "Merrill intends to continue to expand the investor base for the O.A.G. issue, and we would assume and hope that Goldman, Sachs would do the same."
Several traders said there were rumors in the market that Merrill Lynch had left the impression with both Goldman, Sachs and the company that it would be submitting more bids than it did.
The possible common stock offering in Maxwell Communication's American operations has been widely viewed as resulting from a need to reduce the company's debt. Maxwell's stock, traded in London, has fallen 14 percent over the last three months since a sister company, Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C., went public. The Mirror offering was at first described as oversubscribed, but it has since run into investor hostility. The shares now trade 15 percent below the offering price.
The Daily News of New York, also owned by Mr. Maxwell, is not part of Maxwell Communication and would not be included in such an offering.
The structure of the Official Airline Guides preferred stock offering is supposed to provide ample protection for holders. Martin Maleska, the senior vice president for acquisitions for Maxwell Communication, said he believed it deserved at least an A rating, and could not understand why it was rated a notch lower, at BBB+, by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Mr. Maleska said figures for the first six months of 1991, which have not yet been disclosed, would show that both Official Airline Guides' revenues and operating earnings were lower than a year earlier. But, he added, there were more than enough profits to cover the preferred dividends. He attributed the lower earnings to a drop in tourism resulting from the Persian Gulf war. Official Airline Guides is the dominant provider of airline schedule information to travel agents and computerized reservation systems.
The rules of the preferred stock issue provide that since there were not enough bids, the rate for the next seven weeks is set at 150 percent of the rate on 60-day commercial paper, for a rate of 9.03 percent. Because corporate buyers pay low taxes on preferred stock dividends, that is a very high rate. The underwriters had told investors they expected a rate of 8.5 percent or less.
In the two previous auctions of the Maxwell paper, on April 26 and June 14, the rates had come in at nearly 140 percent of the commercial paper level. That meant the auctions succeeded, but the rates were still well above the rates fetched by companies with similar securities ratings, including the Chrysler Financial Corporation and a number of utilities. Those issues have generally brought rates no higher than 110 percent of the commercial paper rate.

HEADLINE: Oakland Tribune May Close Unless Gannett Settles Debt

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Robert C. Maynard, the owner of The Oakland Tribune, announced yesterday that he would be forced to close the California newspaper on Wednesday unless the Gannett Company, which sold him the paper in 1983, agreed to terms that would eliminate a $31.5 million debt remaining from the sale.
Mr. Maynard said Gannett has thus far refused his offer of $2.5 million to settle the debt. He said such a deal was essential in order for him to secure financing that would enable The Tribune to continue publishing. The $2.5 million would come from an investor Mr. Maynard declined to identify, who would then invest more money in the paper. 
 "This is hardball time," said Mr. Maynard, one of the nation's few black newspaper publishers. In a statement sent by fax to many newspapers, Mr. Maynard said Gannett "is killing The Oakland Tribune for no reason we can understand."
 
Gannett's Response
 In a statement, Gannett said yesterday that Mr. Maynard had not provided it with details "to determine the merits of any offer." But the company did not say whether a $2.5 million offer was acceptable.
The company also noted, "Although The Tribune has been in default with regard to its obligations to Gannett for at least five years, we have continued to assure Mr. Maynard that we would not take action that would trigger a bankruptcy filing and don't intend to."
John S. Reidy, an newspaper analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said Mr. Maynard's ultimatum put Gannett in an embarrassing position because the giant newspaper company would not want to be blamed for the closure of one of the few minority-owned newspapers.
Indeed, it has been a source of corporate pride at Gannett that the company made it possible for Mr. Maynard to buy The Tribune by granting him the loan he is now trying to retire.
"They would look better having the paper survive," Mr. Reidy said.
 
Missed Interest Payments
 Gannett sold the paper to Mr. Maynard, and a partner who owns 20 percent of it, for $17.5 million. Mr. Maynard estimates that he has paid about $6 million in interest. But Gannett has allowed him to miss recent interest payments and the debt has ballooned to $31.5 million.
Like Oakland, The Tribune has been depressed for many years, and Mr. Maynard said the current economic doldrums made it impossible to continue without refinancing. He said the paper had lost about $2 million so far this year.
The Tribune has won many awards in recent years, including a Pulitzer Prize for photo coverage of the 1989 Northern California earthquake. But its circulation has been flat at the 1983 level of about 150,000, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
Last year, Mr. Maynard said the paper would close unless there were severe reductions in labor costs, and he reduced them by 25 percent through wage cuts and layoffs.

HEADLINE: Recovery Gasps for New Orders

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The Will-Burt Company, a parts maker in Orrville, Ohio, senses the beginnings of an economic recovery. Various customers -- a nearby Volvo truck factory, for example, and AMF Bowling Inc. -- are purchasing a few more fenders, doors, bumpers and finely machined parts. As the pace picks up, Harry E. Featherstone, Will-Burt's chief executive, finds himself with a week's supply of steel. But he wishes the stockpile were smaller. "I'd like to order steel daily," he said.
Such thinking helps to explain why the heralded recovery from the recession is having trouble getting off the ground. Much depends on whether Mr. Featherstone and thousands of other American executives conclude, more or less simultaneously, that sales are again brisk enough and sustained enough to warrant restocking. When they do, economists say, the jump in production needed to satisfy the surge in new orders will give the economy a kick out of recession.
 
Not This Month
 
 "There will come a moment when people will decide that they don't have enough in their warehouses," said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton. "But that moment has not arrived yet."
Almost certainly it will not arrive before Labor Day, interviews with executives, industry experts and economists indicate. Across many industries, sales are indeed rising, but many of those interviewed said they lacked confidence that any improvement would endure. What is more, even if they become confident, summer is the worst of times to fire up a recovery through inventory rebuilding.
Retailers, for example, normally postpone major apparel orders until late August while they test the appetite for the new fall styles with pre-season sales. Most major chain stores reported yesterday that July sales of summer goods were listless. [Page D2.]
Similarly, auto sales have clearly outstripped production in recent weeks, but in July and August manufacturers phase out one year's models and begin to make the new lines. While they do so, production is held below par. Then, before setting new production schedules, auto makers must gauge the demand for 1992 models, said Joel Pitcoff, an analyst at the Ford Motor Company.
 
Just-in-Time Strategy
 Finally, the American economy faces an obstacle in this incipient recovery that did not hinder stockpiling after previous recessions. A surge in orders would undoubtedly prompt Mr. Featherstone's company to stockpile some steel. Nevertheless, he and many others are becoming increasingly adept at the new strategy of just-in-time delivery: moving products quickly from the factory to the customer, with the shortest possible stay in a warehouse.
Mr. Featherstone, for example, notes that Caterpillar Inc., a big customer, has eliminated a 500,000-square-foot warehouse in Aurora, Ill. "They want us to hold their inventories and make shipments to them weekly and even daily," he said. "But we are also going in the direction of not holding costly inventories."
Because of the recession, thousands of American companies took to selling from their existing stockpiles, rather than ordering new merchandise they might not have been able to sell. They have lived largely off their stockpiles for nearly nine months now, although the liquidation rate has fallen lately, the Commerce Department reports. Selling from inventory rather than making new merchandise contributed to the recession.
 
Companies Still Liquidating
 Now, with sales somewhat improved, production is beginning to rise as companies cautiously reorder. The big question, though, is whether the new production will increase to the point that the selling from stockpiles finally ceases in this third quarter. If so, that would be enough to end the recession, economists say.
"You don't need a vigorous restocking to drive the recovery," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "All you have to do is stop liquidating."
But many of the executives and industry experts interviewed did not think the inventory liquidation would end before the fourth quarter. And recent surveys conducted by the National Federation of Independent Business, representing small companies, and the National Association of Purchasing Management, representing mostly major corporations, suggest a similar conclusion. In both surveys, substantial percentages of companies said they were still liquidating their inventories.
 
Gillette Cutting Inventory
 At the Gillette Company, liquidation is likely to remain the order of the day until October, said Milton L. Glass, the company's vice president for finance. Nevertheless, since June, Gillette has been selling more razors and razor blades to retailers. The retailers' inventories had fallen too low to meet the demand from consumers, and for two months retailers have been restocking, Mr. Glass said. But Gillette itself is not. Quite the contrary, it is selling to retailers from its own factory inventories, without increasing production.
"Our inventories had built up in April and May, and in June they were on the high side," Mr. Glass said. "Now, we are switching them to the retailers."
Like many of their compatriots, Gillette executives remain skeptical about how long the stronger orders from retailers will last. "You are going to have to wait until October before you can say whether there is a genuine consumer-led recovery or this increase in retail orders is just a flash in the pan," Mr. Glass said.
 
Commerce Department Data
 Some economists optimistically pin their hopes of a production surge on Commerce Department data that show inventories nationwide to be at an unusually low level -- 3.01 months of stocks on hand if production stopped dead today and sales continued at their current pace. That is a decline from 3.06 months last year, on the eve of the recession.
But while inventories nationwide might be very low, the Commerce Department figures can obscure some important variations. While some major industries are still selling from stock, others are not. Sales of household appliances, for example, have risen sharply and, with inventories lean, production has shot up. Such production increases, in turn, prompt companies to rehire workers or pay more in overtime, and those new wages help pump up the economy.
The steel industry, however, built up stockpiles early this year, partly in anticipation of a strike at the USX Corporation that did not materialize. Sales then fell, leaving manufacturers and distributors with too much on hand, which has suppressed production, said Walter Carter, a steel industry specialist at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm.
"We are still in the relatively early stages of reducing the stockpile," he said, adding that the rest of 1991 might be spent in trimming away two million tons of stored steel products.
 
Some Industries Holding Back
 Some industries with lean inventories nevertheless prefer to hold back production until short supplies drive up prices. That is the case among makers of linerboard, the heavy cardboard-like material used to make shipping cartons. Linerboard stockpiles are down to less than six weeks' supply, said Timothy McKenna, a spokesman for the Union Camp Corporation, a major maker of linerboard. But the priority is to get the price toward where it was last January: $370 a ton, compared with $320 today.
Other, less tangible factors are also discouraging the inventory rebuilding that played a major role in recoveries from past recessions. One is low inflation. Companies stockpiled in the past to avoid paying much higher prices for raw materials, parts and finished goods a few months later. Inflation today, however, is running at a low annual rate, under 3 percent, as measured by the Consumer Price Index.
"No one is tempted to buy in anticipation of price increases," said Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a business research organization. "This failure to restock in turn helps to keep prices down."
Imports are also a much greater source of inventories than a decade ago -- a trend that pushes up production abroad but not at home.
"With production now globalized, companies can 'outsource' overseas as well as domestically," Richard B. Berner, a senior economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in a recent article. "As a result, imports now substitute for domestic inventories."
Finally, the credit crunch inhibits stockpiling. Keeping 10,000 pairs of shoes on hand means a retailer must borrow money to buy the shoes and store them until they can be sold to consumers, and then repay the loan. Bankers themselves say they are more cautious than they were in the 1980's about providing such financing. That caution has meant, for example, that the shoe manufacturer and the economy are often deprived of the wealth that comes from producing the extra shoes.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Prices Drop After Auction

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Investor demand for the Treasury's $12 billion of new 30-year bonds was weaker than anticipated yesterday, sending prices down modestly on long-term issues.
The slack demand, which some traders said was a reaction to the brisk rise in bond prices the past week, became apparent soon after the 1 P.M. bond auction. By late in the day, bond prices fell slightly more than a half-point, raising the yield of the just-auctioned 8 1/8 percent bonds to 8.21 percent late in the day from an average of 8.15 percent at the auction. 
 The outstanding 8 1/8 percent Treasury bond was offered late in the day at 98 27/32, down 17/32, to yield 8.23 percent, compared with 8.18 late Wednesday. Before yesterday's decline, the price of the 8 1/8 percent Treasury bond had increased by more than 2 1/4 points since July 29, when its yield was 8.39 percent.
The decline in prices was confined to bonds due in five years and longer. Among shorter-term issues, prices were stable to slightly higher, with the Treasury's new 6 7/8 percent notes due in 1994 ending the day unchanged at 99 30/32 to yield 6.90 percent. Rates on Treasury bills fell a few hundredths of a percentage point, with the three-month issue ending the day at 5.37 percent.
The weakening bond market cut short an early rally in the stock market yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 12.75 points to close at 3,013.86. [Page D6.]
One clear sign that some securities dealers were awarded more of the bonds than they expected, or desired, was that some bonds were awarded with a yield as high as 8.19 percent, an unusually wide spread.
"We had a lot of supply on top of a rally that reduced yields on intermediate notes nearly half a percentage point," said William Brachfeld, head of government securities at Daiwa Securities in New York.
As long as economic data continue to show that inflation is weak and the economy sluggish, Mr. Brachfeld said, yesterday's decline "is just a case of temporary indigestion." But he warned that if economic data showed either a rise in inflation or a more robust economic recovery, it would quickly deter investors.
Economists generally expect that this morning's report of producer prices for July will show no change, or even a slight decline. Some traders then expect that bond prices could recover some of yesterday's losses.
Some Treasury bond traders at firms that also handle corporate bonds said the prospect of a heavy supply of corporate issues next week might also have added to the market's downturn, although demand was good for the $3.2 billion of corporate bonds offered in the past week.
"If the bond market had held at its best levels, there could have been $4 billion to $5 billion of new corporate issues next week," said Lindley B. Richert, head of MCM Inc., a New York firm that monitors corporate securities markets. Because of yesterday's decline in bond prices and increase in yields, he said, new issuance will be much lower, because many corporate treasurers are still willing to wait for rates to come down.
The Federal Reserve's announcement of a $200 million decline in the M-2 money supply measure had little effect on yesterday's trading. The decline, which left M-2 $20 billion below its level of June 17, has reduced its growth rate since the fourth quarter to the bottom of the Fed's 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent objective.
Weak money supply growth, plus signs of a sluggish economy, low inflation and the declining trend in interest rates the past few weeks encouraged the Fed to ease monetary policy a notch on Tuesday. Analysts expect the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to average about 5.5 percent, down from the 5.75 percent rate that has prevailed since late April.
William Griggs, an economist at Griggs & Santow, a New York advisory firm, said the weak money supply was "reflecting some of the current weakness of the economy," as well as the preference of people to use their cash, rather than keeping it in banks with low interest rates. The interest rates at many banks are the lowest since the late 1970's.
"Some of the weak growth in bank accounts that are included in money supply measures also reflects the financial problems of the banking system," Mr. Griggs added.
Although there was a deposit run yesterday at Citicorp's Hong Kong branch, bankers said there were no signs in the wholesale markets that Citibank or any other large New York bank was having difficulty raising funds. But the episode in Hong Kong and rumors of other troubles were taken seriously enough that at least one New York bank arranged for extra staffing on its liability management desk last night and today.
New York banks have been striving the past year to reduce their reliance on funds borrowed in the wholesale markets, and have tried to limit those borrowings to long-term customers.
Following are results of yesterday's auction of new 30-year Treasury bonds:

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Off a Bit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell slightly in the last week in July, the Labor Department said today in a report that drew a mixed reaction from private economists.
The department said that for the week ended July 27, 400,000 Americans filed first-time claims for unemployment benefits, a drop of 4,000 from the week before. The report marked the second consecutive weekly improvement, but analysts were split on the implications. 
 Some argued that the further decline in claims showed the economy was gradually gaining strength, but others said the slight change was further proof that the economic recovery had faltered. "This is just further evidence of a stalled recovery," said David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., consulting firm. "We are in the summer doldrums."
Other economists, however, were impressed that since peaking at 543,000 in late March, claims have generally been on a downward path.
"We are in the early stages of a slow, weak recovery," said Irwin Kellner, chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, pointing to the declining claims as confirmation of that.

HEADLINE: Tax Delinquencies in New York Rising Again

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Property-tax delinquencies in New York City are rising again, as they did during the 1970's, when the city last underwent an economic crisis. But city officials do not expect a recurrence of the wave of the abandonments that destroyed neighborhoods across the South Bronx the last time around.
Many of the new delinquencies are in commercial properties in Manhattan, including a number of buildings owned by some of New York's leading real-estate families. 
 City officials see the increase -- 38 percent in the 12 months ended June 30 -- as a result of the real-estate slump and the reluctance of banks to lend to developers. Landlords unable to pay their bills are in effect using the city as a bank: "borrowing" money by not paying property taxes.
According to the Department of Finance, between June 1990 and June 1991 property-tax delinquencies rose by $86 million, to $315 million, or 3.64 percent of the total tax levy. That is the highest level since 1980, but still a long way from the postwar peak of 7.5 percent that was reached in 1976.
Of that $86 million increase, 70 percent is owed by owners of commercial buildings, and nearly 20 percent of the total is owed by owners of Manhattan office buildings.
The finance department's list of those who are delinquent on their property taxes, water or sewage charges includes some well-known names: real-estate developers like Alex di Lorenzo 3d and Harry Macklowe; the Barbizon Hotel; the Prince George, the former welfare hotel, and Bob Guccione, the publisher of Penthouse magazine.
"It says something about the state of the economy," said Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's Commissioner of Finance. "The real-estate market is in dreadful shape."
The fact that the city's list of delinquencies includes prominent business organizations has Ms. O'Cleireacain relatively unconcerned by this increase in delinquencies. She views it primarily as a cash-management issue. Others are less sanguine: they see the increase, and the big names involved, as a sign of desperation.
"This is further evidence that New York is hurting badly," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
During the Manhattan real-estate boom of the 1980's, many property owners were sufficiently optimistic about the future to refinance their buildings, taking out larger mortgages on the assumption that property values and rents would keep on rising. But with 20 percent vacancy rates now common in Manhattan properties, and property taxes escalating, many owners are not getting enough cash from their buildings to cover their mortgage, maintenance and tax bill.
"The cash flow is no longer there on which millions of dollars were lent," said Joel Picker, a lower Manhattan leasing agent for the Galbreath Company. A recent survey by the consulting firm of Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler found that the number of buildings where operating costs exceeded income increased by 70 percent last year, to almost 10 percent of the 560 buildings that were studied.
 
Vacancies Surge
 "Every owner has a problem building," said Mr. Spinola, of the Real Estate Board, which paid for the consulting firm's study.
Consider the problems that have plagued 2 South William Street, the elegant nine-story office building that was built in 1892 and is home to Delmonico's restaurant. In the last 18 months, the vacancy rate has soared over 30 percent, as a law firm, an executive search firm, a brokerage firm and a computer company have all either moved to cheaper quarters in Brooklyn, gone under or taken space in newer office buildings in Manhattan, the building's rental agent said.
Although a representative of the owner, J. D. Branmaur Inc. refused to comment, the agent, Richard Marcus, said that a building like 2 South William Street can only command rents in the range of $15 a square foot, but has operating costs of $5 to $6 and taxes of $3 to $4 a square foot. When financing costs are thrown in, there is precious little left. According to the Department of Finance, the building's taxes went unpaid for more than a year and the arrears were only cleaned up in June.
Landlords facing temporary cash shortgages used to ask their banks for short-term lines of credit. But these days few banks are willing to lend to the real-estate industry.
 
An Alternative Banker?
 In the absence of bank loans, the city often becomes the only alternative. Unlike commercial banks, which foreclose on properties fairly promptly, the city waits at least 12 months before initiating foreclosure proceedings. There is then a four-month grace period during which owners who come up with the money can get their buildings back. And the city is willing to negotiate a return of the property to an owner for another 20 months after that.
As a reward for its patience, the city has been charging a hefty 19 percent interest rate. But many property owners are willing to pay the price.
Ms. O'Cleireacain says the city generally collects about 95 percent of what it is owed within two years.
A spokesman for Mr. Macklowe said that within the last two weeks, the developer settled a $2 million delinquent tax bill that dated to January. The city said it has no record of that payment but acknowledged that there is a delay in its processing.
And Joseph Neumann, who is reckoned to be the third-largest owner of rentable office space in Manhattan, recently paid back $1.8 million on a building that had been in arrears for more than a year. A spokesman for the company said that in the last two weeks Mr. Neumann had also repaid $2.357 million on two downtown buildings that the city said had been delinquent since January. The city's records do not yet reflect those payments.
"We've been cutting our costs left, right and center," said Charles Herzka, a vice president at Broadway Management, which manages Mr. Neumann's properties. "We saved up the money and we paid our taxes."
Ms. O'Cleireacain said the rise in delinquencies has not heightened the city's own financial problems. For starters, the city is collecting handsome interest payments -- albeit not all upfront. But Ms. O'Cleireacain says this does not pose a serious cash-management problem for the city. The numbers are small in relation to a $29 billion budget.
And since there are always a certain number of slow payers, she simply builds that factor into her revenue forecasts. At the same time that there are new delinquents, the city is collecting payments from old ones who are finally ready to settle their debts.
Still, not everyone views this new trend with quite so much equanimity. Mr. Spinola says it is hardly a healthy sign when some of New York's most prominent real-estate developers have no choice but to borrow at 19 percent from the city.
"Other buildings could go into default," he said, "and the city could end up owning office buildings."
Such a dire scenario seems unlikely, because banks that hold the mortgages on those buildings are likely to intervene rather than let those properties revert to the city. The Glick Organization, for instance, recently defaulted on a property on East 14th Street and the bank which repossessed it, Fidelity New York Federal Savings Bank, is now responsible for repaying $626,624 in delinquent taxes.
 
814 Buildings Claimed
 Still, the finance department's records indicate that nearly 80 percent of the 48 largest delinquent properties are overdue by more than one year. And the number of buildings that the city has actually been forced to take over rose to 1,586 in 1990, from 930 in 1989. So far this year, the city has claimed 814.
And many real-estate experts are not optimistic about a quick recovery in the office market. David Shulman, a real-estate analyst at the Wall Street firm of Salomon Brothers, forecasts that when discounted rents for sublet space are taken into account, the "true" vacancy rate could rise to as high as 25 percent in the future.
Property taxes are also likely to aggravate building owners' problems. The Dinkins administration already has built into its financial plan for the next three years property-tax increases of about $1.6 billion. And some real-estate experts think if the finance department re-assesses buildings to reflect the decline in property values, real tax-rates will have to be raised again to compensate for the shortfall that would otherwise result.
Typically, when the city raises property-tax rates, as it did recently, commercial property owners are insulated because they can pass those increases directly onto their tenants.
But in a market where owners are having to offer rent-free periods, generous renovation allowances and other inducements just to attract tenants, many owners have had no choice but to absorb the tax increases themselves. Ms. O'Cleireacain thinks that is one reason the Real Estate Board became such a vociferous opponent of the city's latest round of tax-rate increases.
"I think it was coming out of their own pockets," she said of owners.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Free-Trade Accord Is Enticing Canadian Companies to U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 8

 BODY:
In 1847, Daniel Massey left New York State for Newcastle, Ontario, where he created the small farm implement company that became Massey-Ferguson Ltd., one of Canada's industrial giants.
Now the company, which changed its name five years ago to the Varity Corporation, has won Government and stockholder approval to move to the United States. It has incorporated itself in Delaware and is moving its corporate headquarters from Toronto to Buffalo. 
 Varity is just one of hundreds of companies abandoning Canada to move south of the border in the wake of the Canada-United States free-trade agreement that took effect in early 1989. Some, like Thompson Transport and St. Lawrence Starch, are Canadian; others, like Toro, Wang, Celanese and Burlington Industries, are subsidiaries of American companies. The businesses are attracted by lower American wages, more modest personal and business taxes and cheaper real estate. And the trade pact reduces the cost for American companies selling in Canada.
 
'Bottom-Line Decision'
 "It's a bottom-line decision," said Donna Nason, manager of Canadian business development for the Greater Buffalo Chamber of Commerce, which is among the legion of American cities and states that have set up what the Canadians view as raiding operations here. Besides Varity, Buffalo has attracted 86 other Canadian companies since July 1987. "The Canadian companies are looking at costs, and like what they see on our side of the border," Ms. Nason said.
The phenomenon of companies shifting operations to the United States affects all of Canada, from British Columbia to the Maritime Provinces, but is felt most acutely in Ontario, which accounts for nearly half of the country's manufacturing employment.
For Varity, the move affects only 40 people, employees in its headquarters staff, of which about a quarter are going to Buffalo. But other companies are shifting plants, sales forces, warehouses and distribution centers. Labor officials say that altogether about 200,000 jobs have been lost as a result of the shift of operations south.
The signing of the trade pact was generally seen as a boon to the Canadian economy -- an agreement that would open up access to the American market, which is 10 times the size of the Canadian market. But the agreement is also proving to have negative effects -- including the flight of business -- as critics of the pact had predicted.
The new trade relationship has also been marked by a growing stampede of Canadian shoppers across the border in search of cheaper gasoline, cigarettes, whisky, clothing and other bargains. The number of cross-border shopping trips in May was up 19.6 percent from a year earlier, according to Statistics Canada, the federal data collection agency. And unofficial estimates suggest that Canadians are spending as much as $2 billion a year in their cross-border consumption sprees.
But for many workers, the most immediate problem is the departure of companies.
The economic dislocation is "at least as wrenching as the U.S. Rust Belt experienced in the early 1980's," said Andrew Jackson, the senior economist at the Canadian Labor Congress, the umbrella organization for Canada's trade unions. "It's been a real shakeout here."
The free-trade pact, he said, has given United States companies "practically unrestricted access" to the Canadian market. Before, he said, a company based in the United States faced substantial tariffs and other regulations that tended to make it tougher for them to sell in Canada. Many American companies set up subsidiaries here to allow them to slip inside the protective walls. The bulk of Canada's foreign investment is American, with a growing amount from Japan.
 
Policies Called 'Shortsighted'
 But others note that the southern migration of business has been accelerated by the severe Canadian recession and by "shortsighted" Government regulatory and social policies.
"Our cost of capital and labor is too high," said Stephen Van Houten, president of the 2,500-member Canadian Manufacturers Association, adding that the country now faces "a severe problem of competitiveness."
He said high interest rates had lifted the Canadian dollar to levels that were hurting exports.
In the first quarter of 1991, for example, bank lending rates in Canada averaged 11.58 percent, compared with 9.19 percent in the United States, according to the International Monetary Fund. That was an improvement from 1990, however, when the average rate in Canada was 14.06 percent, compared with 10.01 percent in the United States, I.M.F. figures show.
 
Labor Wage Gap
 Canadian businesses have also watched their labor costs rise faster than those for American businesses. The average hourly manufacturing wage in the United States in 1987 was $9.91, slightly above the wage rate in Canada, which was equal to $9.42 in United States currency. But by last April, the Canadian wage had risen to the equivalent of $12.97, while the American wage had moved up to only $11.10.
Canada has begun to try to fight back. This year the federal Government replaced an old manufacturers tax with a lower goods-and-services tax that is refunded when goods are exported. Government officials hope that when the economy recovers, corporations will be more inclined to stay in Canada.
But while hundreds of companies have packed their bags, Varity's decision has attracted more than the usual attention because of the company's standing as a national symbol and the $400 million in Canadian taxpayers' money that was pumped into the enterprise over the last 10 years to help it stave off bankruptcy.
 
Job Guarantees
 A $3.6 billion-a-year producer of auto parts, diesel engines and farm equipment, Varity announced its intention to pull out of Canada more than a year ago. That precipitated negotiations with both the federal and Ontario provincial governments, and led to an accord in October.
The arrangements guarantee that the 1,200 workers in the Canadian plants will keep their jobs until 1993. In addition, Varity must pay $50 million to the provincial and federal governments and to former workers and invest $3.5 million in the Woodstock, Ontario, auto parts plant of its Kelsey-Hayes division.
Despite these arrangements, the shareholders' final overwhelming approval of the move last week touched off reactions of disappointment from provincial and federal leaders.
"I regret the way that this has happened," said Premier Bob Rae of Ontario, a socialist. He also said he regretted having to make the deal that allowed it to happen.
A spokesman for the Finance Ministry in Ottawa grumbled, "Obviously, no one is very happy about it."
There was a more muted reaction from Bill Terry, director general in the Ministry of Industry, Science and Technology, who said the company had met "all the conditions" of its agreements and was "within its rights."
 
Not a Protest, Company Says
 The company, which became one of Canada's pre-eminent multinational enterprises before it was threatened with bankruptcy in the early 1980's, insists that it is not rejecting Canada. Victor Rice, its British-born chairman, told the shareholders that the move was "not in any way an act of protest or defiance."
"We shall always cherish our heritage as a pioneer of Canadian industry and a participant of long standing in Canada's economic development," he declared.
Mr. Rice said that even though his company lost $29.7 million (United States) in the quarter that ended on April 30, he expected Varity to be profitable for the full year.
Company executives added that Canadian operations had shrunk to represent only about 5 percent of Varity's global business. About 40 percent of the employees are already in the United States and the rest are chiefly in Germany, Britain, Italy, France and Spain.
Moreover, the company complained, Canadian incorporation had led Wall Street stock analysts and institutional investors to ignore its shares. Shareholders recently approved a 1-for-10 consolidation in the company's shares. The newly consolidated shares closed today at $25.50, up 75 cents each; before the shares were consolidated, they were trading at $2 to $3.
Now that the move is on, Varity will turn its attention to other pressing matters. The next task, Mr. Rice says, is to reduce its debt of more than $1 billion.

HEADLINE: Study Says Fees Are Often Higher When Doctor Has Stake in Clinic

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 8

 BODY:
Doctors' ownership of laboratories, diagnostic imaging centers and physical therapy clinics tends to increase the use and cost of such services without improving access to care for poor people or residents of rural areas, a Florida state agency reported today.
A study done by the agency also found that more than 45 percent of the doctors practicing in Florida, 8,500 of 18,250 doctors, have invested in joint ventures to which they can refer patients. 
 The investments have generated intense debate in Florida and other states, with some people asserting that there is a potential conflict of interest whenever doctors refer patients to clinics in which the doctors have invested.
 
Hard Numbers for First Time
 The Florida study, eagerly awaited by health officials around the country, is the first to document how pervasive such investments are, and how they can add to health-care costs.
The Federal Department of Health and Human Services has adopted rules to limit such investments by doctors paid through Medicare and Medicaid. The results of the Florida study are likely to bolster efforts by members of Congress and officials in other states to adopt broader restrictions on investments by doctors in health-care businesses. But such investments are so widespread that a complete ban would be extremely disruptive, doctors warn.
The study here, by the Florida Health Care Cost Containment Board, adds an ingredient largely missing from the national debate: concrete data, based on a statewide survey of 2,200 clinics and other health-care businesses. The Florida study is far more comprehensive than any done by the Federal Government or other states, but its results are consistent with findings from a more limited survey by the Federal Government in 1989.
James J. Bracher, executive director of the Florida agency, said at a news conference that clinics and laboratories in which doctors had invested had higher costs than businesses offering the same services but not owned by doctors. In addition, he said, there was evidence that the doctor-owned joint ventures were used more frequently, used less-skilled workers and offered limited access to the poor.
In Florida and elsewhere, joint ventures for doctors have proliferated in the last five years. The trend is particularly strong among imaging centers, which diagnose abnormalities in the spine, knees, brain and other parts of the body with techniques like magnetic resonance imaging, CAT scans and X-rays.
Proponents say the joint ventures raise capital for expensive, sophisticated equipment, make it more convenient for people to obtain the latest medical procedures and give doctors more control over the quality of services.
But the critics say there is a conflict of interest whenever a doctor refers patients to laboratories and clinics in which the doctor has invested.
 
More Tests at Higher Fees
 The Florida study is based on 18 months of research done under contract with the board by Jean M. Mitchell, associate professor of economics at Florida State University, and Elton Scott, associate professor of finance at the university.
They reported that investments by doctors had relatively little effect on the cost or quality of services at hospitals and nursing homes, ambulatory surgery centers and agencies providing health-care services to people at home. But they said, "Results clearly indicated problems in either access, costs, charges, utilization or quality of health-care services for clinical laboratories, diagnostic imaging and physical therapy centers."
For example, Mr. Bracher said, clinical laboratories owned by doctors perform "almost twice as many diagnostic tests per patient" as similar laboratories with no physician investors. "The average charge in a full-service joint venture lab is $43 per patient, as compared with an average charge of $20 per patient" in the other labs, he said.
Likewise, the study says that physical therapy centers owned by doctors typically schedule more visits for each patient but use fewer licensed therapists, so there is more revenue derived from each patient.
"A physical therapist employed by a joint venture facility treats an average of 20 patients per day, whereas in the typical non-joint venture facility a physical therapist treats an average of 12 patients per day," the study says. It concludes that the doctor-owned centers "provide a lower quality of care," in part because workers spend less time with each patient.
Florida doctors say they would oppose a ban on investments by doctors in health-care businesses. But some doctors acknowledge that there have been cases of abuse and say they would welcome official guidelines. "There needs to be some state legislation that establishes guidelines for physician investment in joint ventures," said Donald S. Fraser Jr., a spokesman for the Florida Medical Association. Another spokesman for the group, Gerald M. Soud, said, "We don't dispute the findings, but we want to analyze the data."
Dr. Charles P. Hayes Jr., a kidney specialist in Jacksonville, Fla., said the high volume of medical tests and procedures here could be explained partly by the presence of a large elderly population and by doctors' desire to protect themselves against lawsuits alleging medical malpractice. "We may have a sicker elderly population than other parts of the country because a lot of them move down here for their health," he said.
The Florida study surveyed 160 diagnostic imaging centers and found that 92.5 percent of them were owned wholly or in part by doctors. "The study shows that profits for diagnostic imaging centers are higher than for all other types of joint ventures," Mr. Bracher said.
The study compared Florida imaging centers with those in the Baltimore area, which are less likely to be owned by doctors who refer patients for examinations. Doctors ordered about 20 magnetic resonance imaging procedures for each 1,000 Miami residents, as against 12 for each 1,000 people in the Baltimore area.
 
Lawmakers' Interest
 The study does not makes no recommendations, but the board will submit proposals to the Florida Legislature in a few months. "This is a hot topic in Florida and much of the nation," Mr. Bracher said. "Because of the amount of local and national attention this study has generated and the need to avoid widespread speculation about the findings, we thought it was best to go ahead and release these preliminary findings."
The findings indicate that laboratories owned by doctors "perform more tests per patient, have higher charges and provide a lower quality of services" than laboratories having no investments by doctors, the report says.
The study notes that proponents say joint ventures promote access to new health-care technology for people in isolated rural or urban areas. "This does not appear to be the case in Florida, however, as none of the joint venture facilities are located in medically underserved areas," the study says. Thus, it concludes, in Florida "joint ventures do not increase access to rural or underserved indigent patients."

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Meggett Does Everything, Except Agree With Giants

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MENTOR, Ohio, Aug. 8

 BODY:
How much is Dave Meggett worth?
The Giants and Meggett -- an offensive threat as a running back, pass receiver, punt returner and kick returner -- are so far apart in contract negotiations that he might not play this year. 
 George Young, the Giants' general manager, and Harry Hulmes, the assistant general manager, are here with the team as it practices with the Cleveland Browns for Saturday night's preseason game. Tony Agnone, who is Meggett's agent, and Howard Shatsky, Agnone's associate, are in Baltimore.
The Giants have made one offer and Agnone has made one counteroffer. Shatsky said by telephone that he talked this morning with Hulmes. He said Hulmes told him the Giants did not plan another offer now.
Meggett's original two-year contract expired after last season. As a fifth-round choice in 1989, he received base salaries of $75,000 that year and $90,000 in 1990, plus a signing bonus of $37,500. The Giants said they also paid him $200,000 in incentives.
Meggett became a Pro Bowl kick returner as a rookie. He has won All- Pro honors in his two seasons, and his versatility as a runner-receiver-returner has prompted other teams to search for players just like him.
In May, the Giants offered a new contract. According to Agnone and Shatsky, they offered Meggett $1.025 million over three years.
The agents called the offer insulting. They did not make a counteroffer until last week, a three-month wait that Young considered insulting.
The 18-page counteroffer asked for $1.7 million over two years. That consisted of salaries of $700,000 this year and $800,000 in 1991 plus a $200,000 signing bonus.
Young said he considers those numbers outrageous. Meggett's agents feel that, in effect, they are telling the Giants that Meggett should receive makeup money because he had achieved more than expected.
In 1989, the Giants also drafted Myron Guyton, the free safety, and Howard Cross, the tight end. In the last two weeks, they negotiated new contracts that will pay Guyton $450,000 and Cross $400,000 this year.
Agnone said Meggett was prepared to sit out the season, although he said he did not think that would be necessary. Young said he would try to get Meggett signed, but added, "I don't have any idea if we can get it done."
The Giants still have six players unsigned and absent, and one other signed but holding out. Young's negotiating history suggests that he will work on the less problematic contracts first, so serious work on the Meggett contract may not begin until close to the regular season.
In Monday night's preseason opener against the Buffalo Bills, the Giants replaced Meggett with Stephen Baker returning punts, Dave Duerson returning kickoffs and Lewis Tillman as the third-down back. They will continue in those roles for now.
Meanwhile, Meggett sits and waits.
"He's one of the most exciting players in pro football," Agnone said. "You pay him like the star he is."
"We're not playing football anymore," Young said. "We're just playing economics."
