HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

 
Onda
 Among the scores of restaurateurs who are trying to reel in elusive patrons with the alluring bait of economy, Len Allison and Karen Hubert may be the most eccentric. The former owners of Huberts on Park Avenue, which closed last year, moved downtown to smaller and less costly quarters, hired a bare-bones staff and opened a restaurant that defies a simple label.
What do you call a place that on one menu offers shrimp with radish pudding and Chinese sausage, goat cheese lasagna, Indonesian-style veal-shank stew, and roast chicken with lemon -- the United Nations? They call it Onda.
The mahogany-lined rectangular dining room is as offbeat as the food. Bronze candle sconces and little religious paintings line the walls while the Shirelles coo over the sound system. Well-spaced tables are draped in paper, reinforcing the relaxed theme. Servers are casually attired, taking a cue from the gregarious manager, who comes to your table wearing a plaid sport shirt, a nascent beard and a little gold fish dangling from one ear. Hey, this place could be fun.
And it is fun if you order the right dishes, but doing that takes some investigation. Many of the menu items have two prices, one as an appetizer, one as a main course. This is a good idea for those who like to mix and match. An appetizer of sauteed tenderloin of pork is pleasing, the thin slices of meat served on skewers with a spicy peanut sauce and a cooling cucumber salad. Roasted peanuts resurface in a melange of Chinese rice-stick noodles with butterflied shrimp, tofu and bean sprouts. It's a lively combination, on the sweet side, with good textural contrast. The sweet tooth is sated again in the soft-shell crabs with a sweet-hot sauce of fish stock, sake, red pepper and chili pepper.
A nice communal munchie is the crisply fried baby calamari with pungent tamarind sauce. Pastas also can be a starter or a main course. Lasagna with sun-dried tomatoes, bound with a mortar of dense goat cheese, was too heavy and assertive. You might instead try the pansotti, a Ligurian ravioli that is filled with spinach and enlivened with a pastelike sauce of ground walnuts and herbs.
Onda has a small but well-selected wine inventory. Prices are very modest across the board. You might try the fruity, dry 1988 Chinon from Domaine de la Chapellerie ($19) with succulent roasted quails that are oddly paired with a Chinatown-style egg roll filled with cabbage, carrots and Chinese greens. Roasted chicken with a parsley puree under the skin, asparagus and lemon garnish is deftly done. It is crisp outside and moist within, sitting in a clear lemony broth.
Another good choice is a twist on osso buco, sinewy but tender veal shank with a rich, sweetish caramelized onion sauce and toasted polenta sticks. The indelicate Indonesian veal-shank stew, however, is overpowered by coconut milk. The Chinese-style roasted duck is probably the best effort of all, served with bok choy and water chestnuts.
Seafood does not fare so well. Fried red snapper Thai style with scallops and roasted sweet pepper is colorful but bland, and the highly perfumed steamed flounder with ginger and scallion has nothing over what might be served at a run-of-the-mill Cantonese restaurant.
The ingenuous summer desserts are more fun than throwing your sister into a swimming pool. The banana splits reminded me of my teen-age pigouts on a Jersey Shore boardwalk, and the hot fudge sundae is just as excessive, sans bananas. Chocolate rum espresso cheesecake is every bit as iniquitous as it sounds. Lemon pound cake was crumbly dry on one tasting, better the next time.
Onda's funky international approach to budget dining may not be to everyone's taste. But if the idea of a culinary Cook's Tour intrigues you, it can be recommended.
 
Andiamo
 When Andiamo opened in 1987, it was the biggest thing to hit the Lincoln Center area since Luciano Pavarotti first strolled up to the footlights. This stagy northern Italian restaurant boasted a first-rate chef, an energetic staff and a stylish loft setting.
Nearly four years later, it is still going at a relatively brisk pace. The original chef, Frank Crispo, moved on last year and was replaced by his second, Gregory Godon. Mr. Godon's menu is similar in style to his predecesor's, if perhaps just a little less consistent.
Andiamo is hidden down a corridor behind a casual streetfront spot called Cafe Bel Canto, under the same ownership. At the entrance is a soaring loft with a balcony reached by an iron staircase. Track lights illuminate abstract paintings, and a papier-mache saloon pianist is frozen in mid-song on a wide platform at the back of the room. Tables are generously separated, and conversation tends to float away in this soaring space. Nonsmokers may be pleased to know that smoking is prohibited anywhere in the restaurant.
Two upbeat starters are the mussels steamed in a subtle tomato-cream broth, and the mild, beefy-tasting venison carpaccio, which is seared outside, then sliced and served with tomatoes, red onions, cucumbers and provolone. Fried calamari, served over mixed greens and deep-fried spinach, would have been fine had they not lingered backstage too long, arriving flaccid.
One dish could not be passed up, for it sounded too outlandish: prosciutto, fresh figs and peach-flavored whipped cream with mint garnish. After sampling it, my table of four voted 3 to 1 in favor. (I was in the majority.) While the whipped cream was superfluous, the combination wasn't bad at all: minimally sweet, with a hint of peaches. Agnolotti filled with lobster and porcini and served in a mushroom-cream sauce sounded like a sure winner, but the filling could have been bread crumbs for all the flavor of mushrooms and lobster that came through. The sauce was the best part. A rich, fork-tender duck confit is served on greens and beets.
Andiamo's wine list is rich in selections from virtually all over Italy. A good selection of American chardonnays is available, as is a sampling of red Bordeaux. Prices are about average. The service staff is still knowledgeable and hard-working.
Pastas are uneven. A formidable-looking mountain of penne with pesto and sliced almonds has a snowcap of deep-fried leeks. Underneath all this was hidden a fillet of salmon. The whole assembly was like one of those Pentagon test missiles that do expensive swan dives into the ocean: both are made of quality parts, but when assembled they just don't fly. Whole-wheat pappardelle came with flabby, unappetizing sweetbreads in a shiitake cream sauce, and the chef's variation on spaghetti puttanesca, with sausages and tomato, was overwhelmed by salty black and green olives. One of the best pastas sampled was angel hair with briny clams and shrimp and scallops in a good shellfish broth tinged with saffron.
Among seafood offerings, a special of red snapper over spinach with a sauce of lobster broth was delicate and flavorful. Sauteed halibut steak, another special, was perfectly cooked and accompanied by roasted corn and fresh peas. Tuna encrusted with sesame seeds, fennel seeds and crushed red pepper over couscous and a sesame oil vinaigrette was overpowering; the tuna was lost amid the fireworks. Lamb chops, served with white beans, tomato and green beans, are nicely done, as is a grilled sirloin steak with garlic, black peppercorns and roasted vegetables.
If you crave something sweet before the opera or symphony, chocolate layer cake on a chocolate-latticed plate with coconut ice cream should do the trick. Creme brulee with raspberries is pleasing, better than the undistinguished gelati and pallid fruit sorbets. Fried banana slices come with walnuts and Jack Daniels gelato, which is boozy but unbalanced. Instead, try the tuile cone filled with gelatin-thickened Marsala cream and ringed with fresh fruit.
While not so harmonious as it once was, Andiamo is still worth noting when you look for dinner before or after Lincoln Center performances.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Jews Return to Visit Wartime Refuge

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:

20/20
Hidden Jewish Children Of the Holocaust
Produced by Abby Rockmore; Victor Neufeld, executive producer; Stone Phillips, correspondent. At 10 tonight on ABC.
 Tonight's moving edition of "20/20," at 10 on Channel 7, focuses on two of the thousands of Jewish children whose parents found refuge for them among non-Jews before they themselves were taken to German concentration camps. Renee Osten, who now lives in New York City, returns to the Roman Catholic convent in Toulouse, France, where she spent the last two years of World War II and meets again one of the nuns who risked their lives for Renee and other Jewish girls. Henri Weinstock, who now lives in Vermont, embraces the Belgian schoolteacher who rescued him and scores of other Jewish boys. 
 In the report's strongest moments, the survivors tell Stone Phillips of their feeling of abandonment. They could not understand why their parents were deserting them. Mr. Weinstock says that if he and the other boys who found refuge in a Catholic boarding school had known that their parents had been taken to the camps, "it would have driven us mad."
After almost 50 years, the memories still cut deep. Mrs. Osten tells tearfully of seeing her parents' being taken away on German trucks and refusing to look at her and her older sister, who had spent the night at a Christian neighbor's home. The parents' sacrifice, the courage of those who cared for the children, the survival of some in a time of the slaughter of so many are of course heartening. But, as Mr. Phillips reminds viewers, Mr. Weinstock and Ms. Osten were among the fortunate ones.
 
'Mini Dragons'
Channel 13
Tomorrow at 6 P.M.
 "Mini Dragons" is a four-hour set of programs on "the hottest economies on earth." The news in this interesting report is that the hot spots -- South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong -- may be cooling off in some ways and heating up in others.
The opening hour offers a picture of changes in South Korea through five people who represent different, sometimes conflicting interests: the head of one of the multi-national companies that dominate the country; the owner of a small garment factory who is finding it hard to keep up with the competition; a woman who has been imprisoned for trying to organize unions; a farmer's son who wins a place at Seoul University, and a government planner who is trying to get a deeply divided nation working together.
Their stories reveal the pressures building up in a society that owes its success to an unstable combination of tough government and big business on the one hand and low-paid workers on the other. Frequent strikes and protests have forced increases in wages -- to about $10 from $2 for an 11-hour day in a small garment factory -- that are making it difficult for many businesses to compete with Indonesia and Thailand where labor comes even cheaper.
Along the way, one gets a feeling for the group solidarity that seems to be basic to Korean society. Loyalty to the family becomes loyalty to the university, the corporation, the political movement. A busload of new employees of the billion-dollar conglomerate Ssangyong, to which they will devote their entire working lives, sing "It's dazzling . . . our future. Let's work!" Less happy workers sing: "Let's crush labor exploitation."
That farmer's son has hardly arrived at Seoul University before he is participating in a rally. "I belong here," he says proudly. "I'm part of this university."
The hour, somewhat amateurishly introduced and summed up by Yue-Sai Kan, a popular television personality in China, is anything but a rah-rah travelogue. It leaves the impression that the economic miracle is turning into a social nightmare.
Also covered in tomorrow's four-hour stretch (the Channel 13 schedulers are at it again): political changes in Taiwan; Singapore's efforts to sustain its economic momentum, and the future of capitalist Hong Kong as part of a Communist China.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Growing Up With Faith That Miracles Happen

BYLINE: "The Good Times Are Killing Me," initially produced by Second Stage, has reopened at the Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Manhattan. Following are excerpts from Frank Rich's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 19.

 BODY:
The wonderful thing about children is that they believe everything is possible. What makes Lynda Barry's first play a happy occasion is that she captures the innocent abandon of childhood with the wit of a mature writer, but without letting go of the uninhibited child still lurking deep within herself.
Ms. Barry's uneven but highly promising comedy, "The Good Times Are Killing Me," is about Edna Arkins, a pre-adolescent girl of the mid-1960's who believes, for the duration of elementary school anyway, that miracles like movie stardom and racial harmony are to be had for the asking, no matter what obstacles parents might place in the way. Ms. Barry, a syndicated cartoonist ("Ernie Pook's Comeek"), is just as free-spirited as her heroine in her first effort at writing for the stage. Like Edna, Ms. Barry at her best would rather hop, skip and jump than walk a straight dramatic line between any two points. 
 The evening has the rambunctious style if not the campiness of a John Waters movie like "Hairspray" in which the rituals of growing up, the increased racial segregation of rock music and the accelerating civil rights movement all converge on the streets of a changing blue-collar urban neighborhood. Sociological sea changes and intimate familial episodes are both defined by pop songs, whether the singers be Johnny Mathis, Paul Anka, James Brown, Elvis Presley or, in one loopy interlude, Julie Andrews in "The Sound of Music."
Mark Brokaw, the production's impressive young director, is in perfect tune with the playwright's jukebox approach to the traditional memory play. As Edna remarks that a song can make "the past rise up and stick in your brain," so old songs (and old "American Bandstand" or "Soul Train" dances) rise up in fragrant patches to accompany the script's remembered anecdotes about variously beloved and thorny relatives and neighbors. "Good Times" sometimes seems to be touring the early chapters of its heroine's biography with the same ease with which one might pass in and out of distant radio stations while turning a dial. Upbeat episodes like Edna's budding friendship with a black girl next door, Bonna (Chandra Wilson), are as gracefully and economically revisited as such heartbreaks as a father's desertion. Life, by turns romantic and bitter, just keeps popping in and out of the doors that line the set's row-house facade.
As acted by Angela Goethals with a fetching precocity that never turns bratty, Edna is a winning guide to her wonder years. Ms. Goethals is moving, too, when she and her sad-faced kid sister (Lauren Gaffney, another fine child actor) turn their house's basement into a "Record Player Nightclub" that, though conceived as a joyous imaginary refuge from their parents' marital travails, becomes a mausoleum for lost love.
While not as fully written, the story of the black family next door is just as well acted, particularly by Ms. Wilson and Kim Staunton. Even when the writing lacks fine detail, one still feels Ms. Barry's kinship with black characters whose deferred dreams are touched by, but not really redeemed by, such revolutionary phenomena as "A Raisin in the Sun," "To Kill a Mockingbird" and the Black Panthers.
"Good Times" begins to dwindle when the author takes the issue of race relations head on rather than elliptically. Act II devolves into a diagrammatic tale of the gradual parting of Edna and Bonna during the seventh grade, and the girls' story all too heavily symbolizes the larger tale of racial separatism on the eve of the riots of the late 60's. Suddenly a previously free-form play leans on a contrived plot twist -- an exclusionary teen-age party -- and takes to making points didactically. By the final half-hour, the writing has become as formulaic and glib as the television specials on racial tolerance that the play has previously mocked.
Young audiences -- and this is a play sure to earn the respect and laughter of young audiences -- will not mind the faults too much, for the author never patronizes her young characters even when her storytelling becomes a bit numbing to those of parental age. While the failings of "The Good Times Are Killing Me" are real, they are those of breadth, not depth. Lynda Barry's engaging debut as a playwright is anything but cartoonish.

HEADLINE: Black Progress Found, But Poverty Continues

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
More black Americans than ever moved into the upper middle class in the 1980's, but one-third remained locked in deprivation, a private demographic study said today.
And despite a doubling of the proportion of affluent blacks -- those with family incomes of $50,000 or more -- blacks remain the most isolated minority in the United States, according to the report by the Population Reference Bureau, a nonprofit educational group that reports on population trends. 
 The report was prepared by demographic researchers and specialists using Federal statistical data and material from academic sources.
"Evidence points to two African-American communities: one of middle-class and affluent blacks who took advantage of the increased opportunities provided by the civil rights movement, the other of poor, largely urban blacks who remain socially and economically isolated from the American mainstream," said Taynia L. Mann, an author of the report.
The increase in the number of affluent black families since the late 1960's was one of the few positive trends noted in the report.
It said that in 1989, one in seven black families had an income of $50,000 or more. That compared to only one of 17 black families who had similar incomes, adjusted for inflation, in 1967.
The number of affluent black families doubled in the 1980's, and virtually quadrupled since 1967, the report said. The number was 266,000 in 1967, and more than a million in 1989, it said.
The report said one in three white families was affluent by that same measure in 1989, up from one in six families in 1967.

HEADLINE: Only 50 Great Books of the Last 50 Years?;
Besides Orwell

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I must take issue with Russell Baker, who argues in "Looking for Giants" (column, July 27) that books of the past "had more weight back then." 
 Certainly, the books of the 1892-1942 period that Mr. Baker mentions carried great weight and were responsible for important social changes. Likewise, however, it is not hard to find books of the last 50 years (besides George Orwell's "1984") that have been similarly important.
As I peruse my modest bookshelf, I come upon Ralph Ellison's "Invisible Man" and Claude Brown's "Manchild in the Promised Land," both of which alerted Americans to the plight of our black citizens;
John Hersey's "Hiroshima," whose searing depiction of Hiroshima after the atomic bomb surely played a role in preventing world leaders from using such weapons again;
"The Other America" by Michael Harrington, which informed a prosperous nation of its serious social and economic problems;
Joseph Heller's "Catch-22," which did more than slip a new term into our language;
"The Feminine Mystique" by Betty Friedan, which helped jump-start the women's movement;
"The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers" by Paul Kennedy, which cautions us on our tendency to overextend ourselves militarily and neglect domestic needs.
My list is by no means exhaustive. Indeed, it includes only books by Americans. I am sure other readers -- with longer bookshelves -- can add to my list.
 
JAMES TACKACH
Chairman, English Department
Roger Williams College
Bristol, R.I., July 28, 1991

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Banking Companies Offer Variety of New Financings

 BODY:
Various banking companies announced plans this week for new financings to take advantage of low interest rates.
The Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh said yesterday that it planned to issue $150 million in a new series of preferred stock through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch. 
 Frank V. Cahouet, chairman, president and chief executive, said the 9.60 percent dividend on the stock was Mellon's most favorable since 1989.
Also yesterday, the Union Planters Corporation, a bank holding company in Memphis, said it planned to sell $15 million of cumulative preferred stock at $25 a share, with an increasing dividend rate. The rate will increase 50 basis points, or one-half of 1 percent each year for three years, after which the issue becomes callable. The initial rate will be determined when the issue comes to market.
Jack Parker, chief financial officer, said that increasing the preferred dividend rate yearly gave the bank an incentive to redeem the shares. Proceeds will be used to increase Tier I capital because of its $75 million proposed acquisition of Fidelity Bancshares, a Tennessee savings institution.
Earlier this week, the Norwest Corporation said it had placed $175 million in convertible preferred shares privately with institutional investors. Norwest, based in Minneapolis, said the proceeds would be used for general corporate purposes.
Meridian Bancorp Inc. of Reading, Pa., announced plans on Tuesday to offer 2.5 million to 3 million shares of common stock, adding to the 40.5 million shares outstanding. It said it planned to make a public offering, following the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on or about Aug. 15. The company's share price closed yesterday at $18.
Capital Bancorporation, a Cape Girardeau, Mo., bank holding company of 17 units, sold 1,030,195 common shares yesterday through Paine Webber, Inc., at $14.50 a share. One million of the shares were newly issued, while 30,195 were offered by stockholders.
J. P. Morgan & Company, the New York banking organization, offered $150 million of 12-year noncallable subordinated notes yesterday priced at par and bearing a coupon rate of 8 1/2 percent. The lead manager for the notes, which mature Aug. 15, 2003, was the First Boston Corporation.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 14, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about new financings from banking companies referred incorrectly to an offering of convertible preferred shares from the Norwest Corporation. The offering, which was announced at $175 million and then raised to $200 million, was a public offering, not a private one.

HEADLINE: Study Says Fees Are Often Higher When Doctor Has Stake in Clinic

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 8

 BODY:
Doctors' ownership of laboratories, diagnostic imaging centers and physical therapy clinics tends to increase the use and cost of such services without improving access to care for poor people or residents of rural areas, a Florida state agency reported today.
A study done by the agency also found that more than 45 percent of the doctors practicing in Florida, 8,500 of 18,250 doctors, have invested in joint ventures to which they can refer patients. 
 The investments have generated intense debate in Florida and other states, with some people asserting that there is a potential conflict of interest whenever doctors refer patients to clinics in which the doctors have invested.
 
Hard Numbers for First Time
 The Florida study, eagerly awaited by health officials around the country, is the first to document how pervasive such investments are, and how they can add to health-care costs.
The Federal Department of Health and Human Services has adopted rules to limit such investments by doctors paid through Medicare and Medicaid. The results of the Florida study are likely to bolster efforts by members of Congress and officials in other states to adopt broader restrictions on investments by doctors in health-care businesses. But such investments are so widespread that a complete ban would be extremely disruptive, doctors warn.
The study here, by the Florida Health Care Cost Containment Board, adds an ingredient largely missing from the national debate: concrete data, based on a statewide survey of 2,200 clinics and other health-care businesses. The Florida study is far more comprehensive than any done by the Federal Government or other states, but its results are consistent with findings from a more limited survey by the Federal Government in 1989.
James J. Bracher, executive director of the Florida agency, said at a news conference that clinics and laboratories in which doctors had invested had higher costs than businesses offering the same services but not owned by doctors. In addition, he said, there was evidence that the doctor-owned joint ventures were used more frequently, used less-skilled workers and offered limited access to the poor.
In Florida and elsewhere, joint ventures for doctors have proliferated in the last five years. The trend is particularly strong among imaging centers, which diagnose abnormalities in the spine, knees, brain and other parts of the body with techniques like magnetic resonance imaging, CAT scans and X-rays.
Proponents say the joint ventures raise capital for expensive, sophisticated equipment, make it more convenient for people to obtain the latest medical procedures and give doctors more control over the quality of services.
But the critics say there is a conflict of interest whenever a doctor refers patients to laboratories and clinics in which the doctor has invested.
 
More Tests at Higher Fees
 The Florida study is based on 18 months of research done under contract with the board by Jean M. Mitchell, associate professor of economics at Florida State University, and Elton Scott, associate professor of finance at the university.
They reported that investments by doctors had relatively little effect on the cost or quality of services at hospitals and nursing homes, ambulatory surgery centers and agencies providing health-care services to people at home. But they said, "Results clearly indicated problems in either access, costs, charges, utilization or quality of health-care services for clinical laboratories, diagnostic imaging and physical therapy centers."
For example, Mr. Bracher said, clinical laboratories owned by doctors perform "almost twice as many diagnostic tests per patient" as similar laboratories with no physician investors. "The average charge in a full-service joint venture lab is $43 per patient, as compared with an average charge of $20 per patient" in the other labs, he said.
Likewise, the study says that physical therapy centers owned by doctors typically schedule more visits for each patient but use fewer licensed therapists, so there is more revenue derived from each patient.
"A physical therapist employed by a joint venture facility treats an average of 20 patients per day, whereas in the typical non-joint venture facility a physical therapist treats an average of 12 patients per day," the study says. It concludes that the doctor-owned centers "provide a lower quality of care," in part because workers spend less time with each patient.
Florida doctors say they would oppose a ban on investments by doctors in health-care businesses. But some doctors acknowledge that there have been cases of abuse and say they would welcome official guidelines. "There needs to be some state legislation that establishes guidelines for physician investment in joint ventures," said Donald S. Fraser Jr., a spokesman for the Florida Medical Association. Another spokesman for the group, Gerald M. Soud, said, "We don't dispute the findings, but we want to analyze the data."
Dr. Charles P. Hayes Jr., a kidney specialist in Jacksonville, Fla., said the high volume of medical tests and procedures here could be explained partly by the presence of a large elderly population and by doctors' desire to protect themselves against lawsuits alleging medical malpractice. "We may have a sicker elderly population than other parts of the country because a lot of them move down here for their health," he said.
The Florida study surveyed 160 diagnostic imaging centers and found that 92.5 percent of them were owned wholly or in part by doctors. "The study shows that profits for diagnostic imaging centers are higher than for all other types of joint ventures," Mr. Bracher said.
The study compared Florida imaging centers with those in the Baltimore area, which are less likely to be owned by doctors who refer patients for examinations. Doctors ordered about 20 magnetic resonance imaging procedures for each 1,000 Miami residents, as against 12 for each 1,000 people in the Baltimore area.
 
Lawmakers' Interest
 The study does not makes no recommendations, but the board will submit proposals to the Florida Legislature in a few months. "This is a hot topic in Florida and much of the nation," Mr. Bracher said. "Because of the amount of local and national attention this study has generated and the need to avoid widespread speculation about the findings, we thought it was best to go ahead and release these preliminary findings."
The findings indicate that laboratories owned by doctors "perform more tests per patient, have higher charges and provide a lower quality of services" than laboratories having no investments by doctors, the report says.
The study notes that proponents say joint ventures promote access to new health-care technology for people in isolated rural or urban areas. "This does not appear to be the case in Florida, however, as none of the joint venture facilities are located in medically underserved areas," the study says. Thus, it concludes, in Florida "joint ventures do not increase access to rural or underserved indigent patients."

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
States Collecting For Many Causes

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Once the Federal Government introduced its political campaign checkoff, which since 1967 has allowed taxpayers to designate $1 of their taxes for Presidential races, it was perhaps inevitable that tight budgets and interest-group activism would combine to make the idea almost irresistible to states.
With North Dakota the last to fall into line, each of the 40 states with a broad-based personal income tax now has at least one checkoff box. In all, there are 125 programs, or an average of more than three for each state, according to a survey by the Federation of Tax Administrators. Most of the state checkoffs are taxpayer donations, rather than a diversion of tax money. 
 Since 1988, 16 programs have been added in 10 states, with Massachusetts installing the first in the nation to benefit AIDS patients; Arkansas, Mississippi, Utah and West Virginia adding educational checkoffs, and California, Illinois and Oregon providing the opportunity to help fight Alzheimer's disease.
The other two dozen causes include the arts, the United States Olympic Committee, the homeless, drug education, historic projects, child abuse, the aged, Vietnam veterans and trees.
Alabama and California have eight checkoff programs each, while Idaho and Rhode Island have six each; only seven states have just one.
"The most popular by far is non-game wildlife," said Ronald W. Alt, senior research associate for the federation. This category, which includes land preservation, is on the tax forms of 37 states, including New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Eighteen states have a political checkoff.But while the money raised by state checkoffs isrelatively small -- $30.1 million in 1989 -- the practice seems here to stay. Louisiana, dismayed by the unwieldiness of 12 checkoffs, eliminated all of them from 1988 returns. By 1990, however, the state had three.
"With declining state resources and growing social demands, voluntary donations gathered through the income tax are likely to be seen as a potential source of revenue by an increasing number of causes," the federation predicted.
 
 Debating the Luxury Tax
 For the better part of two years -- until it reversed course in the 1990 budget agreement -- the Bush Administration adamantly opposed tax increases. Now it is against a tax cut, one that many people contend would benefit the economy, not to mention an important political constituency of the Administration.
At issue is the luxury tax imposed last autumn on high-priced boats, aircraft, jewelry, furs and automobiles, a tax estimated by the Joint Tax Committee to raise almost $1.5 billion over five years -- and comforting to many politicians because most taxpayers would view it as a tax on the rich.
But the numbers projected, a growing number of critics charge, largely disregard changes in people's behavior, including the fact that lower demand for these items puts those who make and sell them out of work. According to two Republican members of the Joint Economic Committee, Representative Olympia Snowe of Maine and Senator Connie Mack of Florida, the luxury tax will cost 9,400 jobs in the yacht, airplane and jewelry businesses alone this year. They say the Government will lose nearly $5 for each $1 the tax generates.
More than 250 members of Congress have co-sponsored repeal measures -- half a dozen have been introduced -- said Walter E. Huizenga, president of the American International Automobile Dealers Association.
But the Treasury has said it does not favor repeal "at this time," noting that the luxury tax has been in place for barely half a year and that the economy has been in recession. It is thus "too early to assess what the tax's impact will be in terms of effect on the industry, revenues realized or difficulty of administration."
The unstated reason, however, is undoubtedly the fear that any tampering might begin to unravel the budget deal.
 
Footnotes

* Total corporate taxes, including payroll taxes, at all level of government rose to 83.8 percent of profits in 1990 from 58.9 percent in 1980, according to the Tax Foundation, a business-supported research organization.
* The I.R.S. will conduct a two-day conference on electronic filing in New Orleans on Aug. 29-30.
* Representative J. J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, head of the Ways and Means subcommittee overseeing the I.R.S., is urging a second "taxpayer bill of rights" to improve the one adopted in 1988.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Also Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher yesterday against most major currencies in light trading despite new evidence of moderating inflation that suggested interest rates may be headed lower.
Gold prices were also higher. Gold for current delivery in New York rose $1.20 an ounce, to $358.40, on the Commodity Exchange. And the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid for gold at $358.50 an ounce, up $2 from late Thursday. 
 The United States Producer Price Index fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July, following a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported.
The inflation news seemed to suggest that price increases would remain subdued in coming months, which would give the Federal Reserve leeway to cut interest rates to help invigorate the economy.
Lower rate expectations would normally depress the dollar because rate declines reduce the potential yields that foreign investors would receive on dollar-denominated securities.
 
Behind the Rise
 Yesterday's rise in the dollar "caught a lot of people by surprise," said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at Algemene Bank Nederland in New York. But he said there had been interest in buying the dollar since it sank earlier in the week toward 1.7 German marks.
Christa Bleyleben, a vice president for foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston in Boston, said some traders had already incorporated the possibility of lower United States interest rates and higher German rates into the price of the dollar.
She said the dollar's decline from 1.8 marks over the last two weeks showed that traders recognized that "the economy is not out of the woods yet and that there may be some delayed recovery here." A rise after that kind of a decline is not unusual, she said. The dollar finished yesterday in New York at 1.7288 German marks, up from 1.7140 late Thursday.
Dealers said there was also considerable dollar buying yesterday to cover short positions.
Before the price report was released, the dollar had risen by 0.85 yen, to 136.30 yen, in Tokyo. It finished at a higher rate of 136.80 yen in London after the release of the report. In New York, the dollar rose to 136.55 yen, from 136.15 late Thursday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.6965 from $1.7005 late Thursday. In New York, the pound fell to $1.6945 from $1.7065.
Late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, were: 1.5145 Swiss francs, up from 1.5010; 5.8805 French francs, up from 5.8330; 1,295.50 Italian lire, up from 1,284.00, and 1.14655 Canadian dollars, up from 1.4650.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 17.66, to Below 3,000 Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average fell below the 3,000 level yesterday for the second time this week, closing at 2,996.20, down 17.66 points.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was relatively low at 144.07 million shares, down from 163.9 million on Thursday. Declining issues outpaced advancing ones by 868 to 695. 
 For the week, the Dow dropped by 10.06 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell yesterday by 2.20, to 387.12, while the American Stock Exchange's composite index fell 0.61, to 365.98. In over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index was off 1.08 at 508.31.
 
Gains Soon Eradicated
 A better-than-expected report on the inflation front yesterday morning on a drop of two-tenths of a percent in the Producer Price Index for July lifted stocks but the gains were soon eradicated.
Birinyi Associates, which follows program trades, said all five made yesterday were sell programs, with a combined time of 41 minutes, during which the Dow fell by a cumulative 35.35 points.
Paul J. Kronlokken, a technical analyst for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis, said the stock market went full circle, with the full breadth down most of the day. "Initial reaction to the producer price figures was good for stocks, behind a bond market rally," he added. During the day the market attempted a couple of rallies, but fell short each time.
Early gains were erased as investors began fretting over this week's quarterly refunding, particularly the sale of the long 30-year bond, which did not do as well as the three-year and 10-year note auctions.
"On an intra-day basis the market found support with the Dow at 3,010," Mr. Kronlokken said, "but 3,000 is a psychological level, and you always find some resistance above or below."
Technology and health-care stocks made early gains, but gave them all back toward the close, he noted.
In reporting the drop of two-tenths of a percent in producer price figures, the Labor Department attributed a good portion of the decline to a steep fall in gasoline and food. Without those often volatile components, the core rate rose by two-tenths.
Wall Street economists had expected the index to be unchanged with the core rate up by two-tenths of a percent.
Among the most active stocks yesterday, with 2.96 million shares traded, was Westinghouse Electric, which fell 1 1/2, to 22 3/4. Westinghouse had announced that the chief financial officer of its troubled Westinghouse Credit unit had resigned.
Deere fell 7/8, to 50 7/8, as Shearson Lehman Brothers lowered its 1991 earnings estimate for the company, to $1.35, from $1.70. Deere's fiscal year ends Oct. 31.
 
Outlook Depresses G.M. Stock
 General Motors fell 1 3/8, to 38 1/8. Jacob T. Battenberg 3d, a G.M. vice president, in a talk to security analysts, said the auto maker did not expect North American operations to return to profitability in the next two to three years. He added that the company would lose money in North America until auto sales returned to 15 million units a year.
USX-Marathon rose 1/8, to 28 3/8. Paul Ting, an Oppenheimer analyst, said he had been briefed on the potential size of an oilfield Marathon discovered in Tunisia. "It's very bullish for the company," he added.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Top Officer Leaves Westinghouse Credit

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that the top financial officer of its troubled credit subsidiary, which took a nearly $1 billion charge against earnings last year, had resigned to pursue other interests, including a possible post with the parent company.
The executive, Laurence A. Chapman, 41 years old, resigned from the Westinghouse Credit Corporation at his own initiative, a spokesman said. The resignation was effective immediately. Mr. Chapman had been in the post since mid-1988, the spokesman said. 
 A native of England who became a naturalized American citizen, Mr. Chapman had been with Westinghouse for 10 years and before that had been a senior executive with the Royal Bank of Canada. Mr. Chapman asked Westinghouse's public relations department to decline requests for interviews.
James W. Meighen, 47, executive vice president of investment policy and portfolio management, will assume Mr. Chapman's post immediately and will also retain his previous responsibilities.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Westinghouse shares fell $1.50 yesterday to close at $22.75, on heavy volume of nearly three million shares.
The credit subsidiary, which is part of Westinghouse's financial-services operation, is one of the nation's largest such operations. It lent heavily to commercial real estate developers, as well as to leveraged-buyout firms that took on heavy debt. In addition, it had about $650 million in marketable securities, most of which were high-yielding junk bonds. When the economy turned sour, analysts said, so did many of Westinghouse Credit's loans and bond holdings.
Albert E. Turner, an analyst who follows Westinghouse for Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago, estimated that 90 percent of Westinghouse Credit's loan portfolio involved either commercial real estate, now in a severe downturn, or lending to leveraged-buyout firms. "You tend to get into businesses that you think you're good at," he said. "And they looked good at it for a few years."
In February, Westinghouse took a $975 million charge against its earnings in the fourth quarter of last year, about $925 million of which applied to Westinghouse Credit.
Analysts said they would not be surprised if Westinghouse had to take further charges against earnings because of the troubles at the credit unit, perhaps even in the range of several hundred million dollars.
The financial-services operations, including the credit unit, reported a loss for last year of $844 million because of the restructuring charge, in contrast to an operating profit a year earlier of $164 million. The unit's revenue rose 13.2 percent last year, to $1.2 billion, from the previous year's $1.06 billion. The financial-services operation also owns United Federal Savings, a medium-sized savings and loan in Galesburg and Peoria, Ill.
Last month, Westinghouse reported a 50 percent drop in second-quarter earnings to $127 million, or 41 cents a share. It said the financial-services operation's revenues were down slightly, but its profits were "sharply lower" from the second quarter of 1990.

HEADLINE: Increase in Bridge Upkeep Is Planned

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Beneath the 79th Street bridge on the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn, workmen wearing bright orange vests recently demonstrated a well-known solution to New York City's bridge crisis: they connected a hose to an 8,000-gallon water truck and washed the underside of the bridge, removing dozens of pounds of debris that would have led to widespread corrosion.
For decades, engineers have warned that deferring the maintenance and cleaning of bridges would cause the structures to deteriorate rapidly and eventually cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in emergency repairs and major reconstruction. 
 But transportation officials have continued to slash budgets for bridge maintenance and cleaning, especially in hard economic times and also because the Federal Government provides funds for bridge reconstruction and not for maintenance.
Now it finally seems that New York State is taking some of the necessary steps -- like cleaning bridges on the Gowanus Expressway -- to reverse this trend.
 
Priority for Prevention
 State transportation officials said this week that they planned to spend 20 times more than they did five years ago to maintain and clean state-run bridges in New York City.
Officials of the New York State Transportation Department said they would spend between $40 million and $50 million in fiscal 1991 on bridge maintenance and repair, compared with $20 million in 1990. The state spent $1 million to $2 million on such programs in fiscal 1987.
"We have completely redefined our priorities and put preventative maintenance at the top of the list," State Transportation Commissioner Franklin E. White said in a recent interview. "Deferring maintenance makes no sense. It is the equivalent of eating your children."
The effects of decades of neglect can already be seen in New York City. About 50 percent of the 662 state-run bridges in the city and 56 percent of the remaining 842 operated by the city are considered structurally deficient and unable to carry the loads for which they were designed.
 
Reconstruction Delayed
 Bridges built by the state are maintained by it, and the same is true for the city. To pay for the substantial increase in bridge maintenance, the state plans to spend less on bridge reconstruction; some severely deteriorated bridges that were scheduled to be rebuilt will have to wait.
Michael Francese, director of the State Transportation Department's New York City office, said the state's bridges were deteriorating so rapidly that "the quickest way to turn things around is to pump as much money as possible into maintenance and repair."
Mr. Francese said the state's new maintenance program would concentrate on cleaning and painting bridges every 12 years and repairing joints, bearings, cracks, drains and crucial vertical structural members.
In the long term, preventive maintenance will save the state hundreds of millions of dollars, Mr. Francese said, citing a 1990 study by a consortium of civil engineering professors that found the city and state could save $5 on reconstruction for every $1 spent on maintenance.
 
Ruinous Effects of Salt
 The 842 city-owned bridges, including the four major East River bridges, are maintained by the city's Department of Transportation. While the city is spending more on preventive maintenance than it has in the past, officials cut the planned expansion in bridge maintenance this year to help offset swelling budget deficits.
When a bridge is not painted and maintained regularly, its steel parts are exposed to water, salt and debris, and this causes them to corrode internally. The primary cause of corrosion is the salt that is spread to melt snow or that comes from the water below.
Salt mixes with water and seeps into the bridge's reinforced concrete, which acts like a rigid sponge. Then the salt decomposes, and the resulting chloride ions attack the reinforcing steel bars. The rust that forms on the bars causes them to expand, spalling (flaking or chipping) the concrete above the reinforcement.
For other bridges outside of New York City, the state has increased its budget for bridge maintenance to $60 million for fiscal 1991, from $25 million five years ago.

HEADLINE: Short-Term Rates Slip; 30-Year Yields Up

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Short-term interest rates fell slightly yesterday following a Government report of a decline in producer prices in July. But the good news on the inflation front was of little benefit to the long-term market, where interest rates rose a notch as securities dealers, still burdened with a heavy supply of new 30-year Treasury bonds, pushed prices down.
Among Treasury notes auctioned earlier this week, securities dealers said investor demand had been strong, and the supply of unsold notes was not burdensome. The 6 7/8 percent issue due in three years was offered at 100 3/32, up 5/32 to yield 6.84 percent, well below the 6.92 percent average yield at Tuesday's auction. 
 The 7 7/8 percent issue due in 2001 was offered at 99 12/32, up 3/32, to yield 7.97 percent, a slightly higher yield and lower price than Wednesday's auction, when the yield was 7.94 percent.
 
 Not Enough Demand

The new 8 1/8 percent Treasury bonds due in August 2021 closed at about 98 3/32, down 3/32 to yield 8.22 percent, up slightly from the 8.21 yield late Thursday. After the Labor Department report of a decline of two-tenths of a percent in the Producer Price Index for July, the long-term bond improved to about 99 7/32, but there was not enough demand for that gain to be sustained.
In the short-term market, the rate on three-month Treasury bills fell to 5.32 percent from 5.37 percent, as traders said demand benefited from a decline in overnight interest rates yesterday and hopes that the low inflation report would encourage the Federal Reserve to reduce short-term rates.
Nervousness about deposit runs at Hong Kong branches of both Citibank earlier this week and the Standard Chartered Bank yesterday were widely discussed in the market but did not seem to result in any signficant flight to the quality of Treasury bills. Analysts noted that there was no increase in Eurodollar deposit rates that would suggest a drop in investor confidence in large banks.
 
Not Seen as Fed Signal
 Although the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market fell to 5 1/4 percent yesterday, many analysts said the drop was not a signal that the Fed was trying to ease monetary policy more than expected earlier in the week. On Tuesday, when the Fed signaled an easing move by temporarily buying Treasury securities, analysts immediately concluded that the Fed was encouraging a decline of one-fourth of a percentage point in the overnight funds rate, to 5 1/2 percent from 5 3/4 percent.
Louis v. B. Crandall, a market analyst at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, estimated that the decline in the funds rate yesterday was temporary. He noted that after the overnight bank loan rate rose to a peak of 30 percent late Wednesday, the Fed "overcompensated" and supplied extra reserves through temporary purchases of securities for customer accounts.

HEADLINE: Iraq Rejects U.N. Draft Resolution Allowing It to Sell Oil to Buy Food

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Iraq today rejected a draft United Nations resolution that would let it sell a limited amount of oil to buy food and medical supplies.
"The draft resolution does not provide the financial resources, even at a minimal level, to meet the needs of our people in terms of food, medicine and important humanitarian equipment," the Iraqi News Agency quoted Prime Minister Saadun Hamadi as saying. 
Mr. Hamadi said the resolution would deny Iraq sovereignty over its natural resources and bring Baghdad under the control of other countries.
The draft would allow the sale of up to $1.6 billion worth of embargoed Iraqi oil over six months. Much of that amount would be available for food.
 
War Reparations
 The rest would be used to pay war reparations, cover the cost of destroying Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, pay half of the expenses of a United Nations commission demarcating the Iraq-Kuwait border and reimburse the United Nations for overseeing the return of looted Kuwaiti property.
The Baghdad Government would not control any of the money, which oil purchasers would deposit directly into a United Nations escrow account.
Mr. Hamadi said the "colonialist powers" were not concerned with the suffering of the Iraqi people but wanted to solve their own financial problems at Baghdad's expense.
The American representative at the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, sought to play down Mr. Hamadi's statement. "I would say stand by for further word," Mr. Pickering told reporters in New York.
 
Investigation of Nuclear Program
 In Baghdad, the head of a United Nations team looking for evidence of an Iraqi nuclear weapons program said today that Iraq's uranium enrichment program was not for peaceful purposes.
David Kay, the leader of the fourth nuclear inspection team to visit Iraq, said the secrecy surrounding the program and the methods employed made no sense for a peaceful program.
But he stopped short of saying whether he thought Iraq had produced a bomb.
Under the terms of the Security Council's cease-fire resolution, Baghdad must disclose and dismantle its weapons of mass destruction. Iraq has said its nuclear programs were for peaceful research. The United States has accused it of lying to conceal a secret nuclear weapons program and has threatened fresh military strikes if it does not come clean on nuclear secrets.

HEADLINE: A Revamping at Alcoa As Pressures Mount

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, said yesterday that it was broadly reorganizing itself for the second time in five years in a continuing battle against the industry's problems of low prices and deep price discounting.
The changes at the Aluminum Company of America will eliminate two layers of management and give more autonomy to the company's 25 worldwide business units, covering everything from smelting to bottle cap production. Industry experts said the moves were clearly the latest efforts by Alcoa's chief executive, Paul H. O'Neill, to change the corporate culture of the Pittsburgh-based company. But they were mixed on how effective his actions would be. 
 Mr. O'Neill, 55 years old, said his objective was to fashion a leaner, more productive and energetic company that could make money even during a recession.
 
New Quarterbacks
 In an interview yesterday, Mr. O'Neill said the plans would "change the flow of power from the traditional path in corporations." He added, "This gives business-unit leaders the responsibility to, in effect, be the quarterbacks."
The company said it was responding to the increasing competition in the aluminum industry, in which slashing operating costs had become even more of an obsession in the recent years of deep price cutting by rivals like Reynolds and Alcan. Analysts added that Mr. O'Neill, who in 1987 became the first outsider to head Alcoa, was determined to raise the low earnings Alcoa posted in the last two years.
Alcoa said yesterday that the positions of president and group vice president had been eliminated. Instead, there will be three executive vice presidents whose role will be to advise the heads of the 25 business units. The company said that no layoffs were planned as part of the reorganization.
Alcoa previously had three operating groups: metals and chemicals; aerospace and industrial products, and packaging systems, all headed by group vice presidents who reported to the president and chief operating officer, C. Fred Fetterolf. Mr. Fetterolf, 63, retired last week in what he characterized as a disagreement with Mr. O'Neill over "business principles." Neither he nor the company would elaborate. The business units reported to group vice presidents.
Many industry experts had doubts that Alcoa's reorganization of executives could have much effect in a cyclical business whose fortunes are tied, more than anything, to the worldwide price of a commodity like aluminum.
"This is more of a fine-tuning than anything else," said Robin G. Adams, president of Resource Strategies Inc., a metals consulting firm based in Exton, Pa. "I don't think there were any glaring weaknesses in their organizational structure."
But Mr. O'Neill clearly believes there is a correlation, saying that improvements in the culture and structure of companies like General Electric had contributed to their financial success.
"Structure can make a big difference," he said. "We will reduce the amount of time it takes to make a decision and I am convinced that as a result we will make better decisions. Effectively, there is no one left between the business unit head and me."
 
Demand Is Down
 These are difficult times for the aluminum industry. Demand has fallen, particularly in the important automotive and construction industries.
In the more robust days of the last few years -- aluminum prices reached a peak of $1.65 a pound in 1988 and were as high as 93 cents last September -- earnings have been strong. But prices for the first half of this year have fallen, to about 68 cents a pound in the first quarter and to around 60 cents in the second.
Alcoa reported net income of $178.2 million for the first six months of this year, down 43 percent from the period last year. But while Alcoa's earnings have plunged, the company's major North American rival, Reynolds Metals, reported a 51 percent drop for the first half and the Canadian-based Alcan Aluminum lost money in the same period.
Mr. O'Neill has sought to refashion Alcoa's corporate strategy ever since the company's board ousted his predeccessor, Charles A. Parry, and brought him to Pittsburgh from the International Paper Company, where he was president. Mr. O'Neill immediately dropped the company's diversification into such high-technology areas as advanced composite materials and ceramics, which were pursued by Reynolds Metals.
Mr. O'Neill has also linked the compensation of employees and dividends to company profits. Workers in aluminum operations split up to 17 percent of any return on assets above 6 percent. At the same time, senior managers' increases in compensation are tied to meeting a number of performance goals, including such nonfinancial areas as energy conservation and safety.
 
'Open to New Ideas'
 "We have seen a positive change in the years Mr. O'Neill has been here," said an official of the Aluminum, Brick and Glass Workers Union. "There is the feeling that he is listening and is open to new ideas." The union official refused to be identified.
Not all of Mr. O'Neill's decisions have met with such acclaim. Late last year, he stunned the industry by deciding to go against the accepted practice of price discounting. That decision proved costly, with Alcoa losing as much as $100 million in sales and several percentage points in market share, industry analysts say.
Mr. O'Neill defends the decision, saying that Alcoa has regained whatever market share it lost. Moreover, he said, "I thought it was an ideal time to see if it was possible for us to take a different posture from the industry pattern of the past."
While analysts disagreed on the effects of the changes announced yesterday, Peter Anker, a metals analyst with the First Boston Corporation, gave high marks to Mr. O'Neill's plan.
"It is an indication of a desire to do something to make the company more responsive to customers," he said. "We're seeing more of that these days in American industrial enterprises: trying to get companies back to providing service to customers."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell 0.2% in July

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Prices almost always behave better after recessions. The Government's latest inflation report shows that they are doing so now.
Producer prices dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in July, the fourth decline since February. "There's not much inflationary pressure in the economy," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill. 
 Gains on the inflation front have generally followed the pain of recession. It is not unusual for producer prices to decline early in recoveries, as wholesalers and manufacturers keep trimming inventories. This time, better weather for growing fruits and vegetables and ample supplies of oil have been driving down food and gasoline prices, too.
 
The Fed Is Pleased
 The Federal Reserve, which eased interest rates last Tuesday, welcomed the report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics as another sign that inflation was subsiding. "The conditions for lower inflation are in place, and we're starting to see some progress," said David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Fed. But the bond market barely budged.
Better-behaved prices give the Fed more maneuvering room. "Good inflation news allows the Fed to ease without disturbing the bond market," said William Dudley, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
So far this year, the oft-quoted prediction of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, that inflation would wind up about one percentage point below its pre-recession rate seems to be materializing. The broadest measure, the fixed-weight G.N.P. deflator, went from a 5 percent annual rate in the winter to around 3 percent in the spring. Wages have been rising slowly, and commodity prices have been weak.
What is more, "the fundamentals are in place to make substantial progress," Mr. Mullins said. The factory-utilization rate is below 80 percent, unemployment is 1.5 percentage points higher than a year ago, and the recovery seems to be anemic. Money-supply growth over the last year has been modest.
But economists and Fed officials caution that good inflation news is not likely to tempt the Fed to abandon its cautious stance. "It's important to keep money growth at a moderate pace," said Lee Hoskins, president of the Cleveland Fed.
And Mr. Wyss said, "The Fed has room to loosen, but they won't want to use too much of that too soon."
For one thing, last month's decline in producer prices mostly reflected much cheaper fruit and vegetables and less expensive gasoline. Excluding the volatile food and energy prices, the index was up two-tenths of 1 percent, and it was 3.3 percent above a year ago. "The core rate is still higher than the Fed would like," Mr. Wyss said.
 
 Some Worries Persist

Further, the rise in producer prices, which exclude services, is typically about one percentage below the rise in overall prices. "I'm still worried about service-sector inflation, which is still in the 5 to 10 percent range," said Harvey Rosenblum, research director at the Dallas Fed. With the Fed aiming, as Mr. Greenspan has said, eventually to nudge overall inflation down to a rate between five-tenths and 1.5 percent, the Producer Price Index would ultimately have to bobble around zero.
Bond investors, Mr. Mullins said, were apt to remain skeptical for a while. "It will take more than a couple of good numbers to convince investors that inflation is moving down permanently," he said. "We will have to produce more evidence of progress."
But additional reassuring news may not arrive immediately, said Donald Ratajczak at the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University. Gasoline prices have been climbing this month, and a Midwestern drought has sent the futures prices of many agricultural commodities higher. Mr. Ratajczak expects the Producer Price Index to show an increase next month. In the meantime, tax increases may cause a rise in the July consumer price report that is due out next week.

HEADLINE: Home Prices Sag, but Not Enough for Many

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 7

 BODY:
As home prices dropped on Long Island, Thomas and Patricia Nolan of Farmingdale scoured the real estate ads for a house in their price range.
They are still looking. Prices are lower, but not low enough for them to be able to get together a down payment and get out of the apartment they are renting. 
 "I could probably afford a mortgage, but how do you get the down payment?" asked Mr. Nolan, a New York City transit police officer with two children.
Despite the much-touted drop in housing prices, thousands of low- and middle-income residents like the Nolans throughout the metropolitan region are still cut out of the market, housing experts say. On Long Island in particular, where median housing prices are the 10th highest in the nation, listings would have to fall thousands of dollars more before such residents could afford a house.
Their best hope for homeownership rests with low-cost housing programs run by government or nonprofit organizations for people or families whose income is between $20,000 and $60,000. But there are not nearly enough units planned or under construction to meet the need, despite aggressive efforts by some Suffolk County towns and the interest of private builders looking for any work they can get during the recession.
"The price decline hasn't done anything," said Peter J. Elkowitz, program administrator of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a not-for-profit group in Happauge. The three-year-old organization has planned or developed hundreds of single-family homes and town houses for first-time buyers at subsidized prices under $80,000.
Partnership officials could not estimate how many Long Island residents continue to be priced out of the housing market. But "everytime we advertise, we get swamped," Mr. Elkowitz said.
A 72-home development planned by the Partnership for the community of North Amityville in Babylon has attracted more than 300 applications. Other subsidized housing programs on Long Island are routinely oversubscribed.
The Town of Islip's College Woods development in Central Islip, the largest suburban affordable housing program in the state, attracted more than 1,100 applications for 100 homes in June 1990, said George Gatta Jr., who is the executive director of Islip's Community Development Agency. This year, it received more than 900 applications for 150 homes.
"It's still absolutely, definitely the American dream, and they're all, one way or another, trying to find it," said Nancy C. Manfredonia, executive director of the Central Islip Civic Council, a nonprofit organization deeply involved in College Woods.
 
Plenty of Work
 Strong demand for low-cost single-family housing continues throughout New York State.
"We could spend $50 million with no problem," said Juan Villanueva, director of the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation. The agency now distributes $25 million annually for housing subsidies statewide, and has supported construction of nearly 1,100 units since 1985. In all, about 1,400 such units have been built in Long Island since 1985, the Long Island Regional Planning Board estimates.
The reason the recent price declines have offered such scant relief is that they are falling from such heights. Median home prices on Long Island fell 10.5 percent between 1988 and 1991, to $156,100 from $174,400, according to the National Association of Realtors, a Washington-based trade group.
But the median income for a family of four on Long Island is $54,500. Since a common rule of thumb is that a family cannot support a mortgage that is more than twice its gross income, many people remain well out of range.
"Once you get over $100,000 or $110,000, you're dealing with people on my waiting list," said Nina Stewart, East Hampton's housing director.
Most of the new affordable housing projects on Long Island are being constructed in Suffolk County. Since 1985, for example, nearly 900 state-subsidized units have been have been complete or planned in Suffolk, compared with 31 in Nassau.
"I can't paint a rosy picture for you," said Raymond H. Malone, Nassau's Commissioner of Housing and Intergovernmental Affairs. Mr. Malone ascribed the lagging effort in Nassau to lack of buildable land and the high cost of the land that is available. The county has concentrated instead on subsidizing rehabilization efforts for renter and owner-occupied housing.
But Peter Klein, a builder active in low-cost housing programs and former president of the Long Island Builders Institute, said this effort was not enough. He called Nassau's record "an abysmal failure."
"Most of what has been done is lip service," Mr. Klein said. "The need is there. The political will isn't."
Suffolk County has much more undeveloped land. Some of the affordable housing programs have taken advantage of that, but the College Woods development in Central Islip is a revitalization effort using land in a once blighted, crime-ridden neighorhood known as Carleton Park.
"If you picked the worst neighborhood in New York City, that's what it was like," Mr. Gatta said.
Hundreds of old houses are being knocked down, to be replaced by about 370 new ones in styles like ranch and colonial. More than 30 families have already moved in amid the dust and noise of a major construction project. The highest price is $100,000, after a $25,000 state subsidy; the project's income limits are $28,000 to $57,000.
The Nolans of Farmingdale entered a lottery this spring to buy a house in College Woods, but ended up on the waiting list.
Caroline and Thomas Dieso have been luckier. They entered the first College Woods lottery and already are living in a three-bedroom, two-bath home that cost $99,000, which works out to $823 a month in mortgage payments, taxes and insurance.
Until last January, the couple rented an apartment in East Islip. A single-family home at market prices was out of the question, Mrs. Dieso said.
 
'Commitment to Keeping People'
 "We weren't thinking about it at all because it was too expensive," she said. "We could never have afforded a $1,200-a-month payment."
One of Long Island's most active housing programs has been run by the Town of East Hampton, which has sponsored or built 240 houses, most in the last six years, Ms. Stewart said. East Hampton has only about half of one percent of Long Island's population, but has been responsible for about 17 percent of the affordable housing built.
"The town really has made a commitment to keeping people who grew up there," Ms. Stewart said.
Joining in the effort to promote low-cost projects are many developers who would have been less interested a few years ago in programs that typically limit how much a builder can make.
"It's better to make 10 percent of $90,000, then 20 percent of nothing," said Mr. Villanueva, of the state affordable housing agency. "They have to stay busy."
A Riverhead program to build 21 subsidized homes attracted proposals from 15 builders, said Andrea Lohneiss, the town's community development director.
"You're not going to get rich doing this, but you're not going to get hurt either," said Mr. Klein, whose company, Klein & Eversoll Inc., won the contract.
Participation can help a company's image, he said. And "it has the additional benefit of doing something socially gratifying."

HEADLINE: Decade of Rep. Smith: Fluke to Tactician

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
When Christopher H. Smith came to Washington a decade ago as a 27-year-old Representative, he was widely considered a political fluke, an anti-abortion zealot who lucked into his seat when the incumbent was indicted in the Abscam scandals.
"I learned very early on what I am, who I am and it's not unsettled by that type of cheap shot," said Representative Smith, who has beaten the odds in repeatedly winning re-election in his heavily Democratic New Jersey district. "Most politicians have had some break." 
 Now the six-term Republican, the chairman and tactician of the House Pro-Life Caucus, is on the verge of gaining increased national attention as the field marshal of White House efforts to sustain a promised Presidential veto of legislation to allow federally financed family planning clinics provide advice about abortion.
Mr. Smith says he has been prepared for prominence by his House Bible study class, a bipartisan group of 10 representatives. "In what can be a very ego-building job, it makes you see very clearly that you're no different from anybody else," he says. "There's a very heavy emphasis on living humbly and living your philosophy of doing unto others as you would have them do unto you."
 
'Could Become a Test'
 But the national attention likely to be lavished on Mr. Smith also may create new difficulties for him in his Central New Jersey district, which, like the country, generally supports abortion rights, according to several polls. The New Jersey chapter of the National Abortion Rights League already is planning to make him a target in next year's election, as are some other groups advocating abortion rights.
"He could become a test of abortion politics," said Stephen Salmore, a political science professor at Rutgers University's Ea gleton Institute and a frequent consultant to Republican candidates.
Although Mr. Smith has sought to broaden his legislative interests, abortion remains his passion, making him "the point man" in the the anti-abortion movement's leadership that includes fellow House Republicans Robert K. Dornan and William E. Dannemeyer, both of California, and Vin Weber of Minnesota.
"We all take leads on different issues," Mr. Smith says, modestly describing the movement's leadership as a collective. But nudged he compares the coterie of leading anti-abortion legislators to a basketball team.
He sees himself as "the playmaking guard, sometimes taking the shot and other times passing, but stealing the ball as often as possible." Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, he said, is "the slam dunker;" Mr. Dornan "the shooting guard;" Mr. Dannmeyer "a forward," and Mr. Weber in "the backcourt."
 
'He's the Mistake'
 But Mr. Smith dismisses suggestions that his leading role in fighting abortion makes him vulnerable at home. He notes that he repeatedly has been attacked by abortion rights groups but has still won re-election with steadily rising majorities. And his district is ideal for an incumbent, forcing candidates to buy time in two of the country's most expensive media markets, New York and Philadelphia. That combination has discouraged many potential opponents.
"He's the mistake that will be there for the next 20 years," Mark Setaro, a lawyer, said after he lost to Mr. Smith last year.
Further, Mr. Smith distanced himself from down-the-line conservatives by amassing a centrist voting record on issues other than abortion. He was one of the first Republicans to break with the Reagan Administration on domestic affairs like health care and the environment and opposed it more than half the time in six of its eight years, according to Congressional Quarterly publications.
He has been an outspoken advocate for Soviet and Romanian dissidents and votes frequently with Democrats on economic, foreign and cultural issues.
 
'A Pure Spirit'
 "Chris Smith is a pure idealist," says Mr. Hyde, who is widely considered the father counselor to opponents of abortion rights. "He's a real inspiration, tenacious. Just when you get cynical here, along comes Chris Smith, eyes bright, ready to take on the goliaths. He's a pure spirit, an idealist.
But critics say he is little more than a political willow without deep roots beyond opposition to abortion. They note that he broke with the Reagan Administration in 1986 and voted to impose sanctions on South Africa. But the same year he voted against a resolution seeking the release from prison of Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress.
"I would like to see a pluralistic South Africa, the complete abandonment of apartheid," he said in explaining that he did not consider the black leader a political prisoner and accusing the Congress of terrorism. While he supported South African-backed Angolan rebels and United States-financed Nicaraguan rebels, he said he could not overlook Mr. Mandela's refusal to renounce armed struggle until economic sanctions were given an opportunity to force the South African Government to abandon apartheid. "Taking tires, filling them with gasoline and burning people alive, is barbaric."
 
'Almost a Jekyll and Hyde'
 But the lightning rod for most criticism remains his hard-line, unwavering stance that all abortion is murder and all abortionists are murderers. "He's almost a Jekyll and Hyde: a fairly tolerant guy, compassionate, open minded on almost any front," said Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon. "But suddenly when it comes to choice, it's something else. A look comes in his eye. He almost looks like he's been electrocuted. His eyes bulge and the rhetoric changes."
Mr. Smith dismisses such criticism. "For 11 years, I've been hearing I'm a right-wing zealot: I'm a moderate conservative," he says.
Tension between Mr. Smith and Mr. AuCoin has become palpable since an abortion debate three years ago. The Oregonian noted that Mr. Smith's efforts to ban all abortions would force his daughter to suffer through a pregnancy if she were impregnated during a rape. In what he describes as "an effort to make an abstract decision real," Mr. AuCoin asked Mr. Smith, who is married and has four children, what he would do if his daughter became pregnant because of a rape.
 
Preparing for Class
 Mr. Smith argues the question was an effort to inflame and notes that few pregnancies result from rape. "Killing the baby doesn't undo the crime of the father," he says. He adds that if one of his daughters were raped, he would try to prevent conception through "high estrogen therapy." The difference between his procedure and RU-486, the so-called abortion pill that he has staunchly denounced, "is a question of intent," he said, adding, "You can't tell within an hour, a day, even several days whether an egg has been fertilized."
Mr. Smith says he came to the abortion issue in 1972 while preparing for a class at Trenton State College when he read an Associated Press story about a fetus that had survived an abortion. "It got the wheels turning about where were those child's rights," he said.
After he graduated from Trenton State, he went to work in his family's wholesale sporting goods business and took the plunge into the political arena the following year, managing the unsuccessful 1976 Senate primary campaign of a Democrat, Steve Foley. "I found I could work 12 to 15 hours a day, get up and do it again," he recalled. The next year, he became executive director of New Jersey Right to Life.
 
Campaign in '82
 But elective politics called. He switched parties but lost in 1978 as the token opposition to Frank Thompson, a veteran Democrat who was chairman of the House Administration Committee. But he won in 1980, when Mr. Thompson was convicted of bribery and conspiracy in the Abscam scandal and later served two years in prison.
Mr. Smith, conventional wisdom said, had fallen into a two-year Washington sojourn through luck. When he ran for a second term in 1982, State Senator Joseph Merlino never took him seriously, broadcasting a commercial showing a young actor hitchhiking to Washington and being kicked down the Capitol steps. "Another politician gone bad," said the voiceover in a takeoff of the 1939 classic "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington."
But the Representative struck back with the film's star, Jimmy Stewart, who endorsed Mr. Smith as representing the lead character's "honesty and integrity." Mr. Smith returned to Washington.
