HEADLINE: Discovering Columbus

BYLINE: By John Noble Wilford; John Noble Wilford is a Pulitzer Prize-winning science writer for The New York Times. This article is adapted from "The Mysterious History of Columbus," which will be published in October by Alfred A. Knopf.

 BODY:
FEW STORIES IN HISTORY are more familiar than the one of Christopher Columbus sailing west for the Indies and finding instead the New World. Indelibly imprinted in our memory is the verse from childhood: "In fourteen hundred and ninety-two/Columbus sailed the ocean blue." The names of his ships, the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria, roll fluently from our lips. We know how Columbus, a seaman of humble and obscure origins, pursued a dream that became his obsession. How he found not the riches of Cathay but a sprinkling of small islands inhabited by gentle people. How he called these people Indians, thinking that surely the mainland of Asia lay just over the horizon.
Yet the history of Columbus is frustratingly incomplete. When and how in the mists of his rootless life did he conceive of his audacious plan? He supposedly wanted to sail west across the Ocean Sea to reach Cipangu, the name then for Japan, and the region known generally as the Indies. But was he really seeking the Indies? How are we to navigate the poorly charted waters of ambiguous and conflicting documentation everywhere Columbus went and in everything he did? We are not certain how he was finally able to win royal backing for the enterprise. We know little about his ships and the men who sailed them. We don't know exactly where he made his first landfall. We don't know for sure what he looked like or where he lies buried. We do know he was an inept governor of the Spanish settlements in the Caribbean and had a bloodied hand in the brutalization of the native people and in the start of a slave trade. But we are left wondering if he is to be admired and praised, condemned -- or perhaps pitied as a tragic figure. 
 Walt Whitman imagined Columbus on his deathbed, in the throes of self-doubt, seeming to anticipate the vicissitudes that lay ahead in his passage through history:
 
What do I know of life? what of myself?
I know not even my own
 work past or present;
Dim ever-shifting guesses
 of it spread before me,
Of newer better worlds,
 their mighty parturition,
Mocking, perplexing me.
The man who wrote to his patron, Luis de Santangel, on the voyage back to Europe in 1493, proclaiming discovery and assuring that he would not be forgotten, probably had no such thoughts. He could not foresee posterity's "ever-shifting guesses" concerning his deeds and himself any more than he could assimilate in his inflexible mind what he had done and seen. But it was his fate to be the accidental agent of a transcendental discovery and, as a result, to be tossed into the tempestuous sea of history, drifting half-forgotten at first, then swept by swift currents to a towering crest of honor and legend, only to be caught in recent years in a riptide of conflicting views of his life and of his responsibility for almost everything that has happened since.
 COLUMBUS'S REPUTATION in history has followed a curious course. His obsession, obstinacy and navigational skill carried Europe across the ocean. "The Admiral was the first to open the gates of that ocean which had been closed for so many thousands of years before," wrote Bartolome de las Casas a half century later in a comprehensive account of the voyages, which remains to this day a major source of knowledge about Columbus. "He it was who gave the light by which all others might see how to discover." But he was then anything but the stellar figure in history he was to become. His immediate reputation was diminished by his failures as a colonial administrator and by a protracted lawsuit between the crown and the heirs of Columbus, casting doubt on the singularity of his plan for sailing west to the Indies. (Testimony by some seamen who had sailed with Columbus suggested that one of his captains was actually responsible for much of the idea.) In time, Las Casas forced his contemporaries to question the morality of the brutal treatment of Indians at the hands of Columbus and his successors.
By the early years of the 16th century, Amerigo Vespucci, a more perceptive interpreter of the New World and a more engaging writer, had already robbed Columbus of prominence on the map. His star was also eclipsed by explorers like Cortes and Pizarro, who obtained gold and glory for Spain and had the good fortune to conquer not an assortment of islands but splendid empires like those of the Aztecs of Mexico and Incas of Peru, and by mariners like Vasco da Gama, who actually reached the Indies, and Magellan, whose expedition of circumnavigation was the first to confirm by experience the world's sphericity -- and also left no doubt about the magnitude of Columbus's error in thinking he had reached Asia.
Many books of general history in the first decades of the 16th century either scarcely mentioned Columbus or ignored him altogether. Writers of the time "showed little interest in his personality and career, and some of them could not even get his Christian name right," according to J. H. Elliott, a British historian. Responsibility for the neglect has been attributed in part to Peter Martyr, an Italian cleric in the court at Barcelona, whose correspondence, beginning in the months after Columbus's return, was widely read. It made much of the years of discovery but gave only passing notice to Columbus himself, though acknowledging his fortitude and courage.
With the poverty of available documentation about the man, there were few alternative sources of information. Yet to come were the works of the contemporary observers Gonzalo Fernandez de Oviedo (who would write an encyclopedic history of the early discoveries), Bartolome de las Casas and Columbus's son Ferdinand, who would write the first definitive biography of Columbus. Nearly all of Columbus's own letters and journals had long since disappeared.
By the middle of the 16th century, Columbus began to emerge from the shadows, reincarnated not so much as a man and historical figure but as a myth and symbol. In 1552, in a ringing assessment that would be repeated time and again, the historian Francisco Lopez de Gomara wrote, "The greatest event since the creation of the world (excluding the incarnation and death of Him who created it) is the discovery of the Indies." Columbus came to epitomize the explorer and discoverer, the man of vision and audacity, the hero who overcame opposition and adversity to change history.
By the end of the 16th century, English explorers and writers acknowledged his primacy and inspiration. "Had they not Columbus to stirre them up," Richard Hakluyt, the historian of exploration, wrote in 1598. He was celebrated in poetry and plays, especially by the Italians. Even Spain was coming around. In 1614, a popular play, "El Nuevo Mundo descubierto por Cristobal Colon," portrayed Columbus as a dreamer up against the stolid forces of entrenched tradition, a man of singular purpose who triumphed, the embodiment of that spirit driving humans to explore and discover.
The association between Columbus and America prospered in the 18th century, as the population became increasingly American-born, with less reason to identify with the "mother country." No one in Boston or New York is recorded to have celebrated Columbus on the bicentennial, in 1692. But within a very short time, the colonists began thinking of themselves as a people distinct from the English. By virtue of their isolation and common experience in a new land, they were becoming Americans, and they looked to define themselves on their own terms and through their own symbols. Samuel Sewall of Boston was one of the first to suggest their land should rightfully be named for Columbus, "the magnanimous heroe . . . who was manifestly appointed of God to be the Finder out of these lands." The Columbus who thought of himself as God's messenger -- "As the Lord told of it through the mouth of Isaiah, He made me the messenger, and he showed me the way," Columbus wrote on his third voyage -- would have been pleased at this turn in his posthumous reputation. But Sewall was also indulging in a practice that would become rampant: enlisting the symbolic Columbus for his own purposes -- in spirited defense of the colonies, which were being described by theologians at Oxford and Cambridge as the Biblical "infernal region," or in plain English, "hell."
By the time of the Revolution, Columbus had been transmuted into a national icon, a hero second only to Washington. The new Republic's celebration of Columbus reached a climax in October 1792, the 300th anniversary of the landfall. By then, King's College in New York had been renamed Columbia and the national capital being planned was given the name the District of Columbia, perhaps to appease those who demanded that the entire country be designated Columbia.
It is not hard to understand the appeal of Columbus as a totem for the former subjects of George III. Columbus had found the way of escape from Old World tyranny. He was the solitary individual who challenged the unknown sea, as triumphant Americans contemplated the dangers and promise of their own wilderness frontier. He had been opposed by kings and (in his mind) betrayed by royal perfidy. But as a consequence of his vision and audacity, there was now a land free from kings, a vast continent for new beginnings.
In Columbus, the new nation found a hero seemingly free of any taint from association with the European colonial powers. The Columbus symbolism gave Americans an instant mythology and a unique place in history, and their adoption of Columbus magnified his own place.
In "The Whig Interpretation of History," Herbert Butterfield, a British historian of this century, properly deplored "the tendency of many historians . . . to produce a story which is the ratification if not the glorification of the present." But historians cannot control the popularizers, the myth makers and propagandists, and in post-Revolutionary America the few who studied Columbus were probably not disposed to try. Even if they had been, there was little information available on which to assess the real Columbus and distinguish the man from the myth.
By the 19th century new materials had emerged -- some of Columbus's own writings and a lengthy abridgment of his lost journal of the first voyage -- that might have been used to assess the real man. Instead, these manuscripts provided more ammunition for those who would embellish the symbolic Columbus. Washington Irving mined the new documents to create a hero in the romantic mold favored in the century's literature. His Columbus was "a man of great and inventive genius" and his "ambition was lofty and noble, inspiring him with high thoughts, and an anxiety to distinguish himself by great achievements."
Perhaps. But an effusive Irving got carried away. Columbus's "conduct was characterized by the grandeur of his views and the magnanimity of his spirit," he wrote. "Instead of ravaging the newly found countries . . . he sought to colonize and cultivate them, to civilize the natives." Columbus may have had some faults, Irving acknowledged, such as his part in enslaving and killing people, but these were "errors of the times."
The historian Daniel J. Boorstin observes that people "once felt themselves made by their heroes" and cites James Russell Lowell: "The idol is the measure of the worshiper." Accordingly, writers and orators of the 19th century ascribed to Columbus all the human virtues that were most prized in that time of geographic and industrial expansion, heady optimism and an unquestioning belief in progress as the dynamic of history.
This image of Columbus accorded with the popular rags-to-riches, log-cabin-to-the-White-House scenario of human advancement. This was the ideal Columbus that schoolchildren learned about in their McGuffey readers. The orator Edward Everett reminded his audience in 1853 that Columbus had once been forced to beg for bread at the convent doors of Spain. "We find encouragement in every page of our country's history," Everett declared. "Nowhere do we meet with examples more numerous and more brilliant of men who have risen above poverty and obscurity. . . . One whole vast continent was added to the geography of the world by the persevering efforts of a humble Genoese mariner, the great Columbus; who, by the steady pursuit of the enlightened conception he had formed of the figure of the earth, before any navigator had acted upon the belief that it was round, discovered the American continent."
With the influx of millions of immigrants after the American Civil War, Columbus assumed a new role, that of ethnic hero. Irish Catholic immigrants organized the Knights of Columbus in New Haven in 1882. The fraternity's literature described Columbus as "a prophet and a seer, an instrument of Divine Providence" and an inspiration to each knight to become "a better Catholic and a better citizen." The knights grew in number and influence, promoting academic studies in American history, lobbying for the Columbus memorial erected in front of Union Station in Washington and seeking the canonization of their hero.
At the same time, French Catholics were mounting a campaign to elevate Columbus to sainthood, on the grounds that he had "brought the Christian faith to half the world." But, despite encouragement from Pope Pius IX, the proponents got nowhere with the Vatican. Columbus's rejection was based largely on his relationship with Beatriz Enriquez de Arana, his mistress and the mother of his son Ferdinand, and the lack of proof that he had performed a miracle, as defined by the church.
The 400th anniversary of Columbus's voyage was marked by a yearlong commemoration throughout the United States. To the beat of brass bands and a chorus of self-congratulation, Americans hailed the man who had crossed uncharted seas as they had now leaped a wide and wild continent. As part of the celebration, Antonin Dvorak composed "From the New World," a symphony evoking the sweep and promise of the beckoning American landscape. President Benjamin Harrison proclaimed, "Columbus stood in his age as the pioneer of progress and enlightenment." In New York, Italian immigrants, who had joined the Irish in search of an identity with the larger American community, raised money for a statue atop a column of Italian marble, placed at the southwest corner of Central Park, which was renamed Columbus Circle.
The grandest of all the celebrations, the World's Columbian Exposition, in Chicago, was billed as "the jubilee of mankind." President Grover Cleveland threw the switch on that new invention, electricity, to set in motion the many machines and architectural marvels by which the United States advertised itself as an emerging giant among the nations. Columbus was now the symbol of American success. The invocation was a prayer of thanksgiving for "that most momentous of all voyages by which Columbus lifted the veil that hid the New World from the Old and opened the gateway of the future of mankind." Clearly, the exposition was more than a commemoration of the past; it was also the exclamation of a future that self-confident Americans were eager to shape and enjoy.
A few historians, seeking the man behind the myth, struck chords of a refreshing counterpoint to the adulatory hymns. Henry Harrisse's diligent examination of all known Columbus materials left scholars no excuse for continuing to treat the man as a demigod, though he, too, rendered a largely favorable judgment. "Columbus removed out of the range of mere speculation the idea that beyond the Atlantic Ocean lands existed and could be reached by sea," he wrote in "Christopher Columbus and the Bank of Saint George." He "made of the notion a fixed fact, and linked forever the two worlds. That event, which is unquestionably the greatest of modern time, secures to Columbus a place in the pantheon dedicated to the worthies whose courageous deeds mankind will always admire."
It was the biographer Justin Winsor, more than any other respected historian of the day, who cast a cold light on the dark side of Columbus's character. He had objected strongly to Columbus's proposed canonization. ("He had nothing of the generous and noble spirit of a conjoint lover of man and of God," he wrote at the time.) In his view, Columbus forfeited any claim to sympathy when he robbed of proper credit the lookout who had cried "Tierra!" and thus took for himself the lifetime pension promised to the first person to see land.
"No child of any age ever did less to improve his contemporaries, and few ever did more to prepare the way for such improvements," Winsor wrote in his 1891 biography. "The age created him and the age left him. There is no more conspicuous example in history of a man showing the path and losing it. . . ." Columbus left his new world "a legacy of devastation and crime. He might have been an unselfish promoter of geographical science; he proved a rabid seeker for gold and a viceroyalty. He might have won converts to the fold of Christ by the kindness of his spirit; he gained the execrations of the good angels. He might, like Las Casas, have rebuked the fiendishness of his contemporaries; he set them an example of perverted belief."
Winsor's withering assault on the Columbus of legend was the exception in the late 19th century, and not taken kindly by those who held to the prevailing image. They had created the Columbus they wanted to believe in, and were quite satisfied with their creation.
But by the early 20th century, historians were beginning to expose contradictions, lacunas and suspected fictions in the familiar story. No one could be sure when and how Columbus arrived at his idea, what his real objective was or what manner of man he was -- an inspired but rational genius, a lucky adventurer clouded by mysticism, a man of the Renaissance or of the Middle Ages. It wasn't until 1942 that Columbus was rescued from mythology and portrayed as what he had been first and foremost: an inspired mariner.
In his biography, "Admiral of the Ocean Sea," Samuel Eliot Morison, drawing on the accumulating documents and his own seafaring expertise, chose to stress the one aspect of Columbus that has been beyond serious dispute. Morison's Columbus was no saint, but he could sail a ship and possessed the will and courage to go where no one had presumably gone before.
 THE WORLD AND America are changing, of course, and Columbus's reputation is changing, too. Modern life has made disbelievers of many who once worshiped at the altar of progress. In the years after World War II, nearly all the colonies of the major empires won their independence and, like the United States in its early days, began to view world history from their own anticolonial perspective. The idol had been the measure of the worshipers, but now there were atheists all around. To them, the Age of Discovery was not the bright dawning of a glorious epoch, but an invasion. Columbus became the avatar of oppression. Another Columbus for another age.
"A funny thing happened on the way to the quincentennial observation of America's 'discovery,' " Garry Wills wrote in The New York Review of Books in 1990. "Columbus got mugged. This time the Indians were waiting for him. He comes now with an apologetic air -- but not, for some, sufficiently apologetic. . . . He comes to be dishonored."
Today, historians are addressing consequences as well as actions -- increasingly approaching the European incursion in America from the standpoint of the native Americans. They speak not of the "discovery" but of the "encounter" or the "contact." Alfred W. Crosby, at the University of Texas at Austin, has examined the biological consequences of Columbus's arrival. While some -- the exchange of plants and animals between continents, the eventual globalization of biology -- were generally beneficial, he found others, like the spread of devastating disease, to be catastrophic.
In public forums, Columbus is tarred as the precursor of exploitation and conquest. Kirkpatrick Sale, in "The Conquest of Paradise," argues that Columbus was a grasping fortune hunter whose legacy was the destruction of the native population and rape of the land that continues to this day.
Descendants of American Indians and the African slaves brought to the New World, as well as those who sympathize with their causes, are understandably reluctant to celebrate the anniversary of Columbus's landfall. Leaders of American Indian organizations condemn Columbus as a pirate or worse; Russell Means of the American Indian Movement says that Columbus "makes Hitler look like a juvenile delinquent." In a 1987 newspaper story, the Indian activist Vernon Bellecourt was quoted as calling for "militant demonstrations" against celebrants in 1992 "to blow out the candles on their birthday cake."
The governing board of the National Council of Churches, a predominantly Protestant organization, resolved that, in consideration of the "genocide, slavery, 'ecocide' and exploitation" that followed Columbus, the quincentenary should be a time of penitence rather than jubilation. In 1986, after four years of impassioned debate, the United Nations abandoned its attempt to plan a celebration.
Once again, Columbus has become a symbol, this time of exploitation and imperialism. It is time that the encounter be viewed not only from the European standpoint, but from that of the indigenous Americans. It is time that the sanitized storybook version of Europeans bringing civilization and Christianity to America be replaced with a more clear-eyed recognition of the evils and atrocities committed in wresting a land from its original inhabitants.
But are we burdening him with more guilt than any one man should have to shoulder? Should not the guilt be more broadly shared?
Columbus should be judged by the evidence of his actions and words, not by the legend that has been embedded in our imaginations. What do we know of Columbus the person, who really was, and of the times, as they really were?
Columbus, as far as we can tell, was born in 1451 in Genoa, apparently the eldest of five surviving children in a family of wool weavers. (One child was a girl, rarely mentioned in historical accounts.) They were tradespeople of modest means. But of them, as of most aspects of his early life, Columbus said nothing. Some of his ancestors may have been Jewish, though this has never been established and, in any event, it seems to have had no direct bearing on his life and exploits. His family was Christian, and so was Columbus -- demonstrably so. His surviving journals and letters are replete with invocations of the names of Christ, Mary and the saints, and he often sought the advice and hospitality of Franciscans.
Even more crucial than his ancestry may have been the time into which he was born. Columbus grew up hearing of the scourge of Islam, the blockage of trade routes to the spices of the East and the parlous times for Christendom. All this could have nourished dreams in an ambitious young man with nautical experience. Columbus did write that at a "tender age" he cast his lot with those who go to sea, shipping out on several voyages in the Mediterranean. In 1476, he found his way by chance to Portugal, where exploration of the sea was a dynamic of the age and the search for a new route to the Indies was an economic and religious imperative.
He gained a knowledge of the Atlantic in voyages to England and Ireland (perhaps as far as Iceland) and at least once down the African coast. His marriage to Felipa Perestrello e Moniz took him to the Madeiras, where he would study Atlantic sailing charts and hear the many tales of westering voyages, and gave him access to Portuguese nobility. In these years he presumably conceived of his bold plan, but it was rejected by John II of Portugal.
So after his wife died, Columbus took their young son, Diego, and went to Spain in 1484, again seeking royal backing. He managed to make friends with influential Franciscan friars and members of the royal court. "Columbus's ability to thrust himself into the circles of the great was one of the most remarkable things about him," writes John H. Parry, an American historian. But he would spend the next eight years entreating the court and defending his plan before royal commissions.
During this time, he fell in love with Beatriz Enriquez de Arana of Cordoba; they never married, but she bore their son, Ferdinand, who became his father's devoted biographer. Ferdinand described his father as a "well-built man of more than average stature" who had a complexion tending to bright red, an aquiline nose and blond hair that, after the age of 30, had all turned white.
Only after the fall of Granada in January 1492, which ended the Moorish presence in Spain, did Ferdinand and Isabella finally relent, apparently on the advice of Santangel, the king's financial adviser. Contrary to legend, Isabella did not have to hock her jewels, and Columbus did not have to prove the world was round. Educated Europeans were already convinced, but he seems to have been the first to stake his life on it.
Columbus was a consummate mariner, everyone seemed to agree. As Michele de Cuneo, who sailed with him, said: "By a simple look at the night sky, he would know what route to follow or what weather to expect; he took the helm, and once the storm was over, he would hoist the sails, while the others were asleep." And he found a new world. If there had not been an America there, he would probably have sailed to his death and certainly to oblivion. He could never have made the Indies, which lay far beyond where his miscalculations had placed them. He was wrong, but lucky. No explorer succeeds without some luck.
He made three more voyages, but his skill and luck deserted him on land. He was an inept administrator of the colony he established at La Isabela, on the north shore of what is now the Dominican Republic. Ruling by the gibbet for three years, he antagonized his own men to insurrection (some lieutenants tried to seize ships and get away with a load of gold) and goaded the native Tainos into bloody rebellion. Thousands of Tainos were raped, killed and tortured and their villages burned. At the first opportunity, Columbus captured Tainos and shipped them to Spain as slaves, a practice not without precedent in Europe or even among the people of pre-Columbian America. Las Casas sadly lamented the practices of his countrymen: "If we Christians had acted as we should."
The geographic interpretations of Columbus were muddled by preconceptions. He tended to see what he wanted to see and took native words to be mispronunciations of places in Cathay. He forced his crew to swear that one of his landfalls, Cuba, was the Asian mainland. His was not an open mind. He sought confirmation of received wisdom, usually church teachings, rather than new knowledge. Enthralled by the proximity of what he believed was the earthly paradise, he failed to appreciate that he had reached the South American continent on his third voyage. The waters of the Orinoco, he wrote, must flow from the fountain in Paradise, "whither no one can go but by God's permission."
Still, Columbus persevered, often racked with the pain of arthritis, which worsened with each voyage, and also tropical fevers. His four voyages, between 1492 and 1504, showed the way to countless others. As he approached death in 1506, his mind was consumed with self-pity, mysticism and a desperate desire to seize Jerusalem in preparation for Judgment Day. He wrote in a letter to the court: "All that was left to me and to my brothers has been taken away and sold, even to the cloak that I wore, to my great dishonor. . . . I am ruined as I have said. Hitherto I have wept for others; now have pity upon me, Heaven, and weep for me, earth!" Columbus did not die a pauper, legend notwithstanding. But his death, in Valladolid, Spain, went unheralded.
How are we to judge the historical Columbus, the man and not the legend? Was he a great man?
No, if greatness is measured by one's stature among contemporaries. We will never know if the course of history might have been any different if Columbus had been a kinder, more generous man. To argue that Columbus was acting in the accepted manner of his time is to concede that he was not superior to his age. To contend (with ample supporting evidence) that even if Columbus had set a better example, others who followed would have eventually corrupted his efforts, is to beg the question. Moreover, the only example Columbus set was one of pettiness, self-aggrandizement and a lack of magnanimity. He could not find in himself the generosity to share any credit for his accomplishments. Whatever his original objective, his lust for gold drove him from island to island and, it seems, to the verge of paranoia. And the only future he could anticipate was wealth for himself and his heirs and, probably more than most people of his time, the chimera of the imminent end of the world.
Yes, if greatness derives from the audacity of his undertaking, its surprising revelation and the magnitude of its impact on subsequent history. Columbus did cross the uncharted Atlantic, no mean feat. He did find new lands and people, and he returned to tell of it so that others could follow, opening the way to intercontinental travel and expansion. True, if he had never sailed, other mariners would eventually have raised the American coast, as the Portuguese did in reaching Brazil by accident in 1500. But it was Columbus who had the idea, ill conceived though it was in many respects, and pursued it with uncommon persistence, undeterred by the doubters and scoffers. As it was put in the apocryphal story, Columbus showed the world how to stand an egg on its end.
Whether he was a great man or merely an agent of a great accomplishment, the issue really is his standing in history. And that depends on posterity's changing evaluation -- Whitman's "evershifting guesses" -- of him and the consequence of Europe's discovery of America. His reputation is inextricably linked to America. Ultimately, Columbus's place in history can be judged only in relation to the place accorded America in history. Surely we have not finally established that place.
It would be interesting to know how Columbus will be characterized in 2092. For it seems that his destiny is to serve as a barometer of our self-confidence and complacency, our hopes and aspirations, our faith in progress and the capacity of humans to create a more just society.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30; Column 3; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Amos and Andy's Social History

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mel Watkins reviewed "The Adventures of Amos 'n' Andy: A Social History of an American Phenomenon" by Melvin Patrick Ely on July 7. I found the entire article objectionable for several reasons. 
 The review does not place the radio show in its political, social or economic setting. This century began with the most repressive and violent actions against black Americans since slavery. In the South, black professionals, wealthy black people and black veterans of World War I were put back in "their place" through threats of violence that ranged from tarring and feathering to disfiguring to lynching.
The "Amos 'n' Andy" television show did not provide, as Mr. Watkins says, a "visual disclosure of genuine African-American stage humor." The use of language did not ring true, the program was not an honest representation of blue-collar or professional blacks, and it refused to acknowledge institutions that framed black life -- racism and poverty.
The author apparently tries to lend some validity to "Amos 'n' Andy" by stating that in the 1930's blacks enjoyed the radio show; then he notes that in the 50's blacks protested the television show. Mr. Watkins suggests that blacks protested the show because they were uncomfortable with black actors exposing the idiosyncrasies of black life to white America.
The protests in the 50's reflected an increasing Afro-American pride that was inspired by many things, but to list only a few: the Harlem Renaissance, the experience of black World War II soldiers in Europe and the roots of the civil rights movement.
 
PORTIA E. ADAMS
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Talking;
Roof Rules Regulating Residential Havens

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY apartment dwellers can be passionate about preserving the right to spend leisure hours on the roof during the warmer months.
The best roofs -- adorned with plantings and planking and carrying the more gracious title of sundeck -- tend to have been created in the larger, postwar buildings. Such structures already provided the stronger support needed for such an amenity, reports Andrea Bunis, president of ABR Management of Manhattan. 
 But not only the weather starts heating up when the trek upstairs begins. Tempers may rise too if the noise, littering or carelessness starts to pit neighbor against neighbor.
It then becomes apparent that rules concerning roof use need modification. The roof itself may also need special attention if it is to remain the building's preferred "backyard" and not be damaged or deemed such a nuisance that it has to be declared off limits.
When preparing or revamping roof rules, it might be useful to begin by compiling a list of city regulations regarding roofs. These can then be incorporated in an individual building's regulations, with the appropriate citation to carry added clout. For example, under its fire prevention code the city forbids anyone to barbecue on a roof, with fines for violators of up to $100 for the first offense and $500 for a subsequent offense.
The Multiple Dwelling Law makes the building's owner or board of directors responsible for keeping the roof in good repair according to the local building codes. The building's professional engineer who regularly inspects the structure should be able to provide details about codes and penalties.
Regulations should include hours of permitted use; policies concerning guests, particularly limiting numbers; whether residents may bring their own furniture; a prohibition on ball playing or other active sports, a ban on loud music; acceptable attire and the minimum age for unaccompanied minors.
A ban on certain types of drink may also be needed. Michael Cantor, a principal with Cantor Management in Brooklyn, noted that several of his client buildings have had to close off their roofs because residents were stuffing soda cans down vent pipes and it was impossible to identify the culprits.
Some managers and lawyers further suggest that simply posting the rules in a public place, such as a notice board in a lobby or on the roof itself is not enough. A letter needs to be circulated to residents covering the rules along with the reasons for the restrictions.
A manageable security system is vital, in particular to protect residents whose apartments open onto the roof. Allan Rosenberg, executive vice president of Darwood Management of Manhattan, recommends the kind that permits residents to deactivate the alarm on the door to the roof with a special key. A double benefit of this, he noted, is that the threat of having to give up the key if rules are not followed can be a powerful tool for compliance.
A professional engineer should inspect the roof at least once each season to make sure it can safely carry the weight load for general access and is in full compliance with the codes, warned Michael Lynn, president of Project Consulting Associates of Manhattan.
Mr. Lynn, an architect, noted that most roofs also accommodate elements of the building's mechanical systems. Although these are normally fenced off, "we constantly see deterioration," he said. "Guard rails will rust and come loose." An old parapet may not be high enough to meet current codes, he added. And there may be nothing on the roof's surface to prevent penetration from spiked heels or chair legs.
MANAGERS report that one of the best and most economical ways to prevent damage is to cover the roof with loosely woven wood decking -- like the surface of a suburban deck. This elevates foot traffic and furniture from the roof surface and is cooler and more pleasant to walk upon.
Wally Rosenwach, chairman of Sitecraft of Long Island City, Queens, a company that has installed such decking on the roof of dozens of co-op and rental buildings, said it comes in sections of varying sizes, such as 2- by 2 or 3- by 3 feet. It can easily be installed and the cost is around $12 a square foot. The company is one of a number that also supply wooden benches (yet another safeguard against the damage that can be caused by improper placement of personal garden chairs) and planters with a drainage base designed specifically for roof use.
An additional value of decking is that it reduces noise. Leo Frantzman, president of the 98-unit co-op at 201 East 77th Street, said complaints by upper-floor residents about the noise level generated from the roof from all the walking and moving around of chairs abated substantially after the board installed planking.
However, to obtain the maximum absorption level, he said, the co-op purchased planking with four inches of clearance from the roof surface instead of the customary one-inch elevation. A shower was also installed, a convenience to make it unnecessary for residents to return to their apartments for showers. That reduced the noise level from trips back and forth to the roof.
But even with all these safeguards the roof might still have to be closed off. Mr. Cantor said some roofing companies refuse to provide a full warranty if they know the roof will be reopened to general access after a resurfacing. In some buildings, roofs were closed because of excessive vandalism and mischief.
If this happens certain rent-regulated tenants may wish to file with the Department of Housing and Community Renewal, the state agency that supervises rent regulation, for a lower rent based on reduced services. Craig Kraus, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in rent-regulation, said that this may only be granted if the roof had been set up as a recreational area -- not if the renter had simply gone up there informally.
A compromise might also work, as it did for an 18-unit brownstone co-op on the Upper West Side. Until a year ago, it had a magnficient roof area with trees, shrubs and picnic tables. But following a severe problem with leaks the architect recommended lightening the load and resurfacing -- all of which seemed to doom the roof garden, said Ingrid Dichter, the past president.
Under the compromise, a small area will remain open, decorated with just a few lightweight planters and limited to just a few residents at a time.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1616 words

HEADLINE: TriBeCa West: The Issue of Boundaries

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
FOR decades, a grubby industrial neighborhood west of City Hall and wedged between the financial district and Canal Street went virtually unnoticed. But by the late 70's, urban pioneers -- many of them artists squeezed out of SoHo by the gentrification of that onetime industrial area -- discovered its spacious, inexpensive and mostly vacant factories, warehouses and lofts.
Within a decade the area was transformed from an after-dark urban ghost town to one of the city's fastest growing and most desirable residential neighborhoods. The new arrivals dubbed it TriBeCa, for "triangle below Canal." 
 Despite its economic metamorphosis, the area has retained a remarkable number of well-preserved late-19th- and early-20th-century brick and cast-iron industrial buildings. Taken as a group, they provide a rare picture of one of New York City's turn-of-the-century commercial faces, and tomorrow the City Council's Land Use Committee will hold the second of two public hearings on a proposal to approve part of TriBeCa -- the section known as TriBeCa West -- as a historic district.
The hearing is a result of new rules that came out of last year's Charter revisions, which abolished the Board of Estimate, the body that used to have the final say on proposed landmarks and historic districts. By Sept. 10, the full City Council must act on the Landmarks Commission's recommendations -- approving, amending or rejecting them.
TriBeCa West covers 17 blocks bounded by Reade Street on the south, West Broadway on the east, Greenwich Street on the west and Hubert Street and Ericsson Place on the north. Most buildings in the district were built between 1860 and 1910.
"TriBeCa is an extraordinary example of urban industrial design," said Laurie Beckelman, chairman of the Landmarks Commission. "But beyond its historic and architectural value, TriBeCa is a remarkable illustration of successful adaptive reuse."
The commission is currently considering three additional historic districts for TriBeCa: TriBeCa North, bounded by Hubert, Watts, West and Varick Streets; TriBeCa South, to encompass the neighborhood between Chambers and Thomas Streets from West Broadway to Broadway, and TriBeCa East, from Worth to Canal Streets and West Broadway to Lafayette Street.
While the Real Estate Board does not pretend to represent any particular constituency in TriBeCa, its president, Steven Spinola, will appear tomorrow to press a case for whittling down the historic district. Mr. Spinola said that while the organization recognizes the special historic and architectural qualities of some of the buildings in TriBeCa, the district, as now defined, is substantially larger than it needs to be.
"TriBeCa has buildings that represent an important part of the city's history," said Mr. Spinola. "We support their preservation. But there are many others in the area that either do not contribute to the neighborhood's fabric and feeling because they have been altered to the point where they do not conform to any significant historic architectural style, or are so new that they never did make that kind of contribution."
Once known as the Washington Market district, after the city's main produce marketplace, which was demolished as part of an urban renewal push in the 1960's, the neighborhood was home to many of the city's candy factories, spice companies and butter and egg merchants.
Outwardly, TriBeCa has retained most of its rough edges. Many streets are still paved with cobblestone, and raised metal loading platforms are part of the streetscape, as are iron awnings and window shutters. It is still home to many commercial companies and wholesale food business, both new, like Aux Delices des Bois, which imports wild mushrooms, and old, like A. L. Bazzini Company, a nut and candy business.
But behind the aging brick and cast-iron facades are art galleries, chic restaurants and shops and some of the city's most luxurious loft-style residences.
According to a survey of land use made by the Planning Commission, 56.48 percent of the buildings in the proposed district are now used as residences, with 17.6 percent functioning as warehouse or semi-industrial spaces, 5.7 percent of the buildings hold wholesale goods businesses and 5.7 percent are used by office companies. Retailing, film-related businesses, other industrial companies and community facilites comprise the balance of the occupied space.
The Planning Commission report found that 6.74 percent of the buildings were empty and that vacant land and parking lots accounted for just over 3 percent of the space.
If developed in accordance with existing zoning, which calls for a ratio of 5 square feet of floor space for each foot of building site, the empty lots would generate 307,395 square feet of commerical or industrial space.
The City Planning Department is in the midst of a land use survey for the neighborhood with the objective of proposing revised zoning regulations.
Of particular concern to the Real Estate Board are vacant parcels that have been included in the historic district. The board says there are seven such properties, most of them are currently being used as parking lots.
"WITH the inclusion of vacant land and nonconforming buildings," Mr. Spinola said, "the landmarks process is being used as a tool to control future development there."
"As far as we are concerned," he continued, "it is de facto planning and zoning and not preservation."
If the board had held the pen when the boundaries for TriBeCa West were drawn the district would cover only the area from Reade to Franklin Streets, between Greenwich Street and West Broadway. Those boundaries are on a map the board has sent to City Council members as part of a vigorous lobbying effort to get the Council to reduce the district's size.
But doing so would exclude from the district several buildings that architectural historians say are as significant as others in TriBeCa West. One of them is the former warehouse at 117-119 Hudson Street at North Moore Street. Built between 1888 and 1889, it was designed by Thomas R. Jackson. Another is the Baker William warehouse, the 1905 six-story, Neo-Renaissance building at 48-62 Beach Street designed by Charles Haight, who was responsible for many buildings in TriBeCa.
Hal Bromm, a member of Community Board 1 and chairman of its landmarks committee, said that development potential in a neighborhood does not have to be understood as the potential for new high-rise construction.
"The population growth rate in TriBeCa is 88.9 percent," said Mr. Bromm. "That is the highest rate of any residential neighborhood in Manhattan. It speaks strongly to the fact that people are moving to the area, spending money and supporting services."
Mr. Bromm criticized the Real Estate Board for waiting two years after the Landmarks Commission's public hearings on the district to come forward with its own proposal.
"This is an attempt to politicize the process," Mr. Bromm said. "Rather than let the City Council act as a final review process, they are coming in at the 11th hour to make points that should have been made to the Landmarks Commission over the last two years when the record was open, or to the Planning Commission during its hearing on the district.
"To wait until now is a subversion of the process and an attempt to discredit the proposals for future districts in the neighborhood."
While property owners often protest the inclusion of their buildings in historic districts, support for historic district designation for TriBeCa West has come from residents, merchants, the community board and some commercial property owners there.
BUT Stanley Scott, the founder of S.V. Scott Printing Company is not among them. Mr. Scott, who owns the building at 145 Hudson Street as well as the parking lot directly to the west, believes that neither the building nor the parking lot belongs in the historic district.
"I don't see the value on landmarking vacant lots," said Mr. Scott, who, with the help of city Industrial Development Agency bonds, in 1980 bought the loft building where he had been a tenant since the 1960's. "But if that is done, it seems to me that there should be some consistency in the decision."
Mr. Scott said that his lot, which faces Hubert Street and is on the edge of the district, was included but that other border parking lots were not.
Ms. Beckelman said that the West Broadway parking lot, which is between Worth and Leonard Streets, was excluded from the district because it is part of a full block piece on a major avenue that has "obvious development potential."
"Other lots were mostly midblock pieces that are part of significant northern and western boundaries for the district," said Ms. Beckelman.
The Landmarks Commission saw fit to exclude from the historic district a string of midblock buildings on the southern boundary along Reade Street, including a two-story warehouse that still bears a red, blue and yellow Creamoland Butter sign.
Some Council members acknowledge the significance of the Council's consideration of TriBeCa West.
"The Riverdale historic district was the first to come before the Council," said Walter L. McCaffrey, a Queens Democrat and member of the Land Use Committee. "But it is mostly residental and the issues were pretty clear. With TriBeCa West it will be the first time the committee and Council will make these kinds of determinations for a mixed-use neighborhood.
"There is definitely support for landmarking," he continued, "but you can't ignore the potential for economic gain so there has to be a clear delineation between zoning and landmarking."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Silver Glimpsed in Cloud Over Bridgeport

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
 WHEN Bridgeport's petition for bankruptcy was denied 10 days ago by Federal Bankruptcy Judge Alan H.TW. Schiff, the local real estate community braced for the worst. "I thought, oh boy, we're going to see everybody calling up and pulling out of deals," said Charles Coviello, a broker with Realty World-Trio Associates on East Main St. "But nobody did."
He had said the same thing after the June 6 announcement by Mayor Mary Moran that she was filing for bankruptcy protection. If anything, business got better throughout June and July. 
 "The basic message of bankruptcy," said Steven Auerbach, the city's Director of Economic Development, "is that filing means a restructuring of the city's debt and will be a stabilizing influence on taxes."
The petition was denied because, the judge ruled, the city has enough money to pay its bills for the current fiscal year. He added that it may file again when its resources are exhausted.
But brokers are not apprehensive.
"There is an optimism about the city in spite of some uncertainty," said William Raveis, president of Raveis Real Estate in Fairfield. "But I think the cards are in favor of the Bridgeport buyer."
Buyers coming to Elaine Carvalho, a realtor with Memoli & Memoli in Bridgeport, have apparently shared that optimism recently. "We closed four deals in June, with five more pending," she said. "Last year I had three deals from Jan. 1 to July 1."
Among her recent sales was a two-bedroom Cape Cod near the Trumbull border, to Mandy and Bert di Silva, who had rented an apartment in Bridgeport. "We got it for $25,000 less than the asking price of $100,000," Mrs. di Silva said. "The city has hit bottom, it can only go up, and this is our foot in the door. Investors and first-time buyers like the di Silvas are the leaders in the current market.
"We have many investors interested in two- and three-family houses," said Bob Csom, manager of the Stratford office of Beazley Realty, a statewide agency. "The glut of commercial space is driving them into residential properties, and rentals have always been a good commodity in Bridgeport. People transferring into the area from outside the region do not have Bridgeport on their list, but Bridgeport has the best values. Prices haven't been this low in 10 years."
Mansions overlooking Black Rock Harbor on up to three acres, priced from $500,000 to $1.9 million, would cost twice as much in lower Fairfield County.
Beazley Realty, as well as other large firms like Dollar Dry Dock, Raveis and Elmer R. Craw, have moved out of Bridgeport since 1988, leaving smaller local firms to handle the walk-in business. Many of the larger brokerages believe that the recent spurt of sales is simply due to a more widespread improvement in the housing market and not solely to Bridgeport's fiscal troubles.
Some brokers, in fact, say the state of Bridgeport's economy has hurt the local real estate market and helped its neighbors.
"It has put a hold on residential sales and made selling property that much more difficult" in the city, said Dian Vince, manager of the William Pitt agency's Trumbull office. "First-time buyers are worried about the city's economy and are looking elsewhere, making the surrounding towns the beneficiaries of Bridgeport's troubles."
Pitt, based in Stamford, has never had a Bridgeport office but carries a large inventory of foreclosed properties there.
"THE suburban communities offer better education and lower taxes," said Jeff Craw, a broker with Elmer R. Craw in Monroe. "Bridgeport offers more house for the money. The break-even point governs the sale. People don't say they want to buy in Bridgeport; they just want a $110,000 house. They may be able to afford $120,000 in the suburbs because of the tax differential. I had two recent customers shy away from Bridgeport. One young couple concerned about high taxes would not commit to a house they liked very much at $120,000."
A house selling for $130,000 in Bridgeport is taxed at $3,171, according to Richard Ruggio of the assessor's staff. In Trumbull, a $130,000 house is taxed at $2,795; in Stratford, the tax would be $1,653. But the average price of a three-bedroom house in Bridgeport is $113,000; in Stratford, $150,000, and in Trumbull, $230,000.
Two- and three-family houses in the city are selling for $110,000 to $120,000. Richard Stein, president of the Greater Bridgeport Board of Realtors, said there had been "a 25 percent increase in sales of multifamily houses since early June."
Joan A. Gamble, owner of Realty World-Trio Associates, just sold a foreclosed six-family house at 587 Brook Street to a Greenwich investor for $147,000. "His cash flow will be $1,500 a month after expenses," she said.
The Kimball Group of Bridgeport and the Rasamny Realty Group of Danbury are buying Bell Tower, a foreclosed condominium complex in Bridgeport, from Comfed Savings Bank of Lowell, Mass. "We took nine binders the last weekend in July," said James Kimball.
Converted from the 1901 Shelton School on Alice Street, the imposing red-brick building will contain 44 units. Nine two- and three-bedroom units measuring 1,500 to 1,650 square feet were sold by the original developer for $124,000 to $134,000. Fifteen identical, centrally air-conditioned units (including the nine on binders) are available from $65,000 to $69,000. The rest are still under construction. All units have working fireplaces, cathedral ceilings, stoves, refrigerators and dishwashers.
To help finance home purchases, GE Mortgage Insurance Company and People's Bank of Bridgeport offer a free, six-week Community Home Buyers Course for families of any size with incomes up to $60,000. After "graduation," they qualify for a mortgage at 33 percent of their monthly income instead of the usual 28 percent.
Home inspections are subsidized, and a reserve of two months worth of mortgage payments is waived. Of the 250 families who have taken the course since March of last year, 50 have obtained mortgages and bought homes.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bell Tower, a foreclosed condominium at former Shelton School. It will have 44 units.; Six-family house on Brook Street has been sold for $147,000. (Photographs by Steven Castagneto for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY FOLLOW-UP

 BODY:

Auto Injury Cases
THE State Department of Insurance estimates that nearly four million New Jersey drivers now have auto insurance policies that carry the "verbal threshold" -- an insurance option that lowers premiums but limits lawsuits by permitting individuals to sue for only serious injuries. 
 And though drivers who take the option are able to easily calculate the premium savings resulting from their choice, a debate over what they have given up, and what constitutes serious injury, has raged in legal circles since 1989, when the option first became available.
 That debate will be resolved soon, lawyers say, when the Appellate Division of State Superior Court delivers its opinion in a case that most experts agree will set the standard for auto injury cases for the foreseeable future.
"This is the fulcrum of the auto insurance issue in New Jersey," said Gerald Baker, a Hoboken lawyer who filed briefs in the case on behalf of the New Jersey chapter of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America.
Mr. Baker said that the auto injury case, involving a plaintiff who sustained neck and back injuries but no broken bones, would establish for the first time what the State Legislature envisioned when it included the verbal threshold option in the state's insurance law.
"It all comes down to whether we take away innocent victims' rights to make a claim for injuries," Mr. Baker said.
The case before the Appellate Division is an appeal from a decision by Judge Burton L. Fundler of Monmouth County Superior Court, who ruled that the verbal threshold barred injured parties from instituting lawsuits for pain and suffering when injuries were of the "soft-tissue" type, like sprains and strains.
Mr. Baker said the Appellate Division was expected to answer two crucial questions in deciding the appeal: What constitutes a "serious" or "permanent" injury and who makes that determination, a judge or a jury?
Personal injury lawyers say that many soft-tissue injuries can be both serious and permanent and that a jury, and not the judge, should make that determination. Indeed, they say, if a trial judge can make that determination and dismiss soft-tissue lawsuits, then many seriously injured parties would effectively be denied their rights to jury trials.
Mr. Baker said many lawyers who had clients with potential cases were waiting for the Appellate Division's decision. And in at least one county -- Middlesex -- a Superior Court trial judge has temporarily suspended proceedings in 15 automobile injury cases until the opinion.
Lawyers who represent insurance companies are also awaiting the decision.
"I think that the Legislature's intent was to eliminate minor cases," said James Martin, a North Brunswick lawyer who represents both insurance companies and injured parties in personal injury litigation. "Unfortunately, soft-tissue injuries generally fall within that category."
Mr. Martin said not all soft-tissue injuries would necessarily be considered minor. "Those that are severe will survive any interpretation of the statute," he said.
But Mr. Baker said the uncertainty over what injuries were actionable under the verbal threshold had worked to the disadvantage of some injured parties.
"Some lawyers are just rejecting soft-tissue cases out of hand," he said. "Others are taking them and then settling them cheaply."
Most lawyers, Mr. Baker said, simply don't know what to do with soft-tissue injury cases.
"What do you do when someone walks into your office with a neck injury that the person's doctor says is significant?" he said. "Who decides whether to put the case into suit? It's a hazardous decision for a plaintiff's attorney."
He said many lawyers were just doing nothing until they received some guidance from the courts.
"I probably have 75 cases in my office right now," he said, "and I'm just sitting on them."
 
Tourism at Shore

Despite optimistic predictions that business would be booming at Jersey Shore resorts this season, merchants in Seaside Heights say that though the summer has been hot and the water cool, the tourist trade has been lukewarm at best.
Encouraged by clean beaches and an unusually high number of rental reservations earlier in the year, officials enthusiastically expected Shore resorts to attract record numbers of vacationers who, reeling from the recession, would choose areas closer to home.
It appears, however, that many people stayed even closer to home than expected.
"We have been very, very slow," said Joe Kascuba, manager of the Midway Steak House, a concession stand on the boardwalk in Seaside Heights. "I would say our business has been off about 30 percent."
On a particularly sweltering Saturday afternoon recently, Mr. Kascuba was found standing behind an almost empty grill with a sparse array of customers, most of whom were buying soft drinks instead of steak sandwiches.
"All I can say is, thank God it's hot," Mr. Kascuba said.
Some local business people say that conditions this summer seem tailor-made for the tourist industry.
"Weatherwise it's been a 10, and waterwise it's been a 10," said Leo Szalkowski, a Lavallette real-estate broker. "But touristwise it has probably been a six and a half."
Mr. Szalkowski, who has been in the real-estate business for 30 years, said that the motel owners and other real-estate experts he had spoken to were generally disappointed by the low numbers of out-of-town visitors.
"The motels have been doing a good weekend business, but during the week there are a lot of vacancies," he said. "There was a lot of fanfare at the beginning of the season, but I don't think it really panned out."
Some officials, however, say merchants' pessimistic perceptions may be the result of overly optimistic expectations.
Amanda French, director of programming for the Toms River-Ocean County Chamber of Commerce, said she was not disappointed by the number of tourists because she had managed to keep a tight rein on her expectations.
"It's what I expected because I expected it to be better than it was in previous years," Ms. French said. "And by all means it's better than it was, though we still have a long way to go."

HEADLINE: Triangle Where Business, Taxes and Neighborhood Intersect

BYLINE: By RAY CORMIER

DATELINE: YORKTOWN

 BODY:
OLD CROMPOND ROAD winds downhill from Zino's Nursery at Route 202, past one modern house and several other older residences, some meadows and patches of trees. It could be a country road in the Catskills.
But to some town officials here, this little neighborhood looks more like a Platinum Half-Mile. 
 The master plan that the town updated and approved in 1983 sees the 69.29 acres that resemble a triangle between Route 202 and the Bear Mountain Parkway Extension, just west of the Taconic State Parkway, as an ideal area to attract light industry and much-needed revenue. In 1989, the Town Board proposed to rezone the area, from commercial on the perimeter and residential elsewhere, to accommodate light industrial uses.
Old Crompond Road is also home to 10 families. And 10 undeveloped acres along Route 202 are where one local landowner wants to develop businesses for his children to run.
 
<SC0>Two Years of Talk
 There are the three competing concerns over what has come to be known as the Bear Mountain Triangle: a neighborhood's way of life, American entrepreneurship and the fiscal well-being of the municipality. They are intertwined in a way that could arise in many suburban communities as developable land disappears and tax pressures grow.
The property owners in the Bear Mountain Triangle won a reprieve in October 1989, when the Town Board failed to muster an 80 percent majority made necessary by the property owners' petition opposing the rezoning.
But the subsequent two years of petitions, legal wrangling and negotiations have left the property owners alternately angry and frustrated, living in a kind of zoning limbo.
"It's been a real nightmare," said Joseph M. Adrian, a Hawthorne real-estate appraiser who lives in Yorktown and wants to build an auto mall with a dealership and other automobile services along Route 202 in the Bear Mountain Triangle.
The 1989 proposal would have changed Mr. Adrian's commercial zone to an industrial category, barring the kind of businesses he planned. "Town boards have got to a point where with the stroke of a pen they can ruin someone's life," he said.
James Kutter, whose family has lived on Old Crompond Road since the 1930's, said: "We've been here three generations; others have been here five or six. Now they say 'We don't care about your roots,' in order to get another $1 million in revenue."
 
'No Hidden Agenda'
 A neighbor of his, Edith Cassinari, said her family has lived in the area since 1924. She, too, sounded frustrated, saying of town officials, "They don't want to listen to us."
But Anthony L. Grasso, one of two current Town Board members who voted to rezone the area in 1989, said recently: "No one is trying to force anyone out. There's no hidden agenda. I feel we have to do what's right for the whole community. Our commercial tax base isn't high enough."
How far does a town go in following a master plan?
"A master plan is a kind of great overview of the town over 20 years or more," said Lester Steinman, director of the Municipal Law Resource Center of Pace University in White Plains. "Master plans are looked upon as very theoretical."
 
'When People Are There'
 David Portman, a private planner with Frederick P. Clark & Associates in Rye, who like Mr. Steinman would speak only of general planning principles and not about the specific issue, agreed, adding, "The bottom line is the Town Board has to decide what is best for the town."
Town Superviser Nancy R. Elliott, who cast the lone vote against the rezoning plan in 1989, said of the plan's effects: "If we were looking at a blank map on the wall, that's one thing. But when people are there, that's another."
And Mr. Grasso acknowleged, "Master plans are not cut into stone."
But the issue seems far from being settled.
Mr. Adrian started planning his auto mall in 1986 on 10 acres that for decades was mostly zoned for commercial use. He said that he had spent more than $200,000 on his plans and that he had filed a suit that said the town had induced him to spend money on development plans and then tried to outlaw those plans with the zoning proposal.
Members of the Town Board have said his plans would be approved, as long as they did not include a car dealership. Board members said the road, which already has some auto dealerships, could not accommodate any more. But Mr. Adrian said he still wanted to open one, and he is disputing a town ruling on wetlands on the property limiting its use.
Mr. Adrian initiated the petition opposing the rezoning, which meant that a "super majority" -- 80 percent -- approval was required for the plan to take effect. With one board member, Gary Ajello, abstaining because he was the lawyer for a property owner in the area, Mrs. Elliott's no vote killed the proposal to rezone most of the site for light industrial use, rather than commercial use. She said she was concerned about the longtime residents. "Longevity played a part in my thinking," she conceded.
Some board members have said the new zoning would make the land more valuable, but Mrs. Elliott asserted that "it doesn't while they are living there." In other words, a parcel is more valuable only if a company wanting to build there makes an offer acceptable to a landowner.
Naomi Tor, director of planning, explained that the concept behind the master plan for the area was to keep commercial development on the south side of Route 202, where the Building and Design Center, a home furnishings mall, already exists. The north side would be for industrial and office space and a new interchange district for travel-related services to take advantage of the proximity of the Taconic State Parkway.
"The planners felt in the larger picture we must be economical in the use of our land," she said. "We don't have that much land for that kind of use." She added that the Old Crompond Road area "is isolated, not a good place for a residential community."
 
'Negative and Positive Impacts'
 But Neal Bailenson, a Councilman who voted for the rezoning in 1989, said it was Mr. Adrian's proposal for an auto dealership that "was the original impetus" for the rezoning proposal.
He said that the master plan called for nonresidential use of the area and that there already were some nonresidential uses on some parcels: at the west end there is an auto-body shop, and one resident stores construction equipment on another parcel. "Whenever you do rezoning, there are negative and positive impacts," he said. "You hope the town can benefit and you can limit the negatives."
An impact study done for the Town Board in 1988 by Tim Miller Associates of Brooklyn estimated that the rezoning would produce a tripling of assessments and tax revenue and the creation of 6,000 jobs, figures Mr. Kutter said were exaggerated. To create that many jobs on 70 acres, he said, "you would have to denude the land" for buildings and parking space.
Several residents echoed the comment of Brian R. Hoy, who said he liked the seclusion that the semi-rural nature of the neighborhood provides.
Mr. Kutter and his wife, Ann, have looked at real estate in the area. They and Mr. Kutter's elderly parents live in adjoining houses.
"We looked at $500,000 houses that don't give us what we have here," said Mrs. Kutter, who has been a leader in trying to negotiate a compromise and is secretary of the town Republican Party, the party of all five board members. The Kutters's house, a modest-looking bungalow from the street, has 10 rooms for them and their teen-age son, and there is a pool in the backyard.
 
Willing to Compromise
 Mr. Kutter, a consultant to international computer companies, said he had turned down a lucrative position in London to keep from leaving his roots and his parents, who are in their 80's.
The Kutters and others said they did not mind compromising to allow some form of additional tax base in the area as long as their homes are protected. Eugene Orloff, who is retired, said: "We're not being obtuse or stubborn. I do not know exactly what's being proposed."
Mr. Grasso, Mr. Bailenson, who also voted for the rezoning in 1989, and Mrs. Elliot have met with the residents of Old Crompond Road, but a compromise has eluded them. Talks of buffers for the residential properties, switching the industrial space across Route 202 and other ideas have yet to be put into a proposal, and the residents remain frustrated. As one, Brian R. Hoy, said, "It always seems the towns and counties get their way."
No one has fought the Town Board harder than Mr. Adrian. He said late last month that he still wanted to start an auto dealership and that he would sue over the most recent wetlands limitations imposed on him by the town. The board members all agree any question of rezoning must await settlement of the Adrian case.
Besides providing a source of income for four of his six adult children, Mr. Adrian said, "I thought my plans were for the betterment of the area and would bring taxes into town."
Mr. Bailenson, who surprised many in town by announcing on July 23 that he would not seek a fourth term this fall, said of Mr. Adrian's proposal, "I was reluctant to see 202 become another Central Avenue."
About rezoning in general, he added: "You have to be professional about it, and it has to make sense. This seems to make sense. But we're still going to make some people unhappy."

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: At a Seaside Gallery, It's 'La Boheme' With a Happy Ending

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: CITY ISLAND

 BODY:
RON TERNER knew the scene: the icy reception at the art gallery door, the noncommittal response from a brusque employee, the portfolios returned without comment. Because of his own brush with rejection as a young photographer he decided never to run his own gallery that way.
Now 42 years old, the man who has owned the Focal Point Gallery for 18 years here has retained a genuine friendliness that draws artists from miles around. The gallery specializes in photography, and Mr. Terner promises a sharing of ideas, if not an exhibition, to any artist who wants to bring in work. 
 Near the Hutchinson River Parkway just below the Westchester County line, City Island looks no trendier than when Mr. Terner moved here in the early 1970's. The Focal Point Gallery itself, set among pizza shops, laundromats and marine-supply stores on the island's one long commercial street, is as unpretentious as Mr. Terner and his wife, Niru, who runs the place with him.
 
Jewelry Underwrites Other Projects
 One recent summer day, the couple's golden retriever, Tandra, lolled under a table. A fan circulated the humid air. Mrs. Terner, a native of India, displayed an exotic collection of jewelry from behind a well-stocked counter. Customers wandered in and out, greeted either by Mr. or Mrs. Terner or by their 13-year-old son, Rajeev.
It is the sale of jewelry, Mr. Terner explained, that allows him to pursue his real interest: showing the work of established artists like Armand Rumayor, whose work was then on the walls.
He can exhibit up-and-coming photographers like the five whose group show opened at the gallery on Aug. 2, without worrying if the pictures will sell, and he can continue the nude photography he has concentrated on for many years -- now exploring the boundaries between painting and photography to create increasingly abstract imagery.
 
Coming Upon Photography
 In addition, he is able to publish his own works and those of others by means of the Focal Point Press, a nonprofit enterprise Mr. Terner founded. The press in turn helps finance many of the gallery's projects.
Mr. Terner's City Island story reads like a "La Boheme" with a happier ending. A native of the Bronx, he said he had been influenced "to make art my life" by his grandmother, the late painter and art therapist Anne Kellogg. Searching for a medium in which to express himself, Mr. Terner found photography at the age of 20, at first regarding it as "a tool to help me with my painting and drawing."
He took his early portraits and street photography to Manhattan galleries, but it was on City Island that he found kindred spirits. Crafts were flourishing here at the time and Mr. Terner became friends with a group of artists working in jewelry, woodcraft, stained glass, pottery and painting. He sold his first pictures at an outdoor exhibition, and with the encouragement of his friends, opened the Focal Point Gallery when he was 26.
He lived at the back of the gallery, relying on a pot-bellied stove for warmth. "I remember chopping a lot of wood -- probably 10 cords a season," Mr. Terner said. "It rained and snowed inside. I bartered for meals by doing people's portraits and restoring old photographs."
 
'I Sold the Pups for a Tripod'
 When his first golden retriever had puppies, "I sold the pups for a tripod and lens," Mr. Terner recalled. "I got a cat who ate the mice who ran over me when I slept."
But Mr. Terner was happy, he said, more so after a striking Indian woman walked into the gallery one day. "I wouldn't let her go," Mr. Terner said of Niru. Now the Terner family lives in a house down the street from the gallery. Mr. Terner is the only artist left living here of the early group of friends. While there are antiques shops and a private art dealer in town, his is the only art gallery.
 
More Residents, More Tourists
 City Island has changed, he said. There are more people living here -- especially more upper-middle-class people -- and marinas have replaced the boatyards, which were a mainstay of the island's economy. Rents have gone up and condominiums are more numerous. Tourists flock to City Island for its restaurants and the beach.
But he is still happy here, he said, because the island still has its charm. "The people who are coming here to live also want to preserve it," Mr. Terner said.
The photographer doesn't seem to measure success in square feet or slickness. Doing what he wants in the way he wants to do it counts more for him than upscale appearances. The darkroom where he works mornings and Mondays, when the gallery is closed, does not gleam with the latest equipment.
Instead, he proudly showed a visitor a signed, original photograph on the wall by the late Imogene Cunningham that a friend of Mr. Terner's had found in a dump. The black and white picture shows Alfred Stieglitz in front of a painting done by his wife, Georgia O'Keeffe. "A picture by a master of a master in front of a master," is how Mr. Terner describes it.
 
'A Sign, a Calling'
 When his friend gave him the picture -- in perfect condition -- in 1977, Mr. Terner said he "took it as a sign, a calling, not to give up the gallery" as he had planned. After he and his wife visited India several months later he reopened the gallery in a new location. The present gallery is the Focal Point's third site here.
Beside what he called Stieglitz's "watchful eyes" Mr. Turner works with photographs of Albert Einstein and the Indian philosopher Rabindranath Tagore facing him. On the same wall is a color portrait he made of his grandmother, whom he calls "the biggest influence in my life."
Mrs. Kellogg coined the term "PhotoTerns" for Mr. Terner's style of work, which involves painting with chemicals on fixed black and white prints and then refixing them. Prices for the pictures, of which no two are alike, begin at $1,500. Mr. Terner will show his work, which has been exhibited in the Soviet Union and will travel to Mexico next year, at the Focal Point Gallery from Oct. 12 to Nov. 3, with an opening reception for the public on Oct. 12 at 7:30 P.M.
The gallery's exhibitions are generally culled from slides submitted once a year by artists from all over the country. There are exceptions: recently there was a show of Latvian photography.
 
Classical Nude Studies
 The current group exhibition, which includes color abstractions of nature, classical nude studies, impressionistic photographs of exotic dancers and the people who watch them, and the photojournalistic portrait of a family, will be on view through Sept. 29.
Frank McGinnis of Hastings-on-Hudson, one of the five artists represented and the only one from Westchester, is showing nudes strikingly composed in black and white.
In addition to funds from the Focal Point Press, the Focal Point Gallery receives it support in part from the Bronx Council on the Arts, the International Paper Company and the State Department of Cultural Affairs. The gallery's hours are Tuesdays through Sundays from noon to 6:30 P.M. and additionally from 7:30 to 9 P.M. on Fridays and Saturdays. For further information, call the gallery at (212) 885-1403.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Niru Terner, far left, of the Focal Point Gallery on City Island, with a customer at the 18-year-old establishment. Above, Ron Terner, gallery's owner. (Photographs by Roberta Hershenson)
