HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Can the Fed Keep the Cracks From Growing?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Just when everyone knew the economy was recovering, cracks are being noticed again.
The cracks are in the mountain of credit that was built up in the past decade, and it is fair to say that their existence is not news. They spooked the markets last fall, but after that they were not so much papered over as dismissed as irrelevant. 
 But now some companies are finding the credit markets less hospitable than they expected, and there were old-fashioned runs on the Hong Kong operations of Citibank and Britain's Standard Chartered Bank. Both runs were unreasonable, but when the whiffs of crisis start to blow, they do not always swirl with discrimination.
It appears that the runs have ended. Citibank stayed open late and handed out cash to any depositor who wanted it -- the classic tactic to fight a run. By Friday, things appeared back to normal, and the vast majority of Hong Kong depositors had left their money where it was. Blessedly, the run remained a retail event, and did not involve institutions that can withdraw billions within minutes.
The problems in Hong Kong may yet shake the comfortable assumption, prevalent both in the City of London and on Wall Street, that the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International will have political repercussions, not financial ones. In fact, it has brought home to depositors in Britain and Hong Kong, among other places, the risks of putting money in a bank. Those lessons parallel the painful realization that some who are owed money by Executive Life will not get it all back. Both are likely to make people more cautious. Insurance regulators worry that rumors lead to runs by policyholders and bringdown insurers that could have survived.
Last fall, when credit worries were high and bank stocks low, the stock market illustrated the fears. Now, it reflects the confidence that followed the Federal Reserve's aggressive easing, which continued last week. Most bank stocks are holding up, although they are not hitting new highs, as the S.&P. 500 did last week. But shares faded after bonds began slipping on Thursday, and the Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down 10.06 points, to 2,996.20.
That market strength is a blessing for the economy. Many companies that need capital have found a way to get it from the market, often by selling shares in a subsidiary. The money can then go to meet debt obligations that otherwise would cause problems. Citicorp shares are weak, but many others are strong enough that banks should be able to raise capital.
The market irony is that it is starting to look as if the bears may have been right when they warned that the Fed could not get the economy moving again simply by pushing interest rates down. Many now think the revised figures will show that there was a further economic decline during the second quarter. Analysts are cutting profit forecasts at a rapid rate.
But so far, the stock market is willing to retain faith that the Fed's actions will work. Let us hope that faith is justified.

But Most Bank Stocks Are Rising," tracks weekly index of seven New York bank stocks, June 29, 1990-Aug. 9, 1991.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Sweden Gets a Case of the Jitters

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Sweden is stumbling.
After a surprisingly robust performance this year, the stock market has gotten a case of the jitters, the result of a pessimistic economic outlook and the uncertainty surrounding the upcoming elections this fall. 
 Since Aug. 1, the Swedish market's Affarsvalden index has declined 2.4 percent, closing Friday at 1,096.20. It has fallen 4.7 percent from its 1991 high of 1,149.80, which was set on July 11.
James Capel Inc. in London is telling its clients to take profits now and wait until the fourth quarter before deciding on whether they should return to Stockholm. UBS Phillips Drew of London is cutting its forecast for the Affarsvalden index to 1,050 by year's end, down from 1,100.
Because many of the country's blue chip companies, like Astra and Ericsson, depend on exports, the outlook for the economies of Europe and the United States are just as critical to investors as that for Sweden. And the news is not rosy. The recovery in America may not be vigorous. In England, the recession is dragging on. And in Germany, a major Swedish trading partner, the economy is slowing and interest rates could rise another notch.
The change in sentiment toward the Swedish market is also a result of a worry over the latest round of six-month earnings reports, which began to come out last week. SKR, the ball-bearing manufacturer, announced a 95 percent drop in pre-tax profits. The company said it expected earnings to improve in the second half of the year, an announcement that gave the stock market a little lift at the end of the week.
Sweden's own economic outlook is also darker than many local investors had thought. The recession is expected to continue through this year, the experts say, with forecasts showing a weak recovery, at best, developing next year.
Although analysts at UBS expect corporate earnings to increase 20 percent to 25 percent in 1992, part of the rebound will be a result of one-time restructuring charges many companies are taking this year year to cut costs. Some companies, like Volvo, also had major costs for development of new models, which will not be repeated.
The September election, in which the current Government of Social Democrats, led by Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson, will be fighting for its political life, is also adding uncertainity.
The possibility of a coalition government of several conservative and non-Socialist parties could add impetus to the move that is seeking to tilt what was once a major Western welfare state toward an open market orientation. But the coalition, analysts argue, could break apart over other issues, like nuclear power and membership in the European Community. And in recent polls, the Social Democrats, although still trailing, have gained some ground.
Much of the impetus for the market rally came from signs of a change in the Social Democrats' attitude and economic management. Less inclined toward innovation, the Government, analysts say, is now more likely to use inflation than the unemployment rate as the key guide to policy.
The Government's decision to apply for membership in the European Community also encouraged many foreign investors to buy stocks before the country's stock market is forced by E.C. rules to open its door fully to foreigners. According to James Capel, foreigners were net purchasers of 3.7 billion kronor worth of stock by the end of May, compared with 1.2 billion kronor for all of last year.
The decision to tie the krona to a basket of European currencies, as represented in the European Currency Unit, gave the Swedish currency a new stability. It opened the way for cuts in interest rates at home and raised confidence that the government would not use krona devaluations just to make Swedish exports cheaper abroad.
In addition, two major deals, both involving the Wallenberg family, which has major stakes in many Swedish companies, poured billions of kronor into the market, helping to spur domestic buying. One was the friendly $2.8 billion takeover of Alfa-Laval, a manufacturer of dairy machinery, by Switzerland's Tetra Pak. The second was the purchase by the Wallenbergs of the remaining shares in Saab-Scania that they did not own.
The market also rebounded from a very low level, having fallen 37.6 percent after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Even after this year's rally, the market is 18 percent below its pre-invasion level, according to the Financial Times index of world stock markets. During the war rally in January and February, the market was the top performer in the Financial Times index, rising 27 percent.
"There is no room for any disappointments coming through," said Roddy Bridge of UBS in London. "If this earnings period disappoints, the cash that had been supporting the market can turn around and the market can fall. This is what I am hoping for so that we can take a look to see if we should go positive on the market again."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2965 words

HEADLINE: Piercing Wall Street's 'Lucite Ceiling'

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
When pressed, Bernard B. Beal will say that he made his most critical career decision at gunpoint. It was the summer of 1972, and Mr. Beal, the son of an elevator operator in Brooklyn, had just finished his scholarship-sponsored studies at the Wooster School in Danbury, Conn. He had applied to various colleges, but preferred entrepreneurship. So he took his college fund and bought a stake in a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx, which he helped manage. When a gunman arrived one hot night, the young manager tried to bolt and a bullet grazed his leg. Bernard Beal decided that maybe college was a better idea after all.
College and an M.B.A. from Stanford led to a nine-year stint at E. F. Hutton, now Shearson Lehman Brothers. Then, in 1988, Mr. Beal at last became an entrepreneur: He joined with several partners to form M. R. Beal & Company, one of the fastest-growing minority-owned investment banking firms on Wall Street. 
 In a way, he is still under fire.
M. R. Beal has entered the securities industry at a time when Wall Street firms are battling to preserve their slice of a shrinking business. But it is also a time when the financial community, mirroring the national debate about the nomination of Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, is groping for ways to open the doors of Wall Street to minorities and women without abandoning the notion of rewarding individual merit.
In many ways, Bernard Beal's experience captures the soul of that debate. He acknowledges that his firm benefits from various state and local government programs that set aside a portion of bond underwriting business for minority- and female-owned firms. But he is quick to add that he wants to be in charge of those deals. "We couldn't survive on a 5 to 10 percent set-aside program," he said. "The people we've hired are used to running transactions."
Nor will he limit his role to just underwriting municipal bonds. His firm also actively trades them through one of the largest trading desks of any minority-owned firm on the Street. "There is no way that there is any advantage to being a minority firm in the buying and selling of securities," said Mr. Beal. "Nobody is going to sell a bond to you for one-eighth of a point less just because you're black."
 
A Corporate Aim
 And while some minority-owned firms are content to stay in the realm of municipal finance, where the growing power of black and female politicians bolsters their access to business, Mr. Beal is determined to expand into corporate finance -- a stony field jealously guarded by the oldest and most powerful firms on Wall Street. Indeed, he sees expansion into corporate finance as a crucial step to provide minorities access to badly needed capital. "We've had social and political advantages," he said. "Now we need the economic advantage."
He has no illusions this will be easy. Most of corporate America's top executives are white males. And despite Wall Street's much-publicized effort to lower barriers to minority firms in recent years, there are few blacks or women in the corporate finance arena.
"It's worse than a glass ceiling, because at least you can break glass," Mr. Beal said. "This ceiling is solid Lucite." He softens his indictment with laughter. "It's just going to take some time, that's all."
It's an effort worth making, said Lee Jackson, a former Wall Street investment banker who is now the collector-treasurer for the city of Boston. "It is time for minority and women-owned firms to break into that market," he said. "They will be met with some resistance, but it is time for someone to knock on those doors, because it's good for the economy, overall, when the corporate world is not just hearing from firms that are predominantly male and predominantly white."
Mr. Beal was senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers in May 1988 when he struck off to become chairman of M.R. Beal -- the initials are drawn from the middle names of his two children (Manning and Mae) and his wife, Valerie Rose. The firm started with just eight people on staff. It now has three dozen -- most of them from the ranks of Wall Street's blue-chip institutions and about two-thirds of them minorities or women.
Diana L. Taylor, the president and an equity partner in the firm, was a senior vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Tom Monti, who oversees both sales and underwriting, was recently recruited from Bankers Trust. Stephen C. Leslie, who runs the trading desk at the firm, is a veteran of Salomon Brothers.
 
Starting in Munis
 Beal devoted itself first to developing its municipal bond business. Since its founding, it has participated in 167 long-term public underwritings totaling $17.7 billion, according to data from Investment Dealers Digest. Last year alone, I.D.D. said, the firm took part in 73 long-term public bond deals worth a total of $8.3 billion. That put it a respectable 24th in I.D.D.'s industry rankings, close behind Pryor, McClendon, Counts & Company; Grigsby Brandford Powell, and W.R. Lazard & Company, -- the other leading minority-owned firms, all of which were well established before M.R. Beal was born.
The growth at minority- and female-owned firms is thanks in part to state and local policies and laws that encourage their inclusion in the syndicates that underwrite public bond offerings.
Some issuers -- California, for example -- require by law that female- and minority-owned firms be included in their bond sales. "We want an open-door policy, not an 'old pals' act," said Kathleen Brown, the state treasurer. "The theory of providing greater opportunity is that it provides more competition, and the more competition there is, the better the deal the state should get." Other issuers, like Detroit and Boston, have informal policies based on government procurement rules.
According to I.D.D., minority- and female-owned firms participated in more than half of the long-term municipal bond deals, by dollar value, that were sold in the first half of this year, up from less than 20 percent in all of 1988.
But the ranking that places minority firms so high gives every member of a selling syndicate full credit for the entire face value of a deal. That is not how Mr. Beal keeps score. He takes credit only for the deals on which his firm has served as the senior underwriter or co-senior underwriter. (The senior manager allocates the bonds in the selling group, and thus can attract the lion's share of the purchase orders -- and the profits -- because buyers are confident the lead firm can fill its orders.)
By that sterner standard -- I.D.D. statistics for lead managers, excluding short-term notes and private placements -- Beal climbed to 69thin the industry last year, up sharply from 231st the year before.
 
An Elusive Goal
 But minority firms still fall far behind the major Wall Street firms in the senior manager rankings.
That is probably less a result of bias than of financial strength, said William H. Hayden, a senior managing director of Bear, Stearns and chairman of the National Association of Securities Professionals, which represents minorities and women on Wall Street. With today's sharper competition for the profits that go with the senior manager's spot, larger, better-capitalized firms are winning out over smaller ones, he said.
However, Mr. Hayden added, "Bernard Beal has great marketing and banking skills, and I have every expectation that he will lead his firm through that process of getting bigger and bigger deals to manage."
Ernest G. Green, a managing director at Lehman Brothers, a division of Shearson Lehman Brothers, agreed that Mr. Beal's ability to get the senior spot as often as he does "is a recognition by issuers that he wants to be seen as more than a minority firm. Plus, he is spending more time on the trading side than other firms do, and that helps."
Not every minority-owned firm sets its sights on running a sales syndicate. Indeed, one criticism of the governmental programs that give minority firms an assured spot is that some small firms do little to earn their place on the team. Each syndicate member is responsible for selling a certain portion of bonds, but Ms. Taylor, Beal's president, said there are instances in which some minority firms simply sell their bonds back to the senior managers or to other dealers for a quick profit.
They refuse, she said, "to take a hit if the bonds drop in value."
Public officials, while loathe to condemn any minority-owned syndicate participants, agree that some, for various reasons, turn in a very uneven sales performance.
"It was initially a problem, because in many cases the minority- and women-owned firms were simply tacked onto the management team and were not given any role in selling the bonds," said Mr. Jackson, the Boston official. "There are probably cases where that still happens, but issuers have gotten more sophisticated. They are saying to the lead managers that you have to give the firms the opportunity to perform and demand that performance."
No one on the Street or in the halls of government seems to have any complaints about Beal's selling effort, however.
Mr. Jackson said he closely monitors how members of his city's selling groups perform and has been "especially impressed" by Beal.
J. Chester Johnson, president of Government Finance Associates, an independent financial advisor to state and local governments, said "They have come through and have moved bonds for a number of my clients. There are certain minority firms that I could not say that about."
Wall Streeters are quick to point out that do-nothing syndicate members come in all colors and sizes. "There are firms that perform and firms that don't perform, but that has nothing to do with race or gender," Mr. Hayden said.
Clearly, this is an issue that rankles Bernard Beal. He recalled getting a plea from a friend at a large underwriting firm who found herself ready to market a deal but with inadequate minority representation. She asked him to step in as a favor. He refused. "People would have said, 'Those guys just showed up and took a check for being black,' " he said. "We will not front for anybody."
As that reaction suggests, Mr. Beal projects a level of uncompromising aggressiveness considered intense even by Wall Street standards. His rivals say he occasionally rubs people the wrong way, although his friends say he is maturing along with his firm. Mr. Green of Lehman Brothers said, "The real measuring stick for a small firm is the relationships they have with the major firms and how wisely they make the trade-offs that involves. Bernard is growing at that."
A few competitors in the business complain, too, about Mr. Beal's "political connections," suggesting that his firm has benefited from his ties to newly powerful black politicians.
"Of course we try to target areas where one of us, usually Bernard, has a very, very good relationship," said Ms. Taylor. "But we still have to show something concrete. We're under more of a microscope, and we have to be sure that the people who hire us will never be embarrassed."
She cited a housing bond issue in Louisiana. "A minority firm doing a senior-managed deal in Louisiana -- that was a coup," she said. "But we had the expertise. All we needed was a chance to compete."
The key word, said Mr. Beal, is "compete." In an argument that echoes complaints of African-American conservatives like Judge Thomas about affirmative action, Mr. Beal rejects the idea that giving minority firms a chance ever justifies giving taxpayers less than the best deal.
"There's this notion that there's an extra cost to doing business with a minority firm," he said. "That simply is not true. In the deals where we've gotten to run the books, we've had the lowest costs. So I don't care why you hire me. You'll keep me because I'm the cheapest and you get great service and great ideas."
Government officials supporting the inclusion of minority firms agree. "It has never cost us an extra penny on any of our transactions to include minority- or female-owned firms on our managing team or in our selling group," said Bella Marshall, finance director for Detroit.
 
Small Successes
 But the real test for Bernard Beal will be pushing his firm into corporate finance, a world where neither political connections nor affirmative-action efforts are of much help.
His initial strategy, he said, was to expand his muni trading desk to handle corporate bond sales. Some of the institutional buyers of municipal bonds are also in the market for corporate bonds and he hopes that connection will help it win a small spot in a corporate bond syndicate.
"We just want to get into the syndicates," Mr. Beal said. "Let us sell a little piece of an issue, and then we'll work our way up."
There have been small corporate finance successes. Led by Alric B. Nembhard, a senior vice president, a Beal team handled a $10.7 million deal in June for a commercial real estate investor trying to finance three buildings that he had purchased from -- and then leased back to -- Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph in Denver. The issue was sold privately to a state pension fund.
In another deal expected in September, the borrower is a privately held Florida utility. "The credit crunch has been an incredible help to us in developing this niche," Mr. Nembhard said. "We can take private companies, new to the rating process and to the market, and teach them what the institutional financing market is all about. That can be a real eye-opener for someone used to dealing only with banks and insurance companies."
Beal intends to prospect for corporate clients among these small- to mid-sized companies. "We hope to fly in below the radar of the big firms," said Ms. Taylor. "None of the larger firms are interested in deals of $50 million or less."
The ultimate corporate finance goal for both Mr. Beal and Ms. Taylor is providing investment banking services to minority and female entrepreneurs, which they see as being underserved by Wall Street.
Mr. Beal sees this mission in an intensely personal light. "Part of the problem the Afro-American community has is that we are consumers, not producers," he said. "Access to capital is what we need to move our community the next step."
 
 
 
'Ms. Inside' Stretches Management Wings

 Most successful Wall Street firms have a "Mr. Outside" and a "Mr. Inside" -- one top executive who drums up new business and another who gets the deals done. So, too, at M.R. Beal & Company, though in this case it's "Ms. Inside."
Diana L. Taylor, president and a founding partner of Beal, is officially in charge of internal management and admininstration. But her colleagues describe her as "the glue" that helps to hold the fast-growing firm together.
A Dartmouth College graduate, Ms. Taylor has an M.B.A. from Columbia University. After stints at two other large Wall Street firms, she joined Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in 1984 and was a senior vice president when she left in 1988 to help found Beal.
Before joining Mr. Beal, she was as focused on generating new business as he was. So management does not come naturally to her. In fact, she said, "Management is something that Wall Street doesn't do very well. People on the marketing side have a time horizon of about 30 seconds, on a good day. On the investment banking side, the people who rise are good at doing deals. So management is really tough."
But at a minority firm, she said, "We feel we have to do a better job than everybody else. If there are one or two typographical errors in one of our proposals, people say, 'Oh, they can't spell.' Of course, big firms have typos all the time."
Ms. Taylor said she would have been attracted to Beal regardless of opportunities elsewhere. "The main difference between working here and working anywhere else is that nobody looks at anybody as a minority or a woman," she said.
One factor in her move was that the "glass ceiling" for women remains pretty much intact at the major Wall Street firms. "I don't see any real conversion experience going on yet," she said.

 
 
POOLING FUNDS TO MAKE A PAC
 As the power of minority politicians grows across the country, Bernard B. Beal, chairman of M.R. Beal & Company, thinks it is time for a change in how minority-owned investment firms handle the sensitive matter of political contributions to elected officials.
Most major Wall Street firms have individual political action committees (PAC's) that support local and national candidates. The Public Securities Association, the trade group for the municipal and government securities industry which has a small PAC of its own, insists that the disclosure of Wall Street's political gifts is sufficient to cope with the public suspicion that such gifts are part of a quid pro quo. But something more is needed, according to Mr. Beal.
"This is an issue that is going to rise up and bite us on the bottom if we don't do something about it," he said. "And it affects minority firms especially, because if you have to buy the business with political contributions, there is no way we can compete. We just don't have that kind of money."
His solution? He and a few other minority firms have formed a fledgling PAC, Afro-Americans for a Better America, to pool what funds are available. One advantage is that this approach gives black-owned firms a clearer voice on public policy issues, Mr. Beal said. Another is that it separates the gift-giving from the deal-making. "I want the decisions to be made by third parties," he said. "I want to be able to say to politicians, 'Hey, it's out of my hands. All our contributions are handled by the PAC.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/August 6-11

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Seidman Gets Ready to Leave the Headaches Behind 

 
For more than a year, L. William Seidman, the nation's top banking regulator, was under pressure from the White House and some in Congress to step down. They did not like the independent way he was managing the savings and loan bailout. Last week Mr. Seidman said he would resign, effective Oct. 16. "I'm now available for any kind of job that will pay a lot of money to do practically nothing," Mr. Seidman said. No wonder; as head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation since 1985, he has had to provide assessments of savings and loan losses, shore up the bank insurance fund, supervise the sale of thousands of properties, merge failing savings and loan institutions and rattle a $100 billion tin cup Congress was forced to fill. No successor has been named, but William Taylor, a senior banking regulator at the Federal Reserve Board, is considered likely to get the nod.
 
Stockholder Backlash
 
The Chrysler Corporation is a little like the Soviet Union -- big plans for the future, not much money. It lost $212 million last quarter and is now the No. 4 auto maker, just behind Honda. So it came as no surprise when Chrysler announced a plan last week to raise cash fast. It will sell 56 million new shares of stock at current prices for $792 million to tidy up its balance sheet. Chrysler hopes the cash will raise its credit rating back to superpower status. But the car company's current stockholders are grumbling. The new offering is equal to 20 percent of all outstanding shares and that means dilution -- tinier dividends, a shrinking price and a smaller share of the vote. "The only constituent whose ox gets gored is the poor common shareholder," said Charles T. Freeman, a portfolio fund manager at the Windsor Fund, a "poor" shareholder that controls 20.1 million shares.
 
Revealing B.C.C.I.'s Strategy
 
Now that the Bank of Credit and Commerce International has captured the world's attention and racked up a 12-count indictment for its alleged misdeeds (more are expected), it is interesting to find out how those bankers actually ran the bank. Last week one of them, Masihur Rahman, B.C.C.I.'s former chief financial officer, began the long process of explaining. Mr. Rahman told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee that B.C.C.I. kept running even though it was insolvent. In 1985, he said, the bank lost $430 million. But it never told the regulators. Instead, it covered up the losses with cash from a B.C.C.I. affiliate in the Cayman Islands, called the International Credit and Investment Company. I.C.I.C. was a "bank within a bank," and it became the center of B.C.C.I.'s fraudulent operations. From 1985 on, "effectively the whole group was finished," said Mr. Rahman, who told the committee he fled London last week fearing for his life. He was threatened by bank officers, he said.
 
Chase Sells -- and Buys
 
At the Chase Manhattan Corporation, decades of financial diversification are being reversed. Chase said last week it would sell its leasing businesses in the United States and Canada for $2.2 billion. Why is it slimming down? To raise cash to buy two troubled savings banks in Connecticut -- Citytrust and Mechanics and Farmers Savings Bank. Together the two banks have assets nearly equal to those Chase is shedding.
 
Relief for Policyholders
 
When the Executive Life Insurance Company of California went under, policy and annuity holders feared the worst. But last week they got some cheering news. A French investment group headed by Credit Lyonnais -- the big state-owned bank -- wants to take over Executive Life. It proposes to inject $3 billion in the company and take over its "junk bond" portfolio. That would prevent a liquidation. The French investors would also guarantee that most of the company's policy and annuity holders would eventually receive at least 81 percent of the value of their investments. But corks are not popping just yet. There is also at least one other serious bid to be considered, said John Garamendi, California's Commissioner of Insurance.
 
The King Goes to Tokyo
 
If Elvis is ever sighted again, he could be singing in Japanese. That much was said in a speech last week by Jack Soden, executive director of the Graceland theme park division of Elvis Presley Enterprises Inc. in Memphis. Mr. Soden said the company was close to making a deal to build an $80 million park near Tokyo. The park would feature more than just the King and his guitar. It would recreate American life in the 1950's and 60's and feature exhibits about other prominent Americans like Marilyn Monroe and James Dean.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A Nudge for the Recovery
 
Around the country economists have been murmuring among themselves that the recovery may stall. What will give it some oomph, they say, are lower interest rates. The Federal Reserve appears to be listening. Last week, it dropped the funds rate to 5 1/2 percent from 5 3/4 percent on news that the employment picture was worsening. That was the first drop since April. The funds rate is what the Fed and some other banks charge for overnight lending. But don't expect rates on credit cards or home mortgages to fall immediately. "I doubt that this latest Fed move will be enough to cause the banks to reduce the prime," said Irwin Kellner, chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Cutting the funds rate is designed more to get capital flowing than to make it cheap. But getting capital flowing is exactly what the credit-crunched economy needs. On the news of lower rates, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 38.24 points but finished the week down 10.06 points at 2996.20.
 
Whipping Inflation
 
To the surprise of many economists, it looks as if inflation is finally being tamed. The Labor Department reported last week that the Producer Price Index -- which measures wholesale prices -- fell by 0.2 percent in July. That follows a 0.3 percent drop in June. Inflation was brought to its knees by the recession, analysts say. Shoppers stayed away from the stores and price plunged to lure them back. With the annual inflation rate at 4 percent or less, many economist think the Fed may be poised to drop interest rates even further.
 
Competing With the Economy
 
What's good for the individual is often bad for the economy, one economic maxim says. That seems to be the case now. Consumers are cutting back on borrowing. In June, according to the Federal Reserve, consumer borrowing fell by 3 percent, the sixth decline in seven months. But since consumers account for two-thirds of all economic activity, that new frugality comes at a price: slower growth.
 
Working Harder
 
Fewer people may be working, but those that do have been producing more. A lot more. According to the Commerce Department, the nation's productivity increased by 1.9 percent from April through June. That is a hefty jump in an important indicator that has been languishing for almost three years. Productivity, which is defined as output per worker, is an especially important indicator. When productivity climbs, wages can rise without cutting into profits.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Not Even a Slap
 
The slap most people were expecting seems to have completely missed the wrists of Japan's major securities houses. The firms admitted making bogus trades to pay back more than $1 billion that their major clients lost, but they were not penalized. The Ministry of Finance in Tokyo explained that no penalities would be imposed because the bogus trades took place in London, not Tokyo. According to Nobuhiko Matsuno, head of the ministry's securities bureau, the trades were also done over the counter, rather than on a recognized exchange. That made it impossible, the ministry claims, to determine if the trading took place at artificial prices. And the ministry also said that though Japanese laws prohibit a firm from promising to compensate a client for its losses, they do not expressly ban payments. In most countries it's the defense lawyers that look for loopholes. In this case, it seems that the Japanese Government has undertaken the search.
 
Polygram Buys a Hit Maker
 
Andrew Lloyd Weber, the powerhouse of Broadway and London's West End, has decided to share the limelight with Polygram N.V., the big Dutch record company. Mr. Weber, who created "Cats," "Phantom of the Opera" and "Starlight Express," among others musicals, is selling 30 percent of his company, Really Useful Holdings, to Polygram for $117 millionplus a payment in 1994 of $17 million. Polygram is also buying the option to acquire a majority of the company in 2003. Mr. Weber's hits have sold more than 10 million albums. The deal will help Mr. Weber repay debts of about $103 million.
 
More Go Jobless in Germany
 
Historically, Germany has always been nervous about two things: inflation and unemployment. Inflation is temporarily under control, but unemployment is rising. In eastern Germany, where the economy has all but collapsed, 1 million people, or 12.1 percent of the work force, are unemployed, according to the Federal Labor Office. The Economics Ministry in Bonn says the number of unemployed could rise 50 percent by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Making Designer Chips On a Desktop Setup

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
Computer chip manufacturing may conjure up visions of huge sterilized factories with workers toiling in white "bunny suits." But a growing number of engineers in the United States are now making integrated circuits on their own desks.
The do-it-yourself chips are known as field programmable logic devices, and they are proving to be important time savers for engineers designing computers, telephone switches, medical devices and other electronic equipment. Instead of waiting for a chip to come back from a factory, which can take weeks, engineers can produce chips in their offices or laboratories in a few minutes and try them out. If the chips don't work, the design can quickly be changed. 
 Such desktop silicon foundries, as they are sometimes called, promise to have as much impact on the semiconductor business as desktop publishing, using laser printers, has had on the printing business.
Field programmable chips have become perhaps the hottest products in the semiconductor business. The two San Jose companies that now lead in the business -- Xilinx Inc. and the Altera Corporation -- have grown right through the recession that is hurting most other chip companies.
"Our problem is we can't ship enough," said Rodney Smith, the chairman and chief executive of Altera. Both Xilinx and Altera will cross the $100 million sales mark this year, and their stock prices are near all-time highs. The Actel Corporation, a privately held concern in Sunnyvale, Calif., with 1990 revenues estimated at $20 million, is generally considered the No. 3 player.
But competition is heating up. Motorola Inc., the largest American semiconductor company, announced last month that it planned to get into the business. The Toshiba Corporation and other Japanese companies are also expected to enter what has been a preserve of American companies.
Several Silicon Valley startups are also taking aim at the market. They include the Quicklogic Corporation of Santa Clara, whose founders invented an early type of programmable chip, and Concurrent Logic Inc. of Sunnyvale. But entering the market might not be easy for everyone. Patents could keep out some companies. And some industry executives say the arena is already overcrowded. One vendor of programmable logic devices, International CMOS Technology, recently filed for bankruptcy protection, while another, Plus Logic, laid off half its employees and replaced its top management.
Programmable logic devices have been around since the 1970's. Among the pioneers in the field was Monolithic Memories, now part of Advanced Micro Devices, which remains a supplier. But devices sold by Xilinx, Altera and others can make more complex circuits than the early products.
Dataquest, a San Jose market-research company, estimates sales of all programmable logic devices will grow from the $828 million of 1990 to $2.2 billion in 1995. Most of the growth will be in the most complex devices, sales of which will grow from $270 million in 1990 to about $1.8 billion in 1995, a compound annual growth rate of close to 50 percent.
To produce a homemade chip, an engineer designs the circuit on a personal computer or engineering work station, usually using commercially available design software. In most systems, a blank chip is then inserted into a small box connected to the computer or work station, which programs the chip in a minute or two.
Different vendors use different technologies. In general, the blank chips, which are made in huge factories, come with logic elements set in an orderly pattern. The customization process involves connecting the logic elements into a particular arrangement.
In the Actel chip, for instance, logic elements are separated by a layer of insulation. Applying an electric charge at a particular point in effect melts the insulation, thus connecting the two elements. The company calls this technology antifuse because the jolt of electricity creates a connection instead of breaking a connection, as occurs in a fuse.
Equally important is the software that converts the engineer's design into the specific pattern of connections on the chip. It is the high software content of the business that vendors of field programmable chips hope will make it hard for others to enter the business. This software can sell for several thousand dollars. A blank chip itself costs anywhere from $1 to hundreds of dollars depending on complexity and on the technology used.
Companies that design electronic products like to make customized chips because it allows them to differentiate their products from their competitors'. Until the advent of the field programmable chips, companies wanting a customized chip used application-specific integrated circuits, or ASIC's, which are customized at a factory. The ASIC provider works with the customer to design the chip, and then it manufactures the chips to order.
But designing an ASIC can cost $25,000, and getting the chips back from the factory can take six weeks. If the chip has a mistake, getting a new one will take another six weeks.
The desktop foundries are far quicker and cheaper for producing a small number of chips. But just as a printing press produces better output than a laser printer, an ASIC factory can produce far more sophisticated chips than a desktop foundry and the chips operate faster.
For large volumes of chips -- say, more than 10,000 -- it is cheaper to use a factory, just as it is cheaper to use a printing press instead of a laser printer to print thousands of copies of a document. For that reason, some companies use field programmable chips only to produce prototypes and then use factory-produced chips in the final product.
Still, companies are willing to put up with the higher costs of field programmable chips because getting something to market quickly is crucial in an industry in which products can become obsolete in as little as a year. "Xilinx wouldn't exist if we didn't reduce time to market," said G. Wesley Patterson, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Xilinx.
Apple Computer used two Xilinx chips in prototypes of a laser printer it introduced in March. The chips performed such functions as communicating with the Macintosh and controlling memory. The Xilinx chips gave Apple "the ability to try out designs and test out designs quickly" and shaved about six months off product development time, said Rob Briody, senior engineer at Apple. Nevertheless, Apple used factory-produced chips in the final product because those chips cost less than $10 per printer compared with $80 for the two Xilinx chips.
Some field programmable chips can be changed even after they are inside the finished product. That allows electronic equipment to alter its own circuitry to suit a given task. Radius Inc. of San Jose makes a computer screen that can tilt on its side, allowing the user to have either a tall narrow screen or a low wide one. A Xilinx chip reconfigures the internal circuitry as the screen is tilted.
In the future, a scientist needing to solve a particular problem might rewire the circuitry inside a computer containing chips with such flexibility as to make it particularly fast at that problem.

GRAPHIC: Photo/Diagram: An electron microscope provides a cross section view of an antifuse (top), with two layers of silicon separated by a thin layer of insulation. A desktop operator can rupture any of the thousands of tiny insulation-guarded openings in the blank chip, allowing current to flow and creating a circuit pattern for a customized computer chip. (The Actel Corporation)

HEADLINE: All About/Air-Conditioners;
When Manufacturers Must Depend On the Miseries of Summer

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
On a blistering summer day, with suffocating humidity and urban tempers on knife's edge, any city can be New York -- hell, with an attitude. Among the small brotherhood of companies that make and sell air-conditioners, however, heat is bliss.
Three days of hazy, hot and humid weather, so an industry rule of thumb goes, means sales, sales, sales. Only when summer lashes back with mild temperatures does this industry, with an estimated $1.2 billion in wholesale revenues, mop its brow. "Unfavorably cool," as one company spokeswoman terms the miserable condition. 
 The industry is prisoner to more than the weather. Production overcapacity, the resulting wave of consolidation and looming changes in Federal energy-efficiency standards mean big changes for the industry, where a few companies -- nine, to be exact -- account for 99 percent of all unit sales.
The upshot for consumers is that air-conditioners are bound to get more expensive, perhaps significantly, because making units thinner, lighter and less ravenous for electricity will mean retooling of plants and changes in methods of manufacture.

 
 
The Geography
Central Air Sells In the Sun Belt
 Air-conditioners are sold in two basic configurations. Room air-conditioners fit snugly into windows and are typically used to cool apartments. Central air-conditioning systems -- huge affairs with elaborate air ducts into each room -- have most of their apparatus outdoors and are used to cool entire houses and apartment buildings.
In the regions of the United States where it is hotter longer, the Sun Belt states stretching from the Carolinas to California, central systems prevail. A big system there may be cheaper and more energy-efficient in the long run. In a place like Corpus Christi, Tex., for example, an air-conditioner typically runs more than 2,000 hours a year, or nearly three months of 24-hour use, according to the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers, a trade association.
By contrast, the Snow Belt states of the Midwest and Northeast favor smaller room units, which may be more energy-efficient, despite their smaller size. In New York, for example, the typical air-conditioner operates about 450 hours a year, or only 19 days of round-the-clock use.
Half of the room units are bought by cool customers who have done comparison shopping. The other half are bought by sleep-deprived consumers panting from humid nights without an air-conditioner.
The problem for the industry is that demand during a heat wave overheats and retailers order too many units. The air-conditioners then have to be liquidated at a discount or held until the next summer.

 
 
After Consolidation
Nine Players Get Most of the Sales
 Draw a diagonal line between Minneapolis and Atlanta, slicing off about a quarter of the country, and 70 percent of all room air-conditioners are sold to the right of that line, mainly in the cities of the Northeast.
Which brings us to Peapack, N.J., the eastern end of that Snow Belt slice and home of the Fedders Corporation, the nation's biggest maker of air-conditioners. Fedders had revenues of $186 million in the first half of 1991, down 14 percent from the same period a year ago.
In 1990, Fedders had a market share of 30 percent, according to Appliance magazine. That includes the January 1991 acquisition of Emerson Quiet Kool for $56 million.
The industry has been consolidating for years, to the point where three companies -- Fedders, Electrolux A.B. and Whirlpool -- account for more than two-thirds of unit sales. Six more companies account for nearly all of the remainder.
In 1990, the industry shipped 4.2 million room air-conditioners, far from its recent peak of 5.1 million units in 1989, according to the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers. But shipments in the first six months of this year -- due to the recession and retailer reluctance to reorder -- have plunged by one-third, to 2.4 million air-conditioners.
Industry executives believe core demand for air-conditioners -- mainly replacement sales -- is 3.5 million units, leaving an overcapacity of 1.5 million units to be wrung out through more mergers and plant closures.
The remaining companies will be bigger, more efficient and run their plants at higher capacity. Or so the theory goes. Fedders makes the most important parts of the air-conditioner in its own plants, rather than in the Far East as many other makers do. Japan, which produces more air-conditioners and more innovations than any other country, still sells primarily in Asia.
But even Fedders is suffering. Profit in the first half plunged nearly 75 percent to $4.1 million.
Salespeople often think air-conditioners sell themselves. They ask consumers rote questions about cooling capacity, size of room, the maximum price they want to pay and little else.
But not at Tops Appliance City, a four-store New Jersey chain. Tops sells as much as $1 million worth of air-conditioners on a hot day and trains its sales staff thoroughly. It sells air-conditioners en masse -- 75 units on a selling floor the size of a small house.
But unlike TV's, whose screens are plain to see, consumers cannot compare air-conditioners. Investigating cooling capacity, noise and fan efficiency would take special, and costly, insulated rooms.

 
 
Designs for the Future
Expect Smaller, Thinner and Quieter
 Like refrigerators, air-conditioners pump heat out of one place and into another. A refrigerant gas, usually some form of chlorofluorocarbons, is compressed by a pump, and then conveyed to a condenser, where it is pressurized, cooled and turned into a liquid.
The liquid is then allowed to expand and return to a gaseous state. As that happens, the refrigerant absorbs heat, or boils. The gas is then compressed again and the cycle continues. An air-conditioner is simply a refrigerator with the door open.
There are, of course, necessary fillips. An air-conditioner cools the entire room, not to a temperature just above 32 degrees, or freezing, but to about 78 degrees, or "room" temperature. A fan sucks warm air from the room into an evaporator coil, where the air is cooled and returned to the room. The heat leaves the outdoor side of the unit, which is why it must be set in a window or wall.
Innovations on this basic design continue. Fedders is introducing later this year its "Micro Sonic." Using more efficient components, it is designed to be smaller, thinner and quieter than other units with about the same energy efficiency ratings. Panasonic, a unit of Matsushita, has come up with a pudgy, upside-down "L" design that is quieter, too. It keeps most of the window-shaking parts outside and below the window.
But real innovation may have to wait until next spring when the Department of Energy comes up with proposals for more stringent energy standards. A 1987 Federal law mandates tougher standards, wringing more performance from less electricity, for most home appliances, including air-conditioners.
"Things are going to get tougher and tougher," said Russell G. Patterson, director of home comfort product marketing at Electrolux A.B. "Stay tuned."

 
 
COOL AIR, JAPANESE-STYLE

At nearly $5,000, the Sanyo Fisher (USA) Corporation's "Tri Zone" may well be the world's most expensive room air-conditioner. It is expensive because the design is radically different.
Instead of a bulky, window-rattling box the size of a large microwave oven, the Tri Zone offers discreet "indoor evaporator units" about the size of, say, a desk blotter. The air-conditioner does not poke out of a window either. The evaporator, or blower, unit cools the room and can hang snugly on a wall.
Like central air-conditioning, the noisiest components of the system are outside the building. But instead of tearing expensive metal pathways, or ducts, through the building, the evaporator units are connected to the outside through 3.5-inch squared hoses that trail through the house to wherever the units are placed. That is why the system is called, inelegantly, ductless cooling.
The American approach is to cool the entire house while Japanese manufacturers have long favored cooling individual rooms. Central air-conditioning systems strike some Japanese as a waste of energy.
"This is a very Japanese approach to air-conditioning," said David Claus, a spokesman for Sanyo Fisher.
But it may not be American, at least not yet. Sanyo has sold only 65,000 of the units recently, compared with the hundreds of thousands of conventional air-conditioners sold by American manufacturers.

HEADLINE: Managing;
When Employees Choose a Charity

SERIES: Second of two articles on corporate philanthropy.

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Every month, the 22 employees on the Adolph Coors Company's Vice Squad -- the wonderfully pronounceable acronym for Volunteers in Community Enrichment Squad -- decide which projects the Golden, Colo., brewery will support. The projects vary from cleaning up a weed-choked lot to providing shoes for needy children to doing repairs on an elderly person's home. But each is proposed, managed and staffed by Coors employees or retirees.
"Letting employees pick and run projects challenges them and shows them respect," said Rosa M. Bunn, Coors's director of economic and public enrichment. 
 Coors is among a growing number of companies to use charitable programs in lieu of lavish raises and limitless promotions to garner employee loyalty. If, at the same time, it can support programs that help educate the current and future work force, so much the better.
These companies are going well beyond matching-gift programs. Some match volunteer time with money and train employees to manage nonprofit projects. Others sponsor programs -- say, local day care centers -- that benefit their employees directly. And quite a few are bolstering educational programs that feed into their industry's needs.
The upshot is that the line between the giving function and the personnel function has blurred. "There is no question that human resources and philanthropy influence each other here," said Mary Beth Salerno, vice president of the American Express Company's domestic giving program, which supports many educational programs.
At the International Business Machines Corporation, the human resources people suggested donating money to causes that I.B.M. employees, retirees or their spouses support with their time. "They understand that supporting charitable work can enhance productivity and retention," said Juan Sabater, director of corporate social policy.
The trend to involve employees in contributions decisions is a boon to local charities that otherwise would have little clout with corporate giving functions. It helps regional theater groups, art museums and other cul- tural groups that women, an increasingly powerful segment of the work force, tend to favor for sponsorship over sporting events.
And it is giving a lift to charities that are not part of United Way. Several companies now allow the American Cancer Society, the Black United Fund and others to mount workplace campaigns. "Our members are gettng into the workplace at the request of the employees," said Robert O. Bothwell, executive director of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, a Washington group of non-United Way charities.
The melding of personnel and philanthropic goals is particularly noticeable in aid to education. The General Electric Foundation, for one, subsidizes university programs that train engineers. And it encourages employees and retirees to teach in high schools. "We've found that G.E.'s local people really want to participate," said Clifford V. Smith Jr., the foundation's president.
Foundations are bound by tax law to eschew projects that benefit their corporate sponsors directly. Corporate giving offices are not so constrained. That is why Citibank's contributions group was able to start a program at a Brooklyn high school that aims to generate bank employees through various work-study arrangements. It does do foundation-like aid as well, such as giving money to black colleges, and to programs that train minority faculty. "We choose projects that teach skills that we need, and that can develop our future work force," said Paul M. Ostergard, Citibank's director of corporate contributions.
Occasionally, the links between philanthropic programs and human resources aims emerge after the fact.
The contributions people at Mervyn's and Target, two department store chains owned by the Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson Corporation, have for several years been operating Family-to-Family, a program that trains local day care providers. Only lately have Dayton-Hudson's human resources people joined in the project. "They finally realized that employees have the same needs as customers," said Cynthia Mayeda, The Dayton Hudson Foundation's chair.

HEADLINE: The Problems of Scarce Capital

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Madis Senner astutely describes some likely effects of scarcer capital on the global economy ("The Grim Shortage of Global Capital," July 28). However, the obvious source of the capital shortage is insufficient saving at prevailing interest rates. The issue is how to increase saving or reduce consumption. The United States, he suggests, should "address the budget deficit." However, improved fiscal balance requires lower government spending (unlikely) or higher taxes -- and this more probable route would reduce the private sector's ability to save. 
 Using internal financing in Germany would have a similar effect on private saving. And asset inflation in Japan is just one result of the Bank of Japan's easy-money environment of the late 1980's. Restrictive monetary policy is the appropriate response to what is fundamentally rooted in excessive monetary growth.
Yes, the supply of capital is shrinking just when the world needs it most. But economists and policy makers must resist the temptation to precipitously implement "solutions" to a problem that is poorly understood.
 
ANDREW VOGEL
New York, July 29

HEADLINE: HAITIANS EXPELLED BY SANTO DOMINGO

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BON REPOS, Haiti

 BODY:
The Dominican Republic has expelled thousands of Haitian sugar plantation workers in recent weeks, inflaming long-latent enmities and suspicions in the two countries that share a single Caribbean island.
The Haitian authorities say that more than 10,000 people have been forced to return to this poor and densely populated country since mid-June, among them many who left Haiti so long ago that they no longer have homes or close relatives here. 
 Officials in Santo Domingo, the Dominican capital, say the blame belongs to the new Haitian leadership, which lent its voice to the outcry by human rights organizations over the recruitment of Haitian cane cutters and their treatment in the Dominican sugar fields. The Haitians would have done better to press their complaints through quieter diplomacy, the Dominicans say.
Many Haitians view the expulsions as an effort by the Dominican Government to arouse racial and nationalistic passions as a distraction from its difficulties with striking labor unions, high unemployment, steep inflation and failing public services.
 
A Painful Separation
 For those expelled, including many of Haitian extraction who were born in the Dominican Republic or have spent most of their adult lives there, the crisis has meant painful separation from relatives and a bewildering return to a country they hardly know.
"They didn't tell us anything," said Hermanis Francois in Spanish, the language he speaks best, as he squatted on the ground at the Haitian repatriation center here with his wife and their few possessions at his side. The grizzled, 50-year-old man, who left Haiti 34 years ago to cut sugar cane, said that one day recently "the Dominicans just rounded us up and carted us off."
"Everything we owned was left behind."
Mireille Sam, director of the Bon Repos center, which has temporarily housed and fed more than 3,200 of the uprooted Haitians, said, "Many of these people were just brought to the border and dropped off, told to get out and left to their own devices." She added that after short stays at the center, because of Haiti's limited means, the refugees are sent off to uncertain new lives in the squalor of the Port-au-Prince slums or to the countryside.
 
Under Sharp Attack
 In recent years, the Dominican Government has come under sharp attack by human rights groups condemning what they assert is the state-owned sugar industry's widespread use of child labor, low salaries, restricted freedom of movement and deceptive recruitment drives of Haitians often resembling outright abduction.
Facing punitive trade sanctions over the issue in the United States Congress, Dominican officials have aggressively rebutted the assertions.
Shortly after the newly elected Haitian Government of the left-leaning Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide began echoing comparisons by human rights groups of the working conditions of Haitians in the Dominican sugar industry with those of slavery, however, the deeply conservative 84-year-old Dominican President, Joaquin Balaguer, already wary of his neighbor, responded angrily by ordering the expulsion of Haitian plantation workers under the age of 16 and over 60.
While Mr. Balaguer seemed genuinely offended, some Dominican observers say the President's expulsion order was not made without domestic political calculations.
 
Sentiments Running High
 "The President has tapped into the historical struggle between the two countries, indirectly promoting the old feeling that those guys over there are inferior, yet they want to dominate us," said a Dominican academic, requesting anonymity. "At the same time, Balaguer is saying to the Haitians, 'Wait a minute, if you pressure me, I'll drop a lot of people on your hands and cause you some real problems.' "
With sentiments running high, human rights monitors say, predominantly Haitian neighborhoods in the Dominican Republic, rather than the sugar estates, soon became the focus of surprise raids by police officers and soldiers, whose actions they assert quickly exceeded the bounds of the President's expulsion decree.
"It seems from the pattern I have seen that they have been focusing on the Haitians who are best established, and this has included people of all ages," said Sarah DeCosse, an observer with the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.

HEADLINE: Optimism Is Disappearing For a Solid Recovery Soon

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The economic recovery that had been widely expected since late spring now seems much less certain, raising the likelihood that a strong rebound in hiring, wages and retail sales will not occur before the fall, at the earliest.
Many economists have reached that conclusion in recent days after confronting statistics and surveys that measure the economy's recent performance. Economic conditions have clearly improved since the spring, the data show, but the progress toward recovery seems to have temporarily halted. 
 "We are going to live for a while in a situation in which it is hard to discern good times," said James P. Smith, a senior economist at the Rand Corporation.
For Mr. Smith and others, the issue is not whether the United States is recovering from recession; it surely will, he says. "The real question is whether our incomes are going to grow at a faster rate than inflation," he said. "If not, or if the gain is only 1 percent a year, who wants to wait 20 years to feel better?"
 
Apprehension About Jobs
 The public is clearly uneasy about the direction of the economy, according to the University of Michigan's monthly surveys of consumer attitudes. The surveys show Americans apprehensive about their lagging incomes, the banking crisis, the cutbacks in public services by states and municipalities and the security of their jobs. All of those concerns are likely to be exacerbated if little new wealth is added to the economy in the next one or two years.
"It is not that people fear that the unemployment rate will rise more," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan surveys. "It is that they don't expect many people on layoff to be recalled or new jobs to open up."
The unemployment rate was 6.8 percent last month, compared with 5.4 percent in July 1990, the first month of the recession.
The Bush Administration and many forecasters had interpreted an upturn in industrial production and in the sale of cars, appliances and homes that began in May as a sign that a robust recovery might have begun. Since July, sales of many items have tended to level off, and two events in the last 10 days suggest the recovery could be in trouble.
 
51,000 Jobs Disappear
 The first was a Labor Department report, released on Aug. 2, showing that 51,000 jobs had disappeared in July; it was the third time in four months that layoffs reduced the number of job holders. Then, on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates to stimulate borrowing and the economic activity that lending makes possible. The action was a tacit acknowledgment that the robust recovery Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, had been expecting in mid-July has not yet materialized.
In case anyone missed the point, the Federal Reserve released on Wednesday a survey of regional business conditions that characterized the recovery as slow and unevenly distributed across the nation. A similar regional survey, published in June, had been more optimistic. The Midwest and the Southwest, while in recession, show more strength than the hard-hit Northeast and other states on the East and West coasts.
 
Politics of a Weak Recovery
 A weak recovery, running into the 1992 Presidential election year, would work against President Bush in his bid for re-election. Administration officials applauded the Federal Reserve's decision last week to reduce a key short-term interest rate. They have been pushing for more more economic growth than the Federal Reserve considers to be possible and this issue is undoubtedly discussed by Mr. Greenspan and Michael Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, in their frequent contacts with each other.
Still the task of reawakening the economy is more difficult than usual, many economists say, because this ninth recovery from recession since World War II has some unprecedented aspects that could delay an upturn. The numerous bank failures, the cutbacks in credit and the collapse of commercial building construction -- unknown since the Depression -- are, by any account, dragging down the nation in ways economists say they cannot easily quantify.
Employment trends are also a puzzle for Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The unemployment rate is not rising because so few people are entering the labor force to seek jobs, she notes. The smaller number of young people now coming of working age in the post-baby boom generation is only part of the explanation.
 
Fewer Women Go to Work
 For some reason -- perhaps the recession itself or the stagnant wage growth of recent years -- the percentage of American women entering the labor force has stopped rising and teen-agers are dropping out. Among the nation's 16- to 19-year-olds, only 50 percent are holding or seeking jobs, the lowest level in 20 years. The percentage stood at 52.5 percent a year earlier.
Mrs. Norwood says the decline has come partly because the service companies that hire young people -- in particular, retail stores and restaurants -- are reducing their work forces to cut costs and become more efficient.
"Looking at the numbers, I don't see any strong growth in employment," Mrs. Norwood added. "It is good that we are not going down any further, but I don't see growth."
Nevertheless, the economy did hit "some sort of a bottom in April or May," said Robert Hall of Stanford University, who is also chairman of the Business Cycle Dating Committee, a group of prominent economists who set for the record books the dates when recessions begin and end. The committee fixed July 1990 as the start of the current recession, but Professor Hall shrinks from suggesting that April or May of this year will turn out to be its end.
 
No Telling Where the Bottom Lies
 "We are by no means prepared to say that April or May was the trough," he said. "If the economy turned down again, and fell lower, that lower period would become the trough."
What puzzles Professor Hall is a trend that appeared early last year, before the economic and political shock of the Persian Gulf crisis. Consumer spending, as a percent of personal income, fell below the postwar norm and has not moved back up, he said. If personal income were to rise -- and the improvement this year has been meager -- consumption might not rise with it, Professor Hall says.
"There is this unknown element in consumption that we have to feel properly humble about," he said.
A rebound in consumption is the great hope of kicking off a strong recovery. More consumption -- of cars, appliances, clothing and many other products -- means rising production, more jobs and higher incomes, which can be spent on more consumption. Or it can be saved, to be indirectly invested in machinery, roads, public works, factories and the like.
 
Absence of Coordination
 "There is not today that growing coordination among the parts that is the essence of recoveries from recession, and there is not that sense of a recovery spreading," said Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a business research organization.
Whatever the obstacles to spreading recovery, the 52 prominent forecasters surveyed each month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, of Sedona, Ariz., had some second thoughts in their forecasts in the August survey, released yesterday. In the July survey, 20 had raised their forecasts of economic growth in 1991 while only 5 had reduced their estimates. But in August, this was reversed: 22 forecasters made downward revisions, while only 14 raised their estimates.
"They are back-tracking on the modest economic growth that they had been predicting," said Robert Eggert, publisher of the monthly survey. "They are back-tracking from modest growth to less than modest growth, but not another dip into recession."

HEADLINE: Even Weicker Can't Overshadow Budget-Fallout Concerns

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Ct. Aug. 9

 BODY:
Reporters and lobbyists crowded around a television in the Capitol on Wednesday to watch the speech in which Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. would say whether he was signing or vetoing the third budget passed by the Legislature. Suddenly the screen was blacked out, then almost entirely filled by a broad back as someone stepped right in front of the television camera in the Governor's office.
It was Mr. Weicker, so large that he seemed to take up all of the space in his office. 
 Minutes later, Mr. Weicker had added to his larger-than-life reputation with his third budget veto, standing against the politics of business as usual. Nearly six weeks into its fiscal year, Connecticut remained without a budget, but he had kept alive his hopes of achieving one that would help pull the state out of recession and deficit, with an income tax if need be.
But the continued budget battle also renewed questions about how Connecticut reached this point, and how Mr. Weicker's term as an Independent governor, and the legislative process itself, might be affected by the outcome.
 
For Some, No Looking Ahead
 For the Governor and his staff, still deep in the delicate task of trying to convert Democrats and Republicans from their anti-income-tax faith, it is premature to look beyond the budget. It is clear enough that a victory would help, and that a loss, or a budget that did not resolve the state's fiscal problems, would hurt. "It's way, way too early," said his press secretary, Avice Meehan.
Others, though, are already asking what lessons can be learned, and what scars might remain, from this test of wills.
"Anyone who's in public life has given some thought to the long-term effect of this deadlock on the state and the political future, or lack thereof, of the various players," said John F. Droney Jr., the Democratic state chairman, whose party has split over the income-tax issue.
For many people, the budget debate has been a brush-up course on the political and economic diversity of this small state, from wealthy Fairfield County, with its hint of a New York accent and desire to reduce the state's high tax on investment income, to rural eastern Connecticut, with the beginnings of a Rhode Island twang and envy of its neighbor's lower sales tax.
 
Political Lessons
 It has also been a civics lesson, as Mr. Weicker, whose third-party campaign attacked politics and politicians, has had to build a working coalition from scratch, without a single member of his own party. Party leaders and political scientists look back to the election, which Mr. Weicker won with 41 percent of the vote by campaigning, after 18 years in the Senate, as an anti-politician independent.
Sarah Morehouse, a professor of political science at the University of Connecticut, said Mr. Weicker began his term without the natural coalition of supporters that officeholders assemble in winning their party's nomination and campaigning together. Normally, Professor Morehouse said, "the governor will have people who are bound to him, who have followed him through the electoral process, and there's been some mutual give and take."
Mr. Weicker, she said, "belittled and maligned the parties during the election, and he may have thought that was the reason he was elected."
"That to my mind was not the way to start building a coalition for a very forward program," she said.
 
Breaking the Rules
 Mr. Droney and his Republican counterpart, Representative Richard Foley Jr. of Oxford, also return to the election. Mr. Weicker was the victor, they said, and by the rules of politics it was up to him, and necessary for him, to reach out and start building a consensus. Instead, he continued appealing to the public and attacking the parties.
"Weicker has demonized political parties and political leaders, but they have existed in this country for hundreds of years for good reasons," Mr. Droney said. "One reason is the ability to coalesce votes around an idea and promote it until it becomes law."
Mr. Foley, whose party Mr. Weicker deserted for his run for governor, also criticized him for not reaching out. But Mr. Foley did not think the rest of Mr. Weicker's term would be as brutal as the budget battle.
"Time is the great healer in politics," he said, predicting that coalitions of Democrats and Republicans would continue to shift on various issues, in support of Mr. Weicker and against him, during his remaining three years.
Morton J. Tenzer, an associate professor of political science at the University of Connecticut, gave Mr. Weicker good marks despite his own doubts last November about how an Independent governor would fare.
 
Support for Approach
 With a party behind him, Professor Tenzer said, Mr. Weicker probably would have won an income tax by now. But he thought the process worked well up until the budget impasse. And unlike many people, including Mr. Droney and Mr. Foley, who accuse the Governor of arrogance, he said, "I don't think his personality has been harmful."
"Some people have complained he hasn't compromised," he said, "but that's because they want him to give up."
Mr. Foley said the budget process may have been permanently affected by the Legislature breaking the taboo of starting a fiscal year without a budget, which he said is likely to be repeated.
"I truly don't believe it will ever go this far again in my lifetime," he said. "But it does make individuals involved in the process less likely to reach an agreement, meaning you have to exert more leverage or leave more on the table."
Mr. Tenzer thinks the Democratic Party is also at risk, because of the depth of feelings in the split between the conservatives who represent the state party's tradition, and liberals who advocate an income tax.
The budget debate has shown the party's conservative leaders to be outnumbered in their own caucuses. "What might happen now," he said, "is that the liberal Democratic majorities in the caucus might eventually seize control of the party."
But the electoral implications of that are serious. The party's candidate last year, Bruce A. Morrison, was from the liberal side, and he finished with barely 20 percent of the vote.
Mr. Droney, who has battled some of his local party chairmen who favor an income tax, played down the split's significance. "There have always been strongly income-tax people," he said, "who have made no bones about it."
