HEADLINE: Kenyan Corruption Is Aired in Death Inquiry

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 10

 BODY:
A long judicial inquiry into the killing of a popular Foreign Minister last year has brought into the open allegations of corrupt practices by Kenya's second most powerful politician and an account of his stormy relationship with the slain official.
While the damaging testimony about Energy Minister Nicholas Biwott has come from a hardly impartial source -- a sister of the slain minister -- the fact that the charges have been allowed to be publicly aired and reported in Kenya's tighly controlled press suggests that President Daniel arap Moi is seeking to limit the political damage that Mr. Biwott's behavior is causing to his Government. 
 Mr. Biwott, who has yet to comment publicly on the allegations, has long been one of Mr. Moi's closest political associates, and international financial experts say he has amassed a large fortune from foreign investments and other dealings abroad.
It is those kinds of dealings that were at the center of the corruption charges leveled this week at the long-running inquiry into the death of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko, whose partly burned body was found about four miles from his home in western Kenya in February 1990, shortly after he returned from a trip to the United States. Mr. Ouko, who was considered an articulate and effective spokesman for Kenya abroad, had been shot through the head.
The allegations by Mr. Ouko's sister, Dorothy Randiak, that Mr. Biwott had demanded a share in a foreign venture as a condition for letting the project proceed seemed to shed some light on why Kenya, like many other African countries, has had trouble attracting investment.
Mrs. Randiak testified that the Foreign Minister had described Mr. Biwott and corruption as synonymous. She said Mr. Ouko had told her that his criticism of Kenyan corruption "had earned him enemies," and that he considered Mr. Biwott to be "dangerous." Mrs. Randiak said the two men had quarreled during an official trip to Washington because Mr. Biwott envied the special security arrangements granted to Mr. Ouko.
Offering an example of what she said was corruption, she testified that Mr. Biwott had demanded an interest in a molasses plant that an Italian company was thinking of opening in Kisumu in western Kenya, the home constituency of Mr. Ouko. Mrs. Randiak said her brother told her that Mr. Biwott's demands had thwarted the project because the company refused to comply.
"Dr. Ouko was complaining that this was giving Kenya a bad image in the Western world on the one hand, and that it was also making his work of formulating foreign policy very difficult," she said.
The nature of the allegations against Mr. Biwott did not surprise Kenyans. What did raise eyebrows was that Mrs. Randiak was allowed to present her accusations despite objections from the Energy Minister's lawyers.
Some people were also startled by the prominent display of her testimony on front pages of the three daily newspapers, including the Kenya Times, which is owned by the governing party.
Stories that the Government deems contrary to its interests are often suppressed through telephone calls from the President's office.
Mr. Biwott's friendship with President Moi goes back to the 1950's, when Mr. Biwott helped Mr. Moi in his first campaign for a parliamentary seat. Both men are from the same tribe, the Kalengin, a pastoral people based in the Rift Valley. Now Kenyans are wondering if Mr. Moi is hearing complaints from the Kalengin people about Mr. Biwott's practices, and is finding his friend an embarrassment.
Mr. Biwott's financial dealings have been publicly discussed on one previous occasion, during a debate earlier this year in Parliament on a bill imposing a new tax on foreign oil companies.
The tax revenue was to go into a fund at the Energy Ministry that would be personally administered by Mr. Biwott. Some members of Parliament said that such an arrangement was like giving Mr. Biwott a blank check. But the debate was cut off, and the parliamentary bill was approved unanimously.

HEADLINE: New York Leads Big Cities in Robbery Rate, but Drops in Murders

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
New York City led the nation's 25 largest cities in robberies last year, claiming the dubious distinction for the second straight year at a time when reports of violent crime were surging across America, an analysis of data released today by Federal officials indicates.
In a city where crime has become a dominant theme of private and political discourse, a record 100,280 robberies were reported to the police last year -- 13.7 for every 1,000 residents, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's annual Uniform Crime Reports for 1990. 
 But despite a record 2,262 homicides last year, New York City dropped from ninth to 10th in murders per capita, and its homicide rate was only slightly higher than the average for the country's 25 largest cities, an analysis of the Federal data by The New York Times showed.
New York City had 30.9 murders for every 100,000 residents, just above the big-city average of 29.2, and would have ranked 11th, behind Chicago, but for the 87 deaths in the Happy Land social club fire, The Times analysis showed.
 
Five-Year Trends
 Using 1990 census data and Federal and local crime statistics, the analysis calculated and ranked the per capita robbery and murder rates for the nation's 25 largest cities over the last five years, and ranked robbery and murder rates for New York's five boroughs for 1990.
Tracking the five-year trends, New York's robbery rate turned down in 1986, but has been rising steadily since and passed previously top-ranked Detroit in 1988, the analysis showed. New York's murder rate has shown a steady though gradual rise since 1986, but has been lower than those for Washington, New Orleans, Detroit, Dallas and Baltimore.
Within New York City, The Times analysis showed, the Bronx had the highest murder rate, with 54.2 homicides for every 100,000 residents, followed by Manhattan with 33.8, Brooklyn with 33.3, Queens with 16 and Staten Island with 7.7.
But Manhattan was found to lead New York's boroughs in its rate of reported robberies last year, with 18.1 for every 1,000 residents, followed by 15.8 for Brooklyn, 14.8 for the Bronx, 9.3 for Queens and 2.7 for Staten Island.
In the nation, Washington, continuing a five-year climb, recorded the highest murder rate among major cities in 1990, with 77.8 killings for every 100,000 residents. The nation's capital was followed by New Orleans, Detroit, Dallas, Baltimore, Houston, Cleveland, Memphis, Philadelphia and New York.
 
Worst Robbery Rates
 The major cities with the highest robbery rates after New York were Chicago, Baltimore, Detroit, New Orleans, Washington, Dallas, Boston, Los Angeles and, tied for 10th, Cleveland and San Francisco. All but the last two exceeded the average rate for the 25 largest cities -- 9.7 robberies for every 1,000 residents.
The F.B.I.'s Uniform Crime Reports for 1990, a 365-page compendium titled "Crime in the United States," was issued by the bureau's Director, William S. Sessions. Its voluminous data are based on crimes reported to 16,000 law-enforcement agencies and the report is regarded as the nation's most comprehensive survey of criminal activity and trends.
Across the nation, the report said, overall violent crime increased 11 percent last year over 1989, with homicides and forcible rape each up 9 percent and robbery and aggravated assault each up 11 percent. In other categories, burglaries decreased 3 percent, auto theft rose 5 percent, larceny was up 1 percent and arson rose 3 percent.
The report said that firearms were used in 3 of every 5 murders in the United States, that 78 percent of the victims were men and that only 14 percent of the victims were murdered by strangers.
 
Most Women Killed by Men
 It also said that, in situations with a single victim and a single offender, 93 percent of the black murder victims were killed by blacks and that 86 percent of the white victims were slain by whites. While 85 percent of the men were killed by other men, it said, 9 out of every 10 women were slain by men.
Experts have cited many factors, including surges in drug use and drug disputes, for the rising homicide rates. Thomas A. Reppetto, a criminologist who heads the Citizens Crime Commission of New York, a private organization that analyzes criminal justice issues, said one explanation for New York City's high robbery rate lay in the way people get around.
"This is less of an auto town than other places," he said in an interview. "People take subways and other public transportation. They walk a lot. They are much more vulnerable to robbery than people who ride around enclosed in iron boxes."
The F.B.I. report said some of the complex factors that accounted for crime rates included the density, composition and stability of populations; modes of transportation; economic and cultural conditions; climate; the effective strength of law-enforcement agencies; attitudes of citizens, and the policies of government.

HEADLINE: Canadian Seeks 3d Term Amid Drop in Polls

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, after months of disappointing economic news and declining support in the polls, came to Canada's most populous city this week to fire up his party's faithful and open a campaign for a third five-year term as the national leader.
Yet against the fanfare of his Progressive Conservative Party's convention, the last one before it must face voters within two years, another drama was playing outsidethe hall where protesters were making their own pitch -- to dump the Mr. Mulroney. 
 The conflicts on the shores of Lake Ontario touched the issues that are likely to dominate a new national campaign from Vancouver to the Maritimes -- unemployment, free trade, privatization, taxes, high interest rates, deficit spending and national unity.
At one point the police had to intervene to keep unemployed construction workers away from the Tory delegates after one of the delegates had taunted the workers: "Why don't you get a job?"
High interest rates have cut construction activity in Canada, and construction unemployment, depending on which specific sector, is running at from 20 percent to 60 percent.
For the nation as a whole, joblessness is still running at a six-year high of 10.5 percent, almost half as high as the official rate in the United States.
The protesters, who besides construction workers included truckers, disabled people, provincial public servants, feminists and farmers, had set up in a place beside the convention center that they called Mulroneyville.
From the main street, marked by a signpost labeled "Layoff Lane," , people were invited to mail a letter to the Prime Minister, telling him what a lousy job he was doing.
 But inside the convention hall it was a far different story. The 2,500 delegates gave their leader one standing ovation after the other as he outlined his strategy to keep the party governing until the turn of the century.
 
Counting on Economic Recovery
 "They think of him as some kind of magician," said Gerry Caplan, a political analyst who used to advise the New Democratic Party. "Remember, before the last election he was also lower than a snake's belly in the polls, and he brought it off."
For victory this time he is counting on three elements: recovery from the recession; declines in the federal budget deficit and credible progress in resolving the constitutional crisis to keep the country from splitting apart.
"I am here before you," he told the cheering delegates on Wednesday, "bloodied and sometimes bowed, but completely determined to fight another winning battle for a united Canada."
Then on Friday in a dramatic show of solidarity behind the Prime Minister, the delegates voted 92 percent in favor of recognizing Quebec as a "unique society" with the right to choose its own future.
Although the resolution is mainly symbolic, it sends a signal to Quebec that while the French-speaking province is free to pull out out of the confederation if it so chooses, the governing party is going to pull out all stops to accommodate Quebec's distinctness within proposed new federal structures.
Although economic recovery has proved slow and faltering here as in the United States, the Prime Minister insisted in his speech to the delegates that the recession was over and that "we'll bounce into the election in 1993 with prosperity all over."
It was the first time that he has mentioned when elections might be held. The mandate expires in the fall of 1993, but under the Parliamentary system, the Prime Minister has the flexibility to call for elections any time within the five-year eriod.
The reference suggests that despite his buoyancy at the Conservatives' convention, Mr. Mulroney still thinks he will need all the time he can muster to achieve the desired turnaround in his popularity.
"What we saw here," said Hershell Ezrin, a former Liberal Party strategist, "was a massive effort at resurrection. But conversion even on the road to Damascus has proven difficult."

HEADLINE: PAN AMERICAN GAMES;
Come the Revolutions: Cuba Is Bowling Again

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Once it was a sport for the elite of Cuba: glittering indoor palaces where the clatter of the ball hitting the 10 pins mixed with the tinkle of the rum hitting the ice cubes.
Come the revolution, the bowling apparatus nearly disappeared from the island, no doubt replaced by agencies that served the people better. 
 There was one six-lane center in the town of Sancti Spiritus, on the road to Cienfuegos. There is also the prevailing legend that Fidel Castro maintained two lanes somewhere in his living quarters, but he has said he gave up the sport years ago.
 
The Cool Clatter of the Pins
 Now, the clatter can be heard again. Bowling is back: a 24-lane establishment, Bolera Panamericana, is in operation, at first for bowlers competing in the Pan American Games, but soon for the people of Cuba.
They stand in line in the heat and the humidity, waiting for a free seat in the air-conditioned marvel.
"I'm a baseball fan," said Rosa Martinez of Marianao, waiting patiently in the boiling sunlight. "I've never seen bowling, but I could learn."
Once inside, they watch bowlers in bright shirts -- the Mexicans have a striking Aztec warrior on their backs -- throwing highly respectable scores in the high 100's, all day long.
The handsome center is just another sign of the massive commitment of the Cuban Government to produce medals and provide recreation in a country short on food and gasoline.
When bowling was made an official part of the 1991 games, the Cubans promised to build a center. But as the Cuban economy tightened, there were doubts.
"We were hoping to have help from the U.S., but because of the blockade, that was impossible," said Maria del Carmen Rubio, a director of the center.
The United States Tenpin Bowling Federation wanted to help, "but we had a policy that we would not try to get around our Government embargo," said Gerald L. Koenig, the executive director.
 
Enter the Japanese
 Eventually, the Cubans contracted with a Japanese company to put the bowling center inside a large airy building next to the volleyball arena.
"They took 72 days," said Sergi Vega Urrutia, another director of the center, shaking his head in admiration.
The Japanese sold them 24 reconditioned lanes, with pinspotters and stations for the balls, and seats and tables. It is bright and clean and spacious. There is a bar right behind the middle lanes, although the Pan American bowlers cannot have drinks during competition.
The price for the entire project, including a fascinating Museum of Cuban Sport upstairs, is put at 4 million pesos, which could be anywhere between $600,000 and $1 million, depending on how much value is given to the peso.
The final necessity was a machine to apply the "dressing," the oil coating on the wooden surface. The U.S. federation sent over a $10,000 high-tech machine, developed by John Davis of Florida, but under American Government policy, the machine must come back on the same cargo ship on which it was sent.
 
Bowling, Anyone?
 Once the center was built, though, Cuban athletes had to learn how to bowl. Sports officials began to recruit athletes like Lorenzo Oliva, who plays soccer for a local club, and has a trim midfielder's build.
"I first heard about bowling a year ago," Oliva said. "I think it is a sport of much intelligence, and it has a great tradition. Also, it is the only sport that permits the whole family to play."
Oliva joined a Cuban program that sent athletes to Venezuela. His average was 170 this week, at the low end of the spectrum that had four men over 200 and the highest woman at 191.
Most of the participants in the Pan American competition are the top bowlers in their countries, but the United States bowlers are amateurs, not members of the professional tour. Still, two top amateur women have recently moved into the pro circuit and done well, and Lynda Norry, 23, of Concord, Calif., is thinking about it.
Norry recently won the U.S. Olympic Festival in California with an average of 201, higher than any man or woman. She is here, wearing a brace for tendinitis on her right wrist and in 10th place at 183.
"This is nothing but good news that bowling is a medal sport here," Norry said. "It's too bad it's not a sport in 1992 at Barcelona but we're hoping for Atlanta in 1996."
Asked why bowling should be included with basketball and track and field and swimming, Norry said, "I always tell people, 'You go get a 16-pound ball and bowl 10 games every day. You have to use your muscles and you have to use your brain.' "
The competition runs through Monday. Then the bowlers go back to their home centers all over the Americas, leaving the Bolera to the people of Cuba.

HEADLINE: BOATING;
Any Spare Change? The America's Cup Defense Wants You!

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
The costs of competing in and staging an America's Cup yacht racing series have spiraled in the last decade. But financial support for the event, known throughout its history as a rich man's sport, has not kept pace with prices.
Dennis Conner, the cup's most successful skipper, has found it difficult to raise money for his 1992 Stars & Stripes campaign. His budget, downgraded from $30 million to $20 million in the last year, has stalled out at little more than $10 million, the amount raised so far.
 
Might Be Forced to Go With One Boat
 The lack of money has forced Conner to put off building a second boat. His team has set Sept. 1 as the deadline for deciding whether to go ahead with a second boat. 
 Jerry La Dow, Team Dennis Conner's executive director, said in a recent interview that the Stars & Stripes defense syndicate will carry on with one boat if it has to. "It's not going to make us feel as good as if we had a new boat," La Dow said. "But we're not discouraged; we've got a good boat."
The decision on a new boat is being made with caution. "The question is, How late can we wait?" said La Dow. "The longer we wait, the better the design will be. It's an evolutionary process. But this is an expensive game; these boats cost $3 to $4 million apiece."
 
Plenty of Prototypes in Past
 In past cup campaigns, in 1980, 1983 and 1987, Conner built two or three prototype yachts. The 12-Meter designs cost about $500,000 each. Conner used the boats as trial horses, ultimately choosing the fastest yacht in his stable for the final cup matches.
Conner's new 78-foot International America's Cup Class yacht made its debut at the I.A.C.C. world championship in San Diego last May. The boat won a berth in the semifinal series, but Conner dropped out of the final races rather than risk a breakdown. It was a calculated move in a campaign preoccupied with survival.
Conner spends more time fund-raising than sailing. Pepsi-Cola, Cadillac and American Airlines have signed on as $3 million "Gold Level" sponsors. But he has been unable to persuade others to step in at that level.
 
$4 Million in '83 to $40 Million in '92
 His original cup plan, which called for three new boats, vanished amid the recession. "Capital has dried up in the last year," said La Dow. "That scares corporate America. They think long and hard about it. It's a lot easier to say no."
The $4 million budgets that supported cup syndicates in 1983 have escalated to $40 million in 1992. The Italian and Japanese challenger teams, both with high-end budgets, are building up to four I.A.C.C. yachts for their 1992 campaigns.
William Koch, a wealthy businessman from Palm Beach, Fla., is financing the only other cup defense team, America 3. Koch plans to fund about two-thirds of his $40 million budget privately. The rest is being raised by outside donations.
 
Organizing Committee Jumps In
 The America's Cup Organizing Committee, the managers for the 1992 race series, agreed two years ago to stay out of the corporate arena. The group was under pressure from defense teams after the same money.
Last week, the organizing committee said it couldn't hold back any longer. Strapped by financial shortfalls of its own, the committee announced that it planned to go after international companies for support.
"Revenue has sharply declined," said Tom Mitchell, the A.C.O.C.'s assistant general manager, in a telephone interview last week. "The only way we can survive is to sharply decline our expenses."
The cup event, which lasts five months, is expected to cost about $25 million. The A.C.O.C. expected to pay for it with money from San Diego's port authority, and from television rights, licensing agreements and merchandising.
Mitchell insists that organizers will not infringe on Conner's or Koch's fund-raising efforts. "There are international sponsors who want to be event sponsors," said Mitchell. "They are companies who would not want to be associated with any one syndicate because the firms have offices all over the world. They're there for the taking, and we're going to take them."
The committee announced last Thursday that it was laying off seven staff employees. Of the $9 million it has spent to prepare for the race series this winter in San Diego, the committee owes creditors more than $3 million.
Jet Ruban Bleu, the 82-foot powerboat designed to break the trans-Atlantic speed record, left Ambrose Light off Sandy Hook, N.J., at 7:04 A.M. Friday morning. But Serge Medac, Jet Ruban's skipper, was forced to give up the attempt yesterday afternoon when the crew discovered a leak in one of the boat's portholes. The crew feared that incoming water might damage the boat's electronics. Jet Ruban turned back at 2 P.M., heading for St. Pierre, a small island south of Newfoundland. The French-built craft and its crew of four had wanted to beat a time of 3 days 7 hours, the record set in 1990 by the 243-foot ferryboat, Hoverspeed Great Britain.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dennis Conner and crew competing on his 78-foot International America's Cup Class yacht in San Diego in May. (Mike Powell/AllSport)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players Association Priority: Taking Care of Business

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Few American unions can boast of being as successful a conduit of cash to their membership as the Major League Baseball Players Association.
The association has become a super-union: a savvy bargaining unit that has won nearly all its battles, and a business agent capitalizing on baseball's licensing mania. No other sports union plays both roles so well. 
 The union has capitalized lucratively on baseball's role as a marketing magnet. Hundreds of companies want a piece of baseball. To depict a player's face on products, or use his name or biographical data, companies must deal with the union. To pair faces with team logos and uniforms, Major League Baseball Properties, the licensing arm of major league baseball, must also be paid.
As administrator of the program that licenses players' faces on products like trading cards, posters and board and video games, the union has paid out $141.9 million in royalties, plus interest, to the players since 1986 -- $124.7 million since early 1990, according to the union's financial filings with the United States Department of Labor. The union's licensing program excludes individual endorsement deals, like Bo Jackson's Nike commercials.
"The increased revenues simply track baseball's increased popularity," said Donald Fehr, the union's executive director and general counsel, "and the fact that the Topps monopoly on trading cards was broken" in 1981.
Early each year, the union's executive board decides how to distribute royalties to the players. Over the last few years, in anticipation of a lockout or a strike, it withheld $76.8 million. This would have been used primarily to make periodic payments to players had last year's lockout by owners continued into the regular season.
When the lockout ended, the harbored cash was paid quickly in lump sums. The most recent payment was made in March, $36.7 million, or about $36,700 for each of the estimated 1,000 eligible players, managers, coaches and trainers.
It is not a major windfall in the context of $900,000-plus average salaries, but somewhat more than extra pocket change.
Licensing fees have greatly augmented the dues ($15 from each union member for every day of a season on a major league roster) to help finance three collusion cases; the 1990 Basic Agreement negotiations; arbitration; licensing; a pension for the union's former executive director, Marvin Miller, and staff bonuses.
"To do what we do without the licensing revenues," said Fehr, "would require a drastically different dues structure."
The 1985, 1986 and 1987 collusion cases cost $4.6 million to pursue, including $2.9 million for the 1986 case. But the union received a huge return when an arbitrator levied a $280-million penalty against the owners.
 
A Comfortable Retirement
 The union also spent $396,791 between 1988 and 1990 on the Basic Agreement negotiations; $114,000 on last year's staff bonuses; $735,453 on arbitration since 1986 and $101,187 last year to administer the licensing program.
 
A Comfortable Retirement
 And Fehr, who represents about 1,000 players, has benefited with a salary higher than most of the top officers of blue-collar unions with tens of thousands of workers. He will receive $500,000 this year, up from $475,000 in 1990. By comparison, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. paid Lane Kirkland $175,000 in 1990, the Teamsters paid William McCarthy $283,483 and the United Mine Workers paid Rich Trumka $79,214.
"Fehr's salary is a lot," said Greg Tarpinian, senior economist of the nonprofit Labor Research Association, "but it's relative when you look at what his members make." Besides, he added: "Nobody wants to license the rights to a machinist's face."
Miller, Fehr's predecessor, is well cared for in retirement: his annual pension of $90,000 has been financed with four annuities that cost the union $1 million.
When Miller came to the union in 1966, its finances were not so flush. Only $5,400 remained in its bank account. Miller scotched a players' proposal to finance union activities with $150,000 from All-Star Game proceeds because it violated the Taft-Hartley Law.
Miller negotiated a licensing program with Coca-Cola to put player pictures underneath bottle caps. It raised $60,000 in 1966, crucial financing until a new dues system brought in operating cash a year later.
Topps, the trading card company based in Brooklyn, was the sole maker of trading cards then, but paid no royalties, only nominal flat fees to the players. In 1968, after players refused to renew their contracts with the company, it began paying royalties.
The Topps monopoly was broken by Fleer in a 1981 antitrust suit. Shortly after that, Fleer and Donruss became Topps' first marketplace rivals in the card business, and were joined later by Score and Upper Deck.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Americans Confront the Debt the House Built

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
THINK of them as little S.& L.'s or insurance corporations, Americans who earned big and invested bigger, especially in real estate, in the booming 1980's, and who are now on the recessionary rocks. They are the burgeoning number of people who are finding that the house they bought is worth less than they owe on it, their credit cards are borrowed to the limit, and they are going bankrupt.
The number of Americans declaring personal bankruptcy has grown by 152 percent in six years, from 285,000 in 1984 to 718,000 last year, and the trend shows no sign of abating immediately, according to the American Financial Services Association, a Washington trade group. 
 The figures tell only part of what is going on in the evolving relationship between Americans and their debts, the experts say. Far from being an indelible personal, social and economic stain, many bankrupts are increasingly likely to regard defaulting on loans as a temporary setback, even a smart financial strategy, considering how quickly lenders extend new credit to former deadbeats. And as the filings increase, the stigma of bankruptcy fades.
"The shame of bankruptcy does not seem to be as great as it once was," said Dr. Robert W. Johnson, senior research associate at the Purdue University business school's Credit Research Center in West Lafayette, Ind. "Consumers nowadays seem more concerned about losing their credit and they are learning that you can go bankrupt and get credit back very quickly."
In business bankruptcy, a debtor seeks to delay payments to keep a business, but a Chapter 7 personal bankruptcy wipes out a person's debt, except for taxes, alimony and child support payments. The same exceptions apply to a Chapter 13 bankruptcy, in which an individual agrees to pay off a portion of the total debt in installments. While the assets of a Chapter 7 filer are typically seized and applied toward debt payment,, a recent United States Supreme Court ruling made such a bankruptcy less onerous by making it easier to retain homes and some investments.
Dr. Johnson said that a main factor behind the banktrupcy boom is devaluation of what is the biggest investment for most people: their houses.
"The New England states had the highest rate of housing market loss and the sharpest increase in bankruptcy filings," he said. "People have to move and find out they can't sell their homes for as much as they were counting on, perhaps to pay some other debts, so they file for bankruptcy."
There is some evidence that the distress is sharpest in the Northeast. In the first quarter of this year, Massachussetts, Maine, New Hampshire and Rhode Island plus Puerto Rico -- the First Federal Judicial Circuit states -- registered a 67 percent increase in personal bankruptcy filings, a total of 6,835 filings, compared with the first quarter of last year. The rest of New England and the Mid-Atlantic states showed the next highest rates, going from 14,948 filings in the first quarter of last year to 21,852 for the same period this year.
 
A Booming Business
 Nationwide, personal bankruptcies in 1990 increased by 16.4 percent over the previous year, and this year's first quarter figures are 28 percent ahead of last year's record numbers.
"I'd like to think my business is so good because of the good job we do, but it is mostly due to the fact that there are so many more foreclosures today than at any time since I started practicing, 35 years ago," said Sid Schneider, a New York City attorney who specializes in bank foreclosures of houses and co-op apartments.
"The price increases in real estate that occurred in the 1980's were not realistic," Mr. Schneider said, "but people paid them because they were earning a lot and they had a lot to spend. Now that times are bad, people aren't buying real estate, and the people who can no longer afford the houses they bought don't have anyone to sell them to."
Today's families coming in for personal financial counselling are older and better off than the usual run of families in financial trouble, said Jay Muzychenko, vice president of the National Foundation for Consumer Credit, a credit-industry-supported financial counseling service that tries to keep debtors out of the courts and abreast of their bills.
"This recession is hitting white collar workers, the middle manager types, and this is not the traditional group that has faced layoffs before," Mr. Muzychenko said. "They are people who were making more money, so they had more debt, including for real estate."
But Mr. Muzychenko and Dr. Johnson agree that there is something more than just a soft economy that has hit white collar workers harder than usual. The level of installment debt, Dr. Johnson noted for example, has increased much more modestly -- by 26 percent, to $732 billion, since 1986 -- than the number of bankruptcies. But in an era unmarked by self-denial of the trappings of comfort and leisure, credit has become easier to get as banks and lenders, themselves stung by real estate losses, look for new sources of income.
Softer lending policies may explain why bankruptcy does not always spell the end of credit worthiness. Studies have found that about 10 percent of bankrupts establish new lines of credit within six months of filing, Dr. Johnson said, a third obtain new credit within three years, and after five years half have reestablished themselves. They may not file for protection again for six years, which can give a perverse boost to someone's risk worthiness. "Some people give recent bankrupts credit because they think, well, they can't go bankrupt for another six years," he noted. "But they're still not a good bet. Our studies show that a quarter of bankrupts are back in trouble after four or five years."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Computer Age: Still a Work in Progress

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
WHEN the International Business Machines Corporation introduced its first personal computer 10 years ago tomorrow, the company hoped to sell 250,000 machines over the life of the product. Others predicted that machines would be in every home and on every desk, and those without them would be left behind in the race toward the information age.
Both predictions were wrong. The personal computer has succeeded far beyond I.B.M.'s wildest expectations, with millions sold and computers now accepted as a fact of life almost as basic as electric power. But the grander vision of a computerized society has not yet been realized. In many cases, computers have mainly been used as faster calculators and better typewriters and have not yet radically altered the way we live and work. 
 "We've mostly just used them to pave the cowpaths," said Paul Saffo, a researcher at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif. "We're mostly just doing old things in a new way." But, he added, "the main event is yet to come." Indeed, the pace of change in the next decade is expected to be as great as in the last one.
The revolution would have happened with or without I.B.M. Apple Computer, Tandy Corporation and others had been selling personal computers since 1977, and machines for hobbyists appeared two years before that. But the I.B.M. machine catalyzed the invasion of personal computers into the American workplace because it was made by the trusted provider of computers to corporate America.
 
Making Billionaires
 Since then, the world has seen an explosion of computing power. It is hard to imagine that before personal computers came along, there were only about 230,000 computers in use in the United States. Today there are more than 55 million in this country and more than 110 million in the world.
And the power of machines has continued to double every two years or so. Today's personal computer can calculate at least 12 to 20 times faster, has 64 times more internal memory and 500 times more disk storage than the original model for the same price in inflation-adjusted dollars. The most powerful personal computers are nearly 100 times as fast as the originals.
The personal computer has been the basis of a thriving industry, one still largely controlled by American companies. It has created entrepreneurial heroes and millionaire wunderkinds, like William H. Gates, the founder of the software giant Microsoft, who is worth $4 billion at age 35. But the ascendance of the desktop machines has meant painful contractions for companies that make larger computers, not the least of these being I.B.M. itself.
With the advent of the personal computer, the typewriter has completely disappeared from many offices. Middle managers do their forecasts and analyses on electronic spreadsheets. The computer helps architects design buildings, scientists analyze experiments and students simulate what it would be like to live in revolutionary France or travel at the speed of light.
It has given small businesses and individuals capabilities once reserved for large corporations, like printing newsletters and brochures. It has united people in different locations with common interests into "virtual communities" through computerized conferences. It has helped the blind to read and the disabled to work.
But as fast as the technology has advanced and diffused, expectations have advanced even faster, so that many of the predictions of the last decade now seem almost humorous and the visions unfullfilled.
Computers are still notoriously hard to use, despite all the talk about user-friendliness. Instead of creating the envisioned paperless office, the computer has only made it easier to flood the office with paper. While relieving some workers of drudgery, it has created electronic sweatshops for those who type in all the data, in some cases even monitoring their performance automatically.
Education has not been transformed by computers, in part because there are not enough machines in schools and in part because the ones that are there are often used merely as electronic flashcards. But it was probably unrealistic to think that any machine could have that much impact on what is a human-oriented process.
Nor are many households doing their banking or shopping on home computers. In fact, for most people, there is still no compelling reason to have a computer in the home in the same way that it is necessary to have a phone or a television.
Even in business, economists say that the overall productivity of office workers has not improved much, despite the investment of hundreds of billions of dollars in computers in the last decade. Productivity in the service industries is rising less than 1 percent a year, compared with 4 percent in manufacturing, said Stephen Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Part of the reason is that many office workers spend most of their day in conversations, not working with a spreadsheet or word processor. Even the benefits of word processing, the ability to make changes in a document quickly, can be lost if writers spend more time making revisions. "You fine-tune, fine-tune and fine-tune because it's easy to do that," said Gary Loveman, an assistant professor at Harvard Business School who has studied the impact of computers on productivity. "I really question whether the value of that is that high."
But many computer experts say the promises of the 80's will be fulfilled in the 90's. Computers will continue to gain in speed and capacity, and much of that new power will be harnessed to make machines easier to use and more versatile, to automate entire businesses instead of just individual workers.
"The theme of the second decade will be to achieve business objectives faster," said Andrew Grove, president of the Intel Corporation, which makes the central processing chips used in personal computers. Computers "are going to become as necessary to the business world as air."
Networks will become so advanced that people will not only exchange messages electronically but collaborate by viewing the same information simultaneously while sitting at terminals miles apart. Electronic mail is already proving indispensable to some companies, though networking fiefdoms must be better united to provide smooth, universal service.
With computers hooked into networks, vast electronic libraries will be available. Today's databases require special commands and often retrieve nothing if even a single letter is mistyped. "They are like Conan the Librarian -- lots of arbitrary rules and no mercy," said Mr. Saffo. But in the future, he said, information robots, or "infobots," will scour the networks for us, retrieving needed information, alerting people to developments in their field and perhaps preparing a customized daily newspaper.
Pocket-sized information appliances will receive and transmit by radio, leading to "anywhere, anytime" computing. By the end of the decade people will be writing and talking to their computers and artificial intelligence will help the machines anticipate their user's needs. Video computers will allow an art lover to take a simulated tour of the Louvre, deciding which hallways to walk down and zooming up close to particular paintings, which will appear on the screen with stunning clarity.
Looking back 10 years from now, some of these predictions will look humorous, and people might be asking questions like those being asked today. Will access to huge electronic libraries help people make better decisions, or merely drown them in useless information? Will "anywhere, anytime" computing shorten the workday or just make it impossible to escape from one's job?
The only thing certain about the next decade of personal computing is that it will be like the first. There will be tremendous change, mind-boggling advances and numerous benefits, and still more visions unfulfilled.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
On Reaganomics' 10th Birthday, Not All Celebrate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TEN years ago President Reagan laid the foundations of the Reagan revolution by signing two laws so sweeping and ambitious that they overshadow most of the legislation passed since then.
Mr. Reagan's historic package of tax and budget reductions cut individual income tax rates by 23 percent over three years, and to an astonishing degree those laws, signed Aug. 13, 1981, still shape the nation's political debate. Politicians still fiercely argue the fairness of those changes and the merits of cutting taxes as a way to stimulate economic growth.
But the relentless demand for Federal largess, the growth of social insurance benefits and the nation's military buildup long ago overwhelmed the budget cuts. Social Security outlays grew 90 percent in the last decade, while spending for Medicaid and Medicare has nearly tripled.
Still, Jack F. Kemp, spiritual father of the 1981 tax cuts, says they had a lasting legacy. "I doubt, in our lifetime or our children's lifetime, that we'll ever go back to a steeply graduated and progressive income tax system" with top rates of 70 percent or higher, he said last week in an interview.
The most important and permanent of all the 1981 tax changes is probably the indexing of tax brackets, which prevents the automatic increase in tax rates that occurs when wages and salaries increase as a result of inflation.
And is the overall tax burden any lighter now? Total Federal, state and local tax receipts declined as a percentage of gross national product from 1982 to 1984, but gradually climbed back to the level where they were when Mr. Reagan took office: slightly more than 27 percent of G.N.P.
C. Eugene Steuerle, one of the nation's foremost experts on tax policy, who was Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury from 1987 to 1989, said that after a round of state tax cuts in the late 1970's and the Federal income tax cut in 1981, state and local governments increased taxes in the ensuing decade. At least 33 states have raised taxes this year as they wrestle with serious fiscal problems. To be sure, Federal income tax rates are lower today, but Social Security payroll taxes are higher. About 32.5 million families pay more in Social Security payroll taxes than in income taxes, the Congressional Budget Office has estimated.
The tax revolt of the late 1970's and early 80's reduced overall levels of taxation only "slightly and temporarily," said Mr. Steuerle. It focused on two of the most unpopular levies, the income tax and the property tax, but did nothing to slow the growth in Social Security taxes, he said. President Bush has resisted a proposal by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan to cut Social Security payroll taxes.
The magnitude of the 1981 tax cuts is such that if all their provisions were still in effect, they would have reduced Federal tax receipts by $322 billion last year. In fact, almost two-thirds of the revenue loss has been offset by tax increases and other changes since 1981.
In 1986, Congress lowered income tax rates again, but significantly broadened the definition of taxable income, curtailing tax shelters, limiting many personal deductions and repealing the investment tax credit for businesses. In "The Tax Decade," a book to be published this fall by the Urban Institute Press, Mr. Steuerle reviews the extraordinary outpouring of tax legislation in the last 10 years and concludes that the result for most income groups was "almost no change in average tax rates."
However, in the 1980's the tax rate on the last dollar of earnings -- the rate most likely to affect individual decisions about work and savings -- did drop for many people. For example, the top rate for the most affluent people dropped from 70 percent in 1980 to less than half that today.
But Mr. Kemp, now Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, expresses despair that "we have forgotten the lessons of the early 1980's." Underlining the rift in Republican ranks, he said, "The budget agreement engineered last year by my good friend Dick Darman inadvertently paralyzes the President's call for a cut in the capital gains tax rate," because such a cut would produce revenue losses, according to conventional estimates. Mr. Darman is the Federal budget director.
When Mr. Reagan cut taxes, he "did it on faith," Mr. Kemp said. But now, he added, "we're listening to econometric models that tell us lowering the capital gains tax will lose revenue, and lowering the payroll tax will destroy the economy."
Mr. Bush abandoned his campaign pledge of "no new taxes" last year and supported a budget package that raises more than $150 billion of additional revenue over five years. He continues to call for a cut in the capital gains tax, even espousing it in a speech to low-income people at a housing project in St. Louis a few months ago. Congressional Democrats have blocked the capital gains proposal on the ground that it favors the wealthy -- it would lower the tax on profits from the sale of stocks, bonds, real estate and other assets.
On Tuesday, at a 10th anniversary celebration sponsored by the Heritage Foundation, Mr. Kemp will speak and there will be a videotaped message from Mr. Reagan. But Mr. Bush, who once derided the Reagan policy as "voodoo economics," was not invited. "Inviting Bush to this event would have been like inviting a nudist to a Moral Majority meeting," said Burton Yale Pines, senior vice president of the foundation.
While the overall tax burden has not changed much, there have been clear winners and losers from the changes in the last decade, particularly the Tax Reform Act of 1986, intended by Mr. Reagan to encourage "risk-taking, innovation and that old American spirit of enterprise." Among the losers were people who had invested heavily in tax shelters. The biggest winners included wage earners with few deductions, credits or exclusions under the old tax law.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
A Long-Running Battle On How to Divide The Medicaid Burden

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
NO sooner had Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins agreed to put aside their differences over what to call a city-state conference than they found themselves squabbling over its agenda. The Mayor wanted to advocate, again, that the state assume more of the city's $2 billion in Medicaid costs. The Governor, in turn, did not want the city's financial problems cast solely in that light -- and then laid at his doorstep.
The issue is hardly a new one. 
 In the mid-70's, 14 of New York City's top bankers and union leaders agreed to meet informally to discuss the city's financial problems. One of the first issues they decided to take up was Medicaid, the Federal health-care program for the poor, and the heavy financial burden it was imposing on the city. A manifesto of sorts resulted, which proposed that Washington pick up half of the state and local governments' Medicaid expenditures.
"State and local governments should not be forced to contract needed public programs or to raise their taxes to uncompetitive levels because of this national problem," read the statement, signed by Walter Wriston, then chairman of Citicorp, David Rockefeller, then chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, and Victor Gotbaum, then executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, and others.
This unusual political alliance then went to Washington, where the group pleaded their case before President Jimmy Carter. "We got nowhere," said Jack Bigel, the labor consultant who was co-chairman of the group.
Fast forward to 1987. Times are good again. But Mayor Edward I. Koch is alarmed by the city's soaring Medicaid costs and names a task force headed by William J. Grinker, then commissioner of the Human Resources Administration.
Its final report, optimistically entitled "Medicaid in the 1990's: Recommendations for Change," concluded, among other things, that the state of New York had the country's most expensive Medicaid program, and required its towns and cities to pay a larger share of those costs than any other state. It suggested that a portion of the city's Medicaid recipients participate in an experimental program to control costs.
Two years later, another Koch commission issued a lengthy report on taxes. It found that New York was one of only nine states that required any local contribution to the Federal welfare program, and that the 50 percent contribution the state imposed on its cities and counties was the highest in the nation.
It also found that only four other states required contributions from their local governments for Medicaid. And while New York City was paying 37 percent of the non-Federal share of that program, the next highest local burden in other states was 15 percent.
The commission concluded that while New York City's taxes are higher than any other city in the country, it is because its spending is higher. And that is "in part because a significant portion of the city budget is for programs that are more commonly financed today by states (and historically by the Federal government) than by localities."
 
Money for Police and Schools
 Fast forward again, to 1991. Mayor Dinkins has created a management advisory task force made up of business, labor and political leaders. It, in turn, has a subcommittee on health care headed by Mr. Bigel. In a 90-page report published in April, the subcommittee found that health-related expenditures now consume 21 percent of the city's $30 billion budget and that of the 14 states now requiring counties to contribute to Medicaid, only New York approaches the maximum of 30 percent allowed by law.
Given this history, it is hardly surprising that in the summer of 1991, when the city is once again trying to extricate itself from a financial vise, the pressure is growing for the state to assume a larger portion of the city's Medicaid costs.
City officials point out that if New York City were located in 45 other states, it would have an additional $2 billion in tax revenues that it could direct to services generally associated with local government -- including police, fire and education -- instead of to Medicaid. They note that the annual cost to New York City of welfare payments is $350 million.
After all, what should be more important to the state than the city's financial health? City officials like to remind state officials and others that 40 percent of the state's jobs are still located in the city, and the city's economic activity generates 50 percent of the state's tax revenues.
"The idea of a state Medicaid pick-up has surfaced as a silver-bullet solution to New York City's problems," acknowledged Drew Zambelli, secretary to Mr. Cuomo.
When the Mayor and the Governor agreed in early July to a joint study group of their interdependent financial problems, the sharing of Medicaid costs quickly emerged as the hot topic.
The Mayor wanted it to rank high on the agenda, and it was no accident that one of the people he named to represent the city on the group was Finance Commissioner Carol O'Cleireacain, who was a staff member on the mid-70's group.
But the Governor was more wary. While the Governor has always favored the state assuming a larger share of Medicaid, Mr. Zambelli said Mr. Cuomo thinks the dollar amounts are so large that it is unrealistic to expect the issue to be resolved politically anytime soon.
And since the state cannot deliver the kind of financial relief the city needs now, the issue itself should not take precedence over other more pressing issues.
That is where things stand after more than 15 years of blue-ribbon panels.
Yet, there has been headway. When Mr. Cuomo took office he agreed to reduce the city's portion of long-term Medicaid costs to 20 percent of the non-Federal share, which has resulted in savings of $2.4 billion since 1984.
As city and state representatives discuss the issue privately, the emphasis seems to have shifted away from whether the state should assume a greater share to how and when, according to some of the participants. Yet Mr. Cuomo, and legislators, want more assurances that before the state assumes more financial responsibility for Medicaid the program's costs would be under better control.
And therein lies the new rub. As long ago as the mid-70's, the bankers and labor leaders in that informal group suggested that a flat payment for Medicaid patients would remove the financial incentive for doctors to suggest more patient visits and longer hospital stays. The concept has since been formalized in the form of health-maintenance organizations in the private sector, and endorsed by subsequent study groups.
The question now is whether such a concept can be introduced in New York State for Medicaid patients, in what is known as "managed Medicaid." That is what the 1987 proposed experimental program was all about. But even though legislation allowing such a program was passed in 1987, its implementation is still being studied by the city.
"These ideas aren't new," Mr. Zambelli said, "but the politics are changing. People are beginning to realize they can't afford the alternative any more."

HEADLINE: THE REGION: In Connecticut;
Another Week Without Much Hope for a Budget

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
SIX weeks into its fiscal year, Connecticut is the only state still without a budget, and despite another week of rollercoaster politics it has none in sight.
The end seemed near for a few hours on Wednesday, when Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. vetoed a budget for the third time, saying it, like its predecessors, was not honestly balanced and struck at the poor and middle class by expanding the reach of the state's 8 percent sales tax. 
 Even Mr. Weicker seemed to think the veto, offering no new path for the General Assembly to follow, might push legislators to end their frustration by finally overriding him.
"I think the odds are clearly against me, because there is a great desire to flee the premises," he said after his televised veto message.
But Mr. Weicker, in his calmly delivered but sharp-edged message, had stirred anew the public's growing frustration over the deadlock.
"For too long the needs of some in the legislature have had little to do with the needs of Connecticut," Mr. Weicker said.
The message had its effect, and on Thursday the House and Senate -- their members under pressure, including calls from constituents -- decided it was futile to try to override the veto. But neither did they know where to turn next, with everyone dug deep on opposing sides of the key issue, an income tax.
Connecticut's fiscal troubles are like those in many states: the recession has blunted tax revenues after a decade in which spending soared. The result is a deficit that would approach $2 billion at the end of this fiscal year, in a $7.6 billion budget, if taxes were not raised.
Connecticut now stands alone, without a budget, in part because of Mr. Weicker's insistence on a budget that is free of fiscal gimmicks and that stimulates the economy by cutting sales and business taxes. The only plans he has favored included income taxes, and they have all died.
"Opposition to an income tax has gone beyond the political, beyond the philosophical," said Representative Richard Foley, who is also the Republican state chairman. "It has become a religious experience."
The state may also be alone because Mr. Weicker is an independent, with no party behind him. To form a coalition on the income tax, he has had to find legislators willing to buck their own parties. But as someone who campaigned as an anti-politician, perhaps he has also felt less need to seek compromise merely so business can go on as usual.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. explaining his third veto of Connecticut's budget. Disagreement over an income tax remains the key impediment. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Democrats in Congress Push for Jobless Bill

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The Democratic leaders of Congress are trying to turn up the political heat on President Bush by enlisting state and local officials to lobby for a bill that would extend unemployment benefits.
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington; the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, wrote to 27 Democratic governors and 346 Democratic mayors on Friday asking them to press Mr. Bush to sign the $5.2 billion jobless benefits bill passed last week. 
 The bill was sent to the White House on Tuesday, and the President has until Aug. 17 to act on it. The measure will become law on that day with or without his signature, but it will be meaningless unless Mr. Bush declares an emergency that will initiate the benefits.
The bill would allow up to 20 additional weeks of unemployment pay for those who have exhausted their basic 26 weeks of benefits. About 8.8 million Americans are unemployed, and benefits have already run out for some 1.6 million of those workers.
The Administration has been cool to the legislation, insisting that the nation's economy is recovering and that there is no emergency that would warrant the spending of more Federal dollars and deepening the deficit.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
A Tale Of Two Faces

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
Senator Jay Rockefeller has dropped out of a Presidential race he never really wanted to make. Coming on the heels of Representative Richard Gephardt's decision not to run, this new departure caused a predictable -- but not necessarily warranted -- chorus of moans and groans from Democrats hankering for a candidate.
Mr. Rockefeller has built a career in West Virginia that seems inevitably pointed toward a Presidential bid. But he had not planned to make it this early in his career, has plenty of years left and successfully resisted party pressures to force him into what at best would have been a long-shot campaign. 
 It seems ever clearer that Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, who has issued another disclaimer, also will sit this one out. Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee, like Mr. Gephardt a loser in 1988, must think long and hard before risking another defeat, even if this time as party nominee.
This line of speculation -- it's only that -- suggests the possibility that the Democrats might turn to their 1988 Vice Presidential candidate, Lloyd Bentsen of Texas. He is not elbowing his way to the front either, but he was generally praised for his campaign four years ago, particularly his debate victory over Dan Quayle; and it would be hard for him to turn down his party's call after accepting it in 1988.
The reluctance of acknowledged leaders to run also keeps open the possibility of a "new face" -- someone from outside the accustomed field of speculation, perhaps outside the party political scene. Shortly before Mr. Rockefeller opted out, for instance, a "draft committee" circulated a letter urging support for Ralph Nader, the well-known consumer advocate.
Mr. Nader has made about as many enemies as friends with his in-fighting skills and tenacity in Washington; but he's never run for office and the draft committee could say with a straight face that he "is not a politician." That's usually a Republican line, and may be an asset in a year when the public seems more than usually turned off on confessed politicians.
The New Republic also chose, in the current issue, to publish an attack on Bill Moyers, the former White House aide turned television journalist, whose name causes much excitement among Democrats taken with the idea of a new face. If he's drawing fire without even being a candidate, someone must take him seriously.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who does seem eager to run, would qualify as a new face in Presidential politics, also because he's one Democrat apparently unafraid to claim New Deal heritage or to call himself a liberal. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, whose views are more "centrist," also would be a newcomer to Presidential, though not to Democratic Party, politics.
But the new face the Democrats most need to see would be one for George Bush, who now looks unbeatable, and whose presumed campaign issues -- victory in the desert and opposition to quotas -- now seem insurmountable. By November 1992, however, it's not too far-fetched to suggest that that face of invincibility may look more like a map of economic decline.
The Administration has been talking bravely about recovery from the recession, but the Federal Reserve's "beige book" -- an economic review prepared by its 12 regional banks -- tells a different story. It reports continued weakness in real estate, retail sales lagging in major markets and overall improvement only at a "slow, uneven pace."
Acting on this picture of an economy that might be about to drop back into recession, the Fed again reduced the rate at which banks lend each other money, to 5.5 percent. The beige book's gloomy picture may cause even further interest-rate reductions this fall, since the demand for business loans remains weak.
Most unhappily for Mr. Bush, unemployment continues at about 7 percent, and an actual loss of 51,000 jobs was reported in July. The only improvement has come from people dropping out of the work force -- hardly an encouraging sign. State and local government layoffs, forced by recession and the loss of Federal aid, are just beginning to have economic effect.
Not even the most ardent Democrat could wish for victory in 1992 at the cost of an economic collapse. But with Mr. Bush displaying so little ability to take action against continuing, perhaps worsening recession, or to comprehend its effect on so many Americans, by mid-1992 he may no longer be wearing the face of an easy winner.
In that case, the Democrats will have little trouble putting on a good face of their own -- new or old.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 664 words

HEADLINE: Pinch-Hitting for the Democrats;
Invest in the Future? Yes, but How?

SERIES: The Missing Campaign/An occasional series

 BODY:
As the Democratic convention grows closer, the field of candidates grows steadily smaller -- and the chance for illuminating debate grows remote.
Senator Jay Rockefeller and Representative Richard Gephardt have now counted themselves out, and so far, the only rallying cry is that yes, Democrats have discovered economic virtue. Former Senator Paul Tsongas, the only declared candidate, and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, a leading undeclared candidate, urge the sensible goal: 
 America should invest in itself, in the future.
But neither they nor anyone else has faced up to an inconvenient fact: investing more means consuming less. Presidential leadership is about leveling with voters, telling them who will have to ratchet down their purchases, and why.
Americans consume 97 percent of everything they earn, holding U.S. rates of investment and productivity growth below those of our Western allies. The danger is that the U.S. might be sliding into economic mediocrity.
Decisions to buy equipment, attend school and acquire training will be made by millions of individuals -- which Congress may want to encourage with tax reforms and other policies. But Government investments are also important. The task is to recast Federal spending toward the future. Here are some plausible guidelines.
Human Services. The U.S. economy depends on rapid adoption of new information and technology. That requires workers who are well trained and adaptable. Yet millions of children lack adequate education, health care and nutrition, and an increasing number of workers, especially immigrants and minorities, enter the workplace with low skills.
During the Reagan years, the dollars spent on Federal programs for education, training, employment and related social services fell by an astounding 21 percent, taking inflation into account.
Programs like preschool education, job training for disadvantaged workers and welfare-to-work experiments do not work wonders. But they do show promise. Isabel Sawhill and Jason Juffras, researchers at the Urban Institute, propose a sensible guideline: restore Federal, state and local support for human services to levels reached during the 1970's. That would mean an annual boost in spending of about $35 billion, or 15 percent.
Physical Infrastructure. The nations's highways, bridges, railroads, water treatment facilities and airports need repair. But some estimates -- as high as $3 trillion -- dangerously exaggerate the problem. Studies show that performance of existing facilities could be maintained at an additional cost of $20 billion a year.
More important than spending more money is spending the money better. That would require levying user fees to unclog congested airports and highways; it would also require that Congress end pork-barrel transportation projects.
Paying the Bills. The $55 billion needed to pay for this increased public investment is hardly daunting in a $6.5 trillion economy. Some of the money could come from cutting defense faster and raising taxes.
But ultimately Congress will have to confront the fact that, apart from defense and interest, about half of all Federal spending goes to the elderly. Unless these gargantuan payments can be modified, there won't be any money for investment.
The idea of paring payments to the elderly strikes terror into Congressional hearts. But there are reasonable ideas to debate. One is to tax the untaxed portion of Social Security benefits, which would not affect the poor. That alone would raise some $30 billion a year -- about enough to pay for the proposed education and training programs. Another is to gradually raise the eligibility for Medicare.
Redirecting Federal spending into productive investments could be a powerful theme for the campaign, but only if Democrats are prepared to move beyond vaporous virtue and convince voters that investing billions for the sake of their grandchildren is worth today's cost.

HEADLINE: The Atlantic Charter: Design for Tomorrow?

BYLINE: By Arthur Schlesinger Jr.; Arthur Schlesinger Jr. is professor of humanities at the City University of New York.

 BODY:
A document drawn up a half-century ago today can plausibly be seen as the foundation of the new world that lies at last within humanity's grasp. Not many historic pronouncements have dated so little as the joint declaration to which Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill subscribed on Aug. 12, 1941.
The two men met in a shrouded rendezvous at Placentia Bay off the coast of Newfoundland -- a destination to which they had traveled in utmost secrecy through dangerous waters on heavily armed warships. Though Roosevelt and Churchill had been exchanging messages since World War II began in 1939, they had never talked face to face. Beyond satisfying his curiosity about the other -- and these were men with acute instincts for history -- each had particular objectives. 
 Churchill, for obvious reasons, wanted to get America into the war. Roosevelt, for less obvious reasons, wanted to formulate principles for the peace. American association with Britain in a statement of peace aims, he hoped, would hearten European resistance to Hitler, and the right peace aims would reassure Americans that solidarity with Britain need not compromise American ideals.
To get the peace aims right, F.D.R. wanted a guarantee against the "secret treaties" that had disgusted Americans after World War I; he wanted assurances against closed trading systems, and, fearing isolationist wrath at home, he wanted to avoid language that might sound like an internationalist plot to revive the League of Nations. This fear of the isolationists was hardly idle: on the very day Roosevelt and Churchill finished drafting their declaration, the House of Representatives barely succeeded in extending the draft, by a single vote.
After two days of amiable but forceful argument in Placentia Bay, Churchill accepted a compromise on freedom of trade; F.D.R. a compromise on international organization. They agreed in rejecting secret treaties. The final statement was Wilsonian in spirit and in language: no territorial aggrandizement; self-determination of peoples; a freely trading world; economic and social security; freedom of the seas; disarmament of aggressor states pending the "establishment of a wider and permanent system of general security." Two days later The London Daily Herald gave the document its enduring name: the Atlantic Charter.
The two leaders were satisfied with their handiwork. If Churchill had failed to get the United States into the war, he had at least wonderfully solidified what came to be known as the "special relationship." Roosevelt now had British endorsement of peace aims that would at once justify convoying British ships in the Western Atlantic and, if it came to that, might later justify war itself.
Nevertheless, many considered the Charter a disappointment. British opinion found it a poor substitute for American intervention. Americans saw the recycled Wilsonianism as a collection of pious platitudes. Judging by opinion polls, the Charter was, in the words of the historian Theodore Wilson, "a propaganda bust."
During the war the British and the Russians chipped away at the Charter's lofty principles, claiming exemption for their own "existing obligations" (Churchill) and "historic peculiarities" (Molotov). After the war the Soviet Union trampled on most of the Charter's points. Even the United States fell short of full dedication to the ideals.
Yet the ideals never faded away. In January 1942 the Declaration of the United Nations explicitly adopted the Charter's "purposes and principles." These purposes and principles informed Bretton Woods in 1944 and the U.N. Declaration on Human Rights in 1948. Today they constitute the philosophical and juridical basis for President Bush's new world order.
Take a look at the Atlantic Charter 50 years after. Is not the world dreamed of by Roosevelt and Churchill at last coming to pass?
Consider the goals of Aug. 12, 1941 -- "the right of all peoples to choose the form of government under which they will live," equal access "to the trade and to the raw materials of the world," "improved labor standards, economic advancement, and social security," assurance that all "may live out their lives in freedom from fear and want," relief from "the crushing burden of armaments," establishment of a community of nations. After half a century of bitter contention, the Atlantic Charter sets forth the agenda on which most nations are at last agreed.
They didn't do too badly, those two inspired prima donnas, when they met off the coast of Newfoundland 50 years ago.

HEADLINE: What the U.S. Can Do in Peru

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has good reasons for helping to train and equip the Peruvian armed forces and police to combat drug traffickers and the leftist guerrillas who protect their trade. Sending 50 U.S. military personnel to assist an army notorious for human rights abuse does not mean that Washington is sliding toward another Vietnam, or even another El Salvador.
But to avoid being dangerously drawn into another country's political conflicts, policy makers will have to keep the limited nature of their mission clearly in mind: to help a democratically elected government implement its drug-control strategy and fend off guerrillas who get in the way. 
 That does not require the U.S. to be neutral in Peru's larger guerrilla war. The Shining Path rebels are brutal terrorists, with no strong base of popular support. President Alberto Fujimori's Government is democratically legitimate and economically competent. But Peru's present problems, including ethnic and regional strains, disease, insurgency and declining living standards, have deep historical roots and cannot be solved from abroad or by mainly military means.
The cocaine traffic is another story. The huge U.S. appetite for drugs helps drive this lucrative industry. Thousands of Peruvian peasants have been drawn to the remote Upper Huallaga Valley, where they can make far more money growing coca than they could from more traditional pursuits.
Shining Path, which has its main base in the Andean highlands, has exploited the cocaine traffic to open a new military front. The guerrillas pressure drug traffickers to pay more for the farmers' coca crops, and offer farmers and traffickers protection against army and police raiders.
Two years ago at the Cartagena summit meeting, the Presidents of the U.S., Bolivia, Colombia and Peru agreed on a joint strategy. The centerpiece was military cooperation, although useful new approaches, like Peru's crop substitution program, have since been added. The U.S. training mission in Peru is a result of the Cartagena understandings and has the support of the Fujimori Government.
There are defects in any anti-drug strategy that concentrates mainly on supply. Progress in squeezing Andean and Mexican traffickers has been partly offset by the relocation of drug facilities to other Latin American locations.
There are also human rights concerns. Peru today has perhaps the worst rights record in South America. The army, which ruled until 1980, remains a law unto itself; efforts to contain the violent insurgents of Shining Path have often caught innocent peasants in the middle.
The Fujimori Government has tried to rein in abuses, but has limited power. U.S. military trainers are likely to have no more success in changing the Peruvian Army's internal culture than they have had in El Salvador over the last decade.
Still, limited military cooperation against traffickers makes sense; and in Peru, no such campaign can succeed without also attacking the connection between the coca industry and Shining Path.
