HEADLINE: Black Theater Groups Share Dreams

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Aug. 9

 BODY:
Denzel Washington was here. So were Esther Rolle, Avery Brooks, Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee and other actors, as well as directors, script writers and hundreds of fans. They all descended upon this central North Carolina city last week for the second National Black Theater Festival.
Audiences at the six-day event were treated to 20 productions by some of the nation's leading black companies. There were also workshops and seminars on subjects from set design to audience development. 
 "Networking is going on all day and all night," said Larry Leon Hamlin, the festival's producer and artistic director. "Deals are being made, shows are being moved and actors and playwrights are getting jobs."
Mr. Hamlin said he got the idea for the festival, which he founded in 1989, while preparing a magazine article on black theater in the South. "What I heard was a tremendous scream of pain and frustration," he said. "Then I began asking how black theater was faring in the rest of the country, and I heard that same scream."
Mr. Hamlin, as executive and artistic director of the North Carolina Black Repertory Company here, then began to organize a gathering that would involve the nation's more than 250 black theater troupes.
"I had thought there were only 55 or 60," he said. "Here we were in the same business, and we didn't even know each other. I felt we all needed to come together to see if we could share resources and organizational ideas."
The success of the 1989 festival, which drew an estimated 20,000 visitors to Winston-Salem, made fund-raising easier this time, Mr. Hamlin said, noting that corporate sponsors had contributed about $300,000 toward the current budget of $750,000. Attendance is expected to equal or surpass the previous total.
Plans for the next festival, in August 1993, include broadening its scope by inviting black theater companies from around the globe. Mr. Hamlin said he was discussing the idea with troupes in London, Amsterdam and several African countries.
 
Morale Booster
 A more immediate concern is the survival of black theater during recessionary times, said Beth Turner, publisher and editor of Black Masks, a New York-based magazine distributed in 35 states and featuring information about black performing and visual arts. Events like the National Black Theater Festival boost morale and enable acting companies to exchange ideas, she said.
"It's very essential," she added. "Black theater groups, in particular, tend to get caught up in the daily grind of getting the show out. You feel like an island unto yourself. You find there are other theaters that have strength."
Miss Dee, who presided over this year's festival with Mr. Davis, her husband, said that networking by theater groups was perhaps the festival's most useful offering in an era when budget shortfalls often mean cutbacks in arts subsidies.
"We have to strategize to keep them alive," Miss Dee said. "We can't let these theaters die."
She said she was impressed by the week's productions, which included Mr. Brooks's portrayal of Paul Robeson and Mrs. Rolle's of the educator Mary McLeod Bethune.
 
Tribute to Aretha Franklin
 Other offerings included Yolanda King's multi-media tribute to her father, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.; "Blues in the Night," a musical produced by Mr. Hamlin's repertory company, and "Lady Soul: A Cabaret Tribute to the Music of Aretha Franklin," with Leonard Thomas and Peggy Alston.
"This is really a meeting ground for everyone to come together and talk about what the conditions are and to develop new ways to cooperate," said Sidne Mahone, director of play development for the Crossroads Theater company of New Brunswick, N.J. The company is one of America's largest black repertory groups, with an annual budget of $2.5 million.
"There is a recession; that is a reality," Ms. Mahone said. "But what is hard is working in isolation."

HEADLINE: The Right Way to Retool the Soviet Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's letter to the Group of Seven leaders was called inadequate partly because it "hedges on the goal of privatizing large enterprises" (news article, July 16). It would be unfortunate if Western assessment of Soviet economic transformation focused on privatization. Far more important are the steps that should be taken first, such as monetary stabilization, freeing of prices, marketization and full legalization of private ownership. 
 Privatization sounds like the natural way of transforming a state-enterprise economy into a private-enterprise economy. But a privatized enterprise is no more private than a tranquilized person is tranquil.
Part of the history of Soviet state-owned enterprises is incorporated in a stock of plant and equipment so old, so poorly maintained, so designed for military production and so ill suited to the consumer demands of a market economy that most of it could not survive genuine competition.
Another part of that history is embodied in an overstaffed and unmotivated labor force that has never been exposed to the discipline of a labor market. Add to that management staffs that have achieved their positions through years of carrying out the orders of a bureaucratic government, rather than competing for the orders of consumers or businesses.
Imagine what the United States economy would look like if not a single enterprise had been permitted to go out of business in the last half-century. The state sector provides a weak basis from which to start a proud new market economy.
Fortunately, the Soviet population has a large potential for vigorous entrepreneurship. Some of it has surfaced in the last few years in the limited legalization of private ownership, including individually and cooperatively owned enterprises, and joint ventures with Western businesses. Those employed in this private sector now number in the millions.
Because the Government maintains price controls, fortunes can still be made in the black market. As in the United States in World War II, much entrepreneurial effort has been diverted into buying and trading price-controlled goods. And as in the United States after that war, if price controls were abandoned, the black market would largely vanish, and entrepreneurs would produce goods and services that people wish to buy.
The hunger for goods and services is so great, and the facilities for producing them so meager, that fortunes can be made in a competitive private sector. Protected by law and supported by the Government, private savings would expand rapidly. Those savings, supplemented by foreign capital seeking genuine business opportunities, could further expand the private sector and purchase portions of the state enterprises that would stand the test of profitability as perceived by business people with their own capital at risk.
In the long transition, state enterprises could first compete with the growing private sector and then the plant and equipment could finally be retired or bulldozed over to make way for new private enterprises.
If the Soviet economy should one day join the club of major industrial countries, it will be based not on the privatization of decrepit state enterprises, but on the vitality of new, genuinely private enterprises. That requires establishment of a real market economy, which requires abandoning price controls. Before that, however, the huge Government budget deficit must be eliminated and the monetary system stabilized. And before any of those, the fundamental political question of which level of government has the right to make what laws must be resolved.
Such a reform program would tax the administrative resources of the most powerful of governments. For a weak Government, it may be overwhelming. The West should regard it as a great achievement if the conditions for vigorous private enterprise alone were established in the Soviet Union. It should not burden the Soviet Government further by pressing for the privatization of large state enterprises.
 
JOSEPH S. BERLINER
Cambridge, Mass., July 25, 1991
 
The writer, professor emeritus of economics at Brandeis University, is a fellow at the Harvard Russian Research Center.

HEADLINE: The Right Way to Retool the Soviet Economy;
Allies and Partners

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Though your imagination soars bravely in the political-security realm about potential Soviet-American cooperation in "Allies" (editorial, July 28), you stop far short of the long-term economic possibilities. Soviet integration into the international economy has to signify much more than a stake in a stable world order.
When we look at today's wrecked Communist command system amid empty stores, inflation and rapidly declining gross national product, it is easy to forget the Soviet Union's strengths: tremendous agricultural territories, enormous natural resources (including huge petroleum reserves), a huge pool of literate and skilled workers, and a powerful scientific and technological establishment.
The transformation will be lengthy, uneven and worrisomely uncertain. Nevertheless, a worldwide economy in which, with luck, a healthy Soviet Union (however renamed) becomes a major player will be radically different. The three-cornered love-hate competition among the United States, Europe and Japan will open up to all sorts of new combinations and permutations. Whether the goal is to undercut Persian Gulf oil dominance, to embark on new collaboration in space or to initiate major new technologies, a revived Soviet Union will alter global behavior patterns and business alliances.
The United States can, along with sounder domestic policies, revive its competitive fortunes even as the Soviet Union revives its own. While imaginatively helping the Soviets on their journey, we should not forget the main future promise for ourselves.
 
DAVID E. MARK
New York, Aug. 1, 1991

HEADLINE: CHINA BACKS PACT ON NUCLEAR ARMS

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 10

 BODY:
China announced today that it had decided "in principle" to sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, becoming the last major nuclear power to commit itself to the terms of the agreement to curb the spread of atomic weapons.
The announcement came during a summit meeting today between Prime Minister Li Peng and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, whose nation last week marked the 46th anniversary of the two American atomic bomb attacks. Mr. Kaifu, who arrived today for three days of talks, is the first leader of any industrialized country to visit China since the Tiananmen crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in June 1989.
 
'Things Have Changed'
 "On many occasions in the past, China made clear its reasons for not acceding to the treaty," Wu Jianmin, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, said tonight. "Now things have changed. This is for the purpose of attaining the complete prohibition and thorough destruction of nuclear weapons." 
 In recent months, China had hinted it might join the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, and today's announcement, while not entirely a surprise, is expected to be a boost to the international effort this year to curtail the spread of nuclear and conventional weapons, particularly to trouble spots like the Middle East.
The Foreign Ministry spokesman did not say when China would sign the treaty, nor did he say whether "in principle" meant that there were any issues China still wanted to discuss before it signed. He did say, however, that China has not "imposed any conditions" for signing the treaty.
China was the last of the five major nuclear powers to hold out against the accord; on June 3, France committed itself to the terms of the treaty, although it has not yet signed it.
Only a handful of countries -- including India, Pakistan, Israel, South Africa, Argentina and Brazil, which are thought to possess advanced nuclear technology -- have yet to sign the accord. But among the nations that have accepted it are countries like Iraq and North Korea that are believed to have ambitions of developing nuclear weapons.
[The Bush Administration welcomed China's announcement, saying the move was something the United States had long sought. "We welcome this development and we look forward to early ratification by China of the treaty," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said in Kennebunkport, Me., where President Bush is vacationing.]
Mr. Li's announcement appeared to be a friendly gesture toward Japan, which has been more eager than Western countries to re-establish normal ties with China.
 
Ties 'Returned to Normal'
 In the last two years, Japan and China have rebuilt strong economic, commercial and even diplomatic ties, without focusing on the Tiananmen crackdown or human rights abuses. Some Western countries, particularly the United States, continue to have frosty relations with China because of concerns about Chinese violations of human rights and weapons sales.
Prime Minister Li suggested to Mr. Kaifu, in a comment repeated by the official New China News Agency, that China regarded the summit meeting as an indication that Chinese-Japanese relations are now back to normal.
"We are pleased to see that our bilateral relations have returned to normal," Mr. Li said. "We hereby express our appreciation for the positive efforts the Japanese Government and Prime Minister Kaifu have made to restore and develop the bilateral relations."
 
Treaty Took Effect in 1968
 One of the aims of Mr. Kaifu's visit was to encourage China to play a more active role in controlling weapons sales and the proliferation of nuclear arms.
Mr. Wu today did not explain why his country had long opposed the treaty, but China in the past has suggested that the pact was an effort by the superpowers to dominate other countries. Beijing has said the treaty discriminated against developing countries and hindered international cooperation for peaceful uses of nuclear energy.
The treaty, the subject of intensive negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union in the mid-1960's, bans the export of nuclear weapons and nuclear-arms technology. It went into effect in 1968.
The treaty was controversial because it sought to make permanent the nuclear-weapons monopoly of those nations that then possessed such weapons -- the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China -- and sought pledges from other countries nt to acquire any. The treaty also committed the nuclear powers to work toward total nuclear disarmament and to help nonnuclear nations that sign the accord to develop peaceful uses of nuclear energy.
Arms control experts say China's nuclear arsenal is much smaller than those of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain or France. According to a report by Jane's Information Group, China has a nuclear arsenal that consists of 1,455 devices, both strategic and tactical. Many of those include warheads on land-based missiles, but China also has bombs, submarine-launched ballistic missiles and mines and shells.
The Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control has reported that China has transferred sensitive nuclear material or technology to Pakistan, India, South Africa, Algeria and countries in South America.
In addition to seeking Chinese acceptance of the nonproliferation treaty, the United States has been pressing Beijing in the last year to curb its missile sales. Nevertheless, China went ahead recently with the sale to Pakistan of a package of M-11 missiles, which can carry nuclear warheads. It is apparently considering the sale of M-9 missiles to Syria.
China indicated recently that it was considering joining the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international agreement to curb the spread of missiles, but the issue was not raised at today's meeting, according to a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Sadaaki Numata.
 
Issue of Arms Transfers
 Mr. Numata said Prime Minister Kaifu had pressed China for support in Japan's effort to sponsor a United Nations resolution calling upon countries to report weapons transfers. But China said only that it was willing to discuss the subject and gave no commitments.
Japan is now offering low-interest loans to China, and the Chinese have made a request for more economic assistance. But the only announcement of economic aid today was a new donation, worth $1.5 million, in disaster relief for Chinese regions devastated by flooding last month. Japan already had given $500,000 worth of aid.
One reason bilateral ties have improved relatively smoothly is that Japan has tended not to criticize China's human rights abuses harshly. In today's meeting, Mr. Kaifu seemed to touch lightly on human rights issues, referring to the concerns expressed at the recent summit meeting of the seven major industrialized countries about China's process of democratization.
Mr. Kaifu did not seem to win any assurances from China that Communist North Korea would allow international inspection of its nuclear installations.

BEIJING-HANOI TIES WARM
 BEIJING, Aug. 10 -- China and Vietnam announced today that they hoped to normalize relations, and called for further consultations in the near future.
A reconciliation between the two Communist neighbors, after a dozen years of enmity and occasionally armed conflict, would reflect the steps taken toward resolving the civil war in Cambodia. A reconciliation would also improve the chances that a lasting peace could be achieved in Cambodia.
China supported North Vietnam in its war against the American-backed South, but Beijing and Hanoi turned on each other after the Vietnamese invaded Cambodia at the end of 1978 and ousted the Chinese-supported Khmer Rouge Government. In the spring of 1979, China and Vietnam fought a border war.
The announcement today came in a joint communique issued after three days of talks between Chinese Foreign Ministry officials and Nguyen Dy Nien, Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister.
The communique said Hanoi and Beijing agreed that a comprehensive political settlement in Cambodia should be achieved "on the basis of a framework document of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council." That seemed to be a sign that Vietnam and China favor a United Nations plan for elections in Cambodia.
The statement may have been meant to allay fears that the two countries planned to have Cambodian factions loyal to them simply share power in Cambodia without ever consulting the Cambodian people.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 18, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front- page article last Sunday about China's announcement that it would sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty referred incorrectly in some editions to the recent anniversary of the American atomic bombings of Japan. It was the 46th anniversary.

HEADLINE: More Cases Expected in S.& L. Fraud

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THE savings and loan scandals that have grabbed most of the headlines have focused public attention on states like California and Texas, but Federal law-enforcement officials say New Jersey has emerged as one of the states with the highest incidence of corruption in some of its lending institutions.
Michael Chertoff, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said that in just the past year his office had charged 42 people in connection with major bank and savings and loan fraud totaling almost $90 million. Thirty-eight of the defendants have been convicted or have entered guilty pleas, and four are awaiting trial. 
 "There are three ways banks and thrifts can get into trouble: bad luck, bad investments or bad conduct," he said. Some of the bad conduct, he said, was concealed through much of the economic boom of the 1980's, when developers were covering the landscape with office parks and condominiums, and savings and loans and banks were vying to make loans.
 
The Most Takeovers in the Northeast
 Mr. Chertoff said New Jersey had experienced more closures and takeovers of financial institutions, especially savings and loans, than any other state in the Northeast, and said he expected evidence of corruption to continue to surface for some time to come.
"When a savings and loan closes, the F.B.I. immediately gets involved along with the regulators," he said. "Once the institution is closed, the review is like a dead body autopsy; it's infinitely easier to see what caused the closure and whether corruption was involved when it's over."
Mr. Chertoff said that the fraud investigations were time-consuming and labor-intensive and that his staff was being expanded to handle the anticipated growing caseload.
The recession revealed the weakness in many of the projects and also made it more difficult for corrupt officials to hide their misdeeds, Mr. Chertoff said. "It's like a tide rolling out, leaving the litter on the beach exposed," he said.
Gary Penrith, agent in charge of the Newark office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said that when the agency's agents and auditors assisted the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in examining some troubled lending institutions, it was fairly easy to spot signs of insider transactions and properties on which loans were based that were overappraised.
He said agents were not empowered to conduct criminal investigations at that time, but left their business cards with bank employees and encouraged them to call if they had anything to report. In time, the telephones began to ring.
"Some people who knew something felt they had nobody to tell before," he said. "They wanted to clear their consciences."
At one time, Mr. Penrith said, he had 11 active cases in his office.
 
Scheme Generated $10.5 Million
 One of the largest bank frauds in recent years ended when one of the principals turned himself in to Mr. Chertoff's office in August 1989. James Fredericks, a former cashier at the Montgomery National Bank in Somerset County, told of a scheme that had succeeded for eight years and generated $10.5 million through the sale of phony repurchase agreements.
Customers were asked to lend the bank money in return for repurchase agreements made out on bank stationery that told when the loans would be repaid and specified the rates of interest. The bank was declared insolvent in June 1990 because of its losses and taken over by the F.D.I.C.
Mr. Fredericks pleaded guilty to conspiracy and mail fraud charges and agreed to cooperate with the Government. Michael Schneiderman, a former assistant vice president, was convicted of conspiracy, bank fraud and tax fraud, Mr. Chertoff said. Both are awaiting sentencing.
Mr. Chertoff also said that judges were handing out prison sentences for bank fraud, a so-called white-collar crime that in the past usually drew nothing more than probation, restitution and a fine.
Eugene Unger, vice president of the Fidelity Mutual Savings and Loan Association in Westmont, pleaded guilty in August 1990 to the embezzlement of $6 million over a 16-year period, by diverting customers' deposits, manipulating bank records and creating fictitious accounts, Mr. Chertoff said. In March 1991, Mr. Unger received a four-year sentence and ordered to pay back the $6 million.
 
Not All Show Remorse
 Richard Halajian, owner of the New Jersey Yacht Corporation, based in Brielle, was convicted of defrauding local banks out of close to $583,000 through a check-kiting scheme, Mr. Chertoff said. In January 1991 he was sentenced to 18 months in prison and was ordered to make restitution.
Not all defendants show remorse for their misdeeds, even when they admit them in open court, Mr. Chertoff said. He said the guilty plea of Donald Moskowitz, former president of the failed United Savings Bank/ SLA of Paterson, amounted to "a litany of excuses."
"He was watching all the people making money on Wall Street during the 1980's, and he decided that he worked very hard and was entitled to help himself," Mr. Chertoff said.
Mr. Moskowitz pleaded guilty in September 1990 and admitted that he had used bank funds for personal expenses, taken kickbacks from loan customers and evaded personal income taxes, Mr. Chertoff said.
A report released by the United States Attorney's office said the former bank official admitted causing the bank to pay more than $224,000 for unauthorized life insurance policies, with total death benefits of $2.75 million payable to his mother; at least $52,000 in health-care and homemaking expenses for his mother; at least $40,000 in personal expenses charged to bank credit cards, including restaurant, hotel and travel bills, and $10,000 for personal limousine and florist expenses for his friends, his wife and his mother.
He also generated kickbacks in the form of cash, jewelry, furniture and clothing for himself, the report said.
 
Bank Problems Said to Be Few
 Robert C. Forrey, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, said most of the problems uncovered in New Jersey had been with savings and loans.
"Problems with banks are still few and far between, but we deplore it when it happens and are heartily in favor of steps being taken by law enforcement to correct any problems," he said. "There are 40,000 employees in the banking industry in New Jersey, so these abuses are basically unusual.
"Employees who find anything wrong are required first to tell their supervisors and then law-enforcement officials, and we're proud of their record in following that policy."
Mr. Chertoff said that most of the first wave of cases opened to view by the recession had been dealt with, but that information gathered in these investigations had convinced Justice Department officials in Washington that much more remained to be done.
"We're getting 16 additional people in New Jersey to work on nothing but bank and savings and loan fraud," he said. "We expect to continue to develop cases for the foreseeable future."
 
CHARGES AND PLEAS
 Here are some of the major bank and savings and loan fraud cases prosecuted by the office of the United States Attorney for New Jersey:
City Federal Savings Bank of Somerset: Declared insolvent in December 1989, it has been liquidated with an estimated loss to the Government of $1.5 billion, making it one of the five most costly failures, to taxpayers, in United States history. William J. Spagnoli, a former senior vice president, was indicted in January on charges of taking more than $2.5 million in kickbacks from real-estate developers, four of whom have pleaded guilty to paying the bribes. Mr. Spagnoli, who denies the charges, is scheduled to come to trial next month.
United Savings Bank/SLA: described by officials as one of the country's top 100 fraud-ridden savings and loan associations, United Savings was taken over by the Government in April 1990. Shortly afterward, Donald Moskowitz, the former president of the Paterson-based savings and loan, and Ronald Rudd, the former controller, entered guilty pleas to bank fraud and other charges. Mr. Rudd was sentenced to six months in Federal prison and fined $60,000 in May of this year. Mr. Moskowitz faces a maximum of 30 years and $1.35 million in fines.
Montgomery National Bank: Two former officers were convicted in a $10.5 million bank fraud by using using fraudulent repurchase agreements. One of the principals in the scheme, James Fredericks, a former cashier, turned himself into the United States Attorney's office, collapsing the scheme, which had run for eight years. He later pleaded guilty to conspiracy and mail fraud and is cooperating with the Government. Michael Schneiderman, a former assistant vice president, was convicted on 12 counts of conspiracy, bank fraud and tax fraud. Both men are awaiting sentencing. The bank, unable to recover from the losses because of the scheme, was declared insolvent in June 1990.
Midlantic National Bank: Anthony J. Surano, the owner of a mortgage banking firm, pleaded guilty to his role in defrauding the Newark-based Midlantic of more than $7 million between September 1986 and October 1988. He received a sentence of 37 months in prison, the maximum under Federal sentencing guidelines.
First Fidelity Bank: Neil F. Cohen, an auto dealer and part owner of the Ritz nightclub in Manhattan, and Antranig A. Arzoomanian, a former senior vice president of the Newark-based First Fidelity, were indicted in February 1989 on charges of conspiracy and perjury in connection with $3.4 million in bad loans. Mr. Arzoomanian had approved the loans and letters of credit to Mr. Cohen in return for the use of Mercedes-Benzes, cash and other gifts. Mr. Cohen eventually went bankrupt. Both men pleaded guilty. Mr. Arzoomanian received an 18-month sentence and Mr. Cohen 30 months.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 11 about some of the major bank and savings and loan fraud cases prosecuted by the office of the United States Attorney for New Jersey misstated Neil F. Cohen's involvement with the Ritz nightclub in Manhattan. He was an employee, not a part owner.

HEADLINE: Lower Skyline, Higher Aspirations

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
It isn't going to be built tomorrow -- nothing is in New York -- but when it finally does happen, Riverside South, the huge project planned for the 72-acre former Penn Central rail yards on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, now stands a real chance of being a cause for celebration rather than embarrassment.
 The much-debated plan -- in its most complete and successful version yet -- has just been made public. It calls for a lively, Central Park West-inspired skyline of slender, fancifully topped towers along a southern extension of Riverside Drive and Riverside Park. It is a romantic vision of the New York we have always known, not a science-fiction vision of a New York that will never be. And the world's tallest building, the centerpiece of previous plans, has disappeared altogether. 
 It almost wasn't so promising. The first versions of Trump City, as the mega-project was once known, were the architectural equivalent of junk bonds: highly leveraged hubris masquerading as substance. These early schemes, which were also to have included a shopping mall big enough to make Paramus weep, were a prize example of 1980's excess.
 But last March Mr. Trump announced that he would abandon his plan in favor of one developed by a coalition of civic groups for the site, which runs along the Hudson River from 59th to 72d Streets. The report of his abrupt about-face hit urban development circles with about the same impact that the news that the Soviet Union had given up on Communism had in political circles.
 Don't laugh; there are more similarities between Mr. Trump and the Soviet Union than one might think. After all, the developer and the country are motivated by the same impulse: survival. Mr. Trump knew that it would be a freezing day in August before his own plan could ever win approval and, like any skillful politician, he jumped on the opposition bandwagon so deftly that he made it look like his own.
The years of battling over the site won't end with the unveiling of this new design, of course; the political process in New York is never simple, and as the project moves through its long months of official hearings there are bound to be complaints that it is still too big, still too elaborate, still too indifferent to the needs of the city.
 It is big, it is elaborate, and it does not do a great deal to ameliorate New York's social problems. Of course, if the plan contained housing for half the city's homeless and a hospital in which the developers promised to cure cancer there would still be some objections to it: so things go in New York, the city in which saying no is always politically correct.
 But on balance, the plan just unveiled for Riverside South is right. It is dense enough to be economically viable, open enough to provide the city with vast and valuable new public space. It is intelligently tied in to the existing city, yet it holds the promise of being a special, even a unique, place.
 The basis of the scheme is a plan prepared by the architect Paul Willen (initially for the coalition of civic groups as a means of showing that there was an alternative to the Trump proposals) to extend Riverside Drive and Riverside Park southward beyond 72d Street and run the West Side Highway below street level for much of the site. Buildings containing apartments and some commercial space would go up along the eastern edge of the 13-block-long site, and a huge park would fill the western portion, running from the buildings down to the waterfront. In the months since Mr. Trump joined his own opposition, a team of architects led by David Childs and Marilyn Taylor of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill has been at work fleshing the Willen plan, essentially an outline, into reality.
 Key to Mr. Willen's design was his suggestion that the West Side Highway, now an elevated road running along the Hudson River, be moved to the inland portion of the site. Mr. Trump's plan, designed by the architectural firm of Cooper, Robertson & Partners (replacing an earlier and still more outrageous Trump plan by Helmut Jahn), left the elevated highway in place next to the river, cutting off the project's park from the waterfront. Vast towers were to have filled the rest of the site, and the scale would have been overwhelming.
Mr. Willen's design, on the other hand, bespoke a certain modesty and reasonableness. Not the characteristics one has associated with Donald Trump, to be sure, but the 1990's will do that to a man. So far Mr. Trump has been forthright in his support of this project's design principles, contrary though they are to all he zealously fought for up to a few months ago. Instead of huge towers, the Willen scheme called for lower buildings, set along streets that very much resembled the traditional streets of Manhattan.
 The current design team -- which, in addition to Mr. Childs and Ms. Taylor, includes Mr. Willen and Steven Robinson, an architect who represents the community's interests -- is working under the direction of Richard A. Kahan, the developer and former public official who played the critical role in conceiving the present form of Battery Park City in lower Manhattan, surely the finest large-scale development of the last decade anywhere in the nation. Mr. Trump, as developer, is paying the bills and makes the major decisions, but as planning has progressed the entity that has been calling most of the shots is the Riverside South Planning Corporation, which Mr. Kahan now heads and whose board contains a mix of representatives from nonprofit community groups.
 The plan as it now stands calls for 8.3 million square feet of space to be spread out over the site, down from the more than 10 million square feet called for in Mr. Trump's plan. Most of the apartments would be in buildings set along the curved extension of Riverside Drive; at the southern end there would be commercial buildings, including a large film and television studio complex. In a magnificent note of irony, the site that was to have contained Mr. Trump's dream, the world's tallest building, is now to be a void, an entry square in front of the studio structure.
 The most striking thing about the Riverside South plan is the new skyline it projects: a curving, up-and-down sequence of buildings, ranging in height from roughly 15 to more than 50 stories, with lively tops based heavily on the profiles of the skyscrapers of the 1920's and 30's. The tall buildings are relatively slender and carefully placed, so that their height becomes not an oppressive mass but an energizing force on the skyline. It's a reminder that height alone is rarely the enemy in urban design: it's the combination of height and bulk that does a skyline in.
 The placement of the tallest buildings is surprising, and at first glance seems altogether wrong. Instead of putting the height in the middle of the site, where it would be opposite the widest section of the new Riverside Park, the architects have set the biggest towers to the north and south of this point. But it makes sense, for it confers on the generous open curve of the three-block park space the maximum amount of sunlight. And it makes the whole skyline a much livelier and less predictable profile.
 It could still be a bit less pat: looking at the model you wonder if the architects projected a sine curve onto it. But there are some subtle elements, such as the decision not to put a very tall building at the northernmost point at the corner of 72d Street, a space that is given over instead to a curving building that, like the venerable apartment buildings at the corner of 116th Street and Riverside Drive, makes a gracious transition between the side streets and the formal boulevard. Taller buildings are set just south of this point, at 70th and 71st Streets.
 The plan also helps solve the problem of Freedom Place, a truly wretched street tucked behind the huge Lincoln Towers project next door to the Riverside South site, by including a mix of retail and commercial space and landscaping to enliven Freedom Place's banality. It doesn't make Lincoln Towers go away, of course, but it helps.
 The biggest buildings face west, across the new park toward the river, and there is a temptation to worry when a plan like this turns its back on the rest of the city. I don't see this as a real concern, any more than the present buildings of Central Park West -- in so many ways the models for Riverside South -- can be criticized for turning their backs toward Columbus Avenue. This is a vast set of buildings facing the river, and it makes perfect sense for it to turn its best face in that direction; it will be up to the architects to make sure that the designs at street level tie the project into the rest of the urban fabric there, on the ground, where it matters.
 The architects have thus far put forth only a rough proposal for the buildings, and not for the park itself, which will follow in the next few months. Mr. Kahan speaks of his desire not to replicate Riverside Park literally, but to try to rethink the idea of the large urban park and "ask what a major public space in this day and age means to different ethnic groups, and to see what the ecologists can bring to it as well."
 A noble idea, though here it is worth remembering that the great models of urban parks, like Central Park across town, were hardly elitist; indeed, Frederick Law Olmsted, the co-designer of Central Park, wrote of his awareness of the different recreational needs "of the Sicilian and the Irishman," and of his determination that the park serve them all.
 But what of the issues of density and social good that preoccupy so many critics of this plan? Is it too much, in the end giving the city too little? Yes, a little less building would be better. But this is a huge piece of land, and it has to be developed in accordance with some economic reality; less building will mean less park and less public space.
 So, too, with affordable housing. Ideally, there would be significant affordable housing as part of a plan of this kind. It's all a matter of how the trade-off is managed: since the government has nothing to contribute today in terms of subsidizing housing, the money for it has got to come from somewhere. Since the park is to be paid for by the developer, a little less park could mean a little more affordable housing.
 But as things now stand, the public realm does just fine. We have the chance for splendid, even sumptuous, urban design, and generous, perhaps even important, public open space. In a city whose public realm has been pushed to the wall by private greed over the last decade, the Riverside South plan offers the promise of turning things around.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 15, 1991, Sunday

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Sam Howe Verhovek

 BODY:

Neutral but Leaning
 At the core of the struggle over redistricting of seats for the New York City Council has been minority politicians' demands that they be better represented on the expanded council, whose primary is on Sept. 12. But sometimes personal ties can conflict with this theoretical goal. One apparent case involves the loyalties of the Manhattan Democratic leader, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., who is black.
 Although he has been in the forefront of calls for greater minority representation on the council, other Manhattan Democratic leaders now say that Mr. Farrell seems to be favoring a longtime associate, Stanley E. Michels, who is white, over the two black hopefuls for one of the seats whose boundaries have been redrawn to favor a black candidate.
 The race is in the new Seventh District which includes portions of central and west Harlem, along with the western halves of Washington heights and Inwood. Mr. Michels, a four-term Council incumbent, is battling the Harlem district leader, Peggy M. Shepard, and a lawyer, C. Vernon Mason.
 Mr. Farrell, one of the highest-ranking black officials in the state, is publicly neutral in the race. But though he is close to Ms. Shepard, four party officials in northern Manhattan interviewed last week say Mr. Farrell has made it clear he is backing Mr. Michels.
 Mr. Farrell insisted in an interview that he was not endorsing anyone in the race. But he admitted to a warm feeling for Mr. Michels, who has been his ally in local politics for a quarter-century. "I've always considered Stan a very hard worker for our community," he said.
 
 
 
Song's the Same
 A flurry of national attention surrounded last Friday's meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors in Hyannis, Mass., after its head, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, predicted that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would use the occasion to signal an intention to run for President.
 But even before Mr. Cuomo stepped into the hotel to speak, he gave a clear signal that there would be no such signal.
 Anyway, the signal was this: As he stepped out of his car, the Governor was greeted by Harry Belafonte, who was in town for an engagement at the Cape Cod Melody Tent.
 "You know, Harry," said Mr. Cuomo, who appeared bemused by the gaggle of national reporters who quickly surrounded him, "there's really nothing new in this speech. It'll be as familiar to you as your 'Day-O!' is to me."
 
 
 
For Love Nor Money
 Has New York State fallen out of love with itself?
 Not really. But like a devoted suitor who cannot afford an engagement ring, it no longer has the money to tell the world how it feels.
 It all gets back to budget problems. The state tourism budget, which reached a high of $15.8 million in 1988, officials said, is now down to $3 million. And since March, the state has not broadcast any of its "I (heart) NY" television commercials, some of which have featured Mr. Cuomo telling viewers, "you never knew love could be like this."
 While the State Department of Economic Development spent about $2 million last year on summer-oriented tourism advertising, there have been no such public displays of affection this year, although the state is hoping to begin a modest campaign in the fall.
 
 
 
Running or Jumping.
 Speaking of those who may or may not be running for President, add Ralph Nader to the list. The consumer advocate met recently with two of his former staff members who have filed papers with the Federal Election Commission to form a committee to draft Mr. Nader.
 Spearheading the effort is Carl Mayer, a Hofstra University law professor who worked for Mr. Nader's Center for the Study of Responsive Law about 10 years ago.
 "If enough citizens join together and indicate that they want him in the arena, he may relent," Mr. Mayer said. Mr. Mayer and his partner, Matthew Rothschild, publisher of The Progressive magazine, have not decided whether Mr. Nader should run as a Democrat or as an independent.
 The two organizers are optimistic about talking Mr. Nader into a run. "So far, " Mr. Rothschild said, "he hasn't told us to jump in the lake."

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 8; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1022 words

HEADLINE: Franchises Lure Seasoned Executives

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHEN Jeffrey Weiner saw the writing on the wall where he worked, he said, he began to consider going into business for himself.
Mr. Weiner, a 40-year-old former computer-leasing executive from Purchase, who described himself as the "top sales guy, making in excess of six figures a year for several years," said that he did not like the way his company was being managed and that he "wanted to have control of my own destiny." 
 Because he believes corporate executives today are not prepared to become small-business owners, he said, "I thought a franchise was the way to go. And I was very interested in a good master franchise area, such as Westchester or Fairfield."
Through a master franchise, a franchisee buys the right to a geographic territory, instead of just one location. The buyer then subfranchises as many locations as the area can support.
 
An Option to Making the Doughnuts
 Former high-level employees like Mr. Weiner or early retirees with golden parachutes may not be willing to "make the doughnuts or dish out the yogurt," said Thomas Everett of Franchise Service Consultants in Purchase, but their business experiences and access to capital makes them prime candidates for such franchises.
And Westchester has a plethora of such seasoned executives, said Peter I. Hoppenfeld, a franchise consultant in Mamaroneck. "Already the wave of middle and upper managers who have left corporate ranks have added a different dimension to franchising," he said.
Mr. Weiner is still looking for the right master franchise for him. After missing Blockbuster Video "by a couple of months," he said, he hopes to find something in sports memorabilia or video games.
Mr. Weiner is one example of the growth in franchises and master franchises, not only in Westchester, but also nationwide.
 
More Than Fast Food
 "Mention franchising and most people immediately think of fast food," Mr. Hoppenfeld said. "But these days, virtually every line of consumer business uses franchising in some form or another."
Mr. Hoppenfeld, a lawyer who is a partner in the S. H. Development Group, a franchise advisory service, said, "In my estimation there are probably about 5,000 franchisees in Westchester at this time. As for major franchises, the major franchisor in the country, Pepsico, which has Taco Bell and Pizza Hut among others, is here. Carvel was here until very recently. In the metropolitan area, including Westchester, Fairfield and greater New York, I would estimate that there are dozens of major franchisors headquartered in the area."
"It's probably the best way people can get into their own businesses," Mr. Everett said. "It is also one of the safest." Figures from the Commerce Department show that 80 percent of small businesses fail in their first year of operation. But the failure rate for franchises is about 5 percent.
Consultants who work with the Everett organization include several former International Business Machines executives, who go to outplacement companies to speak about franchising. "We talk about the up and down side of franchising," Mr. Everett said. "There's a lot of skepticism at first, but by the end of the meeting, the people in the audience -- who are executives aged 40 to 60 -- are pretty enthusiastic." Mr. Weiner attended one of those outplacement sessions in his search for a master franchise.
 
Getting in on the Ground Floor
 The returns on a master franchise can be very lucrative, said Carol Hance, director of Kidder Peabody, an investment banking firm in Manhattan that looks to franchises as investment opportunities.
"Master franchises are well suited to seasoned executives who aren't going to start their own business by flipping hamburgers," Ms. Hance said. "They're able to use their business skills to sell and monitor new franchises in their master-franchise territory and in return they get a monthly royalty from their franchisees. Some multi-unit franchises are already generating $200 million in annual sales."
Buyers of master franchises, Mr. Hoppenfeld said, are interested in building a good-size business. "They want to get in on the ground floor of a particular industry."
 
For Sale: Organic Lawn Care
 And in a recession, some companies, especially those in the retail business, are using franchising as a means of raising capital and lowering overhead expenses, Mr. Hoppenfeld said.
Others, like a client of his who is in the organic-lawn-care business, are using franchising to expand. Franchising helps companies expand quickly because the franchisee puts up the capital to open a new outlet. Once a franchise is operating, its owner pays the franchiser a monthly royalty of 2 to 10 percent of total sales.
In return for this capital, the franchiser usually supplies training, the territory, advertising assistance and supplies, Mr. Hoppenfeld said.
Stanley Kapica of Armonk, a partner in Turf Specialists of Middletown, said he expected to be marketing franchises, which will be priced at less than $10,000, by early next year.
Mr. Kapica, a former marketing executive, said he had beome interested in Turf Specialists when he began selling organic plant food to its owner, John Jones.
 
'An Emerging Industry'
 "We now have a joint-venture partnership," he said. "There has been a heightened interest and concern for the environment that shows up in Turf Specialists's business. I strongly feel that this is an emerging industry. I believe that more and more people are going to want to have organic products: not only homeowners but golf courses, apartment complexes. I think it is a growth market."
Franchises have also been growing rapidly overseas. "Especially those in the fast- food category," Ms. Hance said. "American executives are snapping them up for Eastern Europe and Mexico."
Similarly, Mr. Hoppenfeld's company recently became allied with Price Waterhouse, the international accounting firm, to provide franchise advisory services to Price Waterhouse's 450 offices worldwide. "Companies around the world are evaluating franchising as a method of distribution and expansion," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stanley Kapica of Armonk, a partner in Turf Specialists of Middletown, spraying a client's yard in Mamaroneck. He plans to market franchises in the organic services by next year. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Stowe

BYLINE: By JANET NELSON; JANET NELSON frequently writes about the outdoors.

 BODY:
From various spots around Stowe, Vt., in summer, it's easy to see how Mount Mansfield's Nosedive trail got its name. Most skiers who have gone down the trail's upper turns probably think the name alludes to its steepness. But from lower elevations, when Mount Mansfield is silhouetted against a deep blue summer sky, the profile of a man's face is clearly visible; below his nose is the Nosedive trail.
Summer business here is now estimated to exceed winter business, filling the 5,000 beds in the center village and along the Mountain Road (State Route 108) on most weekends. As in winter, the focus is on sports and the outdoors. The warm-weather schedule also includes classical concerts, repertory theater and exhibits at the village art center. 
 Some longtime visitors are not completely pleased with the changes brought by increasing numbers of tourists. They remember the Stowe of sleepier years when the Mountain Road was not so congested or dense with mini-malls. Many of the resorts are gentrified motels with original structures that date back 30 or more years, but new additions have changed their character.
For a booklet on accommodations and dining, contact Stowe Area Association, Main Street, Box 1320, Stowe, Vt. 05672; (802) 253-6617.
 
The Outdoors
 Mount Mansfield, highest peak in the state, attracts hikers to its 4,400-foot summit. There is a four-and-a-half-mile Toll Road ($10) that ends at the base of the nose on Mount Mansfield. Some visitors prefer taking the gondola ($9.50 round trip) to the Cliff House restaurant, lower on the mountain, and hiking down.
Smugglers Notch, a narrow pass with cliffs that reach 1,000 feet on either side, offers more difficult climbs. The Notch is said to have got its name in the War of 1812 when cattle were smuggled into New England from Canada. Over the years, the pass has grown from a footpath to an automobile road, but it is so narrow and winding that it is closed in winter. Even in summer, drivers pass through slowly, hugging the right side.
The easiest and most accessible hike is along the five-mile Recreation Path, a paved thoroughfare that starts in the center of the village and weaves toward Mount Mansfield. Bikes and roller blades can be rented at outfitters along the route, but most people hike or jog. Besides the Recreation Path, the region has an abundance of trails, including the Long Trail, which crosses Mount Mansfield and connects with 20 other hiking routes.
Golf is popular because of the 18-hole, par-71 course at the Stowe Country Club, (802) 253-4893. Greens fees are $36; cart rental, $14. There is a nine-hole course at the Farm Resort, (802) 888-3525, six miles north of Stowe on Route 100. Greens fees are $14 weekdays, $16 weekends; cart rental, $11. About 10 minutes away, the Copley Country Club, (802) 888-3013, off Maple Street in Morrisville, has an 18-hole course. Greens fees are $14; cart rental $17.
There is a 9-hole course in Waterbury, also about 10 minutes' drive from Stowe, at the Blush Hill Club, (802) 244-8974, off Exit 10 of Interstate 89. Greens fees are $15.75 on weekdays, $18 on weekends; cart rental, $15.75.
Many lodges offer packages with discount golf fees at the Stowe Country Club, and golf can be studied at the Natural Asset Golf School at Stoweflake Inn, (802) 253-7355, on the Mountain Road, which has two-day weekend or five-day midweek programs for guests at the resort as well as for those staying elsewhere. The five-day program costs $895 for each of two people sharing a room and includes accommodations, breakfast and dinner daily, daily morning instruction sessions and four days of golf.
There are about 50 tennis courts at lodges and inns, but the Topnotch Racquet Club, (802) 253-9649, on the Mountain Road, is the center of tennis with 4 indoor and 10 outdoor courts with rates of $15 an hour for the public and $10 for guests at the resort. In Stowe village, the high school tennis courts are free.
Horseback riding is also available at Edson Hill Manor, (802) 253-8954, on Edson Hill Road, where lessons cost $30 an hour and trail rides are $18 for 50 minutes, and at Topnotch, (802) 253-8585, with rates of $20 an hour for guided trail ride, $35 an hour for private lessons.
 
Events

The Grand Prix Horse Show, Aug. 14 to 25 at the Trapp Family Lodge, is the final test for riders who have entered a series of jumping events in Vermont. During the week, preliminary and schooling classes compete all day. On Saturday, starting at 1 P.M., 30 or more top riders from around the world compete in the International Jumping Derby. The fee to watch is $7, $5 for children.
Polo is another attraction with a series of matches through the summer. Most of the teams are from New England, but a few foreign groups add spice. The matches (free to spectators) are held several weekends a month at the Stowe Polo Field off Route 100 north of the village.
The Mountain Road antique market is held in three tents at the Topnotch Field from Aug. 31 to Sept. 1. More than 100 vendors participate. Entry fee is $3.
At the Foliage Craft Fair at the Topnotch Tennis Center on Sept. 28 and 29, about 160 Vermont artisans, many from the Stowe region, offer wares for sale. Entry fee: $4.
 
Performing Arts
 The Stowe Stage Company, (802) 253-7944 or (800) 388-4253, presents "Godspell" on Aug. 16 and 24; "Twelfth Night" on Aug. 17 and 23; "Sound of Music" on Aug. 14 and 21; "Equus" on Aug. 15 and 20; "Comedy of Errors" on Aug. 13 and 22, and "Judevine" from Aug. 27 to 31. Tickets are $12. Performances begin at 8 P.M. at the Stowe Playhouse on Mountain Road.
Concerts at the Gazebo on the Library Lawn are offered at noon on Saturdays in August.
 
Where to Stay
 There are close to 70 lodges in Stowe. About half of them qualify as country inns. Most establishments offer package plans with or without meals.
The Green Mountain Inn, Post Office Box 60, (800) 445-6629 or (802) 253-7301, at Stowe's main intersection of Routes 100 and 108, has been an inn from its founding in 1833. Rates: $45 to $65 a person a night. Behind the original facade, however, is a renovated interior plus an expansion that includes an outdoor swimming pool.
The Trapp Family Lodge, (800) 826-7000 or (802) 253-8511, at 42 Trapp Hill Road off Luce Hill Road, has been rebuilt from the 1980 fire that destroyed the original structure. It is still very Austrian -- and elegant and formal -- despite the modern sports center, swimming pool, tennis courts and other amenities; $180 to $210 for two.
The Stoweflake Inn and Resort, (800) 253-2232 or (802) 263-7355), Post Office Box 369, on Mountain Road, is an example of a motel-turned-resort. The rates range from $34 to $56 a person. On its 50 acres, the Stoweflake has outdoor and indoor pools, a sports center, saunas, a game room, tennis courts, lawn games, a golf practice tee, a conference center, a restaurant and a bar.
The Hadleigh House, 1386 Pucker Street, (802) 253-7703, is a converted farmhouse dating from the early 1800's with just three guest rooms. Rates are $55 a person with breakfast. The 1860 House Bed and Breakfast Inn, (800) 248-1860 or (802) 253-7351, Post Office Box 276, on School Street, has five rooms. Rates are $75 to $105 with breakfast.
Budget choices: The Yodler, (800) 227-1108 or (802) 253-4836, 123 Mountain Road, with rates of $39 to $85 for two; Golden Kitz, (800) 548-7568 or (802) 253-4217, 1965 Mountain Road ($46 to $60), and the Salzburg Inn, (800) 448-4554 or (802) 253-8541, Post Office Box 487, Mountain Road ($57 to $67).
 
Where to Eat
 There are about 40 restaurants in the village and along the Mountain Road. Reservations usually required.
Ten Acres Lodge, (802) 253-7638, 14 Barrows Road off Luce Hill Road, is an intimate country inn that specializes in scalloped veal with Italian fontina cheese and roast lamb with Vermont chevre served with local vegetables; each $19.
Topnotch, (802) 253-8585, on the Mountain Road, has wide-ranging fare that includes a spa menu; a popular dish is Hunan duck with a spicy sauce, wild rice pancake and vegetables for $19.50.
Stubbs, (802) 253-7110, on the Mountain Road at Edson Hill Road, has a ranch-like setting and features lamb, veal and seafood. The sauteed Vermont calf's liver with balsamic shallot sauce is $12.95.
There may be a wait at Whiskers, (802) 253-8996, on the Mountain Road, but cocktails in the garden make it pleasant. Lobsters, steaks and seafood are popular; prime rib with salad bar is $14.95.
The Shed, (802) 253-4364, on the Mountain Road, specializes in burgers and unusual salads. The Shedburger, served for 25 years, is marinated in beer and spices and served on an English muffin for $4.40.
Mr. Pickwick's Polo Pub, (802) 253-7558, on the Mountain Road, has a bar with 100 different beers and pub fare featuring pot pies as well as fish and chips, which costs $7.95.
 
Shopping
 Ski shops begin their end-of-season sales in March but get serious in summer. Along Main Street, four stores have the aura of shops in earlier days. Lackey's, (802) 253-7624, is part variety store, part museum. Next door is Stafford's Pharmacy, (802) 253-7361. If Lackey's doesn't have it, Stafford's probably does.
Across the street is Val's Country Store, (802) 253-8487, carrying homemade food products -- salads, sandwiches and the like.
Shaw's General Store, (802) 253-4040), a landmark since 1895, has catered to skiers and outdoors enthusiasts since 1966. More modern is the Silver Den, (802) 253-8787, on Main Street, with a collection of silver and gold jewelry made by Vermont craftspeople. A V-shaped slalom ring costs $10 in silver, $110 in gold.
Next door, Everything Cows, (802) 253-8779, reflects the importance of the dairy industry to the state's economy. There are cows to hug, wear, view, eat; boxer shorts printed in a cow motif cost $14 to $18.
Exclusively Vermont, (802) 253-8776), around the corner on the Mountain Road, offers good design, unusual items, typical crafts -- all of them made in the state. Simon Pearce glass goblets, for example, are about $36 each.

LENGTH: 719 words

HEADLINE: Liz Taylor's Great Society

BYLINE: By Barbara Ehrenreich; Barbara Ehrenreich is author, most recently, of "The Worst Years of Our Lives: Irreverent Notes on a Decade of Greed."

 BODY:
Hats off to Liz Taylor for her decision to marry a blue-collar man, the construction worker Larry Fortensky. Other stars talk about grave social problems. They stud the star-studded benefits. They assemble in great tuneless choirs to sing to us about the issues of the day. But Liz, bless her durable little heart, proposes to actually get something done.
The social problem in question is the one that goes by such ungainly terms as "class polarization" or the "shrinking middle class" -- the insidious economic trend that is making the rich richer, the poor poorer and the middle class exceedingly nervous. 
 Liz must have read the same grim bulletin that just crossed my desk, "Selective Prosperity: Increasing Income Disparities since 1977," from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. She must have shuddered delicately, much as I did, at the news that middle-income households are barely holding their own while the richest 1 percent of Americans have seen their incomes more than double since the late 1970's. She must have called together her hairdressers, nutritionists, masseuses, publicists -- and for all we know her resident economist -- and cried, "What in God's name can I do?"
And they must have pointed out to her the particular problem of young blue-collar males, whose income in real dollars has been declining for over a decade, leaving them loath to marry. After all, when a blue-collar man marries a socioeconomic equal -- say, a waitress or data-entry clerk -- he takes on a lifelong commitment to fast food, discount furniture and unpaid medical bills. But there is, Liz's staff must have said, an alternative.
The surprising thing is that the Democrats haven't picked up on the Liz Taylor approach. They remain mired in comparatively stale, old-fashioned ideas like extending unemployment benefits. They know that the sure-fire remedy for inequality -- the redistribution of wealth -- is considered boneheaded and atavistic. Unless, of course, the Republicans are promoting it, in which case the redistribution invariably goes uphill. But the Democrats have yet to see the potential of financially redistributive marriages, which are arguably the only truly "pro-family" approach to the economic woes of the middle class.
Consider your average female movie star, with assets in the seven-figure range. If she marries Warren Beatty, which is always a possibility, she will be locking her wealth into the colossal loot already accumulated by those at the top of the pyramid. There is, for example, the disquieting spectacle of Jane Fonda, erstwhile friend of the dispossessed, pooling her aerobics fortune with Ted Turner's vast earnings from CNN. But if our average star were to marry a truck driver, or, better yet, a bus boy. . . .
Are there enough stars, one might ask? Just as the middle class is shrinking, so too is the class of female film stars, who have little to contribute to the great cinematic theme of our age -- the effect of steroids on the human male.
Here I can only point to Madonna, who is shown in her recent film with a constant retinue of a half-dozen young men who might otherwise be dragging down the employment statistics.
Will these couples get along? In the past it was fashionable to think of men like Larry Fortensky as crude clones of Archie Bunker. But we know today that a blue-collar boyfriend is no more likely to be physically abusive than the average blue-blooded medical student. He is, furthermore, accustomed to manual labor and able to operate a vacuum cleaner or change a diaper without being moved to write a press release about it.
And in contrast to your average white male professor type, a blue-collar guy will accept the occasional tip on avoiding sexism without indulging in a full-scale tantrum on the evils of political correctness.
So I see no reason not to proceed apace with the Taylor solution. In fact, the program needn't be only for stars. I envision a vast social healing as the genders and classes come together in socially responsible mating: lawyers and lathe operators, M.B.A.'s and machinists, brokers and bicycle messengers.
After all, even the Democrats seem to agree that all the other approaches -- those involving "programs" and taxes, wages and benefits -- are too dreary and dated for words.

HEADLINE: Issues Linger in Europe's Japan Auto Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The recent agreement between the European Community and Japan to limit Japanese car imports may be the most important quota arrangement in the history of global trade.
The accord will restrict sales of Japanese cars for seven years in what will become by far the world's largest auto market once the European Community removes its internal trade barriers by the end of 1992. 
 European auto makers hailed the agreement, which was announced on July 31, saying it gives them precious time to become more efficient before they face the brunt of Japanese competition. The Continent's auto makers vow to emerge from the seven years of protection far better equipped to compete with Nissan, Toyota and Honda than Detroit's bruised and bloodied Big Three have been able to do.
But some economists say the agreement could prove a disaster, by causing the Europeans to delay efforts to become more efficient. At the same time, these economists say, the community's quotas could cause the Japanese to build more plants in Europe, just as American quotas on cars from Japan encouraged the Japanese to build assembly plants in the United States.
The first of what are likely to be many battles stemming from the vaguely worded agreement has already broken out over the issue of Japanese production in Europe. Many Europeans, notably the French and Italians, boast that they were smarter than the Americans in negotiating their agreement, asserting that the accord sets a ceiling on the number of cars the Japanese can produce in Europe.
Community officials say they negotiated the agreement with the understanding that Japan's auto makers will produce no more than 1.2 million cars in Europe by 1999 -- up from 260,000 now but well below the 1.8 million cars a year that some industry and government officials had long predicted that the Japanese would be assembling in Europe by 1999.
But the Japanese heatedly deny that the accord sets a ceiling on their European production. Indeed, the Japanese say that what pleases them most is that the agreement does not place an express ceiling on the number of cars they can assemble in Europe. According to this interpretation, Nissan and Toyota would face no barriers to expanding their British plants.
"Whether this will be 1.2 million or not, this is what the E.C. Commission said unilaterally," Yutaka Kume, president of the Nissan Motor Company, said in an interview. "This is not something that will bind the Japanese side."
Some Europeans argue that if production of these Japanese "transplants" exceeds 1.2 million units, then import ceilings should be lowered correspondingly. To the extent that the agreement encourages the Japanese to build plants in Europe, among the few clear winners here would be the European auto parts companies like the German manufacturer Robert Bosch G.m.b.H.
 
Import Limit Is 1.23 Million Cars
 The agreement, which runs from the end of 1992 to the end of 1999, in effect freezes Japanese car imports at 1.23 million units. This would give Japanese imports 8.1 percent of the 15.1 million cars that government officials expect to be sold in the European Community in 1999, compared with 12.2 million cars last year. By comparison, last year's United States market was 9.3 million cars.
Under the strict European interpretation of the accord, Japanese imports and transplants could take 16.1 percent of the market, up from the current share, which is slightly above 10 percent.
"As far as the volume manufacturers are concerned, it gives them a certain breathing space by keeping the Japanese at unnaturally low levels until the year 2000," said Stephen Reitman, an auto industry analyst for UBS Phillips & Drew, a London brokerage. "It will also help focus governments and work forces on the need to achieve competitive efficiencies."
 
Some Pain for Europe's Big Six
 Still, by giving the Japanese five additional market-share points, the accord certain will mean some pain for Europe's Big Six: Volkswagen, Fiat, Peugeot, Renault, General Motors Europe and Ford Europe.
Some pain was inevitable because the whole idea of 1992 and a barrier-free Europe was to create more robust competition. France, Italy, Britain, Spain and Portugal have long had national quotas on Japanese car imports, but with 1992 on the horizon community officials insisted on scrapping these intra-community trade barriers. In their place, however, Europe's auto makers, led by Peugeot, Renault and Fiat, insisted on communitywide quotas to shelter them from unbridled competition.
Community officials, who vow to support free trade, felt pressure to open up their market to Japanese cars, so they decided on this seven-year transition period, which includes informal, slightly higher national quotas. After 1999, all limits on Japanese cars are supposed to be lifted. Most people, however, expect auto executives to push for extending the quotas, as happened in the United States.
In France, Japanese imports will be allowed to climb to 150,000, or 5.2 percent of the country's market, from their longtime ceiling of 3 percent. In Italy, Japanese imports can climb to 138,000 or 5.3 percent of the market, up from their decades-old limit of less than 2 percent.
 
A Sacrosanct Industry
 That the community allowed the continuation of any sort of informal national quotas, thus violating the spirit of 1992, shows how sacrosanct Europe's auto industry is. Although European politicians campaign for a barrier-free Europe, few are willing to see their auto industries collapse, bringing with it lost jobs and perhaps lost elections. Renault's chairman, Raymond Levy, predicts that at least 200,000 workers will be laid off as Europe's auto makers strain to cope with Japanese competition.
Some analysts say Volkswagen and the General Motors Corporation, with its powerful Opel division, might fare the best from the agreement because they have thrived in Germany's relatively open market. Still, with considerable sales in France, Italy and Spain, they may suffer as Japan's auto makers take larger shares in those countries.
Between imports and transplants, the Japanese could take 9 percent or more in France and Italy, compared with less than 3 percent in those markets a few years ago. Since Fiat S.p.A. has about half the Italian market, and Peugeot S.A. and Renault together have three-fifths of the French market, the accord could hurt these companies more than some others.
Still, some analysts suggest that the agreement might hit Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Porsche hardest. "As with other automobile quota agreements, this will encourage an upgrading of Japanese imports," said Jeffrey Schott, an economist with the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "There will be even stronger competition on the higher end of the market where profit per unit is higher."
He said the accord could mean fatter profits for the Japanese, which they could pump back into their operations, giving them a competitive advantage.
Over all, some call the accord a victory for Japan's auto makers because it means a higher market share. But others call it a defeat for Tokyo because the Japanese were given neither free access nor the 18 percent market share that community officials had suggested last year. Hard-line officials like Prime Minister Edith Cresson of France helped bargain down Japan's allowable market share.
"It's probably the best agreement the Japanese could get without causing a significant political conflict with the E.C." said Peter Cope, an analyst with DRI/McGraw-Hill in London.
The accord -- which several officials called "a gentlemen's agreement" because it is not signed -- states, "Japan bears in mind the E.C.'s concern that the necessary adjustments of the E.C. manufacturers toward adquate levels of international competitiveness would be adversely affected if the E.C. manufacturers cannot enjoy the adequate benefit of market growth."
The agreement calls for twice-yearly talks under which the accord might be adjusted if, for instance, Japanese imports exceed anticipated levels or if European auto sales plunge.
 
Learning Detroit's Lesson
 Europe's auto makers vow to be more aggressive in improving their competitiveness than Detroit was. They say they have absorbed the lessons that Detroit learned the hard way, among them: slash costs, reorganize production, listen more closely to the customer and move more quickly from new design to production.
"In Europe it was never so much a question of quality," said one European auto executive. "It was cost. It was productivity. We haven't yet reached the productivity of the Japanese."
Because everyone assumes the Japanese will build more plants in Europe, the Europeans are straining to make their own plants as efficient and low cost as those of their archcompetitors. G.M. officials point to their new plant in Eisenach, in eastern Germany, while Volkswagen expects quality low-cost production at its new plants in Czechoslovakia and outside Barcelona, Spain. In addition to new, highly automated plants in southern Italy, Fiat is looking to projects in Poland and the Soviet Union.
"We know the Japanese challenge," said an official with G.M. Europe. "We know European car manufacturers have to improve continually."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Outside Publishing Centers, A Giant Bookstore Prospers

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
Great bookstores, like great restaurants, are usually associated with great cities, where they provide the world-weary with a respite from urban grit.
Yet what may be America's largest bookstore sits not in midtown Manhattan or Chicago's South Side, but on the slope of a hill near a brewery here in the nation's 32d-largest city. 
 In spacious, well-lit aisles covering a city block, Powell's Books crowds nearly a million copies of 550,000 titles. Its 132 sections -- which range from broad subjects like "Children" to categories as tiny as "Spiders" -- are a bustling literary and social oasis in downtown Portland.
The theology section, three aisles long and 10 shelves high, has five shelves devoted solely to feminist theology and two for books on sex and celibacy. The store's "Purple Room," one of six large chambers designated by colors, contains seven shelves of Japanese-language fiction.
As for the poetry section, 9,000 titles strong, "we got the Robert Bly, we got the Robert Service, we got the Robert Browning," said Michael Powell, the store's 50-year-old owner.
Powell's defies most of the conventions of modern book-selling and exemplifies what many publishing professionals believe is a resurgence of the independent bookstore after a decade of dominance by chains like Waldenbooks and B. Dalton.
With their understanding of local interests and willingness to stock many titles, many independents have shown signs of vigor. Meanwhile, the chains, which emphasize best sellers, have suffered from a recession-related decline in shopping mall traffic. Indeed, with an eye on the success of large independents, several chains are opening so-called superstores, with large and diverse stocks.
 
Plenty of Used Books
 Unlike the typical mall bookstore, with an average of about 3,000 square feet in space, Powell's has 43,000 square feet set aside in its main store for page-thumbing. While it carries virtually every popular contemporary book, half the two million volumes that Powell's expects to sell this year will be used books.
And where computers have become the lifeline of the book business, telling store owners what is in stock and when to reorder, Powell's sticks to a manual system of inventory cards, maintained by the 75 people who run the store's sections.
These section heads meet regularly with 30 used-book buyers, who acquire 3,000 books a week and do their peruse-and-purchase routine at a table just inside the store's entrance.
"We're trying to make a statement of what the store's about," said Miriam Sontz, Powell's general manager. "But we've also found that customers love to watch us buy books. It's like going into a restaurant and watching the chefs work."
 
A Challenge in Denver
 Only the Tattered Cover in Denver, with 40,000 square feet of retail space and 150,000 new titles, can challenge Powell's for the distinction of being America's largest bookstore, publishing professionals say.
They offer several explanations for the existence of places like Powell's in smaller cities outside the loop of mainstream publishing. Some believe that Portland's rainy weather makes reading a more popular pastime.
Others say that a great bookstore grows from one seed: its owner.
"Cities give rise to a Powell's and a Tattered Cover because of a Michael Powell and a Joyce Meskis," said Joe Friedman, who until recently was the membership director of the American Booksellers Association. "These people could have kept their stores at 3,000 square feet and done very well. But people were reading, so they decided to keep growing."
 
'Explosion of Reading'
 Mr. Powell has his own explanation for his store's success. "In the 80's, there was an explosion of reading," he said.
Those are encouraging words for a $17 billion industry in desperate need of hope. The American Booksellers Association projects that book sales will grow 8.2 percent this year, compared with 12.3 percent last year.
But Mr. Powell has reason for optimism, having seen his empire blossom from a 2,500-square-foot collection of used books in 1971. Today, the giant Portland store alone now sells more than $10 million worth of books a year, he said.
Other Powell's stores include a 10,000-square-foot annex for technical books, specialty stores devoted to cookbooks and travel books, and another large store in the Portland suburb of Beaverton.
There are also three Powell's stores in Chicago, where Mr. Powell began his career as a bookseller when, as a graduate student at the University of Chicago, he was encouraged by several professors, including the author Saul Bellow, to take over a bookstore. With a $3,000 stake from the sociologist Morris Janowitz, Mr. Powell assumed the lease.
He paid Professor Janowitz back within two months.
