HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fall in 30-Year Yields Is Not Expected Soon

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Investors and economists still expect bond yields to fall eventually from the current level of 8.22 percent for 30-year Treasury issues, but they are not optimistic that the drop will come soon.
Yields on Treasury bonds are much more influenced by traders who are looking for a quick profit in response to immediate reports on inflation and the economy than by long-term forecasts about the attractiveness of today's yields compared with predictions that next year's inflation will be below 4 percent. 
 Many analysts say this week's economic reports are not likely to create the kind of speculative fervor that would lift bond prices and lower yields. But neither are the reports likely to disprove the idea that bond yields might eventually fall as the economic recovery remains sluggish, with no upward inflation pressure.
 
7 3/4 Yield Called Possible
 "One of these days, the bond market is going to wake up and decide that inflation is below 5 percent and might even stay below 4 percent for a sustained period," said G. A. David Gray, co-director of fixed-income investments at the Boston Company, a unit of the American Express Company. "When that happens you could easily see the long bond yield drop to 7 3/4 percent."
But Mr. Gray, like many other investors, is not making any bet that a big decline in bond yields is imminent. For the time being, he expects to hold the maturity of the funds he manages about unchanged, and continue to follow a middle-of-the-road investment philosophy with maturities that match the mix of outstanding issues in the market.
Since bond yields have already fallen from nearly 8 1/2 percent as recently as July 23, the bond market may be "particularly vulnerable to less favorable news" this week about consumer prices and retail sales, said Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
 
An Uninspiring Report
 Surveys by MMS International, an economic analysis firm, show that the Consumer Price Index for July is expected to rise four-tenths of a percentage point, an uninspiring report that would suggest an annual inflation rate still in the range of 3.5 percent to 4.5 percent. Retail sales for July are widely expected to show an increase of about four-tenths of a percent, or better than the average gain of one-tenth of a percent in the last three months, while industrial production could rise about three-tenths of a percent.
"The bond market still has bitter memories of the last recovery, when the Fed tighened as the economy picked up, and by 1984 you had 14 percent Treasury bond yields and massive losses in investment portfolios," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Morgan Grefell. "The market remains scared of a strong economy, and it will need time to be convinced that inflation is not going to ratchet up and the Fed is not going to tighten."
 
Aug. 20 Meeting Planned
 It is widely expected that the Federal Reserve will hold short-term interest rates stable at least until the Aug. 20 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. At that meeting, many economsits expect Fed officials to settle on a policy favoring further easing moves, contingent on weak economic data and, of course, continued low inflation readings.
A review of March 1986 to March 1987 -- the last time that Treasury bond yields stayed below 8 percent (except for a few months in late 1989) -- is a reminder that a Fed move to lower interest rates may not be necessary to attract buyers to longer-term issues.
In July 1986, when 30-year Treasury bond yields averaged only 7.27 percent, the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market averaged 6.56 percent, a percentage point higher than currently, and 30-day commercial paper rates averaged 6.42 percent, or eight-tenths of a percentage point higher than now.
 
Large Amount of New Bonds
 Apart from gauging fresh economic data, the bond market is confronted by a large amount of new 8 1/8 percent Treasury bonds, which remain in the hands of dealers who bought the bonds at Thursday's auction at an average price of about 99 1/2 to yield 8.15 percent. Between July 29 and the auction, bond prices rose about 2 1/4 points, but have since dropped more than half a point.
"There is potential for more of a rally, but securities dealers bought the new Treasury issue at the top of the market and it is going to take a while to distribute," said Glenn I. Henricksen, vice president and portfolio manager at the New York Life Insurance Company.
The task of finding buyers becomes more difficult, he added, when there is an ample supply of new corporate and mortgage-backed secutities offering higher yields. With a borrowing cost of less than 9 percent available for good-quality companies, he said, "there has been talk that a good many well-known household names might come to market."

HEADLINE: Steel Hits Hard Times Again

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
In the late 1980's, when steel producers were seeing some of their most robust times in years, industry executives boasted that their companies had become so lean that they could make money running at 60 to 65 percent of capacity.
Now, American steel plants are running at 70 percent capacity, and many industry analysts expect the steelmakers' losses to exceed $1 billion for the first half of this year. 
 American steelmakers have matched the efficiency of their German and Japanese rivals, but sinking prices, sagging demand and rising labor costs have caused them more hard times. Even as the economy shows signs of emerging from the recession, the evidence of the industry's renewed woes are abundant.
 
Potential Cash Squeeze
 On average, the large steel companies lost $50 a ton in the first quarter of this year -- for a total loss of $700 million, compared with net earnings of $400 million in last year's first quarter. And while not all steel companies have reported earnings for the second quarter -- typically the strongest quarter of the year -- analysts estimate that the industry will post operating losses of another $400 million for that three-month period, compared with operating income of $170 million in the 1990 period.
The American steelmakers' share of the domestic market has actually risen in the last year by about 3 percentage points, to about 80 percent. But continued losses will pinch the steelmakers' ability to invest in the technology necessary to keep up with foreign competitors and comply with environmental laws.
For many workers, the recent months have been eerily reminiscent of the recession in the early 80's, when thousands were laid off.
"These are the worst times I've seen since 1982," said L. E. Smith, president of Local 185 of the United Steelworkers of America, which represents workers at the LTV Steel Company's operations on the west side of Cleveland. He said about 800 workers were idled for about two months earlier this year before being recalled.
"We had hoped that the layoff days were over, but they weren't," Mr. Smith said. "You can't get any worse off than someone being without an income."
To be sure, steel producers in the United States have become much leaner and far more efficient in recent years. Sweeping plant closings, staff reductions and new equipment have caused the number of worker hours needed to produce a ton of steel to drop steadily, to fewer than 4 today, from 6 in 1988 and 11 in 1982.
Many in the industry say that continuing cutbacks in the labor force will further improve efficiency, even as layoffs, early retirements and the raises guaranteed in contracts burden companies with other costs.
Despite the current problems, Joseph N. Gross, manager of strategic planning at LTV Steel, insists that the industry is poised to benefit from the $18 billion that has been invested in plants over the last decade, with billions more to come. So long as the losses do not extend for too many quarters, he said, "the industry's capital spending plans will generally not be affected."
 
Concern Over Prices
 But many industry experts contend that the ability of the steelmakers to emerge from their slump will depend largely on their pricing. Foreign producers have faced far less pressure; steel prices in Japan are as much as $100 a ton higher than in the United States. With demand from American automobile and appliance producers slipping, steel producers have been eager to hold on to whatever market share they can.
That has meant widespread discounting. As a result, the average price for a ton of hot-rolled sheet steel -- the basic product used in everything from pipes and automobile parts to traffic signs and file cabinets -- has slid on spot markets from $345 at the beginning of last year, to about $280 now. And steel buyers said they could usually get prices that are even slightly lower.
"The biggest problem in the steel industry is the pricing situation," said John Jacobson, a steel analyst with AUS Consultants Inc. in Philadelphia. "Prices are now as low as they have been in a decade. Until they do something about the pricing situation, the steel industry will stay in trouble."
LTV Steel, the nation's third-largest producer, reported a $48.8 million loss in the first quarter, including a $32 million charge to cover future medical insurance for retirees. About 400 of the 1,000 workers laid off over the last year are still idle. The company said that its new orders had dropped and that it had had to scale back operations at the Cleveland mill, where it produces steel ingots.
"Prices are now at 1982 levels, and when you look at virtually any other commodity or product, that is simply not the case," Mr. Gross said. "There has been an impact from the recession in that we and the entire industry are worse off because we lost money. When you lose money over the long run, you can't have funds to keep the plants competitive."
The recession's impact extends far beyond LTV. The USX Corporation's steel division, the nation's largest producer, had an operating loss of $502 million in the first quarter, including charges against earnings to cover the closing of its Fairless Works steel operations near Philadelphia and the layoffs of 2,100 employees. The company said overcapacity at home and abroad and declining prices had made the plant closing necessary. USX said its steel business had a $39 million operating loss for the second quarter.
Inland Steel Industries closed its structural steel business along the Indiana shore of Lake Michigan, which produced steel for buildings, bridges and construction, earlier this year. Many of the 325 workers took early retirement or were laid off. Inland, which lost $18.7 million in the first quarter, said competition had become too sharp.
The LTV Corporation said its steel division had a $23.4 million loss in the second quarter. Bethlehem Steel, the nation's No. 2 steelmaker, reported a $29 million net loss for the second quarter.
The industry's plans for a fall pricing offensive have only a modest chance of success. LTV Steel touched off the campaign in July when it announced price increases on a number of sheet-steel products, beginning Sept. 29. Several other steel producers responded with their own increases, but many analysts doubt that the increases will stick.
Buyers resisted Bethlehem Steel's attempt to raise prices last year, forcing the company to cut its increases by half. In the industry's most recent efforts to bolster prices, Bethlehem is already undercutting its competitors. After some rivals announced plans to raise prices on some sheet-steel products by about 7 percent this fall, Bethlehem said it would only ask for 4 percent more.
 
Optimism in Industry
 But industry executives are optimistic that higher prices will stick this time. "These price increases will hold because the industry realizes that we're still at 1982 price levels," said Mr. Gross of LTV. "We have to get a return on our investment."
Executives contend that the worst times are already over. "The auto makers are talking about stronger third- and fourth-quarter schedules," said Andy Ellwain, general manager of market sales for Inland Steel. "The appliance industry also is beginning to recover, with increased production at all of our strategic appliance customers."
But analysts question the health of the industry, in view of its failure to at least break even with factories running at 70 percent of capacity. Even if demand surges, they say, steelmakers will see brighter days only if they resist the urge to reach for a larger slice of the market by cutting prices.

HEADLINE: Harry Helmsley: Unfit for Trial, but Fit for Business?

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The people who worked with him are already beginning to talk about Harry Helmsley in the past tense, and the United States Attorney in Manhattan has dropped tax-evasion charges against him, citing what he regards as Mr. Helmsley's mental incompetence. The man who was a kingpin of New York real estate for more than five decades has receded from public view to the point of vanishing.
Yet Mr. Helmsley's immense real-estate operation is still moving along, shrunk in size, less vigorous, but possessing the many complex partnerships and service contracts that have been the foundation of his wealth. And despite the possible prison term that his wife, Leona, faces for tax evasion and his court-determined incompetence to stand trial, Mr. Helmsley appears to continue at the head of his companies.
 
'He Gives Us His Input'
 "All major decisions are made by Mr. Helmsley," said Gerald N. Schrager, the Helmsleys' real-estate lawyer and chief legal adviser and, since the legal and business troubles involving him and his wife began, the Helmsley spokesman. "He gives us his input every time he thinks it is appropriate." 
 If the 81-year-old Mr. Helmsley is in charge of holdings estimated at more than $4 billion, still by far the largest commercial real-estate brokerage in New York City, is he senile?
To what extent has Mrs. Helmsley's criminal notoriety, her infamous temper, her description by her own defense lawyer as "one tough bitch" and her depiction in a television movie as a cruel and dishonest "Queen of Mean" affected her husband's business?
And who will determine the future of the Helmsley operation?
In withdrawing 47 charges of fraud and tax evasion, Federal prosecutors relied on competency tests supervised by the State Supreme Court in Manhatttan, where the Helmsleys had faced similar state charges that were dismissed. According to court documents, those tests relied in part on evaluations conducted by doctors hired by Mr. Helmsley and his lawyers. Those doctors said Mr. Helmsley could not stand the strain of a trial.
 
No Comment by U.S. Attorney
 Asked to comment on the apparent discrepancy between Mr. Schrager's account of Mr. Helmsley's current abilities and the court finding of mental incompetence, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan declined to comment directly. The office's public information officer, Deborah Corley Guzman, said, "I would refer you to the wording of the motion to dismiss."
Mrs. Helmsley, who is now 71, was sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan to four years in prison for her part in the tax-fraud scheme, in which the Helmsleys' were accused of charging personal expenses to their business ventures. On July 31 the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld her conviction but sent her case back to the trial court for resentencing.
 
Finding by Psychiatrist
 On May 23, meanwhile, Dr. Murray A. Gordon, a psychiatrist, concluded that Mr. Helmsley suffered from dementia caused by hypertension and poor cerebral blood circulation. Dr. Murray wrote that the developer "lacks capacity to understand the proceedings against him, or to assist in his own defense."
But Mr. Schrager said Mr. Helmsley still presided over a multimillion-dollar property and services empire that was "stabilized." It is also one that has been shrinking in recent years, and one that Mr. Helmsley is, by the available evidence, trying to shrink further.
He has already shed some outlying brokerage holdings, his Manhattan real-estate insurance operations and his long-term lease on the million-square foot former Macy's warehouse in Long Island City, Queens. He is also seeking buyers for his Harley Hotel chain and for his residential brokerage and management company, Brown Harris Stevens Inc.
Perhaps most important in terms of prestige, Mr. Helmsley's partners in the jewel in the crown, the Helmsley Palace Hotel, are trying to force the Helmsleys out of control of the hotel and, Mr. Helmsley's consultants say, force the sale of the Palace.
The Palace partners' assert that the Helmsleys' billing of the costs of improving their Connecticut house to the hotel, and Mrs. Helmsley's criminal conviction arising from those actions, were responsible for the hotel's disappointing financial performance in recent years.
 
Major Role by 'Queen'
 Several former Helmsley employees insisted in interviews that Mrs. Helmsley has had a major impact, at first for the better, but more recently for the worse. She was a brilliant if ruthless real-estate executive, they say, and the nationwide advertising campaign that identified her as the "Queen" standing guard over customer services at the Palace produced great dividends.
But her tightening control over the Helmsley operation and, by many accounts, over Mr. Helmsley himself has been just as damaging, said these former associates, who asked that they not be identified.
 
Trial Led to Defections
 No one in the management of the company returned telephone calls for comment, and Howard J. Rubenstein, Mr. Helmsley's public-relations consultant, referred all questions to Mr. Schrager. Mr. Schrager did not respond to a request to interview the Helmsleys.
Several former Helmsley-Spear associates were blunt in their criticism of Mrs. Helmlsey, who is still listed as a broker at Brown Harris Stevens, but who does not appear to have had a role in the company's day-to-day operations since her 1989 conviction for fraud and tax evasion.
The former employees' criticism focuses on both Mrs. Helmsley's actions within the business, where she was noted for on-the-spot dismissals that Mr. Helmsley occasionally reversed, and on her public notoriety before, during and after the tax-evasion trial. The latter cost the company credibilty, said a former Brown Harris Steven broker who was part of a mass dismissal last October, and who now works at another management concern.
The broker said many shareholders in buildings managed by Brown Harris Stevens read about Mrs. Helmsley's paying personal expenses out of business accounts and no longer wanted the company to manage their building.
Perhaps as a consequence, and perhaps also because of a growing fragmentation of the city's co-op management industry, Brown Harris Stevens's client list has been shrinking, with a half-dozen trophy buildings forsaking the company for other agencies.
Mrs. Helmsley meanwhile is in seclusion with her husband while her appeal is pending.
"When the leader passes on," another former Helmsley-Spear broker said, using the now familiar past tense when speaking of Mr. Helmsley, "there is still the framework of a very big company there, even though the momentum and the energy are drifting away. Now the company is just waiting for the next leader to come along."
 
Associates Become Managers
 Mr. Helmsley is childless, and with his wife facing a possible prison term, day-to-day management of the company has fallen to two of Mr. Helmsley's oldest associates, Irving Scheider and Alvin Schwartz. Both are major shareholders in Helmsley-Spear and are reported to have an agreement to buy Mr. Helmsley's position on his death.
Craig Panzirer, Mrs. Helmsley's grandson from one of her two earlier marriages, is a salesman in the company but is not yet regarded as a potential successor to the helm.
Mr. Schrager, the lawyer, declined to account for the discrepancy between the court report of mental incompetence and Mr. Helmsley's reported command of his business. He spoke only of Mr. Helmsley as contented and in control.
"From a global view, the Helmsley interests are stabilized," Mr. Schrager said. "They are not exposed to the vagaries of the marketplace to the extent that the rest of the real-estate busines has been. We are not undertaking any new development projects at this time, because the marketplace doesn't call for any, and we are basically focusing on managing the existing interests."
But what activity there is constitutes shrinkage.
The Harley Hotel chain of 14 hotels in the East and Middle West has been rumored to be for sale for some time. Mr. Schrager offered only a faint denial, saying it has "not been actively put on the market," though the company would enterain offers.
Last year Mr. Helmsley sold Helmsley-Greenfield, a Philadelphia-based brokerage with several mid-Atlantic branch offices, Mr. Schrager said, while Brown Harris Stevens Inc., the residential management and brokerage company, has been on the market for nearly a year.
 
Insurance Business Transferred
 Helmsley-Spear's big insurance department, which wrote policies on both commercial and residential properties, has also been transferred, under terms neither side would reveal, to the Frank B. Hall Insurance Company, controlled by Saul Steinberg, the financier.
Helmsley-Spear Inc., meanwhile, has been shrinking internally as well, perhaps to a greater extent than the many other brokerage and management concerns that have been forced to cut back in the current real-estate recession.
In 1986 a standard directory of Manhattan real-estate brokerages listed Helmsley-Spear's headquarters at the Lincoln Building, 60 East 42d Street, 27 branch offices nationwide, 86 brokers and 145 sales people. The current directory shows nine national offices, not counting the old Helmsley-Greenfield affiliates, 67 brokers and 59 sales people.
Besides the hotels, the brokerage and the management agencies, Mr. Helmsley controls a handful of important buildings, although real-estate ownership has never been as large a part of his wealth as it has been for some of the city's other real-estate leaders.
After seeing Mr. Helmsley not too long ago, Mr. Schrager reported: "He said, 'I've only had one job, but it's the only one I've needed, and I think it has worked out fairly well.' And I said, 'It certainly has, Mr. H.' "

GRAPHIC: Table: "Helmsley's Manhattan Real Estate Empire"
 
Harry B. Helmsley's owns an interest in many properties in New York City and across the country through private syndication partnerships. His firms, Helmsley-Spear Inc. and Helmsley-Noyes Inc., have refused to list these interests, for which no public record exists.

HEADLINE: Labor Cuts by New York City Are Fewer Than Anticipated

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
To Diane Tripp, New York City's fiscal crisis has been a personal betrayal. Her job as a Health Department contract administrator gone, she worries about paying her $764-a-month rent in Flatbush and supporting her 7-year-old son. She broods about relocating to "a place that is up-and-coming fiscally, like New York used to be."
But so far, the pain from the city's fiscal troubles has flowed deep, but not wide. A month after the tumultuous adoption of a $28.7 billion recession-driven budget, just over one in 100 city workers has lost a job, far fewer than the Dinkins administration had predicted. And the most onerous service cuts have yet to be carried out. 
 "Its obvious that at this point, doomsday has not arrived," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the state Municipal Assistance Corporation, who had worried that the budget cuts could have catastrophic consequences.
 
Less Doom Than Promised
 So far, 3,013 city employees have been laid off from a total work force of 243,000, according to a recent city tally. That is far fewer than the 6,300 reported to have been laid off in June, or the 14,500 layoffs called for in Mr. Dinkins's budget in April. During a similar period in July 1975, amid a deeper fiscal crisis, 26,000 workers were laid off, according to budget officials.
The most striking change between expectation and reality occurred at the Board of Education. Earlier this year, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez warned of 10,000 layoffs, including as many as 7,000 teachers. Now, with increased enrollment and budget cuts expected to increase class size, the board may be hiring new teachers, rather than laying them off, city budget officials say.
And in protracted negotiations with municipal labor unions, many workers who were already laid off may get their jobs back if the city and the unions can agree on cost-saving concessions.
 
Politics, Luck or a Ploy
 City officials attribute the lower number of layoffs to a combination of politics, luck and skillful planning. Some jobs were saved through last-minute negotiations with the City Council, they say, others though stepped up attrition or an early-retirement program in the schools.
They say Mr. Dinkins remains committed to reducing the work force by more than 7,000 jobs next June, through 3,100 additional layoffs if necessary. "If we can reduce the need for layoffs, that is good news," said Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director.
Mr. Michael despaired of pleasing the city's critics: "First they said we couldn't do it. Then they said it wasn't as elegant as you want it to be. Then they said what about next year? How do you know you can do it next year?"
But some fiscal analysts and labor leaders contend that over the last year, Mr. Michael has repeatedly exaggerated the need for layoffs as a bargaining ploy -- much as he called for turning off 74,000 street lights to save money -- in an unsuccessful effort to pressure the unions for concessions.
 
'Crying Wolf Once Too Often'
 "I don't want to gloat, because we have 3,000 people out there without jobs, but we have been saying to the Mayor's people all along: You can do it with attrition and early retirement, not 10,000 layoffs," said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the city's largest municipal union.
Marc V. Shaw, the City Council's finance director, said: "After more than a year of threats, they ran into the point where they were crying wolf once too often and no one believed them. There is going to be a tremendous number of teachers hired, let alone layoffs."
Some analysts say that the reduced job-loss figures show that despite the political turmoil swirling around this year's budget, the cuts may represent minor trims in a city government that may still be too large and too expensive for its shrinking tax base.
"A great deal of the lifting was done through tax increases," Mr. Rohatyn said to explain why the impact on services did not cut deeper.
 
118 More Workers at Year's End
 Compared with private jobs in the city during a deep recession, the city work force has largely been spared.
The number of jobs in the city's financial industries has plummeted by 16 percent since the 1987 stock market crash, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In the last 22 months, the number of construction jobs in the city has fallen by 18 percent, the number of manufacturing jobs by 10 percent and wholesale and retail jobs by 7 percent.
In contrast, city government grew through much of the recession. In June, at the end of the last fiscal year, 118 more city workers were on the payroll than when the year began, even after months of retrenchment. And the total, 243,208, after a decade in which 50,000 employees were added, was the largest to be reported at the end of a fiscal year since the city began keeping consistent records in 1975.
If the Mayor is able to reduce the work force by more than 7,000 jobs -- and some of the city's outside monitors remain skeptical -- it would bring the work force down only to its level in 1989, when Mr. Dinkins was campaigning for Mayor. The decline would be less than 3 percent, compared with 4.2 percent in private jobs since the recession hit home 22 months ago.
"There is a lot of pain for the people who are affected," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Labor Statistics Bureau, "but so far you are not seeing the kinds of numbers we have seen when the financial crisis hit in the mid-1970's."
Originally, the city administration called for 14,500 layoffs of regular full-time city employees and 6,500 more layoffs at libraries, museums, private social-service agencies and the city's autonomous hospitals corporation.
But by July, about half of the layoffs had been averted through stepped-up attrition, last-minute negotiations and shifting workers who would otherwise have been laid off to other jobs. Fewer than half of the remaining layoffs have been carried out so far.
 
Smaller, Grinding Reductions
 As the number of layoffs was being tempered, so were the harshest service cuts called for in the budget: Libraries were not shut; pools remained open. Unpalatable cuts were replaced with smaller, grinding reductions in maintenance, supplies and cleaning, which were all but invisible to the public but which could eventually take a toll.
And many department commissioners -- hoping, perhaps, for a last-minute reprieve -- delayed the worst of the cuts until later in the year. The Parks Department, for example, one of the agencies hardest hit, delayed laying off maintenance workers until the end of summer.
While large parks remain in good shape, said Robert L. Garafola, a deputy parks commissioner, small playgrounds are dirtier and graffiti that was once scrubbed off is lingering.
At Riverside Park in upper Manhattan, two of 38 park workers, a gardener and a playground attendant, were cut. And last week, Charles McKinney, the park administrator, got an emergency $700 grant from a support group to pay for removing a tree with Dutch elm disease near West 105th Street.
 
How to Cut Tens of Millions
 Even before the latest round of cuts, street cleanliness had fallen to its lowest level in two years, with the city rating 70 percent of the streets acceptably clean in June, the latest date for which a figure was available. But sanitation officials said a decision by Mayor Dinkins to provide $5 million for overtime to empty trash cans on Sundays could halt the slide.
At the Human Resources Administration and the Health and Hospitals Corporation, most of the cuts have been limited to administration and support staff, security officers, custodians and other cleaners. More than a thousand child-welfare caseworkers are to be laid off in the fall, officials said, increasing the work for those who remain. City hospital administrators were still meeting frantically last week to decide how to cut tens of millions of dollars from the budget.
City departments are still drawing plans for a 5 percent reduction in managers that is called for in the budget, a cut that could translate into 200 jobs. City budget officials say that in this fiscal year and the last, 1,700 city administrative employees are being cut, along with 2,000 employees at the Board of Education headquarters and the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
Under current city plans, after the count of city employees is reduced this year, it will creep upward in the next three years. Commissioners and the city's critics alike see many of the present cuts as temporary retrenchment, in which services will be restored and workers rehired as soon as the city can afford it.
 
'A Sledgehammer in the Chest'
 But with the city facing continuing and increasing budget gaps in the next few years -- even if the city economy rebounds somewhat, as the city expects -- Mr. Dinkins has pledged to restructure the government to permanently lower costs.
That is of little comfort to Miss Tripp, who was laid off June 28, or to Harold Taylor, a Health Department community worker who cleaned out his desk last week.
Miss Tripp, who has a master's degree in urban planning, was hired in December to help run a new city anti-violence program. Now she is looking for work in New Jersey and elsewhere across the country while she struggles to qualify for unemployment insurance after, she said, an error by the city showed she had not worked long enough to be eligible.
Mr. Taylor had worked for the Health Department since he was hired off the welfare rolls in 1978. Getting a layoff notice felt "like getting a sledgehammer in the chest," he said.
He is now preparing to start training for a respiratory therapy job, for which there is much demand, and he has already warned his two children that he might not be able to afford their child-support payments for a while.
He says his 10-year-old son is at a stage in which "he sees it and he wants," and does not understand what it is like to have a father out of work.
His 17-year-old daughter, he said, put an arm around him and said: "It's all right Daddy. I can get a job."

GRAPHIC: "New York City's Payroll: How Did It Get So Big?"
 
New York City's work force is at its highest level since the city began keeping consistent records 16 years ago. Even if the city carries out its ambitious budget-cutting program, the work force will still be above the level of June 1975, at the onset of the city's previous fiscal crisis.
 
In the past decade, the number of people in city government grew by more than a quarter, while the city's population grew by only 3.5 percent. The planned head count reduction of 7,151 workers to balance the budget for 1992 would reduce the city's work force by only 3 percent.
 
City agencies do not say that services have gotten that much better, but the city's problems - crime, homelessness, drugs, the AIDS crisis - have gotten that much worse, forcing a greater role by government.
 
Here is a look at the growth of eight agencies and some of the reasons the agencies say are behind it. Figures are for June 30 of each.
 
Graphs: Full-time employees on June 30 of each year from '81 to '91 at Correction, Education Environmental Protection, Finance, Housing, Police, Social Services and Transportation agencies; The total number of New York City's full-time employees on June 30 of each year from '75 to '91
 
CORRECTION: Although the Department of Correction, had the biggest growth in the number of employees, 161.9 perent in civilian and uniformed workers in decade, it was just keeping up with the prisoners it guards. The average daily prison population in the city went from 7,035 in the 1981 fiscal year to 19,000 in the 1990 fiscal year, an increase of 170 percent.
 
EDUCATION: Federal and state mandates to increase bilingual and special education accounted for most of the 22.8 percent increase from 1981 to 1991. Special education enrollment jumped 145 percent from 1979 to 1990, although the total enrollment increased only 1.5 percent. The bureaucracy is being cut; the number of people at the board headquarters has dropped to 3,600 from 5,200 in January 1990.
 
ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION: The department's personnel expansion of 28.9 percent in 10 years can be attributed to its increased duties. The department had primarily been responsible for monitoring the city's water supply, but in the past few years, Federal mandate3s have required that it take on air pollution and hazardous waste. In addition, it will soon begin to step up enforcement of the noise pollution laws.
 
FINANCE: Responding to the findings of a 1981 audit, the city increased the number of auditors and assessors in an attempt to collect more tax revenu. This largely accounts for the 36.9 percent increase in the Department of Finance staff from 1981 to 1991. But the 1990's are bringing retrenchment; the head count dropped by 66 people, or 2.9 percent, from the end of fiscal 1990 to 1991. Another 75 positions have already been cut for fiscal 1992, a drop of 3.3%
 
HOUSING: Housing Preservation and Development increased its staff by 19.4 percent in 10 years. The department attributes this to the increased demand for apartments for the homeless and to the capital plan of the mid-1980's, which calls for building more housing. In addition, the number of abandoned buildings that the department had to take control of almost doubled in this period. Bt the personnel drop that H.P.D. has seen in the past few years has continued; it has already lost 357 jobs, or 8.2 percent, from budget cuts.
 
POLICE: Murder and non-negligent homicide totals rose steadily in this period, from 1,896 in 1988, to 1,905 in 1989, to 2,245 in 1990. Under pressure to fight back, Mayor Dinkins assembled a package of taxes last year and increassed the number of officers on patrol. The department grew 23 percent from 1981 to 1991 and it will get more officers; 373 will be added by the end of the fiscal year 1992. Civilian jobs are another matter; 631 will be lost as a result of budget cuts.
 
SOCIAL SERVICES: In this department, where 97 percent of the budget is spent on programs mandated by Federal and state governments, a growth in cases meant a growth in caseworkers. Welfare recipients have increased 10 percent; the number of children in foster care has tripled in the last five years. The staff grew in tandem, up 48 percent in 10 years. But the department will lose almost 7 percent of its staff because of the fiscal crisis; 759 jobs have already been cut and 1,422 more are to be lost.
 
TRANSPORTATION: Deteriorating bridges and increased traffic account for much of the Department of Transportation's 41.3 percent increase in staff from 1981 to 1991. The city's bridges required more inspectors and maintenance workers, which resulted in a doubling of the highways and bridges staff. The number of traffic agents rose by 70 percent, but those workers doubled the amount of money they brought in through parking tickets, to about $300 million.
 
THE TOTAL: The number of New York City's employees increased 26.8 percent from 1981 to 1991. In the same period, San Francisco's total grew 11.2% AND Miami's grew 6.9%. From 1984 to the present, Boston's total increased by 1.6% and Chicagos's fell 7.3% from 1980 to 1990. (Comparisons were not available for the full 1981-91 period for the last two cities.) (Sources: New York City Office of Management and Budget; San Francisco City Comptroller's Office; Miami Budget Department; Boston Office of Personnel Management; Chicago Department of Personnel) (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Chemical Makers Identify A New Hazard: Their Image

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The nation's chemical makers, troubled that the public associates them with toxic-waste dumps, poisonous spills and carcinogens, are cranking up a $10 million advertising and communications campaign to convince people that chemical plants are run by friendly, responsible people.
It is part of an industrywide effort led by the Chemical Manufacturers Association to rebuild the industry's image. The trade group, which represents the makers of 95 percent of the chemicals produced in the United States, has begun a "responsible care" program that requires manufacturers to clean up their problems or leave the group. 
 In addition to adopting a set of general safety guidelines, plant managers are being encouraged to reach beyond the front gates and into the local communities to ease fears that chemical plants are lethal accidents waiting to happen. The association is encouraging managers to organize plant tours and public events to explain their operations.
 
Low Public Confidence
 In the last two years, surveys have shown that the public does not have much confidence in the chemical industry. Concerned that the public associates it more with the lethal gas leak seven years ago in Bhopal, India, and the polluting of the Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, N.Y., than with economic growth and helpful products, the chemical industry wants to be seen in a better light. More important, it wants to head off more stringent government regulation.
"We said, 'Look out, guys. We are going to end up in worse shape than the atomic industry if we don't do something,' " said John W. Johnstone Jr., current chairman of the trade association and the chairman of the Olin Corporation, a chemical maker based in Stamford, Conn.
He said the public's low opinion of the industry came as something of a shock to chemical company executives. "We thought of ourselves as righteous and very successful," he said.
A Roper Organization survey conducted last year for a chemical manufacturer, S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. of Racine, Wis., found that only 8 percent of people polled thought business would develop new, more environmentally safe products. And an overwhelming 72 percent of the respondents favored additional government regulation and strict enforcement.
In 1989, a survey commissioned by the Chemical Manufacturers Association showed that people regarded the industry as less environmentally responsible than either the nuclear or petroleum industries. Only tobacco was considered worse.
Environmental groups say they are skeptical of the chemical group's image-improvement efforts, and they criticize its "responsible care" program as too vague. They also say the program, which calls for chemical companies to adopt a set of management codes, lacks an outside audit to prevent companies from inflating their results.
 
'A Bunch of Aimless Words'
"The codes are nothing but a bunch of aimless words," said Karen Florini, a lawyer with the Environmental Defense Fund. "Without them specifying their accounting procedures, data collection methods and auditing, it is hard to take them seriously."
Vincent Covello, a risk-communications specialist at Columbia University, said: "There have been a series of national traumas that have raised questions about the competence of industry. We have had Love Canal, Times Beach, Three Mile Island. Even the Challenger explosion fits in that category."
He said the chemical industry was particularly tarred by the connection between exotic-sounding compounds and cancer, and by the reluctance of executives to do anything but denounce proposed environmental legislation. "They sat behind their fences for 30 years and refused to get involved in the community," Mr. Covello said. "Now, with all the environmental concerns, nobody wants them as a neighbor. They are having trouble finding sites for new facilities."
 
Generally Worded Codes
 At the heart of the "responsible care" program are six management codes, four of which have been completed by the association. The ones now in effect cover relations with nearby communities and response to emergencies, pollution prevention, process safety and distribution of products. All consist of a series of generalized statements.
For example, one part of the pollution prevention code requires members to "include waste and release- prevention objectives in research and in the design of new or modified facilities, processes and products." The companies are required to evaluate themselves against each of the codes each year, and report whether they are studying or implementing the code provisions.
Jon Holtzman, the director of communications of the Chemical Manufacturers Association, said the process commits the 185 companies in the association to "continuous improvement" rather than reaching one or more numerical goals.
But Joan Bavaria, president of Franklin Research and Development, which calls itself a socially concerned investment adviser, said the companies would have to do more to regain their credibility.
"We will need steady, clear implementation and an information-disclosure system before we can believe them," she said.
 
Considering a Third-Party Review
 Officials of the trade group concede that some form of independent audit of the industry's environmental practices will be needed to make the program believable. "We have internal audits now, and, in some cases, community evaluations," said Lori Ramonas, the director of the program.
"Long term, we are trying to figure out how to do a third-party review," she said. "We do not know how to do it yet, but we are giving it some thought."
Mr. Holtzman said the association began advertising before the program was fully under way to "commit publicly" to environmental improvement. The first print advertisement depicts a parent's concern as he drives past a chemical plant with children and realizes he does not know what is being made there or how hazardous it might be.
The ad's text tells of the outreach efforts of some companies and includes a toll-free "800" number, so readers can find out about the operations of chemical plants near them. The industry plans five more advertisements, each dealing with a different section of the program's codes.

HEADLINE: A Twist in Fair-Trade Case: Japanese Charge U.S. Rival

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
In an aging factory near the airport here, hundreds of young women from Singapore and neighboring Malaysia are assembling an American classic known to generations of students: the portable Smith Corona typewriter. Across the globe in Bartlett, Tenn., 400 American workers in a similar factory are building competing typewriters for a Japanese company, Brother Industries Ltd.
From those simple facts arises one of the strangest and most politically charged trade disputes in recent times. 
 In the minds of many, the dispute raises the question of whether American trade laws are wildly out of touch with the politics and economics of contemporary manufacturing.
 
Turning the Tables
 The Smith Corona Corporation has battled Brother and other Japanese rivals for years, saying they were "dumping" foreign-made typewriters in the United States -- that is, selling them below the fair-market value in an attempt to seize market share from competitors. A few months ago, turning the tables, Brother became the first Japanese company to make the same charge against a competitor based in the United States.
Pointing to the fact that it makes its typewriters in a Tennessee plant with American workers, Brother claimed that it, not Smith Corona, was the true representative of the American industry. And it said the Singapore plant was being used to dump typewriters in the United States -- damaging Brother's American subsidiary and threatening the jobs of hard-working Tennesseans.
Brother's bold strategy has sent a ripple through Japanese industry. In Tokyo, executives of Japanese companies that have become increasingly impatient with American trade complaints -- from electronics producers to auto makers -- say that if Brother's counteroffensive works, they may follow suit.
No matter how the case is resolved, it points up questions that American trade policy is now only beginning to sort out: Should the United States try to protect American companies, no matter where they manufacture? Or should it try to protect American jobs and workers, even if that means bolstering the profits and business of a Japanese company?
"Regardless of which side wins," Robert Reich, the Harvard economist, wrote recently in The New Republic, "it seems appropriate to pause and ask why we have an anti-dumping law at all, now that the American economy has gone global."
Referring to the Nissan Motor Company's American manufacturing and sales operation, Yutaka Kume, the company's president, said recently that "we view our company as purely American, and I can't rule out the possibility that one day we could" follow Brother's lead. Like Brother, Nissan has a plant in Tennessee.
Smith Corona is outraged by Brother's claim to represent the American industry. "They are flouting U.S. trade laws," said G. Lee Thompson, the company's chairman and a survivor of many trade wars with Japan. "All that Brother does in Tennessee is insert some imported parts in a board and solder it."
Smith Corona has won several dumping decisions against Brother and other Japanese rivals, most recently on Thursday, when the International Trade Commission ordered steep duties on Japanese-made word processors, including Brother's.
But at the same time that the commission, an independent Federal agency that investigates the effects of trade, is issuing rulings against Brother, it is taking Brother's complaint seriously enough that it has approved an investigation of the Japanese company's charges.
Determining whether a product is being dumped is enormously difficult: it involves assessing whether the product is being sold below its manufacturing costs or below its price in its home market. Because so few typewriters are sold in Singapore, in this case the investigation will focus on prices in Europe.
Furthermore, Commerce Department officials have begun examining the Smith Corona plant in Singapore to assess its manufacturing costs. They are doing much the same at Brother's headquarters in Nagoya, Japan, and at its American subsidiary. It will be months before there is an answer.
For American manufacturers who have moved production offshore or entered a web of alliances to cut manufacturing costs, the dumping laws have become something of an international minefield.
The Chrysler Corporation, for example, led the drive a few months ago for Detroit's auto makers to file a major dumping complaint, charging that Japanese companies are selling mini-vans in the United States at prices that are far too low. The trade commission concluded recently that an investigation was warranted, and the Commerce Department is expected to rule by the fall.
But Chrysler, it turns out, may have filed the complaint against itself. One of the vehicles the American makers want to stop is the Expo LRV, a sort of station wagon made by the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation that by some definitions may be classified as a mini-van. Mitsubishi makes the Expo for Chrysler, which plans to sell it under its own names: Eagle Summit and Colt Vista.
Now, Chrysler and Mitsubishi are both scrambling to have the Federal definition of a mini-van changed so that the Expo is not part of the dumping case.
Because a growing number of American autos are actually renamed versions of Japanese models, other car companies may find themselves in similarly awkward positions, as may companies that supply chemicals, drugs, laptop computers and video cameras from overseas.
 
A 12-Year Battle
 Smith Corona's battles against Brother began 12 years ago, when the manufacturing scene was much simpler than it is now. All of Brother's typewriters came from plants in Japan. Smith Corona dominated the market then -- it still holds a share of more than 50 percent -- and it built its machines in the United States and in England.
In 1979, concerned that Brother and a host of other Japanese makers were dumping their typewriters to seize a larger share of the American market, Smith Corona filed its first complaint. One of the first actions defined typewriters as machines with no calculating functions. Brother added a calculator.
But Smith Corona was also going through traumatic changes as it was bought by Hanson P.L.C., a British group that still owns 48 percent of the company. Smith Corona greatly reduced its work force in Cortland, N.Y., where it is based.
 
Smith Corona's Labor Costs
 As Japanese competition drove down prices -- the average retail price of a portable electric typewriter is now about $150 or less -- Smith Corona moved the production of all of its low-end machines to Singapore. Now, labor in Singapore has become more expensive, so the company is doing much of its subassembly operations on a nearby island belonging to Indonesia, where labor rates are two-thirds lower.
Yet, Smith Corona argues that its typewriters are essentially American-bred, if not American-born. The research and development was done in Cortland, the company says, and the tools were designed there.
It is hard to define where value is added to any product, especially if it is a mix of intellectual property and parts and labor. At Smith Corona's factory in Singapore, boxes of parts are marked from Japan, South Korea and Malaysia. Moreover, the plant has precious little automation; most operations appear to be done by hand. In short, the company appears to have eliminated American jobs in favor of jobs in Singapore and Indonesia.
"They are hollowing out the industrial core of the United States," a lawyer for Brother, H. William Tanaka, said recently, "while we are nurturing it."
How much Brother is nurturing American industry, though, is also questionable. The company admits that it moved to Tennessee chiefly to avoid dumping charges. None of Brother's more sophisticated equipment, which is not the subject of dumping charges, is being produced outside Japan.

HEADLINE: Waterbury Killing Puzzles Teen-Age Suspects' Friends

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD with DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 10

 BODY:
Mischief accented their lives. But apparently none of them dreamed it would turn deadly.
Friends said the crime was supposed to have been a trifling act of bravado, a manly demonstration of how easy it was to pull off a petty robbery. There were even overtures to their buddies to stop by and watch the action. 
 But then it sped out of control when a hitch developed in the carefully scripted plan and a young man was shot and killed -- all for $18 worth of Chinese takeout food.
Residents of this struggling New England mill town of 106,000 in the heart of the Naugatuck Valley are still fumbling to understand the chilling events of last Monday night, when the police say five local youths -- aged 13 to 18 years old -- gunned down a Chinese restaurant's delivery man when he refused to hand over some cartons of food. All were arrested within hours of the crime.
 Friends and neighbors of the suspects talked last week of troublemakers and of boredom. In interviews in the racially and ethnically mixed East End neighborhood where the crime occurred, they painted a picture of a group of smart-alecky teen-agers and the torpor and tedium of the hot summer in a city that has never recovered from the years its brass mills shut down. They talked of youths suffering from a dearth of recreational activities and itchy to find some thrills.
 
'This Was Like an Adventure'
 "They did normal stuff," said a teen-ager who said he hung out with some of them, but spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Then like they got bored. This was like an adventure. You know, look for pirate treasure. Climb a mountain. Rob a guy. Something different. But I don't think they expected to go bang-bang."
While some were quick to defend the arrested youths as relatively tame teen-agers who occasionally strayed, many others who described themselves as friends and acquaintances insisted they were a rowdy lot. The youngest member of the group, a 13-year-old who the police say furnished the murder weapon from his parents' gun collection, was portrayed most harshly. He was described as an impish chronic troublemaker who antagonized many of his neighbors by his antics. Everyone, however, said they were stunned that the youths might have killed someone.
The police have charged all five of the racially mixed group with murder, robbery and conspiracy to commit murder. The accused are Gerrod Ellis, 17, whom the police said fired the gun; Linas Zelvis, 18; Vince Hancock, 17, and two youths, 13 and 14, whose names were not released because of their ages. Many neighbors, however, say they are familiar with the two.
The police depicted the crime as the culmination of a plan -- perhaps the encore to a similar holdup four days earlier -- meant to be brought off with a flair for the dramatic.
The police said the group plotted to lure a Chinese restaurant's delivery man the night of July 29 to a vacant apartment near where they live, in a working-class neighborhood largely comprised of clusters of inexpensive strips of bland housing. Each participant had an assignment. One was the gunman. Another was to snatch the food. Another was to get the delivery man's money. A fourth was to steal the car. The final member was to lead them through the adjacent woods.
Not long before 10 P.M., relatives of the victim said, Mr. Ellis placed the order to the Kwok Hing restaurant on Main Street. He gave the address as 134-1 Stonefield Drive, a recently vacated apartment.
Three girls -- Joanne Bologna, 13, Kelly Jordan, 14, and Lindsay Butler, 13, say they frequently hung out with the accused youths. They were sitting on a boulder -- what is known as the rock -- near the apartment when the teen-agers came by and bragged that they were going to rob a delivery man. The girls said they were invited to watch. "They told us -- 'You guys hungry?' " Ms. Bologna said. " 'We're going to hold this guy up. We got a rifle in the woods, but it's not loaded. If you like, you want to watch?' "
But they said they declined and went home. Ms. Bologna was scurrying to beat a 10 P.M. curfew.
Several other youths in the neighborhood said they, too, were urged to stop by to see the robbery unfold. But they said they stayed away. One said there was something good on television.
The site was hardly the sort of secluded setting likely to be chosen to execute a crime undetected. Neighbors were close at hand, on foot and in cars swinging in and out of the parking lot just behind the apartments.
When the delivery man, Fai Yeung, 21, showed up shortly after 10 P.M., the police said he was confronted by the youths and told to hand over the food. Mr. Ellis, the police said, pointed a .22-caliber rifle at him. Mr. Yeung clung to the food and backed away, the police said, and Mr. Ellis shot him in the chest. Mr. Yeung then staggered back to his car, bleeding profusely.
The youths ran off, the police said, with nothing but the food, which they told investigators they later ate.
Lou Albano, 40, a field engineer who lived nearby and was waiting for his wife, Marge, in the lot, dashed over and tried to help Mr. Yeung while the police were summoned. He died at St. Mary's Hospital the next morning.
Mr. Yeung's sister Dow Hung Yeung said he had been badly beaten just a few nights before by a band of youths in the same neighborhood. Normally, she said, Monday was his day off, but he was covering for his other sister, Jen.
 
Told Her About the Slaying
 The police apprehended one of the five soon after the crime. Ms. Bologna, who is the daughter of the Albanos, said that Mr. Hancock called her later that night and told her about the slaying but insisted that he and Mr. Zelvis had run off before the shooting. Ms. Jordan said that Mr. Ellis phoned her and boasted, "I robbed a Chinese guy. I shot him in the butt." The three girlfriends furnished descriptions to the police and the remaining youths were arrested within hours.
Capt. Robert Moran, the acting chief of detectives, said early last week that the shooting had been staged as a spectator sport that took place before an audience. But the three girls and other neighbors said they knew of no one who actually watched. Captain Moran was unavailable for further comment on Friday.
Since the crime, the Albanos said they have received a string of anonymous threatening calls to their daughter. Ms. Bologna, however, seemed unfazed. "You can't be scared," she said. "When you gotta die, you gotta die."
Four nights before the killing, Mia Freeman, a delivery woman from Domino's Pizza, was held up in the same vicinity in a similar fashion. Ms. Freeman said that four or five youths were involved, and that one had a rifle. She surrendered $35 in cash and the pizza that had been ordered.
She said detectives have asked her to determine if those accused of the murder also accosted her.
Apparently all of the youths were born in Waterbury, a classic New England mill town that has passed through the same bruising transformations of so many manufacturing cities in the region. Known as the "brass city," it was a primary maker of brass as long ago as the Civil War when Waterbury foundries made the buttons that went on soldiers' uniforms. But the city's brass mills succumbed to the allure of plastic and to cheaper labor in the South, and began closing in the late 1960's and early 1970's.
Waterbury is comprised of a mixture of tight-knit ethnic groups. The Irish and the Italians predominate, though black and Hispanic populations have grown substantially over the last 10 years. Residents of the area where the shooting took place said that many people have been laid off from their jobs during the recession.
The lawns teem with children of all ages. Neighbors said the accused youths liked to congregate at the rock, gathering with as many as two dozen neighborhood teen-agers.
The 13-year-old, who the police say supplied the weapon, lives with his mother and two siblings. His father, neighbors said, died of liver cancer six months ago. He had kept a sizable gun collection, they said, that the son found easily accessible. Friends said the youth would sometimes take a gun and shoot it in the woods. Neighbors said that the police had been called to the apartment the week before the shooting because his mother reported a gun missing.
"He's been bad before," said Francisco Ruiz, a garbage man who lives a few doors away. "Trouble's always with him."
But none of the five had any more than minor criminal records. And neighbors spoke of how they leaned toward many familiar teen-age pursuits -- riding skateboards, fishing for turtles and operating radio-controlled cars. But other youths said they had taken part with them in stealing cars and going for joy rides, as well as breaking into houses.
 
'Two Sides to Every Story'
 They also spoke of less pleasant pursuits. Mrs. Albano said that the teen-agers used to hurl mud-covered rocks at her door, and she pointed out some pronounced dents. "They are real roughnecks," she said.
None of the parents of the accused teen-agers would consent to be interviewed. Paul Matasavage, a lawyer who represented Mr. Zelvis when he posted bond, would say only "there's always two sides to every story, and in this case it's no different."
A close relative of one youth said he was convinced that the killing was a game that went hideously awry. "They were doing a prank," he said. "They thought it was going to turn out a certain way and in the heat of what happened, when it didn't go the way they thought, they panicked. They were just looking for food and fun and they got blood and jail."
"I can see having a little fun -- beating a guy for the food," Ms. Bologna said. "I never thought Gerrod had it in him to shoot someone."
In the aftermath of the slaying, the Yeung family has kept their tidy, storefront restaurant open, a sign still taped to the window offered free delivery.
The family was born in Foo Chow, China, and envisioned America as an opportunity to realize success through hard work. The father, Ping C. Yeung, left China 20 years ago, with his wife staying behind. He owned a restaurant in New Jersey, as well as one in Georgia, before taking over the Waterbury restaurant last year. His children arrived in this country in 1984.
On Friday, Dow Hung Yeung said the family had been discouraged by the slack business in Waterbury and had been planning to sell and head elsewhere. She said that her mother, who still lives in China, had not been told of her brother's death because she was in failing health. The funeral was to be Sunday.
On the scrubby lawns that separate the strips of apartments in the East End, children continued over the weekend to ride their bikes, chase one another and sit on stoops and talk.
"It's weird," said Ms. Butler. "They're still your friends. But this is life. This isn't like stealing cars."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
More than a million depositors worldwide stand to lose heavily from the seizure of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. Recent revelations portray B.C.C.I. as a personal piggy bank for its Arab and Pakistani owners and favored customers. Millions of dollars were advanced, often without documentation and sometimes in violation of its own limits. [Page A1.] 
 Tokyo's financial markets may allow more competition if Japan's ruling party goes along with a proposal to end fixed-rate brokerage commissions. [D1.]
Brother Industries has become the first Japanese company to accuse an American rival -- in this case, Smith Corona -- of dumping foreign-made products in the United States. [D1.]
The recent agreement to limit Japanese car imports to the European Community may be the most important quota arrangement in the history of global trade. News Analysis. [D1.]
A financial scandal has rocked Poland's central bank, resulting in the suspension of its president and the arrest of its deputy president and five other banking officials. [D2.]
A chunky auto plant manager turned economic guru now wields more real power in the Kremlin than some economists. [A6.]
 
Companies
The creditors of Pan American World Airways endorsed a new $1.7 billion offer from Delta Air Lines. The about-face came after Delta agreed to raise its bid and help finance a reorganization of the bankrupt Pan Am, which would survive as smaller carrier primarily serving Latin America. [A1.]
U.S. steelmakers are losing money, even though they have become more efficient, because of sinking prices, sagging demand and rising labor costs. [D1.]
Chemical makers are concerned about their public image, so they are preparing a $10 million campaign to convince people that chemical plants are run by friendly, responsible people. [D7.]
Pet food companies are hoping to attract more customers by making dog and cat foods without chemical preservatives. [D1.]
Harry Helmsley appears to remain at the head of his real estate companies, even though he was declared incompetent to stand trial for tax evasion with his wife, Leona. [B1.]
 
The Economy
The pain from New York City's fiscal troubles has flowed deep, but not wide. A month after the adoption of a $28.7 billion recession-driven budget, just over 1 in 100 city workers has lost a job, far fewer than the Dinkins administration had predicted. [A1.]
 
The Media Business
The market for television reruns has hit a slump as weak advertising sales reduce the cash that local stations have to spend on syndicated programs. Bill Carter: Television [D1.]
The French TV industry is in severe financial straits, with television executives blaming stiff Government rules about advertising and program content for their losses. [D8.]
Powell's Books may be the largest U.S. bookstore, yet it is in Portland, Ore., rather than a leading publishing center. [D8.]
A one-page fax newspaper has challenged the local dailies in two small Illinois towns with some success, prompting predictions that similar fax papers could spread across the country and pose a threat to newspapers. [D8.]
A record amount of public service advertising was presented last year on television and radio and in newspapers and magazines. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Face of Protests in Wichita Is Religious and Undoubting

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 11

 BODY:
For three days, David Spear drove the 1,700 miles here from his home in San Francisco as fast as his old car would go.
He made the trip with little food, sleep or money, he said, because "the Holy Spirit led me here" to join what has become a monthlong assault on the city's three abortion clinics. 
 It has been a month of protests, prayers and police, a month that has brought national attention to Wichita along with hundreds of abortion opponents like Mr. Spear, a 42-year-old street artist, shoe shiner and window washer.
"I don't dislike pro-choice people," he said. "Some of my best friends are pro-choice and I pray for them. All I want is the law changed. I want babies to live. It won't be easy though because Satan is all around us."
The protests, organized by the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, have resulted in nearly 2,000 arrests since late July. A Federal judge, who issued an order forbidding them to block access to two of the clinics, has received numerous threats and is under round-the-clock protection.
Slightly more than half of those arrested have been from Kansas.
Mr. Spear and the others have come from big cities and small towns, from unemployment lines and steady jobs, from Lansing, Mich., from Boston, from Dayton, Ohio, from Miami, from Portland, Ore. They see themselves, in the words of Mr. Spear, as "warriors of prayer" in a civil war over abortion.
To them the issue is clear and very simple. Abortion, they say, is murder and if it continues much longer America will suffer God's judgment.
"I'm suprised God hasn't allowed another nation to take us over yet," said Gladys Mitchell from Michigan.
Many of the abortion opponents who have flocked here since the middle of July, like Pam Schuffert, 39, of Asheville, N.C., or Joe Stauder, 52, of Ann Arbor, Mich., travel from city to city, state to state, to block the gates of abortion clinics with their bodies.
"I've been arrested in Atlanta, Dobbs Ferry, Washington, Charlotte, Greensboro, Asheville and a couple of other places," Miss Schuffert said. "I still have 10 days to serve in Greensboro and 36 hours in Charlotte."
Before coming to Wichita, Miss Schuffert said, she had just been in jail in Raleigh, N.C., after a protest there.
"I'm weary," she said the other day as she prepared to rush the gate of a clinic here. The campaign in Wichita, she said, "is my 16th rescue," using the term that members of the anti-abortion movement favor for their efforts.
The authorities call it law breaking, and according to results of a survey released today by The Wichita Eagle and KAKE-TV, 78 percent of the 483 Sedgwick County residents surveyed disapproved of the protesters' tactics, and 52 percent said they believed that the city's image had been damaged by the weeks of unrest. The survey, taken Wednesday and Thursday in random telephone calls, has a margin of sampling error of 4.5 percentage points.
On Monday some of the protesters, including a founder of Operation Rescue, the Rev. Joseph Foreman, are scheduled to appear before Judge Patrick F. Kelly of Federal District Court on charges of violating his order.
"A judge's order won't stop us," Mr. Foreman said before being arrested Friday and held on $100,000 bond.
 
Friendly Reception
 Despite the poll's findings, the protesters have received a friendlier reception in Wichita, a city of 300,000, than they have in larger cities.
Operation Rescue and its out-of-town followers have set up camp at the Wichita Plaza Hotel downtown, where a spokesman for the group, Gary McCullogh, said they had at least 40 rooms.
He said the hotel had halved its rate for the group to $25 a room, most of which are shared by four adults.
Other protesters have moved in for a few nights with families here, and several churches have turned their basements into dormitories.
There have been other signs of hospitality rarely offered to the group in larger cities. At a recent rally, the state's Governor, Joan Finney, a Democrat, spoke warmly of its effort.
"I am pro-life," she proclaimed to the cheers of 1,500 people.
For the most part, getting here was not easy for many of the protesters, mainly blue-collar workers like sign painters, store clerks and truck drivers. Mr. Stauder, of Ann Arbor, was a school janitor until he quit his job almost three years ago to devote full time to abortion protests.
The protesters travel in groups and pay for gasoline and food by saving pennies or by soliciting donations from church groups or relatives back home.
"I live very simply," Mr. Stauder said. "I have a brother who gives me $200 a month. I live and travel on that."
But among their ranks are also school teachers on vacation, medical technicians on their lunch breaks, retired couples and newlyweds.
"The rescuers seem like average folk," said Steve Grantstien, a 38-year-old nuclear medicine technician from Wichita and, he said, one of the few Jews taking part in the protests. "It seems like 30 percent of them are retired."
 
Dr. King and John Brown
 The leaders are mostly male and from out of town. They sprinkle their conversation with references to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the civil rights movement, the Holocaust and, because this is Kansas, John Brown.
Nuns, priests and ministers kneel at the rallies, fingering rosaries or clutching Bibles before leading a charge against the clinics' gates. Some have been dragged off to jail as many as six times.
The women, young and old, are "Mrs." or "Miss," rarely "Ms."
"We don't accept that term," said 33-year-old Stephanie Hunley, a Mrs. from Dayton. "It's a feminist term."
 
Nearly All White
 A vast majority of the protesters are white, a fact that apparently causes some concern. After telling a story about persuading a young woman in Dayton not to have an abortion, Mrs. Hunley said, "I'd also like to emphasize that the woman was a black lady."
"I know you don't see a lot of black people out here now," she said without being asked about the lack of black faces in the crowd of several hundred. "But we extend our hand to everyone. We love them, too."
Protesters are stationed almost around the clock outside the Women's Health Care Services, one of the few clinics in the country that performs abortions in the final three months of pregnancy.
Tiffany White, a 19-year-old resident of Wichita, said she became involved with the anti-abortion protests a couple of weeks ago when the guilt and anguish over her own abortion when she was 16 grew overwhelming.
"I was raped," she said. "I didn't even know who the father was. But I loved that baby. I wanted it."
Being young, scared and uncertain, "I turned to my mom." Her mother, she said, forced her to have an abortion, and, "I very much regret it now."
Earlier that day, the street was flooded with 350 abortion opponents, dozens of Federal marshals, local police and a growing band of supporters of the clinics.
Even in that crowd, King David Davis, a 34-year-old unemployed father of three from Wichita, stood out in his black karate uniform, monster mask and gloves covered in fake blood. He has worn the costume almost every day for weeks.
"I represent the evil that is going on in there," he said, pointing to the one-story clinic. "Remember, David was a little man with a small rock, and he was able to destroy a mighty giant. Truth will be our rock."
A boy approached him and tugged on his karate uniform. "The police are looking at you," the boy said. "You need to take the mask off."
