HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
At Saratoga, a Floating Serenade and Symbol

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11

 BODY:
Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney parks her yellow 1964 Jaguar on the grass outside the clubhouse gate at the 127-year-old Saratoga Race Course, and steps toward the paddock in a wide-brimmed summer hat and white dress with huge red polka dots and matching parasol, looking for all the world like a belle being cast for the Ascot Gavotte scene in "My Fair Lady."
The small combo serenading the racing fans outside the gate spots her and promptly strikes up the old tune "Mary Lou." 
 She stops, listens with cheery attention, waves her thanks and sweeps into the large striped tent pitched alongside the paddock. It is crowded with women who paid $40 apiece for luncheon at America's oldest and maybe grandest country race track, with Marylou Whitney as the main attraction and the Ronald McDonald House for needy children as the main beneficiary.
It is a scene that is repeated four or five times a day during the five weeks when New York racing makes its summertime stage in this stately old town in Saratoga County, which is celebrating its 200th anniversary this year, 180 miles north of Belmont Park and light years north of the tumult of big-city racing downstate. It is a slice of 19th-century American life that has been threatened by change but that so far has survived the threat.
And Marylou Whitney stops the music as she floats from one gathering to another, raising or donating money for all kinds of charities and activities from the Salvation Army to the Olympics, racing her horses and spreading the message that Saratoga and its way of life are alive and well and worth preserving.
She is a size-6 dynamo in her middle 60's who reigns as the mistress of the 120 acres of Cady Hill House, one of seven places that she and Sonny Whitney call home, but for the last five years the place they actually make their home.
 
A Packed Agenda
 From this elegant pre-Revolutionary mansion with its 24 rooms, cottages and carriage houses, she runs the family businesses, directs the Blue Goose Stable and rules the same society that she also rules at other times at her 540-acre farm in Kentucky, her 100,000-acre spread with two homes in the Adirondacks, her Fifth Avenue apartment in Manhattan, her ancient 100-room castle in Spain and her tony villa in Palm Beach.
But she also serves as honorary chairman of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center and president of the Museum of the Dance, which she and her husband helped to finance 25 years ago and which now becomes the summer home of the New York City Opera in June, the New York City Ballet in July and the Philadelphia Orchestra in August.
Mostly, she acts as the symbol and the spirit of Saratoga. And she will receive yet another salute for both on Monday night when she steps forward at the Gideon Putnam Hotel to receive the Red Smith Award at the annual dinner of the New York Turf Writers Association.
All in all, it is likely that no sport symbolizes a city more than horse racing in Saratoga, that no family symbolizes a sport in a city more than the Whitneys and that no woman symbolizes the family more than Marylou Whitney.
"This is where we vote," she said the other day, sitting on the porch of the directors' room at the race track. "This is where we live. This is where we spend Thanksgiving and Christmas. This is our first home.
"I loved Saratoga the first time I came here as a bride 33 years ago. Sonny told me he had a house in Saratoga, but he was planning on selling it. But the minute we came up the drive, I started to cry. I said, 'Sonny, I'll offer you twice as much to keep it.' We were only going to stay for lunch at the Gideon Putnam Hotel. But we sat with Frank Sullivan and Monty Woolley and all the other authors and writers and artists. I was wide-eyed. Monty said we should stay the night; we stayed four days."
They actually stayed 33 years, and counting. Sonny Whitney, who is 93 years old and reasonably hale, already had roots in Saratoga going back into the last century. But he and Mrs. Whitney made their own mark on the city when Saratoga and other upstate towns began to wither somewhat after World War II, and new life had to be pumped into the old countryside.
 
Shot in the Arm
 "About 26 years ago," Marylou Whitney said, "Eugene Ormandy and Nelson Rockefeller and Newman Wait came to us. They wanted to start a center for the performing arts here, and asked us to join them. The city needed a shot in the arm, and so did racing here. I think the racing went down during the war when they closed the track. But once we started raising money and established the Center for the Performing Arts, from then on, Saratoga started growing."
"Why Saratoga?" she asked. "Well, Ormandy needed a place for the Philadelphia Orchestra for the summer, and he came here and found it had a natural amphitheater in the park. Nelson Rockefeller was Governor and wanted to revive the economy upstate, and we all put up money to get the arts center launched. After we got the orchestra here, we leased the old Saratoga baths from the state and put the ballet there.
"To keep it thriving, we put on a jazz festival and rock concerts, and Liza Minnelli is here this weekend. Those are the things that keep the arts center going. And racing is the thing that helps keep everything going."
But, for racing, why Saratoga?
"The racing people always came here," Marylou Whitney said. "You win a race here, it's special. People bring their best horses here. I remember Sonny saying, 'I'd rather win a race at Saratoga than any place in the country.' His father and grandfather said it, too. Now, he's out of racing. He retired the C. V. Whitney silks six years ago. But I set up the Blue Goose Stable with Leslie Combs when he had Spendthrift Farm in Kentucky. And now I'm trying to carry on the tradition."
She is carrying it on with the style that made her an international star of society, and she is doing it in her adopted hometown with the apparent approval of her neighbors and townspeople. She gives one party each summer for about 400 Saratogians, even before the racing crowd arrives in town. She averages four or five appearances a day, social and charity, after the racing crowd arrives and the season peaks. She tours the shops along Broadway before Christmas, shaking hands and even singing carols. She tells her five children and 10 grandchildren to stay home on Christmas Day, which she spends at home or at church serving meals. Then, two days later, she gathers her family for a delayed Christmas, and Cady Hill comes alive.
 
Completing the Cycle
 "I decided a long time ago," she said, "to help this community every way I could. Raising money was one way I could. But now I'm also active in the thing that makes Saratoga special: the horse. My ambition is to raise a horse to win the Whitney Handicap here. And possibly do something Sonny never did: win the Kentucky Derby. I want to raise a great race horse. Racing completes the cycle for me here in Saratoga."
People ask where she gets the drive. She doesn't know, either. But she gave up smoking five years ago, and thinks that helped.
"I grew a little, from a size 5 to a 6," she said. "But I feel 100 times better."
Meanwhile, she revels as the symbol of Saratoga and its revival. And she doesn't mind it one bit when she arrives for yet another appearance, or even a whirl, and the band swings into "Mary Lou" one more time.

HEADLINE: PAN AMERICAN GAMES: Sports of The Times;
Bay of Pigs Explains the Games

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

DATELINE: PLAYA GIRON, Cuba

 BODY:
WHEN Agustin Marrero Ferrer fell at the Bay of Pigs, he was carrying a photograph of Fidel Castro in his wallet. That wallet is now in a display case at the earnest little museum where the fighting took place in April 1961.
Castro himself is still in power, performing the wave and standing at attention for the American anthem at the Pan American Games after 30 years of hostility between the nations. So perhaps we should never say "never" about anything. 
 Everything that happens at these games, the hospitality and the security, the hopes and the fears and some of the gamesmanship at the events, must be seen through the prism of the upheaval in 1959, which led directly to the American-sponsored invasion by Cuban exiles at the Bay of Pigs.
"When people ask Castro how Cuba was able to organize these games so well, he says it is all done for the revolution," said Evie Dennis, the head of the United States delegation.
The revolution is part of these games. A huge rendering of Che Guevara dominates one entire wall at the basketball arena; the airport is named for Jose Marti, the martyr of an earlier struggle; and many sports arenas are named after Cuba's heroes and martyrs.
Sometimes you see the slogan El Deporte es un Derecho del Pueblo (Sport is a Right of the People). Other times you see the slogan Patria o Muerte (Fatherland or Death). Sometimes the slogans run together.
For example: the roller-skating competition is being held in Havana at the Centro Raul Diaz Arguelles, named for one of the early leaders of the student movement before 1959.
During the 72 hours of fighting near the Bay of Pigs, Diaz Arguelles was the commander of a unit being rushed to the front from Havana. In 1975, he would die as a general in an ambush in Angola, the highest-ranking Cuban officer to die in that expedition so far from home.
"A week after the Bay of Pigs, we came down here," said his wife, Mariana Ramirez Corria, one of the most accomplished women on this island: singer, actress, television host, writer, feminist, former hematologist for her neurosurgeon-father, and now a mother, grandmother, widow and patriot who has never felt the need to leave her country.
On Saturday, she escorted a few journalists to the Valley Forge of Cuba.
"My husband and I walked around," Ramirez continued. "We could see where the bombs hit, where people were killed. It was terrible.
"I knew guys from the university among the mercenaries. I could not talk to them, but my husband did. His own cousin was captured. He asked his cousin, 'What are you doing here?' I have not been back here until today."
This time she found it different: modern cottages, for rent to workers on vacation, and a pretty beach packed with Cubans who could come up with gasoline.
The healthy children playing in the sand at the Bay of Pigs helped explain why Cubans urge visitors to get out of faded Havana, why they say: "Wait until you see the changes in the countryside. Then, you will understand the revolution."
It is important to come here, to understand why the country has diverted what little gasoline and food it has to serve the athletes and the press. Clearly, sport is a convenient way of channeling the energies and the loyalties of an island badly damaged by the American economic embargo, the drop in Soviet aid and, some would say, three decades of its own centrally planned economy.
Whenever Alberto Juantorena -- the strapping Big Horse who won gold medals in the 400 and the 800 meters at the Montreal Olympics in 1976 -- is interviewed, he pays homage to the revolution. So does Ana Fidelia Quirot, the striking runner who is said to have lifted stones with her hands to help build the stadium, and then amasses gold medals in these games.
"We talk about the revolution because it supports us always," Juantorena said the other day. "Ana Fidelia and I come from the countryside. We have the opportunity to compete. We owe everything to the revolution."
The revolution is 32 years ago, still living history to many people. Fidel Castro, who turns 65 tomorrow, is everywhere, a living icon in olive-green fatigues, flying to Santiago, giving out medals.
Seen from a few feet away, Castro looks weary. He does not smile even while waving his hand at the Cuban people. It has been a long time since April 1961 when he proclaimed, "This day, Yankee imperialism suffered its first great defeat in the Americas."
Now the American defeats come in weight lifting and team handball, but then again, the United States is starting to gain gold medals in other sports, if any of it matters.
The amazing thing is that the United States is here at all. In the museum at the Bay of Pigs, they will hand-crank rough footage of those 72 hours in 1961: soldiers and civilians lying in their own blood. It is not hard to hear the words "Yankee imperialism" in Spanish. Then they shake an American's hand and direct him to a good beach, where Cuban men offer a swig of beer and give the thumbs-up sign and ask, "Are you here for the games?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fidel Castro joining in the wave at U.S.-Cuba women's basketball game Saturday in Havana. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: As Times Get Tougher for California, Its Leaders Push Harder to Save Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11

 BODY:
For decades, California could just lie back and rely on its seemingly irresistible lures to companies and people. If one plant shut or left, two more seemed to blossom amid the palms, and the state's economy consistently outpaced the nation's.
But suddenly California's political and business leaders have been jolted into action. They have belatedly started to mount a rear-guard action intended not to attract new industry but to prevent businesses from running away.
Colorado, Nevada, Utah, Arizona, Oklahoma, Oregon, Idaho and other states, have found easy pickings in California, as has nearby Mexico. And this week, the Commissioner of Economic Development of the United States Virgin Islands, Eric Dawson, plans to make a pitch to business leaders here.
 
Radio Advertisements
 The sales pitches are not restricted to small groups. Commuters on Southern California's freeways often hear this advertisement on the radio: "If your business is based in California, then you already know it means putting up with traffic congestion, smog, doneover regulation, high costs and an irritable work force that result in lost revenues. . . . Now is the right time to cash out of California and go to Pueblo, Colorado."
Pueblo has attracted five plants from California. "All these companies are leaving, and nobody is listening in the Legislature -- I just smile," said Harold E. Mabie, who runs the one-man California office of the Pueblo Economic Development Corporation. "I've been working on a lot of companies the last six months."
Now California has begun to strike back. The California Chamber of Commerce recently organized a Task Force on Saving California Jobs, which has urged the state to ease what it considers the excessive burdens of taxation, environmental regulation and workers' compensation insurance. Gov. Pete Wilson made job retention a priority in the recent legislative negotiations to erase a $14.3 billion budget deficit, asking for new rules to reduce abusive claims for workers' compensation. The Governor was only able to win minor changes.
At the same time, the state's Office of Business Development has increased efforts to keep companies in California, partly by building an "early warning" system of potential defections. Southern California Edison, the electric utility, is offering special assistance to keep its industrial customers from moving away. And in Los Angeles County, probably the most vulnerable part of the state, the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County, a private not-for-profit group, has a new president and a new mission.
"Over the last 10 years, there was no effort to retain jobs or bring them in," said the development group's chief economist, Jack Kyser. "In the meantime, Oklahoma opened an office in Irvine. It was just like a candy store to them. We've never had to work for growth in the past. Something at last is happening."
But the task is complicated by strong feelings among many Californians that the state's recent growth has come at the cost of bad air and water and congestion. While few are explicitly anti-business, many do not put a high premium on retaining heavy industry. "Californians have a big conflict over this," said Phillip E. Vincent, senior economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "Some people do not want any more people here."
Despite the outward trickle of jobs, the California economy remains comparatively vibrant. In 1990, California, already the most populous state, gained more than 16,000 residents a day, growing at more than twice the national average. The state's economy was bolstered over the last decade by growth in manufacturing jobs, particularly in defense and aerospace industries, not to mention the garment and furniture industries.
As New York and other Eastern states were losing manufacturing jobs in the 1980's, California was posting gains. By 1989 the seven counties of Southern California accounted for nearly a fifth of the nation's military contracts and 1.4 million manufacturing jobs, more than the entire states of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut combined.
 
Loss of Jobs
 But in the last year, the trend reversed, with California losing manufacturing jobs at a slightly greater rate than the nation as a whole, nearly 100,000 jobs since last July. The General Motors Corporation recently announced it would permanently shut its automobile plant in the Van Nuys area of Los Angeles by next August, putting 2,000 assembly-line workers out of work. The loss of such high-paying manufacturing jobs has been offset in part by growth in lower-paying service jobs in health care, hotels, restaurants and trade.
Economists say the loss of manufacturing jobs can be attributed both to the national recession and to cuts in military spending. But they also say that the state's comparative business disadvantages -- including high rents and housing costs -- have become increasingly powerful factors in corporate location decisions. According to a recent survey for the California Business Roundtable, a group of corporate executives, 14 percent of California's business leaders said they planned to relocate outside the state and 41 percent said they planned to expand operations out of state.
"We are attempting to face this head on," said Carl Covitz, the state's Secretary of Business, Transportation and Housing. "There's no need to be defensive about it. By recognizing that California is losing its competitive advantage, at least people will understand the implications. We do have serious problems doing business."
That is what Bernie and Sheila Gurstein, native Californians, decided when they uprooted their small family business, U.S. Products, and moved from Agoura, Calif., a suburb of Los Angeles, to Coeur d'Alene, a city in northern Idaho, in 1988. The company, which makes carpet cleaning machinery, wanted to expand but found that the cost of utilities, insurance and labor too high. So the company moved to Idaho, where workers' compensation rates are only $2.60 for each $100 salary, compared with $7.90 in California. The company has 20 employees.
"In California, I had to interview 30 people to find one questionable employee," said their son, Russ Gurstein, a co-owner. "They had an attitude problem. And when the surf's up, you said goodbye to half your employees." Mr. Gurstein added: "Officials listen to you here. Even the Governor came out to welcome us when we arrived."
Still, California retains some major advantages: a huge market, good ports, top-flight universities, a marvelous climate and proximity to Japan and other Pacific nations. "Firms who have the ability to relocate to lower-cost states often choose to do so," said Fred Cannon, chief economist at the Bank of America in San Francisco. "But it is a relatively small share of firms. We are close to a very large market, well positioned on the Pacific Rim. One reason for the high costs is so many people want to live here."
The man leading the Chamber of Commerce's Task Force on Saving California Jobs is Wilford D. Godbald Jr., chairman of the Zero Corporation, a Los Angeles-based manufacturer of aircraft cargo containers, camera cases and industrial cabinets.
 
Educational Program
 He said he was trying to organize a "grass-roots educational program" to show the Legislature how smothering layers of rules were affecting jobs. The goal, he added, is not to lower environmental standards but to make them easier to comply with.
But even as Mr. Godbald campaigns to keep jobs in California, he is exporting them. Zero recently transferred its Zero Halliburton division, which makes camera cases, from Pacoima, Calif., to North Salt Lake City, Utah, shifting 300 jobs. And he soon plans to move the company's Burbank plant, which makes cases to house electronic equipment, to Utah with another 450 jobs.
Mr. Godbald said he would like to keep the company's remaining seven California plants in the state. "I would very much like to stay," he said. "We are nearer the Pacific Basin, we like the environment and the California economy has been more vibrant than the nation over the years. But if the rules become more and more harsh, that will be overshadowed."
In Utah, Mr. Godbald said, the company was able to determine what permits were needed in a few days, a process that could take months or years in California.
Indeed, Utah has been particularly aggressive in attracting California companies. Nearly two dozen have relocated some or all of their operations there in the last two years, including Black Diamond, Lucas Western, Great American West Insurance and Standard Communications.
Probably no company has been more alarmed at the exodus than Southern California Edison, because the loss of major industrial customers means higher rates in its 50,000-square-mile service area. In the last five years, Barry R. Sedlik, Edison's manager of customer planning services, said that 60 manufacturers had either moved or expanded to Nevada, 44 to Arizona and 284 to Mexico.
Some say California should not try to prevent the decline of manufacturing, that it should allow its economy to evolve into one based more on services, trade, culture and research. "We are moving toward a service economy," said Mr. Vincent, the economist at First Interstate Bancorp. "Manufacturing is not the be all and end all."

HEADLINE: Atlantis Mission Ends in Smooth Florida Landing

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 11

 BODY:
After nearly nine days in orbit, the space shuttle Atlantis returned to earth here today without mishap, and the Kennedy Space Center returned to service as a regular landing site for shuttle missions.
"Well done, Atlantis," mission control told the crew of four men and one woman, commanded by Col. John E. Blaha of the Air Force, seconds after the craft touched down at 8:23 A.M. 
 Atlantis lifted off here on Aug. 2, after a series of technical problems and postponements. It carried out 22 scientific experiments and launched a giant communications satellite intended to help channel the flow of information from low-orbiting spacecraft.
The only problem during the flight was the overheating of one of three auxiliary power units used to run the hydraulic systems during liftoff and landing. None of the units, which move wing flaps and rudders, interfered with today's landing, officials said, though the crew delayed turning on one unit to avoid overheating.
Today's landing was the first scheduled here by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration since 1986. Two shuttle flights have been diverted to Florida in the last year because of bad weather at Edwards Air Force Base in California, the primary landing site for the 42 space shuttle missions.
For both economic and scheduling reasons, NASA officials would like to be able to have more shuttle landings at the Kennedy Space Center. By landing here, the space agency saves more than $1 million and spares itself the cumbersome process of putting the shuttle on the back of a Boeing 747 and flying it across the country.
Clearing for the 15,500-foot runway began in 1974. The runway, also used for training, was completed in 1976.
NASA also gains a week in turnaround time whenever a shuttle lands here. Robert B. Sieck, who directs launchings at Kennedy, said the extra time allowed his staff to prepare more thoroughly for the next mission of Atlantis, scheduled for November.
Since the 1986 disaster in which seven astronauts died when the shuttle Challenger's booster rocket exploded shortly after liftoff, NASA officials have preferred to land at Edwards. The California base has wider runways and more predictable weather, although today's landing took place with a clear sky after a night of heavy thunderstorms and lightning.
In preparation for today's landing, both the shuttle fleet and the Kennedy landing strip have been modified. NASA officials said the main landing gear, braking system and steering mechanisms have been upgraded, in line with recommendations by the commission that investigated the Challenger accident.
To reduce wear and tear on the tires of the shuttle fleet, Kennedy's concrete landing strip has also been made smoother. Even so, Robert L. Crippen, director of the shuttle program, said at a news conference after the landing that one of the vehicle's tires "did show some wear on the cords."
The next shuttle flight, that of the Discovery, is scheduled for September. NASA officials said today that tentative plans called for the Discovery to touch down at Kennedy.

HEADLINE: In Guggenheim Restoration, Wright Laughs Last

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
Did the Guggenheim Museum -- whose innovative spiral structure opened to a bemused public in 1959 -- do wrong by its architect, Frank Lloyd Wright? Yes, say Guggenheim officials, who promise that when the museum reopens in February after a $24 million renovation, Wright and his vision will be vindicated.
"We are restoring a monument," said Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director. "It was Wright's last and some say most original building, and our aim is to give it back to the public, reveal it in a way never seen before, consistent with Wright's original architectural concepts." 
 So the space Wright designed as a restaurant on the 88th Street side of the museum will again be a restaurant, using some of Wright's original plans for the first time, instead of a conservation laboratory; the ramp at the top of the spiral will be used as Wright intended, for art instead of storage, and the smaller of the two rotundas, which Wright called the Monitor Building, will be freed of its non-Wrightian glass and wood enclosures and made visible as dramatic space.
"It was clear that the Wright building was compromised, and much of it is in bad shape," Mr. Krens added. "The original architecture has been submerged, and the building is badly in need of repair." The project began in 1988.
The restoration was planned in conjunction with a nearly completed seven-story gallery and office annex connected to the rear of the Wright building. The annex, designed by the architectural firm of Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, has been widely criticized by those who say it detracts from the Wright structure.
 
The Changes Being Made
 All the glass in the Wright building, including that in the enormous domed skylight, is being replaced by thermal panes that filter out harmful ultraviolet and infrared rays. The skylight itself has been redone to seal leaks. The walls are being insulated for climate control, the auditorium stage is being renovated for performances, and new excavation beyond the foundation will provide 10,000 square feet of underground space on Fifth Avenue between 88th and 89th Streets for offices and other functions.
"We are driven by Wright's strict plans, but we want also to make sure that we have a mature, professional museum space," said Mr. Krens, whose eager championship of the Wright building is seen by some as an attempt to deflect criticism that the addition destroys the integrity of Wright's concept. "The only way we are able to give the public the full experience of the original Wright building is because we've put all of the necessary museum functions outside of it." Conservation activities and storage have been transferred to an Upper West Side warehouse, and offices are being moved to the new annex and underground space and to a building in SoHo.
The Guggenheim building, shaped like an upside-down teakettle, took 17 years from initial planning to realization. It was such a complicated construction project that after Wright finished the drawings, it was hard to find a builder. The job was undertaken by George N. Cohen, a contractor who had gained experience with cast concrete when building freeway overpasses. The museum's founder, Solomon R. Guggenheim, who died in 1949, had left only $2 million to build the museum, so Cohen used the most economical methods available, for example using Gunite, a concrete material sprayed from a hose against plywood forms, for the outside walls.
Wright was so grateful to Cohen for cutting costs that he allowed the contractor's name to appear on the building next to his own imprimatur, a red square with his signature through it. This is thought to be the only time Wright shared billing with a builder.
But the Gunite walls were not insulated, as required by the intricate climate-control systems that are standard in museums today. So an important and painstaking part of the renovation is stripping the walls of their interior plaster, applying a special vapor-controlling insulation and replastering them. "With the complex systems they require, museums have to be built like hospitals today," said Thomas A. Sansone, the architectural consultant for the restoration and expansion program, who researched Wright's original drawings for the Guggenheim at the Wright Foundation in Arizona. "They have a similar need for control of various climatological situations."
The entire mechanical system of the Wright building is being replaced and transferred to the annex. This will make the roof of the Wright building -- with its close-up view of the Central Park Reservoir -- accessible for tours and possibly for events, Mr. Krens said.
Many of the deviations from Wright's original vision can be traced to James Johnson Sweeney, the Guggenheim's director from 1952 to 1960. Wright and Sweeney were at odds constantly. Wright aimed at "a new unity between beholder, painting and architecture" and saw the museum as "one extended expansive wall space from top to bottom" with "no stops anywhere." He envisioned the pictures hung without frames on the outward-sloping walls, not "bolt-upright" but "gently inclined, faced slightly upward to the viewer and the light."
But Sweeney, a practical museum man, hated the idea of viewing pictures on a slant. As construction started in 1958, he pressed for the elimination of the sloping walls. What's more, a group of artists, including Willem de Kooning, whose work was hung at the museum's opening, wrote to Sweeney and the Guggenheim trustees pronouncing the sloping walls and ramp unsuitable for exhibitions.
The Wright scheme stayed. When the museum opened in October 1959, however, six months after Wright's death, it was apparent that Sweeney had foiled the architect, using rods that projected out from the walls to hang the pictures upright. He had also demanded several other changes to take account of the growing museum's needs: more office, library and storage space and a conservation laboratory. And he pushed successfully for an artificial lighting system as opposed to Wright's design for natural illumination.
Despite the fact that Wright felt the top of the ramp was the summation of the viewer's experience, Sweeney appropriated all of the sixth and half of the fifth floor ramp levels -- the biggest display areas in the building -- for storage and conservation. When the building reopens in February these areas will be reclaimed for the exhibition of art. False walls have been removed so that the bays, fully used for art for the first time, are flooded with light from both the dome and a skylight that runs like a ribbon around the perimeter of the ramp.
Beyond the battles between Wright and Sweeney, however, the building's suitability as a display space for art has for years been debated by professionals in both art and architecture. If the building has been criticized as impractical, as a visionary rather than a functional space, it has also been vociferously defended. In an interview the other day, Walter H. Kilham, an architect and admirer of Wright who was in practice at the time, said: "I remember Sweeney's differences with Wright, and from the museum point of view, Sweeney was absolutely correct. Wright was impractical. But his ideas were so much more important. There are thousands of practical people, but there's only one Frank Lloyd Wright."
 
Further Depreadations
 Sweeney resigned from the Guggenheim in 1960, but as the museum continued to grow and acquire collections, more of Wright's original design schemes were turned to other uses. Gradually the open spaces of the small rotunda were closed in. When the museum received the Justin K. Thannhauser Collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art in 1963, for example, an elaborate gallery, with brocade-covered walls and a parquet floor that Wright would have sneered at, was created on the second floor of the small rotunda. Eventually every open corner and closet was turned into office or storage space.
The cafeteria on the 88th Street side was used as a library and then a conservation lab, and the important public entrances on the outside ramp leading to the cafeteria and the basement auditorium were closed to the public. When the building reopens, these entrances will be restored.
In 1968, to provide more office and storage space, the museum built a four-story cantilevered annex behind the museum on a site for which Wright himself had proposed a 10- to 12-story extension that might have included artists' residences. The four-story addition, designed by Taliesin Associated Architects, the inheritors of Wright's practice, was torn down to make way for the new annex, which uses its load-bearing columns.
When the Wright building reopens in February, all the walls and other spatial encumbrances that plagued the small rotunda and the passage to the large spiral will be cleared away, said Michael Govan, deputy director of the museum. The rotunda will re-emerge as exhibition and gallery space. "The little rotunda is one of the big discoveries of the restoration," Mr. Govan added. "Its intimate, almost domestic scale contrasts with the public grandeur of the large spiral. Opening up this space makes you understand the logic of Wright's building."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Monday about the restoration of the Guggenheim Museum omitted the name of the architectural firm for the project. It is Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, which also designed the annex.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Management Accountant's Wider Role

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
IN a sign of the times, the National Association of Accountants recently changed its name to the Institute of Management Accountants.
Along with the name change, there is a new importance attached to the title of C.M.A., for certified management accountant, that the institute bestows since management accountants, who work within corporations, are being given wider responsibilities. To get the title, they must have management accounting experience and pass examinations. Many companies, including Johnson & Johnson and I.B.M., provide study programs for the test for their employees. 
 The C.M.A. designation is intended as a counterpart to the C.P.A., or certified public accountant. It is awarded to accountants who have passed the required courses of study and examinations. Management accounting is intended to emphasize the nature of an accountant's work within a corporation as opposed to public accounting, which serves a variety of public clients in a number of ways, including the reviewing of a company's results for stockholders.
Currently there are 94,000 members of the institute, and about 10,000 of them hold the C.M.A. designation, which was first given in 1972, according to Donald W. Baker, president of the organization, who is a C.P.A. as well as a C.M.A. He is also vice president-controller of the Southwire Company, a Carrollton, Ga., maker of copper and aluminum wire cable for the transmission of electricity.
"Management is much more attuned to certification," Mr. Baker said in a telephone interview last week. "In the next decade we will see more emphasis on certification for those in corporate management posts in accounting."
He spoke of a "growing need for management accountants" who have a much broader role to play today in management than the cost and tax accounting in which they specialized in former years. There no longer is "the green-eyeshade viewpoint of accounting," he added.
Increasingly, he said, management accountants will need to understand the global environment and the handling of new, ever-changing technology demands. C.M.A.'s will continue to be used more widely by companies in planning corporate strategy, he added.
"We are becoming one large business community worldwide, and that means the need for more sophistication and knowledge," he said. "People who can provide and interpret the information will be those who hold C.M.A. designations. Employers more and more are recognizing the value of certification."
Mr. Baker urges that young people interested in corporate management via accounting should major in accounting during college and stress communicatons skills.
The institute, first named the National Association of Cost Accountants when it was formed in 1919, pioneered the evolution of cost accounting. This was a very important but confusing subject because it involved the setttlement of the "cost-plus" contracts with the Government during and after World War I, These contracts were based on the cost of producing a product plus an agreed profit. Company accountants also worked as well on projecting the cost of new products being developed. In 1957 the association changed its name to the National Association of Accountants.
Over the years, management accounting evolved to distinguish the internal accounting of companies from the duties of public accountants. And on July 27, 1987, institute officials appeared before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations to recommend the requiring of the C.M.A. certification for financial professionals as a "significant step" in achieving the aims of a national commission appointed to fight fraudulent financial reporting. No action was taken on the recommendation.
The C.M.A. title was first awarded in 1972. Gaining the right to use it requires two years of on-the-job managerial accounting experience and then passing an examination on varied topics. The subjects include economics, finance and management, financial accounting and reporting, management reporting, analysis and behavioral issues, decision analysis and information systems.
The institute gives its examinations twice a year, in January and June, in many cities. The examination consists of four parts, which can be taken one at a time, or all four over a period of two days. "Hong Kong; Fairbanks, Alaska; Amsterdam, the Netherlands, are a few of the places where we give the exams," an institute spokesman said, indicating the widespread availability of the tests.
Once qualified, C.M.A. applicants must agree to follow the code of ethics established by the institute. And once awarded the designation, a C.M.A. who commits a fraud loses certification, in addition to facing any civil or criminal charges.
The C.M.A. designation pays off in higher salaries, acoording to Daniel M. Hrisak, a spokesman for the institute, which has its headquarters in Montvale, N.J. According to the institute, the average salary for a C.M.A. in the 19-to-29 age bracket is $44,698, compared with $31,547 for institute members with no such certification.
In the 30-to-39 age group, C.M.A.'s typically earn $54,240 a year, while counterparts without the title earn $43,622. C.M.A.'s in the 40-to-49 age group average $59,509, while those without the title earn $51,858.
In the key managerial age group of 50 to 59, C.M.A.'s reported salaries averaging $65,361, compared with $63,257 for those without the designation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Light Day While Gold Prices Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against major currencies yesterday in light trading as investors took a wait-and-see approach to changes in German interest rates to be announced this week.
Gold prices moved lower. In New York, gold for current delivery fell 90 cents a troy ounce, to $357.50, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid for gold at $357.45 an ounce, down $1.05 from late Friday. 
 The British pound gained against the dollar yesterday after slipping Thursday and Friday.
In New York, the pound finished at $1.6980, up from $1.6945 Friday. Earlier in London, the British pound rose to $1.6975, from $1.6965 late Friday.
The dollar finished slightly lower against most other European currencies, and held steady against the Japanese yen.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 136.40 Japanese yen, from 136.30 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 136.50 yen, down from 136.80 Friday. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 136.55 yen, unchanged from Friday.
Many currency traders were waiting to see what will happen to Germany's interest rates. Some dealers expect increases across the board in Germany's discount and Lombard rates after the Thursday meeting of the Bundesbank's council, but many traders said anything could happen.
"I think we're in a holding pattern," said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president with Harris Trust and Savings Bank. "Nobody wants to take a view until we see what the Germans do."
"I think most people continue to keep their powder dry -- stay on the sidelines," said David Ethridge, vice president with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. "It's an old adage of trading, you sell the rumor and buy the fact."
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.7245 marks from 1.7288.

HEADLINE: Bank Stocks Lift Market; Dow Rises 5.14, to 3,001.34

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Buoyed by bank stocks, the stock market overcame early losses yesterday to post a gain at the close, with the Dow Jones industrial average again bouncing just past 3,000.
The announcement of the agreement for the $4 billion acquisition of the Security Pacific Corporation by the BankAmerica Corporation sent some big bank stocks sharply higher, but the rest of the market was weak. But in early trading only over-the-counter stocks posted gains, and even a firm bond market could not turn stocks around until the bank news hit. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderately light at 145.6 million shares, up from 144.1 million on Friday. Declining issues narrowly outpaced advancing issues by 776 to 767.
 
Composite Indexes Gain
 The Dow was up 5.14, to 3,001.34, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.90, to 388.02. Most stocks on the Big Board also gained and the composite index rose 0.36, to 212.53. American Stock Exchange issues rose, sending the composite index up by 0.33, to 366.31.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index rose 1.69 to close at 510.
William E. Raftery, vice president of technical research at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, described yesterday's market as light but holding its own. He noted that the market was confused over the economy and had swung with each assessment of an economy that was strengthening to an economy that was weakening, to strengthening again.
"The market will stay at this level, until something gets the majority of the stocks to move," he said. "Right now we have investors just picking through the market, jumping from one segment to another."
Downward pressures stretched across the broad breadth of the market for most of the day, but by late afternoon blue-chip stocks cut their losses to post a slim gain in mild trading. Bank stocks were still up and bond prices were holding and supporting the market.
Mr. Raftery said it was possible the Dow could go to 3,100 and 3,200, with 4,000 reachable, if the bond market rallied.
BankAmerica rose 2 5/8, to 40, while Security Pacific jumped 9 1/8, to 32 1/8.
 
Other Banks Show Gains
 Other bank stocks caught up in the news included Bank of New York, up 2 1/4, to 35; Chase Manhattan, up 1 3/4, to 21 1/8; Mellon Bank, up 1 3/4, to 34 5/8; Citicorp, up 1, to 14 3/4; First Interstate, up 6 1/8, to 33 7/8, and Wells Fargo, up 3 1/4, to 75 1/2.
Special situations in yesterday's market also saw Price, a company whose principal business is in wholesale cash and carry merchandise, rise 2, to 58, in over-the-counter trading, as Chris Vroom, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons gave the company a strong "buy" recommendation. He said the company's plan to offer shares in a real estate investment trust reflected a more aggressive stance toward growth and expects the company to accelerate its warehouse expansion.
ARCO fell 2 7/8, to 116 1/2. A Dean Witter analyst. Eugene L. Nowak, said he had cut third-quarter earnings estimates and those for all of 1991 and 1992. He still considers the stock a good long-term investment, but expects it to trade lower over the short haul as investors reassess what he thinks are diminished earnings propects.
 
Delta Down 7/8, to 72 1/4
 Delta Air Lines fell 7/8, to 72 1/4. Earlier in the day, Judge Cornelius Blackshear of Bankruptcy Court approved the sale of Pan Am assets to Delta in a new deal valued at $1.7 billion. Part of the sale agreement calls for Delta to help finance a plan of reorganization for Pan Am.
Kennametal Inc. fell 3 1/2, to 31 5/8, as investors reacted to reports that the company was the subject of a Government investigation on sales of equipment to Iraq. The company acknowledged that it had sold goods to Irag, or to those who resold products to that country, but it denied that the sales violated export laws.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
For Wall St., a Bigger Bank Is Better

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Wall Street loves bank mergers because it hopes competition will vanish, or at least get a lot less vigorous.
"Scale gives you market heft," said one investment banker yesterday, speaking on condition he not be named. "All of a sudden you have an 800-pound gorilla in some of these markets." 
 The reduction of competition is far from the only benefit of combinations like the one announced yesterday by BankAmerica and Security Pacific, and it is not the one that the banks prefer to cite. The two banks forecast annual savings of $1 billion a year within three years, as tellers are laid off and competing branches are closed.
But in talking to security analysts yesterday, Jerry A. Grundhofer, the president of the Security Pacific National Bank, said, "There are tremendous leverages on the revenue side, and we will take advantage of them." He will become a vice chairman of BankAmerica when its Security Pacific deal is completed.
Wall Street's enthusiasm was shown in stock prices. BankAmerica rose $2.625, to $40, adding $430 million to its market capitalization, while Security Pacific soared $9.125, to $32.125, adding $4.1 billion to its market value.
But Security Pacific shares still ended the day at only 80 percent of the price of BankAmerica shares, reflecting some market caution about the deal, which calls for each Security Pacific share to be exchanged for 0.88 BankAmerica share.
The market reaction indicated doubt that Wells Fargo, which had previously wooed Security Pacific, would try to submit a higher bid. But even though Wells Fargo seems like a competitive loser from the deal, its shares rose $3.25, to $75.50. And First Interstate, which merger rumors immediately named as a possible Wells Fargo target, leaped $6.125, to $33.875.
For now, anyway, investors are prepared to believe in synergy and in the benign effects on profits brought on by reduced competition. With fewer banks around, the hope is that those remaining will be able to offer lower interest rates to savers, charge higher rates to borrowers, and have more left over for shareholders. Even competitors, the theory goes, will benefit as large banks merge.
A generation ago, a combination of BankAmerica and Security Pacific -- the No. 1 and No. 2 banks in the nation's largest state -- would have been dismissed as a clear violation of antitrust laws. But bank officials said yesterday that they did not foresee any antitrust problems, and most analysts agree. Regulators now are less concerned that a lack of competition will hurt consumers than they are that bad loans will destroy banks.
To some on Wall Street, the most interesting aspect of the plan announced yesterday was not the expected savings, but the accounting. There are two acceptable ways to account for a merger, but in recent years banks have tended to use only one of them, known as pooling of interest, for most major deals. But BankAmerica will use purchase accounting.
That decision will enable BankAmerica effectively to add to loan-loss reserves at Security Pacific without having to report lower profits as a result.
The accounting treatment will not affect the reality of the loans, of course. In the past couple of years, problems have mounted, and Security Pacific's stock price has reflected investors' suspicions that more problems were likely to come.
In this takeover, BankAmerica effectively is betting that Security Pacific is not so bad off as Wall Street thinks -- or, a cynic might say, it is betting that BankAmerica is not so healthy as Wall Street believes. As of last Friday, BankAmerica was trading at 1.3 times its book value of $29.04 a share. But Security Pacific, beset by bad real estate loans and problems in Britain and Australia, was trading at just 0.7 times its book value of $32.40 a share.
In fact, the deal announced yesterday included an implicit disclosure that Security Pacific had more problems. In effect, BankAmerica plans to increase the reserves for bad loans by about $1 billion when it makes the acquisition.
If that is all there is to the hits, then the deal would still make sense for BankAmerica, even before it considers the savings that have so entranced Wall Street. Assuming a 40 percent tax rate, the effective write-off would be $600 million. That would mean BankAmerica would surrender stock with a book value of $25.56 for each Security Pacific share, which would have a book value of $27.68.
Finding that $1 billion in future financial statements will be a challenge. That is because of the accounting treatment. If it had been a pooling, the two companies would have combined, with all the historic book values preserved. If a write-off was needed, it would go through the income statement and would show up as a reduction of income.
But in purchase accounting, the buyer -- BankAmerica in this case -- values the assets and liabilities of the company being acquired. It then compares the net value of the assets with what it is paying. Based on the value of its stock last Friday, it will figure it is paying $4.2 billion.
If it winds up paying more than the assets are worth, then the difference will be shown as intangible assets, which are written off over many years. So it could make a large increase in loan-loss reserves, and have that show up as an adjustment to the value of the assets it acquired. If it ended up overpaying, that difference would show up as intangibles.
The rules for bank accounting are complicated in the extreme, and in some cases it is difficult to adjust loan values on acquisition if the problem is one of credit quality. But that can be finessed if the acquiring bank says it plans to get rid of the assets quickly.
That may help explain why BankAmerica's chief financial officer, Frank N. Newman, who will assume the same position in the combined company, said the company was considering a plan to put all or nearly all of the bad loans from Security Pacific, and perhaps some from BankAmerica, into a separate company. That company would owe money to BankAmerica, but its shares would be spun off to BankAmerica's shareholders, making it a separate company. Those plans, he said, were tentative and could be changed.

Smith, the chairman of the Security Pacific Corporation, announced yesterday at a news conference held in Los Angeles that BankAmerica would acquire its smaller California rival. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in sluggish trading yesterday, pushing interest rates slightly lower.
"The market is in very good technical shape," one government bond trader said. "Of the refunding issues sold last week, only the bond is poorly distributed. As long as the economic numbers hold up this week, the market should do fine." 
 Despite the positive outlook, credit market participants spent a good bit of time yesterday talking -- and worrying -- about the potential impact of the market manipulation charges levied against Salomon Brothers by the Government last week.
"Nobody can think about the business because they are thinking about the business," the trader said. "It's impossible to say what the near-term implications of this are, but over the longer haul people are concerned about greater regulation. The timing of this couldn't be worse."
Last week Salomon admitted that at three separate Treasury note auctions held within the last nine months -- for two-, four- and five-year notes -- it had placed bids well in excess of the 35 percent cap any one firm can attempt to purchase at an auction. The firm also said that at some of those auctions it had submitted bids in the names of customers who had not authorized it to do so.
Suspicion that Salomon had been trying to corner the market in these issues had been circulating through the credit markets for months. But traders at rival firms said they derived little comfort when their worst thoughts were realized.
"This is a real black eye for the business," another bond trader said.
Investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commisssion and the Justice Department into Salomon's activities began before Salomon's announcement. With the Government Securities Act of 1986 up for reauthorization by Congress in the fall, market participants fear much tighter scrutiny in the future.
Traders and analysts said it would be impossible to begin to assess the market impact of the Salomon scandal until later this month, when the next two-year and five-year note auctions are scheduled.
"We will have a better feel for Salomon's reaction to this once we get through those auctions," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at Bank of America. "Then we will need to see what the S.E.C. and the Justice Department turn up."
Concerns about Salomon had no apparent effect on trading yesterday, as the successful completion of the refunding auctions and the positive implications of the Federal Reserve Board's decision to ease short-term interest rates last week continued to flow through the market.
Mr. Wood and other analysts said the Fed's move to lower the target for the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market to 5.50 percent had led to speculation that the central bank might move soon to lower the discount rate from its current 6 percent level.
That sort of speculation helped to bolster prices in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
In late trading, the new 8 1/8 percent issue of August 2021, sold at auction last week, was offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield to yield 8.20 percent, down from 8.22 percent late Friday.
In when-issued trading, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes sold last week were offered at a price to yield 7.93 percent, while the new 6 7/8 percent three-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.82 percent.
The recent slide in short-term interest rates was graphically visible in the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.
 
Three-Month Bill Rates
 Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.36 percent, down sharply from an average rate of 5.51 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on the new six-month securities produced an average yield of 5.39 percent, compared with 5.59 percent a week ago.
The drop in rates served as encouragement to a number of investment-grade corporations to price new issues yesterday. Five corporations offered a total of $875 million worth of new securities.
Among the issuers was Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, which offered $200 million worth of 30-year noncallable debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Co.
The 9 percent debentures were priced at $99.178, to yield 9.018 percent, 87.5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the new 8 1/8 percent Treasury bonds of August 2021 at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Motorola 40-Year Debentures
 Goldman, Sachs also acted as lead manager on a $200 million offering of 40-year debentures for Motorola Inc.
The 8.40 percent securities, which may be redeemed by the issuer at par, or $100, on Aug. 15, 2001, were priced at par, 45 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's new 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's and AA-minus by Standard & Poor's.
A sharp improvement in the prices of oustanding debt securities issued by the Security Pacific Corporation highlighted activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds.
Prices of Security Pacific bonds surged by as much as six points shortly after it was announced the bank would be acquired by BankAmerica.
By contrast, traders said that bids on BankAmerica issues slipped by about a point. However, few securities actually changed hands.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Taxpayer's Role In Bank Bailouts

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
FOR months, the national debate over bailing out failed banks has rested on the assumption that the banking industry itself -- not the taxpayers -- would eventually pay the costs of reimbursing depositors who lose money. Now a House Banking Committee report is unraveling this assumption, mostly by illustrating rather starkly that the rules of deposit insurance have quietly been altered.
Until the report appeared in June, Congress had been proceeding with a rather standard strategy: It would advance $70 billion to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to get the nearly broke agency through the current wave of bank failures. The banks, however, would continue their decades-old practice of covering the cost of deposit insurance by paying annual premiums to the F.D.I.C. And they would eventually repay the $70 billion taxpayer advance -- thus preserving deposit insurance as a private, industry-financed affair. 
 "This bill has $70 billion in it for the bank insurance fund premised on the theory that the banks will pick up the tab; that's a very risky premise," Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, told the Senate Banking Committee recently during a debate on bank reform legislation.
As others have, the Senator reacted to the evidence in the House report that Federal Reserve lending practices had made possible the reimbursement of nearly all depositors in many bank failures since 1985, and not just those with insured accounts of $100,000 or less. Such expanded bailouts are raising the possibility that the deposit insurance system will, in time, have to be altered.
One concern is whether the commercial banks, already paying premiums that have quadrupled since 1989, can continue to afford the expanded coverage. The American Bankers Association says, flatly, no. "You have not got an industry big enough or an insurance fund big enough to protect all accounts above $100,000," said Robert Dugger, chief economist of the Bankers Association.
More important: should the banking industry cover all the costs of deposit insurance, even if it could afford the bill? The argument here, increasingly, is also no. The reasoning goes this way: The failure of some big banks would disrupt the financial system and damage the economy. Therefore, these institutions should be saved, with insured as well as uninsured depositors made whole. And since the public would suffer from such bank failures, the public -- the taxpayer -- should pay some or all of the huge bailout cost.
"If the costs are made more explicit in this fashion, then the public can voice some opinion," said Catherine England, director of bank regulatory studies at the Cato Institute. "There can be a debate about whether a particular big bank's failure would be a systemic risk." The recent bailout of the Bank of New England would have been part of this debate.
Congress is reluctant to give taxpayers a permanent role in bank bailouts, although the House and Senate versions of bank reform legislation move in this direction; the House much more than the Senate. The Bush Administration, for its part, says the banking industry should always pay for deposit insurance, never the taxpayer -- except for the $70 billion temporary advance, or the one-time outlays that have been made to resolve the savings and loan association failures.
Only the Fed, surprisingly, is prepared to give ground. Or, as David W. Mullins Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, puts it: "There is considerable logic behind the notion that a portion of the payment for systemic risk resolutions might come from public funds because of the public benefit from safeguarding the financial system and the economy."
By all accounts, the Fed's change of heart reflects embarrassment over the House Banking Committee report. Drawing on Fed data, the House report noted that the Fed had made unpublicized loans from its "discount window" to more than 350 faltering banks, large and small, that later failed. The loans prolonged the lives of these banks, allowing uninsured depositors to withdraw their money.
When these institutions finally failed, the F.D.I.C. reimbursed the Fed for its loans, but no longer had the uninsured deposits at its disposal to help reimburse insured depositors. The F.D.I.C. says the extra drain on the insurance fund over five years was less than $2 billion. But Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, challenges this estimate as much too low.
Whatever the amount, Mr. Mullins distinguishes between "liquidity" loans from the Fed's discount window and "extended" lending. The former would continue; most are short-term loans to get healthy banks through cash shortages. The extended loans, taking the Fed beyond its charter, are the very aid to faltering banks cited in the House report.
During the Depression, the last wave of bank failures, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation propped up banks through loans, and answered to Congress for its dealings. Now Ms. England, other experts and the Fed itself are suggesting that if some faltering banks are to be kept alive and all depositors reimbursed, some new R.F.C. should make this decision -- not the Fed.
"It would be one answer," Mr. Mullins said, "if we could disassociate the resolution funding from our traditional discount window activities."

HEADLINE: The Two Newarks; Boom Amid Bust -- A Special Report;
In Newark, Downtown Glitter Battles Neighborhood Gloom

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Newark has a future. On that most people agree. Its location makes it the transportation hub of northern New Jersey, and $6 billion in new office construction over the last five years has revived confidence in the city.
But whether that future will take the form of a city where people want to live is a question with no clear answer. Newark presents two different images to visitors: one of gleaming steel and glass towers, the other of 100-year-old railroad shacks and multifamily wood frame houses in neighborhoods with few stores or amenities, not even a movie theater. 
 Downtown, new office towers rise near the Passaic River; four dormitories have been completed near the city's four colleges and universities; a new Federal courthouse is under construction; the first 25 town houses in a 90-unit complex have opened, and the United States Postal Service, which had considered moving its regional distribution center to Secaucus, has decided to stay and expand here, possibly creating as many as 2,700 more jobs.
 
'Phoenix Is Rising Again'
 And the city, which has been the butt of jokes for generations, has received an all-American Cities Award from the National Civic League and, because of the city's improvements, has been called the "most livable city" by the United States Conference of Mayors.
"The Phoenix is rising again," said the city's ebullient Mayor, Sharpe James.
But if the Phoenix is rising, its flight has not reached the neighborhoods of this 325-year-old city, which lost 52,000 residents, a decrease of 16 percent, between 1980 and 1990.
Unemployment remains high at 12.6 percent, almost twice the state average. The city's school system is considered one of the worst in the state and is under the threat of a possible state takeover. Newark is second only to New York City in the nation in the per capita rate of AIDS infection -- mostly among intravenous drug users. And residents, as soon as they find the money or have children, flee to other communities.
"Newark is experiencing one of the biggest inner-city developments anywhere," said Norman J. Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. "But the problem is there's no trickle down," he said. "Go five blocks from the core of the business district and you find some of the worst urban conditions in the United States."
The problems in this city of 275,221 are similar to those in other former industrial giants, like Detroit and Pittsburgh. Downtown development has changed the landscape of those cities. But the new offices, condominiums and apartment towers have done little for the neighborhoods.
 
Middle-Class Flight
 Newark, which became the state's industrial leader in the 1800's on the strength of its leather making, brewing and jewelry manufacturing, has suffered a steady decline since World War II. The city has been written off several times, most recently after the 1967 riots, which left 26 people dead and much of the city in ruins. After the riots, Newark lost most of its middle-class residents, who fled in record numbers, leaving the poor to rebuild their lives and neighborhoods with little economic support.
According to Census Bureau statistics, the 1990 population of Newark decreased 27 percent from 1970, when the population was 382,417.
Somehow, Newark survived, mostly on the strength of the people who stayed, either because they hoped to bring the city back or because they had no other choice. Now, their downtown is doing better than in decades, while their neighborhoods continue to rely on nonprofit organizations and block associations for improvements.
"The people who had to or chose to stay through the tough times, those who held the neighborhoods together, deserve as much credit as anyone else and should share in the benefits of any revival," said Richard Cammarieri, a lifelong resident and executive director of the Newark Coalition for Neighborhoods. "There is still some equity here because of them."
 
The Neighborhoods
Who Benefits From Revival?
 But so far, those people have not shared in the revival, said Msgr. William J. Lindner, founder of the New Community Corporation, a nonprofit organization that has built 10 housing complexes for 5,000 people, health-care centers for the poor and a supermarket, among other things, in Newark's most distressed neighborhoods.
"People arrive at Penn Station from the suburbs and go to work in all those complexes, but they don't provide jobs for the people in the neighborhoods," he said. "Our economic needs are so great and yet block grant money doesn't help the neighborhoods. It's used downtown."
Monsignor Lindner cited the construction of a walkway above Raymond Boulevard that connects a new office building -- the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's Legal and Communications Center -- with Penn Station. The pedestrian bridge was built by the Newark Economic Development Corporation with a $1.3 million loan from the city. That money, the Monsignor said, could have been used to repair streets, sidewalks and make other improvements in the neighborhoods.
Alfred L. Faiella, executive director of the development corporation, said the bridge was needed to complete the legal center and to provide a safe crossing for pedestrians. He said the development corporation will use the proceeds from a 450-car garage it is building downtown to pay off the loan. He said the corporation is already helping minority business owners fix up their stores.
"A ride up the main corridors of the city today will show a great deal of improvement over what it was just a few years ago," Mr. Faiella said.
Everett Shaw, president of Renaissance Newark, a civic and business advocacy group, said the $6 billion in downtown construction had helped to renew confidence in the city. That confidence, he said, has already begun to spread to the neighborhoods in the form of housing construction and renovation by private developers.
"More market-rate housing is being built in the city than in the last six decades," Mr. Shaw said, "and more than 2.2 million square feet of commercial space is under construction or contract."
Such development, Mr. Shaw said, provides construction jobs for the short term and the promise of permanent jobs in the long run. Community leaders counter that while the construction jobs are good, they are not enough to sustain a city where the median income is $12,000 and about one-third of the residents receive welfare.
"We need a reality check on some of these things," said Mr. Cammarieri of the Newark Coalition for Neighborhoods. "We have to get rid of the exaggeration and hyperbole about some of the development and talk realistically about costs and benefits.
"It's an old story," he said "We're not where we were but we're still not near where we want to be -- in terms of our needs."
 
The Decline
Downhill Slide In the 50's
 Newark was once a great city with a powerful industrial and business base. It was there that the Prudential Insurance Company was founded. But things began to change by the 1950's, with an exodus of residents and businesses to the suburbs. One of the city's major employers, Mutual Benefit Life Insurance, nonetheless chose to remain. After that the Prudential Insurance Company built a new office tower. At the time, the two buildings were the first new office construction in the city since 1931.
Mutual Benefit and Prudential -- joined by New Jersey Bell, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and First Fidelity Bank -- began a coalition that has been a stabilizing force for decades. The coalition suffered a serious blow recently with the threatened collapse of Mutual Benefit, its acknowledged leader, because of poor real-estate investments. City officials and urban planners say the problems at Mutual Benefit could have serious consequences for the city's future.
The companies have provided the impetus for a proposed $75 million performing arts center, which would be built near the Passaic River and not far from the Newark Museum and Library. The center could be an anchor for further downtown development, such as that already under way with the legal center, a new Blue Cross and Blue Shield building, a new headquarters for N.J. Transit, the state's public transportation agency, and an office building that will house Seton Hall Law School.
 
'We Pulled the Rug Out'
 Such projects, Mayor James said, will help the city to better help its neighborhoods in the future.
In an effort to better manage the city, Mayor James in 1986 hired Richard Monteilh, the former deputy finance commissioner in Atlanta, to be Newark's business administrator. And last month, the Mayor hired William Celester, a deputy superintendent of the Boston Police Department, to be Newark's new police director. In an effort to bolster confidence in the city's neighborhoods, Mr. Celester has ordered the deployment of 70 percent of the city's police force to the streets.
On taking office five years ago Mr. James ordered a management study that showed the city was losing tens of millions of dollars through poor collection of property and water taxes. A crackdown raised the rate of tax collections to 92 percent, from below 80 percent, and ended a peculiar city hall perquisite. "Many of those who weren't paying worked for the city and assumed that they didn't have to pay taxes," he said. "We pulled the rug out from under them."
Since then, Moody's Investors Service has raised the city's bond ratings slightly, thereby making it less expensive for Newark to borrow money.
"People are feeling good about the city," Mayor James said, adding that "the true report card on the city will be the quality of life in the neighborhoods."
 
Paying No Taxes
 "My challenge is to use the development to reach out and touch the neighborhoods and make sure the renaissance is more than new buildings and Broad and Market Streets," he said.
Community leaders insist, however, that that is not being done. They say that the downtown development, as impressive as it is, is not addressing the needs of residents: an improved school system, better housing and improved health services.
About two-thirds of Newark's 24 square miles is occupied by government buildings, schools, parks and Port Authority operations that pay no taxes. The city receives $18 million a year from the Port Authority and about $10 million from other tax-exempt institutions instead of taxes to support the city's $465 million budget.
Richard D. Marshall, professor of real-estate finance at Rutgers University, said that in its eagerness to attract new development, the city has allowed non-taxpaying tenants to occupy prime commercial land. Those institutions include Rutgers, the New Jersey Institute of Technology, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and Essex County Community College.
Nonetheless, Mr. Glickman, of the Center for Urban Policy Research, said that Mayor James has made great strides in changing the city's deep-seated image problems. But those strides may not be enough. "The Mayor is pushing and trying to counteract them, but I don't know if he's going to be able to succeed," Mr. Glickman said. "Conventional wisdom says people will continue to leave. Things might yet turn around but it's going to be a tough job."
 
The Solutions
New Housing Is the Key
 Vic DeLuca, chairman of the Newark Coalition for Low Income Housing, and Steve Finn, director of the coalition's home project, said one way to help turn the city around is to build more affordable housing for the city's poor.
According to the Census Bureau, Newark had 127,424 housing units in 1970, and 102,473 in 1990.
Newark desperately needs affordable housing, they say. Community leaders say that the city has 8,000 to 10,000 homeless families and countless numbers of people doubled up, living in makeshift apartments in basements.
But in 1987 the Newark Housing Authority razed four buildings that contained 800 apartments at the Scudder Homes housing project as part of what was to have been one of the largest public housing demolition programs in the country. Eventually 39 of the 41 high-rise buildings were to have been destroyed.
The housing coalition and some tenants sued and under an agreement signed by the housing authority in September 1989 the authority was given permission to demolish all eight buildings at Christopher Columbus Homes and three of five buildings at Kretchmer Homes. In return the authority had to renovate more than 1,600 apartments and build 1,777 apartments to replace those lost through the demolition.
Since the agreement no new housing has appeared. Some town houses were started on the site of the 1987 demolition but they were so poorly built that two blew down in a thunderstorm in 1989 and the rest were razed.
Construction start schedules for four new town-house projects containing 465 units have come and gone. A ceremonial ground breaking for 100 units at Bergen and Madison Streets was held in April but the June construction start deadline has passed. Benjamin J. Quattlebaum, a spokesman for the authority, said construction will start in September.
Meanwhile, some private developers have built town houses and condominiums for middle-class residents in the Central Ward near the Essex County Courthouse and the cluster of colleges and universities. The Vogue town house development built by Prudential and the Society Hill condominuims, being built the K. Hovnanian Companies, will help to stimulate construction in other neighborhoods, said Dr. Saul K. Fenster, president of New Jersey Institute of Technology.
 
'Some Painful Memories'
 Cora Moody and Pearl Cole, who live in Hayes Homes, a housing project in which all but 280 of about 1,100 families have left, fear that the new housing development will mean they will be forced out of their apartments. Half of the 10 buildings in the project, which is in the Central Ward, are vacant.
"Hayes Homes is in a prime location and I don't think it's fair if we're pushed out," Mrs. Moody said. "I'm all for the renaissance but everybody has to be included."
Mrs. Cole, who has lived in Hayes for 31 years, saw her husband shot by a police officer during the riots when Mr. Cole came to pick her up after work. "We live with some painful memories," she said, "but we've learned lessons from that and we try to help each other. I think the housing authority, the city, H.U.D. and the tenants have to join together and fix the buildings up."
Despite the problems, though, many see a bright future for this city.
"The city has two good strengths," Mr. Glickman said, "its political and business leadership and its location. Mayor James is bright and vigorous and he's working with a very dedicated business leadership.
"And the city has access to the rest of the world and the rest of the metropolitan area by plane, ship, train and highways and that's important when building for the future," he added.
