HEADLINE: THE BANK MERGER;
One Deal Maker Finds No Letup in Demand

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Donald A. Moore is an investment banker who is much in demand these days. A managing director of Morgan Stanley, he specializes in bank deals, and lately he has not had much free time. He has been involved in nearly every major bank merger or acquisition announced this year, including representing the Bank of America in its acquisition of Security Pacific.
Mr. Moore also represented Manufacturers Hanover in its merger with Chemical Bank, and he represented NCNB when it agreed to merge with C&S/Sovran. 
 "I had three days off between Nov. 1st and March 1st of this year," Mr. Moore said, adding that he was including weekends. "Recently, it has been a lot of execution, but we have also been spending a lot of time advising clients."
 
Merger Pressures Grow
 Mr. Moore is not the only one feeling the sweep of merger mania. With each new announcement of a deal, the pressure grows on the management of those banks that have not yet moved to improve their books or their market position.
Mr. Moore and some bank executives say the trend is based on a belief that a merger can produce cost savings for banks, mostly through reducing employment in areas where they have overlapping operations. But also, as regional giants like Banc One in Ohio, Suntrust in Georgia and NCNB in North Carolina build their prowess, many institutions are worried that they could become an also-ran in their own markets. Hence, there is pressure to put together a hefty and profitable market share through regional consolidation.
"There has always been economic pressure for consolidation among U.S. banks," Mr. Moore said, adding, as others have, that the nation needs a mere fraction of the 12,000 or so banks now operating.
In addition to the excess competition, he noted, the credit cycle is in a phase that is putting pressure on bank earnings. Also, problems with bad real estate loans are expected to drag on for several years.
 
Widespread Potential
 When asked where the next deals were likely to show up Mr. Moore, 40 years old, pointed to nearly every region of the country.
"There are some transactions waiting to happen in the Southeast, the West, the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic," he said, adding that there are natural combinations nationwide.
Perhaps more important, the nature of those transactions is likely to change somewhat as pressure grows on bank directors to make acquisitions or take other action to strengthen their companies. Mr. Moore predicted that as buyers get increasingly frustrated at not being able to get their targets to sit and negotiate, there will be more hostile transactions.
Mr. Moore, a California native who lives in New York City with his wife and two children, joined Morgan Stanley in 1975, after graduating from the Harvard Business School. He has specialized in the banking industry for about 14 years and became a managing director of the firm in 1986.

HEADLINE: Cocaine Is Again Surging Out of Panama

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
In most of the world, drug smuggling is a sneaky nighttime affair. But in Panama, nearly two years after President Bush sent in troops to capture Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and crush the cocaine trade, traffickers are boldly hauling drugs at all hours.
On clear mornings, private pilots and others say light planes can be seen circling over Panama's Atlantic and Pacific coasts while crewmen toss bundles of cocaine to waiting cabin cruisers and fishing boats. 
 Other aircraft deliver drugs to dozens of small unguarded airstrips, and an endless procession of skiffs, small wooden workboats, shrimpers and weathered freighters glide along the ragged shorelines, coming from Colombia with cargoes that include cocaine.
"Lots of drugs are coming in," said Captain Jose R. Rosas, the commander of the National Maritime Service, Panama's equivalent of the Coast Guard. "The boats operate all day long, day and night."
As in the past, Panama serves mainly as a way station for cocaine destined for the United States and Europe. But so much cocaine is flooding in that some Panamanians and Americans say the volume is greater than when General Noriega was supposedly giving traffickers safe passage through his airports and harbors in exchange for a share of the profits.
 
Expanding Market
 With General Noriega in custody in the United States and scheduled to go on trial on drug charges in Miami next month, American officials have withheld public disclosure of evidence that might give a measure of the trafficking in General Noriega's day. Nor have Panamanian officials and former Noriega associates come forward with such details.
One of President Bush's stated reasons for invading Panama in December 1989 was "to combat drug trafficking," but since General Noriega's ouster the price of cocaine in Panama has fallen and more of the drug that is being intercepted in the United States is being traced back here.
The Panamanians, with American help, have also been seizing increasingly larger quanitities of cocaine, and Government officials say local cocaine consumption is rising, another indicator that more is entering the country.
President Guillermo Endara and other senior Panamanian officials say they are committed to fighting drug trafficking, but complain that the Government lacks the resources to stem the tide.
 
A Smuggling Free-for-All
 This is partly the result of a decision by the civilian Government to assure that the armed forces and the police do not regain the strength that they enjoyed during the Noriega years, when they cowed the Panamanian public into submission. Though by some accounts the new security forces are less corrupt than their predecessors, they seem to lack a sense of esprit de corps and have not developed into an effective force.
Under General Noriega, cocaine smuggling in Panama was an orderly business, Panamanian and American officials say. He had a close relationship with the Central Intelligence Agency and the Drug Enforcement Administration and won accolades from the drug agency for helping to catch traffickers. But it now appears that the only traffickers who ran into trouble were those who tried to ship drugs without cutting him in.
Since the invasion, cocaine smuggling in Panama has become a free-for-all. Now, law enforcement officials in Panama and Washington say, it is as if the country were beset by an army of ants.
Shortly before the invasion brought the civilian Government to power, the Colombian traffickers began veering away from Caribbean smuggling routes and moving much of their cocaine through Central America and ultimately across the Mexican border into the United States. Panama became the first stop in a route that law-enforcement officials call "the trampoline," which accounts for 70 percent of the cocaine that reaches the United States.
 
Endara Feels the Barbs
 The increasing drug trafficking comes as the civilian Government of President Guillermo Endara is groping for its bearings.
The Government, which inherited $6 billion in foreign debt, a bloated civil service and a thoroughly corrupt and brutal army, has been confronted by strikes, street protests and a crime wave that has produced a bonanza for private security agencies.
After years of political repression but little common crime, Panamanians have been stunned by bank robberies, holdups of restaurants and all their guests, ambushes of business people traveling from airports, and hundreds of burglaries and auto thefts.
Mr. Endara, a 55-year-old corporate lawyer, was respected for his long opposition to Mr. Noriega. But he has appeared indecisive and disorganized and become the butt of jokes about his chubbiness, his love of sweets and his recent marriage to a woman half his age. This spring he broke with the leader of the biggest group in his ruling coalition in a dispute over Government spending policies and lost his majority in the national assembly.
The economy, crippled by nearly two years of American sanctions and finally stopped cold by the invasion, is beginning to percolate again. High-rise buildings and shopping centers are going up, new boutiques and restaurants are opening and retail sales are rising despite persistent unemployment, which has one in five Panamanians without work.
Deposits in Panama's more than 100 banks have gone from $12 billion at the time of the invasion to $16 billion, but foreign investors and tourists are still shying away. In 1987, bank deposits totaled $45 billion.
One of the Government's first steps in reshaping Panama was to dismantle the army and create a new security force with a gentler philosophy and less central control. Most of Mr. Noriega's officers were dismissed. But most of his troops were allowed to put on new uniforms and line up for United States-provided classes in how to be good police officers. They typically earn $300 or so a month. Some go about their duties half-heartedly, Panamanians say. Others fish for bribes and shady opportunities.
 
Drug Boats Are Too Fast
 "The truth is there are a lot of people in the system protecting and actually helping narco-traffickers," said Rodrigo Arosemena, the chief of the customs service.
Even the most dedicated officers are hamstrung by shortages of equipment. The unit that specializes in drug investigations has 80 members who share seven vehicles and a handful of radios. The Maritime Service has 10 vessels, including two shrimp boats, a confiscated speed boat and an 82-foot cutter that the United States Coast Guard delivered in early August. There is no air patrol.
The commanders often feel helpless. "We see the drug boats," said Captain Rosas. "But they're so fast we can't catch them."
Panama is a smuggler's dream. It shares a border with Colombia, the world center for refining and exporting cocaine, that runs through 135 miles of dense rain forest. The Panamanian coasts, rippled with coves, inlets and bays, run for 1,700 miles, about 350 miles more than those of Florida, and the country's waters are dotted with more than 1,500 islands.
Fishermen say it is not uncommon to find plastic-wrapped packets of cocaine the size of hard-cover books floating or scattered on the beaches. People who live near the water and the air fields frequently see traffickers.
"Little boats come in with the stuff and then fine cars, sometimes Mercedes-Benzes, come to take it away," said a woman who watches the action from a window of her home on the Bay of Panama, not far from the presidential palace and the heart of the capital.
The drug trafficking and other security problems are confounding to Mr. Endara and others who fought the dictatorship. Emotionally and politically, they feel that building a strong-armed force is not possible.
"We don't want anything that smells like an army," Mr. Endara said in an interview at his waterfront offices. "If we started increasing our law enforcement instead of building and fixing hospitals, people would protest."
He and the others are willing to better equip the security forces, providing that the United States pays. Gonzalo Menendez, the chief of the national police, said in a reference to the head of the Office of National Drug Policy in Washington: "If Mr. Bob Martinez and all the anti-drug forces want to fight drugs they must supply the resources to the Panamanian Government."
For 1990 and 1991, Panama received $13.2 million from the United States for police training and another $1 million for equipment like radios, emergency lights, sirens and bullet-proof vests. The new Government also got $10 million for equipment and training that had been designated for Mr. Noriega but withheld. In 1990 alone, Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, the three countries where almost all the world's cocaine is produced and refined, received $114.5 million.
The Government has been slow to embrace some United States measures against drugs. It took until this spring, for example, to reach agreement on patrols with the United States Coast Guard and a treaty that gives United States officials access to Panamanian bank accounts in investigations of money laundering and other drug crimes.
 
Money Laundering Continues
 Billions were said to have been laundered under Noriega, and some law-enforcement officials say the country may have been far more important to traffickers for its banking services than as a channel for drugs.
Government officials and some bankers say money-laundering has diminished markedly. But the State Department said earlier this year that it "is still a major concern," and a Treasury official said in an interview the other day that "a high level of money-laundering activity" appears to be continuing.
American officials say the Endara Government has been cooperative. But though Mr. Endara and many of his officials are lawyers and bankers familiar with the banking system, they have initiated no money-laundering investigations that were not first suggested by United States officials.
Mr. Endara and his Attorney General, Rogelio Cruz, were members of the boards of banks that were shut down because of money laundering, but both deny wrongdoing.
Panamanian officials insist they are doing the best they can against the traffickers.
"If you have no planes, no boats and no guns, what can you do?" said Mr. Menendez one morning at national police headquarters. "We're not getting ahead. Why should I fool myself?"

BankAmerica said it would acquire Security Pacific in a transaction worth more than $4 billion, the latest development in a wave of mergers sweeping the nation's largest banks. HEADLINE: THE BANK MERGER;
BankAmerica in $4 Billion Deal To Acquire Rival Security Pacific

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would acquire its California rival, the Security Pacific Corporation, in a deal worth more than $4 billion, the latest in a wave of mergers sweeping the nation's largest banks.
The combination of the two largest banks in the West will create a huge bank, approaching the size of Citicorp, the nation's largest. 
 The new bank, which will retain the BankAmerica name, would also eclipse in size the banks to be formed in two other huge deals announced in the last month -- the mergers of the Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover in New York and of NCNB and C&S/Sovran in the Southeast.
Bank executives and analysts say the wave of mergers, which now appears to be turning into a cascade, is occurring because the American banking system is beset by overcapacity. A merger, particularly of two banks serving the same state or region, can result in huge savings because overlapping branches and personnel can be eliminated. With such savings, banks can often offset losses that they are suffering because of bad real estate loans and the recession.
 
Praised by Seidman
 L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, praised both the proposed deal and the trend of large bank mergers. "It should be good for the efficiency of the system," said Mr. Seidman, who spoke from Nantucket Island in Massachusetts, where he is on vacation.
He noted that it would substantially reduce the banks' expenses and shore up their capital. "People have been predicting this trend for some time, and now it's finally happening."
 
Chairman and President
 The combined bank will use the Bank of America name for its branches and banking activities, and Richard M. Rosenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of BankAmerica, will become chairman and chief executive of the merged company.
Robert H. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Security Pacific, will become president and chief operating officer. The new company will have headquarters in both San Francisco and Los Angeles, but most of the corporate staff will be in San Francisco.
Mr. Smith said at a news conference in Los Angeles, "The benefits, the economies of an in-market merger are overwhelming." He added, "I think we'll be seeing more in the months to come."
Another factor pushing mergers is a desire for American banks to expand nationwide and to compete better globally with foreign banks, many of which are far larger than American ones. "I can't overplay the importance of a world-class position," Mr. Rosenberg said.
BankAmerica, which is based in San Francisco, and Security Pacific, which is based in Los Angeles, said they expected to save about $1 billion a year within three years. That is roughly equal to one-seventh of their combined expenses. Although company officials were not specific, it is expected that thousands of workers will be cut from the combined work force of about 92,000, and that dozens, if not hundreds, of the combined bank's 2,400 branches will be closed.
Such savings would help offset the addition of $1 billion to the banks' combined reserve for loan losses. Security Pacific, while by no means in trouble, has been hurt by bad loans and could benefit from having its capital base strengthened by the merger, analysts said.
Under the terms of the deal, BankAmerica will issue 0.88 of a new share of its stock for each of Security Pacific's outstanding shares. At BankAmerica's closing price of $40 a share today, the deal would be worth nearly $4.5 billion, making it the largest bank merger in American history.
The combination would have about $190 billion in assets, just behind the $217 billion of Citicorp, the nation's largest bank in overall assets, but ahead of Citicorp in domestic assets. Before the recently announced mergers, BankAmerica was the nation's second-largest banking company, and Security Pacific the fifth largest.
The $2.3 billion stock swap for merging Manufacturers Hanover into Chemical Bank will create a bank with $135 billion in assets. The NCNB merger with C&S/Sovran, a $4.3 billion transaction, will create a bank with about $116 billion in assets.
The three recent mega-mergers aroused investors' expectations that other banks will feel pushed into taking similar action, and the stocks of many banks rose today, as a result. Security Pacific's stock, the most active on the New York Stock Exchange, rose $9.125 to close at $32.125, while BankAmerica's stock was the second most active and rose $2.625, to $40 a share. Chase Manhattan, up $1.75, to $21.125, and Citicorp, up $1, to $14, were also on the active list.
The boards of both BankAmerica and Security Pacific have approved today's deal, but it is still subject to stockholder and regulatory approval. The two banks said they expected the acquisition to be completed within six months.
The combined bank would be the largest in California and Washington by far and also the largest in Arizona and Nevada. It would be the second largest in New Mexico and the third largest in Oregon. It would also have extensive operations in the Far East, where both BankAmerica and Security Pacific already have major operations.
"We have a historic opportunity to become the leader in American banking," said Mr. Rosenberg of BankAmerica.
 
No Antitrust Problems Seen
 He added that he did not expect any antitrust problems. Banks, he said, were facing competition not only from one another but also from other types of companies, like the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in credit cards and the Ford Motor Company, which owns a savings and loan and a leasing company, in consumer finance.
However, analysts said that regulators might require some branches to be divested because the combined banks' market share would be too high in some areas, particularly in Washington, where BankAmerica already owns Seafirst, the largest bank, and Security Pacific owns Rainier, the No. 2 bank, and in parts of California, where they are dominant.
Mark Foster, policy analyst with Consumer Action, a San Francisco consumer group, said the merger "is going to mean less competition and less consumer choice." Consumer groups in California have long contended that the four large banks' dominance in the state means that Californians receive lower interest rates on deposits and pay higher interest rates on loans than people who live elsewhere.
Wall Street analysts, in contrast, praised the move, saying it would result in huge economies of scale and bolster BankAmerica's earnings in the long run. "The merger strikes me as being a brilliant move," said Thomas H. Hanley, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Security Pacific surprised Wall Street with poor financial results in three of the last four quarters, partly because of problem real estate loans in Britain, Australia and Arizona and the cost of quitting certain businesses. The weak California real estate market has casts a cloud over all California banks.
Taking on Security Pacific's loan portfolio could present a major risk for BankAmerica. However, the bank's officials said they had thoroughly examined Security Pacific's portfolio. Other industry analysts said that any new problem loans could be compensated for by the savings in expenses because of the merger. In addition, BankAmerica will probably seek to sell some of Security Pacific's non-banking businesses.
Today's announcement is evidence of a stunning recovery by BankAmerica, which was perilously close to failure five years ago and was almost taken over by First Interstate. From 1985 through 1987 BankAmerica lost $1.8 billion because of bloated expenses and bad loans to developing nations and to companies in energy, agriculture and real estate.
But after selling assets to offset loan losses and cutting expenses, the bank has worked its way back to health. BankAmerica has now earned more than $1 billion in each of the last two years, placing it among the nation's healthiest banks.
BankAmerica has begun expanding aggressively, hoping to become a nationwide consumer bank, while the giant New York banks are preoccupied with problem real estate loans. It has bought more than a dozen banks and failed savings and loans throughout the West in the last year and half, and it bid unsuccessfully for the Bank of New England.
Because it will now have its plate full with Security Pacific, BankAmerica's expansion might pause briefly. But Mr. Rosenberg said, "We think we will still have the capability to continue to expand."

HEADLINE: F.D.I.C. Is Getting New Chief

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to nominate William Taylor as the next chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to succeed L. William Seidman, Administration officials said today.
The appointment of Mr. Taylor, a career official who is now the Federal Reserve Board's top banking regulator, is expected to be announced this week by the White House. Mr. Seidman told the President last Tuesday that he would be stepping down from the agency that oversees the nation's banks at the end of his six-year term on Oct. 16. 
 The President's decision lays to rest speculation that the appointment of Mr. Taylor, who had been the leading candidate, was in jeopardy because of criticism over the Fed's handling of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and several American banks it apparently has secretly owned for years.
Mr. Taylor has asserted that the Fed did not learn of the secret ownership until this year, although evidence has appeared that the Central Intelligence Agency knew about the secret ownership of the banks as early as 1986. The Fed's supervision of the case and of an industry plagued by significant bank collapses is expected to dominate his confirmation proceedings.
 
Named Last Year
 President Bush first named Mr. Taylor as Mr. Seidman's expectedsuccessor last year, when the White House sought very publicly to force Mr. Seidman from office because he was viewed by some Administration officials as being too independent. While Mr. Taylor had remained the leading candidate to succeed Mr. Seidman, Mr. Bush told reporters last week after Mr. Seidman's resignation that he had decided to "start over and take a hard look."
Mr. Taylor, 52 years old, did not return a telephone message today seeking comment. If he is confirmed by the Senate, he will bring a more low-key personality to the post than Mr. Seidman, the 70-year-old administrator who established a reputation for his bluntness and his forceful advocacy on behalf of the F.D.I.C. One lawmaker last year comparing the two men described the succession as a shift "from a spritely personality to a plaid one."
Under the 1989 law that set up the Government bailout of the nation's savings and loans and which Mr. Seidman helped to shape, the chairman of the F.D.I.C. also serves as chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the savings bailout. Mr. Seidman is also resigning that position and Mr. Taylor will assume the title.
 
A New Position
 But Administration officials, stung by accusations that the bailout has been too slow and concerned about a possible legislative overhaul of the bailout, announced earlier in the summer that they intended to create a new position of chief executive to oversee the bailout and remove the F.D.I.C. from day to day management of it. And Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has undertaken a search to fill that position.
Mr. Taylor is generally highly regarded on Capitol Hill and has also had a good working relationship with officials at the Treasury Department. He is often seen at Congressional hearings at the elbow of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who has relied on him heavily as a senior adviser.
He is most closely identified among industry executives and regulators as a strong, almost obsessive, proponent of high capital standards. He worked closely with regulators from around the world in coming to a uniform standard that ties bank capital -- its cushion against losses -- to the riskiness of its assets.
He has also been behind the Fed's decisions in recent years to gradually permit banks, in limited instances, to underwrite corporate securities. That a practice has been restricted by the Glass-Steagall Act, which was written during the Great Depression as a remedy to the banking crisis.
 
A Full Plate
 At the F.D.I.C., Mr. Taylor will have his hands full. The insurance fund that protects bank deposits has been rapidly depleting because of the increasing number of bank collapses. At the same time, regulators have been under considerable political pressure not to be too harsh on the industry for fear that the banks will further tighten credit while the economy is struggling to recover from recession.
Mr. Taylor has had significant experience handling banking and savings crises. Most recently, he served as Washington's senior regulator in London when authorities from around the world decided to seize dozens of B.C.C.I.-related banks. Earlier this year, he was the Fed's top man supervising the seizure and rescue of the Bank of New England. And in the mid-1980's he was involved in supervising banking crises in Ohio and Maryland.
Last year Mr. Taylor served a brief stint during a pivotal point in the savings and loan bailout as the acting president and chief executive of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Cabinet-level body headed by Mr. Brady that sets overall policy for the bailout. He replaced Daniel P. Kearney, whose departure was a setback for the bailout and came after Mr. Kearney clashed with Treasury officials who had been seeking to assert greater control over the effort.
After graduating from Cornell College in Mount Vernon, Iowa, in 1961, Mr. Taylor became an examiner with the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. He left in 1969 to run the lending department of a bank and then in the 70's moved to Rouse & Company, where he ran the developer's real estate finance operation. He returned to the Fed as a superviser in 1976.

HEADLINE: 'Mirror Image' Chemistry Yielding New Products

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
LEGIONS of chemists are invading a looking-glass world of mirror-image molecules, and a boom in chemical research is producing new drugs, pesticides and even perfumes that exploit the differences between these molecular twins.
Scientists believe that mirror-image chemistry may also shed light on the nature and origin of life itself. On earth at least, the building blocks of life are mostly left-handed molecules rather than the random mixture of left-handed and right-handed molecules found in extraterrestrial objects like meteorites. 
 Many chemicals important to life are combinations of mirror-image twins, in which one partner may cure disease, quell headaches or smell good, while its mirror-reversed counterpart may be poisonous, smell repugnant or simply be inert. Scientists are investigating the chemistry of thousands of such pairs, learning to make pure forms of the desirable twins, and thereby creating many new products.
Looking-glass chemistry depends on the fact that some chemicals come in two forms, which differ in the same way that a left hand differs from a right hand.
Chemical compounds that come as mirror-image pairs are sometimes compared with left-hand and right-hand gloves and are referred to by chemists as "chiral" (pronounced "KYE-ral"), or handed molecules. Each twin is called an enantiomer (pronounced en-ANT-ee-oh-mer).
Despite the close resemblance of such twins, the differences in their biological properties can be profound.
In 1960, hundreds of European babies whose mothers had taken the sedative thalidomide were born deformed. Some chemists believe that one of the two mirror-image molecules contained in thalidomide may have been responsible, and that had thalidomide been purified to exclude the evil, mirror-image twin, the disaster might never have occurred.
Because the left- and right-handed twin of a chemical pair often behave very differently from each other in the body, chiral twins are coming under increasing scrutiny among chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturers, biologists, agronomists, entomologists and regulatory agencies. As a sign of the trend, a new professional journal, Chirality, began publication two years ago.
"There's been enormous recent progress in asymmetric synthesis," said Dr. Ernest L. Eliel, a chemist at the University of North Carolina. Asymmetric synthesis is a class of chemical techniques that produce a single enantiomer of some compound, rather than a mixture of both twins, as most chemical processes produce. Many pesticides are mixtures of chiral twins, of which often only one is active, Dr. Eliel said, and when economically feasible, it is better to manufacture the potent enantiomer alone, unmixed with "ballast." The makers of pharmaceuticals are especially concerned that the chemical handedness of a drug may influence its efficacy and safety. For example, one enantiomer may have a potent biological effect, but, in rare cases, according to Dr. Paul J. Reider, director of process research at Merck and Company, its mirror-image twin may have the opposite effect.
In the case of drugs, he said, a pharmacologist may ask whether both enantiomers are metabolized, stored or excreted by the body in the same way.
Typical of the chiral drugs widely used in pain-relieving products is ibuprofen, a compound developed by Boots Pure Drug Company in England whose mirror-image enantiomers have distinctly different properties. The left-handed twin is about four times more potent than the right-handed twin.
In itself, this might be grounds for manufacturing the left-handed enantiomer in pure form.
But pharmacologists have discovered that enzymes in the body are able to take right-handed ibuprofen and convert it into the more potent left-handed form.
This means that there would be little point in incurring the extra manufacturing costs of separating the mirror-image. Ibuprofen, sold today as an ingredient in more than 50 pain remedies, is therefore manufactured as a mixture of equal parts of left-handed and right-handed molecules.
Some chemicals must be prepared in pure form containing only one chiral twin. One is a substance called cyclopropane carboxylic acid. When manufactured as an equal mixture of left-handed and right-handed molecules, it has a foul smell. But if only one twin is produced, the result is a substance used commonly in the perfume industry.
Dr. Reider estimated that some 70 percent of the latest drugs are manufactured "asymmetrically" to consist wholly or largely of one enantiomer. Examples are the blood-pressure drug Vasotec, the anti-cholesterol drug Lovastatin and steroids used in the treatment of arthritis and other diseases.
Chiral twins are sometimes produced separately for different uses. Eli Lilly & Company, for example, makes the sedative drug Darvon and its mirror-image twin, a cough medicine named Novrad, spelling Darvon backwards.
Chiral differences are also important to pheromones, natural chemical odors secreted by animals as signals. Pheromone signals are used to mark territorial ranges, to invite reproductive partners and to warn off predators, among other things.
One of the chemists developing synthetic pheromones to lure insect pests to their destruction is Dr. Donald S. Matteson of Washington State University at Pullman. Most of these pheromones must consist of only one chiral twin to work; the use of the wrong twin or of an equal mixture of both twins may not work at all.
Dr. Matteson's group has synthesized four insect pheromones that are identical in their handedness to the natural ones. To do so, they used natural handed molecules derived from sources like pine trees to create templates for starting out the pheromone molecules with the correct handedness.
 
Don't Drink Looking-Glass Milk
 In Lewis Carroll's tale "Through the Looking Glass," Alice wonders whether "looking-glass milk" on the other side of the mirror would be fit to drink. Dr. Matteson answers that it would not, because biologically active molecules in the milk, notably sugars and proteins, would have the wrong handedness for Alice to digest, unless her own chemistry were converted to its mirror image by passing through the looking glass.
But the very indigestibility of wrong-handed compounds may have its uses. The sugars that are used by the body, for example, are right-handed; left-handed sugars are indigestible. This fact is the basis of at least one patent for a sweetener made from a left-handed sugar that supposedly is non-fattening.
Wrong-handedness is also a possible basis for the development of new antibiotic drugs.
Amino acids, the building blocks from which proteins and the other chemical ingredients of life are assembled, are chiral molecules that can take either left-handed or right-handed form. But with the exception of glycine, which has no handedness, the amino acids in almost all living things are exclusively left-handed.
A bizarre exception to the left-handed rule is a microorganism called Bacillus licheniformis, which makes the protein in its cell wall from right-handed amino acids. Scientists believe the organism does this to make itself indigestible to the killer cell phagocytes in animal blood that would normally attack it.
Drug companies study the use of molecular wrong-handedness to poison disease-causing bacteria without poisoning their human hosts.
 
Springing a Chemical Trap
 Dr. Reider explained that although human beings and other animals can metabolize only the left-handed enantiomer of the amino acid alanine, bacteria contain an enzyme capable of converting right-handed alanine to the digestible left-handed variety. The strategy of a drug designer might therefore be to attach a suitable poison to right-handed alanine molecules. Because the human body could not metabolize the right-handed compound, it would not be affected by the poisonous booby trap. But a bacterium could devour and metabolize the right-handed compound, thus poisoning itself.
Although the boom in chirally pure substances began only recently, the realization that mirror-image twins behave differently dates to the early 19th century. In 1844, the German chemist Eilhardt Mitscherlich discovered that although a solution of commercial tartaric acid in water twists a beam of polarized light to the right, a solution containing a related compound, sodium ammonium paratartrate, has no effect on the light beam.
In 1848, Louis Pasteur discovered that the paratartrate actually consists of two different kinds of crystals that can be clearly discerned under a microscope. Using tweezers, he separated the crystals and dissolved them in separate solutions. Passing polarized light through each of the solutions, he found that one solution twisted the light to the right and the other an equal angle to the left. The reason the unseparated paratartrate solution had no effect on the polarized light beam, Pasteur realized, was that the light-twisting effects of its two enantiomers canceled each other out. The reason the constituents behave oppositely is that their molecules are mirror images of each other.
Many methods are used today to synthesize or separate enantiomers, but some still involve variations of Pasteur's approach.
With the new emphasis on chiral chemistry, government officials in Europe, Japan and the United States wonder whether there is a need for regulations that address the handedness of drugs.
Some chemists believe too little money is available for research to determine the pharmacological differences between enantiomer twins.
 
Work on Anesthetics
 Dr. Jerrold Meinwald of Cornell University and his associates have devised chemical methods for separating the enantiomer pairs in three common anesthetics, halothane, enflurane and isoflurane. Their success with these technically difficult separations means, in principle, that enantiomers could be produced in sufficient quantity to conduct clinical trials. Because small amounts of anesthetic are metabolized by patients, it would be useful to determine any differences in the toxicity of their enantiomers, Dr. Meinwald said.
"Scientists really don't know much about how anesthetics work," he said, "and study of their enantiomers might shed light on this question, while possibly helping to eliminate the small risk of dangerous side effects that some anesthetics have."
But funds are lacking for large-scale animal tests of anesthetic enantiomers, he said, and without these, further research is stymied.
The pharmaceutical industry has counseled caution in regulations concerning the handedness of drugs. The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association said last year that each case should be decided on its merits by the manufacturer.
The Federal Food and Drug Administration essentially agrees.
Dr. Judi Weissinger, assistant director of the agency, said, "The F.D.A. is not going to insist on some inflexible checklist" of analyses and trials of chiral drugs. Instead, she said, the agency would continue to alert manufacturers to prudent guidelines.
Underlying all chiral chemistry is the fundamental question of why the amino acids making up virtually all living things are exclusively left-handed.
The fact that they share the same handedness is easily explained. "To fit biological molecules together properly, you must use molecules with the same chirality. The helical DNA molecule, for instance, could not be assembled from a mixture of enantiomers. The components must all have the same handedness," said Dr. Eliel, the University of North Carolina chemist.
But why are they left-handed and not right-handed?
Many scientists believe that the direction of handedness resulted from the flip of a chemical coin, and that once the pattern was established, subsequent molecular development had to follow suit.
But some theorists say they believe that left-handed biology may have its origin in the "weak" nuclear force. This force, which drives certain types of radioactive decay, is not precisely even-handed but has a slight left-handed bias. A group of British investigators found in 1985 that the mixing of the weak force with the electromagnetic force would slightly favor the formation of left-handed amino acids.
But right-handed and left-handed amino acids appear to exist in roughly equal quantities in meteorites that hit the earth. And an analysis published last month in Physics Today by three Soviet scientists, Vladik A. Avetisov, Vitalii I. Goldanskii and Vladimir V. Kuzmin, argued that the weak force is far too weak to have determined the direction of biological handedness.
Scientists may never know what gave life its chiral bias, but on one point they agree: without an initial spin, no one would be here thinking about it.


GRAPHIC: Molecules that exist as mirror-image twins often have very different properties. The left-handed and right-handed versions of the carvone molecule have the same composition -- 10 carbon atoms, 14 hydrogens and one oxygen -- and their structures are mirror images.

"The Importance Of Being Handed"
 Chiral chemicals are handed in the same way that hands themselves are either left or right. The direction of a molecule's handedness determines the types of interaction a chemical can have with other chemicals.
 
Atlanine
This amino acid is one of the building blocks of life. Animals can use only the left-handed form. Bacteria can use the right-handed form by converting it to left-handed alanine.
 
Thalidomide
 This sedative deformed babies born to women who took it. Some scientists say only one form may have been at fault, while the twin may have been harmless.

HEADLINE: Phoenix Asking if Bias Played Role in 9 Killings

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Without a clear motive in the slayings of nine people at a Thai Buddhist temple last weekend, residents of this desert city were left to confront the question of whether this was an anti-Asian hate crime.
Officials said they were still pursuing all possible motives in the crime, and offered no evidence that racism was behind the killings of the six monks, one nun and two disciples at the rural temple early Saturday. 
 The Maricopa County medical examiner, Dr. Heinz Karnitschnig, said that some of the victims were hit by shotgun blasts as they had their hands raised, and that all nine were then killed with shots from a small-caliber gun to the head or neck as they lay face down on the ground. The authorities said there were no signs of a struggle.
Some Asian and non-Asian residents voiced concern that the killings were a racist hate crime, given a national context of concerns about harassment against Asians and the rapid growth of the state's tiny Asian population.
In Arizona, according to the 1990 census, Asians and Pacific Islanders increased by 150.6 percent since 1980, to 55,206. The census counted 16,303 Asians in Phoenix; only about 2,000 of them are Thai. The city's total population in 1990 was abot 983,000.
 
Comfortable in Phoenix
 Officials said the state had not experienced a significant level of anti-Asian harassment to date, and some members of the Thai community here said they felt comfortable in Phoenix.
A spokesman for the Phoenix Police Department, Sgt. Kevin Robinson, said the city had not seen a pattern of harassment of Asians. Addressing another possible motive in the killings, he said Asian gangs did not have a significant presence here.
"Regarding hate crimes against Asians, we are not finding anything specific, no sort of pattern that has been going on," he said.
At the Siam restaurant in Glendale, not far from the temple, the manager, Prakong Garland, said she had always felt comfortable in Phoenix.
"We never bother anybody and I never have problems," she said. "I like the hot place in Arizona. And over here are nice people."
Her restaurant was the site today of a meeting of 50 people along with Thailand's Ambassador to the United States, who arrived here from Washington. She said the main issue was the question of whether to return the remains of the victims to Thailand for a ritual cremation.
The crime has been front-page news in Thailand and the Government there has asked American authorities to give the investigation top priority, The Associated Press reported. But it said news organizations there were not focusing on the killings as a crime resulting from bias against Asians.
"The reaction has been very sad, shocked, quite strong," the Ambassador, Birabhongse Kasemsri, said.
 
Low-Level Harassment
 Ashok Jain, president of the Arizona Asian American Association, said Asian residents faced a constant low level of harassment that ranged from verbal insults to the throwing of eggs.
He and others cited two recent instances in which abusive graffiti, including swastikas, were painted on a Chinese Christian church and on a wall outside the Japanese-American Citizens League in Glendale.
The temple, Wat Promkunarum, moved to its rural setting 20 miles west of downtown Phoenix after neighbors in the city had complained about the crowds of worshipers it attracted and the sounds of unfamiliar Thai music.
Helen Zia, the president of the New York chapter of the Asian-American Journalists Association, said that on the national level an anti-Asian climate had been growing, fed both by angry memories of the Vietnam War and resentment of Japanese economic success. In a telephone interview, she said these sentiments seemed to be directed at Asians in general, ignoring national distinctions.
Although no national figures have been gathered, she said, "There has been a significant increase in anti-Asian hate crimes, from harassment to assault to deadly violence."
She cited instances that ranged from attacks on Vietnamese fishermen in the late 1970's, to the killing of a Chinese man, Vincent Chin, in 1982 in Detroit by men who resented Japanese auto companies.
In recent cases, she said two white men in Wilmington, N.C., had attacked a group of Chinese and Vietnamese men, killing one of them, and in Houston last August a group of white supremacists had beaten to death a Vietnamese teen-ager.
The shocking nature of the temple killings here and the absence of public evidence about its motives have fueled fears of racism among some residents.
Rabbi Albert Plotkin of Temple Beth Israel here, said: "Hate crimes are a plague around the nation. I call it a disease like the plague, like the black death, that is spreading, and unfortunately we are as susceptible to it as anyone."
 
'Not an Asian Hate Crime'
 But Manny Wong, publisher of The Asian-American Times, a monthly newspaper here with a circulation of 5,000, said: "I hate to say this, but I don't think it is. It is not an Asian hate crime, stereotyping these Asian people." His theory is that the killing involved a war among religious sects.
Speaking to reporters outside the temple, Sheriff Tom Agnos of Maricopa County said investigators were leaving all possibilities open, including robbery, gang violence and personal vendetta.
But he offered the strongest evidence to support robbery as a motive, saying bedrooms had been ransacked and rings may have been removed from the hands of the victims.
But he said the temple itself had been left undisturbed, and worshipers said it contained gold and jade statues as well as a "money tree" hung with donations of dollar bills.
 
Searching for Vehicle
 In the first public sign of a clue to the killers, investigators today asked for help in finding a late-model red and white Ford Bronco II with tinted windows that was seen leaving the scene on Saturday morning.
Voicing the sentiments of the community, Sheriff Agnos said, "I think this crime is horrendous and I believe the community will not tolerate anything like this."
As small groups of Thai mourners stood outside the temple, where police investigations continued today, Annie Walker, a resident of Phoenix who said she had no ties to the Buddhist community, arrived in tears to place a large bouquet of chrysanthemums by its gate.
"All I wanted to do is bring flowers," she said. "It doesn't hurt."
She placed them near a bouquet of bougainvillea that had been brought earlier by other non-Thai mourners, bearing a card reading, "To the family and members of Wat Promkunaram."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Asian and non-Asian residents of Phoenix are confronting the question of whether the killings of nine people at a Thai Buddhist temple this weekend were prompted by anti-Asian hatred. Two worshipers, Nuan Moore, left, and Mali Kamerow, wept yesterday outside the temple. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Is Baseball Slap Happy On Fines?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
MAYBE it's the recession. Eight years ago George Steinbrenner made disparaging comments about National League umpires, and Bowie Kuhn, then the commissioner, fined him $50,000. Last week Lou Piniella questioned a National League umpire's integrity, and Bill White, the National League president, fined him $1,000.
If White's action was a slap on the wrist, what was the $500 fine he levied against Rob Dibble for throwing a baseball at a batter running to first base? Given Dibble's previous transgressions -- he has served seven games' worth of suspensions for two incidents earlier this season -- White's fine was a wag of the finger that said: "Now, Robby, you did a naughty thing so you be a good boy and don't do it again." 
If that was what White told Dibble while fining him what amounted to less than 20 percent of one day's pay, the world will not know it. At least not from White. The man who was visible and audible for 18 years as a broadcaster on Yankee games has become baseball's Claude Rains. Without the screen magic that aided Rains, when news conferences are held following owners' meetings on such matters as National League expansion, this once frank and friendly fellow becomes the invisible man.
But White's inaccessibility and unwillingness to comment publicly are only a footnote to the primary topic here: his relatively light penalties for what his predecessors viewed as serious baseball offenses.
"Dibble has accepted counseling and I think that had a lot to do with it," said Piniella, the Cincinnati Reds' manager, of White's decision. The manager's own volatile behavior hardly makes him a good role model for his tempestuous relief pitcher.
"He's already missed seven games," added Piniella. "I think the counseling was the most important consideration."
Dibble apparently was supposed to have begun -- but he didn't -- counseling long before the July 23 incident that prompted the latest penalty. The volatile pitcher fielded Doug Dascenzo's suicide squeeze bunt between the mound and the first-base line. He picked up the ball, ran five steps toward the line and straddled it before he fired the ball at Dascenzo's legs. Earlier in the season, he was suspended first for throwing a pitch behind a batter's head and then for throwing a ball into the outfield stands and injuring a woman.
Obviously, Dibble has a short attention span, and it's difficult to understand how a $500 fine is going to get his attention for longer than the time it takes him to write the check.
In the same game, Andre Dawson flung 15 bats onto the field in protest of his ejection for arguing a third-strike call. Rarely the source of trouble, Dawson was suspended for one game, a penalty that could cost him $18,132 in pay. If he warranted a one-game ban, Dibble, a three-time loser, should have received seven games. That penalty would cost Dibble $18,269. Seems like it would have been a good idea because someone had better stop Dibble before he really hurts somebody.
While talking about Dibble's latest episode, Piniella did not disclose that White had fined him, too. But the $1,000 penalty was paltry compared with the $5 million lawsuit Umpire Gary Darling has filed against Piniella for defamation of character. The day after a game in which the Reds had a home run taken away, Piniella charged that Darling was biased against the Reds. "I've hired a lawyer," Piniella said, declining to comment on the lawsuit.
The irony of the legal action is that Richie Phillips, the umpires' union lawyer, who filed the suit, should hope as hard as Piniella that a judge throws it out. Phillips is the last person who should want the umpires testifying under oath about what they think and do. Players, whose relationship with umpires prompts images of two armed camps, would wait in line to testify about what umpires have said and done on the field.
The lawsuit aside, should managers make the kind of comment Piniella did about Darling?
"I never make comments about an umpire," said Sparky Anderson, the dean of major league managers. "I don't like to settle my problems with an umpire in the paper. If he missed a call, I know it, he knows it, the world knows it. Television shows the replays for everyone to see."
At the same time, the 22-year veteran thinks the lawsuit is absurd. "If we're going to be petty," he said, talking about the action, not the amount, "we're going to see policemen out on the field for a fight between two teams carrying people off. We can carry this so far off the scope, it becomes laughable."
And the next time a player is moved to throw a ball at a runner, he'll tell the league president he plans to seek counseling.

HEADLINE: Universities Become Full Partners to Cities in South

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.

 BODY:
When the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa opened an extension here in 1936, it was designed to be just that -- a small offshoot in the city, offering courses to students who could not attend the main campus.
But today, it is the University of Alabama at Birmingham, not its parent institution, that is the state's hotbed of ideas and progress. 
 U.A.B. is now the largest employer in the state; it runs the state's most comprehensive hospital, which recently opened a $104 million clinic designed by I. M. Pei, and it counts its economic impact on the region at about $1 billion a year.
The story here has been repeated across the South, as urban universities have become the economic generators in their cities. As their economic importance has grown, these universities -- in New Orleans, Charlotte, Atlanta and other cities -- have also increased their roles as community leaders, attacking social problems, preserving cultural institutions or generally filling a leadership role once played by business leaders.
And they have played an equally important role in changing the character of the population around them, not only by providing employment but also by making a college education more accessible to poor inner-city residents.
 
Transforming Cities
 "U.A.B. just simply took Birmingham into the First World economically," said H. Brandt Ayers, editor and publisher of the Anniston Star, in Anniston, about 70 miles to the east.
Educators and sociologists say this is part of a broad trend, apparent for some years in the Northeast and now reaching its full impact in the Middle West and especially in the Sun Belt.
As textile, shipping and manufacturing industries that fueled cities like Birmingham and New Orleans began to shrink or die over the last 20 years, the public urban universities increasingly replaced them as major employers and shapers of the new urban landscape.
"Urban universities are doing for the cities in the 1990's what the land-grant colleges did for the rural areas in the 1800's," said Greg O'Brien, president of the University of New Orleans, which is part of the Louisiana State University system.
 
Taking It to the People
 Land-grant colleges and universities were developed to bring public higher education to the country, with a mandate to focus on agriculture and mechanical arts. Now urban universities, created for the most part less than 40 years ago, have also changed the socioeconomic profile of people who get college educations.
The classic pattern in the South and Middle West, where the big state universities were in small towns, was that only those urban youngsters with solid family incomes were likely to go off to college for four years. The urban universities have brought the classrooms to the population centers, eliminating travel and boarding from the cost of a college education.
It seems a simple truth, but the concept that education dollars ought to be spent where people live seemed hard to grasp for Southern legislators, who were attuned to spending their higher education budgets mainly in towns like Tuscaloosa, Oxford, Miss., and Athens, Ga.
When money and students began to flow into the new urban universities, it changed not only local economies but also the educational pecking order within many state university systems.
 
Housing, Race Relations and More
 "We are in the midst of a transfer in our economy from an industrial economy to sophisticated service industry," said Marguerite Barnett, president of the University of Houston, which has established an institute to help revitalize Texas school districts. "With most of our people living in cities, a diverse new population, it is the urban university that is on the cutting edge of change."
Ivory-tower isolation and the traditional town-gown divisions common to small university towns have begun to change, too. Although most university administrators insist they are nonpolitical, many have used the weight of their payrolls to push local governments for improvements in public services and race relations.
Otherwise, the educators argue, they cannot attract the faculty members they need to sustain their reputations and lure the hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal contracts and grants that enrich the local economy.
For example, the University of North Carolina at Charlotte chose a site north of Charlotte and created a new town, University City, which has attracted numerous corporations and improved the region's economy. Georgia State University in Atlanta has a partnership with the local school system to train teachers and administrators, and is working with a mayoral task force to develop residential housing downtown.
 
Partner to the City
 As the profiles of urban universities have risen so has their ability to attract the kind of star talent that only the more prestigious regional universities, like Vanderbilt in Nashville and Emory in Atlanta, had lured for years. After persuading the Coca-Cola Company to endow a jazz chair at its institution, the University of New Orleans got Ellis Marsalis, a highly regarded teacher who is the father of the jazz musicians Wynton and Branford Marsalis, to be the first to hold it.
The university also helped resuscitate the New Orleans Symphony after it was closed for nearly a year, a typical example of the community-university links that have developed.
"Very few public urban research institutions will simply be located in their cities in the 21st century," Dr. Barnett said. "They will have to be a partner in their cities if they're going to continue to thrive."
One theme at these universities in the Deep South is that the painful passage through the civil rights struggles of the 60's gave some communities a more open attitude toward diagnosing and treating other community problems.
"History and truth are so close to the surface here that we live with a great sense of reality in the South," said Tennant S. McWilliams, vice president of academic affairs at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. "We've got problems, but the only way to get out from under them is to confront them."
 
Opening Doors for Blacks
 U.A.B. reaches deep into the public life of Birmingham, providing assistance to 90 public schools, research to a burgeoning number of small businesses and design for a model school in a new industrial research park.
To tighten the political bond between the university and the city, U.A.B. gave leave to one of its faculty members to work on the staff of the city's first black Mayor, Richard Arrington Jr.
"It sits right in the middle of the black community, and in its scope, sensitivity and comprehensive commitment to urban life, I doubt there is another university that can match it," Mayor Arrington said.
Because Birmingham once represented segregation at its most monolithic, U.A.B.'s impact is sometimes most easily measured in its impact on educational opportunity for blacks.
 
Tight-Fisted Legislature
 Twenty-five years ago, the city had no accredited public college that admitted blacks. Today one-fifth of U.A.B.'s 16,500 undergraduates are black, the highest percentage of black students at any predominantly white institution in the state.
Twenty-five years ago, blacks were barred from what was then the state's only medical school, and they could not get nursing or paramedical training in Birmingham. Today 14 of the 165 first-year students at U.A.B.'s medical school are black, and four of them ranked in the top 10 percent of their undergraduate classes.
The university is also deeply involved in the effort to build a civil rights museum here.
Such activities can create strains between urban universities and their state legislatures. The Alabama Legislature, historically hostile to Birmingham, is one of the nation's most tight-fisted with education spending. While most state universities draw half of their operating budgets from their legislatures, U.A.B. received only 25 percent, or $162 million of a $633 million budget for the 1990-91 school year.
Thus, though Birmingham reaps enormous benefit from U.A.B., it is Federal tax dollars in the form of grants and contracts, scholarships and fees from its hospital services that sustain the university.
 
Cultivating Its Garden
 That local business leaders recognize the benefits of the university is evident, however, in a recent capital fund-raising drive. Some of the city's top corporate executives led it and helped raise $67 million, a noteworthy development in a city whose business executives have seldom exerted the kind of leadership exhibited by counterparts in Atlanta, Charlotte, Houston and other Sun Belt cities.
The struggle to raise money is mirrored in a kind of bootstrap approach to academics that flies in the face of political efforts to end affirmative action and may be unique to U.A.B.
When the university here decided to boost its number of minority faculty members, for example, it eschewed raiding other universities in favor of a long-term effort to develop its own pool of talent. It has a 10-year, multilevel program that provides support for high school students through post-doctoral candidates. Short-term needs are supplied through visiting professorships. The program costs $850,000 a year.
"That's hard state money, and we take it right off the top," said Charles A. McCallum Jr., the university's president. Largely because of the program, U.A.B. has 44 black doctoral students in mathematics and science.
In some states, legislatures have recognized the enlarged role of urban universities in sustaining cities. An urban college consortium in Ohio got its Legislature to reinstate $30 million in state financing for its programs after initial cuts, by showing the economic advantages the colleges bring the state.
At the Federal level, Congress may finance the Urban Grant University Program of the Higher Education Act for the first time since it was enacted in 1980. The program would provide financing for just the kind of city-university partnerships that have been growing across the country.
"Urban universities form a very special function in education, and that role can be expanded as one city after another undergoes transition," said Representative Thomas Sawyer, Democrat of Ohio, who along with Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, has proposed $10 million in financing for the program. "That same engine that drove the economy of this nation during the shift from agriculture to urban industrial dominance has the same potential in an urban setting."

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
Travers Hits Town, Excitement Follows

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

 BODY:
These are the best of times and the worst of times in horse racing, and nobody in the business seems to know how to keep the former from being obliterated by the latter.
They are the best of times at Saratoga Race Course because this is Travers Week, the week of the 122d running of the Travers Stakes, "the midsummer Derby." 
 It marks the first time since the Kentucky Derby that the archrivals for 3-year-old honors have raced together on the same track:
Strike the Gold, who won the Derby; Hansel, who won the Preakness and Belmont Stakes, and Fly So Free, the winterbook favorite for the Derby, who revived and won the Jim Dandy Stakes here two weeks ago.
They will race the Derby distance, too, a mile and a quarter. They also will make this year's Travers the most dramatic race since the Kentucky Derby on May 4 and the most important before the Breeders' Cup championships on Nov. 2. And if that's not enough theater for one race, the winner also pockets the lion's share of a $ l million purse.
All three of the main contenders worked out on the track this morning while the glow of the best of times began to gather round the barns. But everybody remembered that these were also the worst of times in the racing business. The inflated economy of the 1980's has burst in the 1990's, collapsing the price of everything from a horse farm to a horse.
At the yearling sales here last week, in an auction held in a pavilion one block from the main gate to the track, the average price for a horse plunged 40 percent from last year.
Even the wealthy Arab and Japanese investors kept their hands in their pockets this time. At the Keeneland sales in Kentucky three weeks ago, the best yearlings in the thoroughbred business went for 11 percent below last year's average, even though the royal Maktoum family of Dubai spent $25 million of the $75 million paid for the horses.
Gimmicks won't help.
At Belmont Park, they printed 25,000 buttons with pictures of Meadow Star and Lite Light for their duel in the Mother Goose Stakes in June, and only 17,472 customers showed up. Another brainstorm was announced today when the New York Racing Association and the New York State Lottery unveiled a giveaway game involving "scratch-off tickets" with a horse-racing theme.
But the main focus of horse racing, and of its promotions, marketing ploys and advertising campaigns, should be the horse. And that's why Travers Week marks a return to the best of times at Saratoga after one of the worst of weeks. The star of the show is the horse.
It's not easy to win the Travers. Only one favorite has won it in the last five years (Easy Goer in 1989). Affirmed didn't win it. Conquistador Cielo didn't win it. Alysheba ran sixth in it. When it's run next Saturday again, two of the three big horses in the race won't win it, maybe all three.
Strike the Gold ran first in the Derby, sixth in the Preakness, second in the Belmont and third in the Jim Dandy. His chief tormentor, Hansel, ran 10th in the Derby, first in the Preakness and Belmont, third in the Haskell Invitational. The winner that day was Lost Mountain, who had run 12th in the Derby and seventh in the Belmont. And Fly So Free, last year's juvenile champion, won five straight before running second in the Blue Grass, fifth in the Derby and first in the Jim Dandy.
Tom Bohannan, who trains Lost Mountain, tried to get a handle on all this gyrating and came up with this: "Strike the Gold just got beat by Fly So Free, and Hansel beat Strike the Gold, and we just beat Hansel. I feel confident."
So does Nick Zito, who galloped Strike the Gold in the morning sunshine and said, "Now, if we can just get a few more days like this, we'll be in good shape."
Hansel galloped a mile and a half this morning with his regular exercise rider, Pam Fitzgerald, who said, "He'll be back tomorrow, then he'll walk Wednesday, gallop Thursday and gallop again Friday."
Fly So Free was on the track before 6 o'clock this morning, galloping two miles under Bob Caputo, his regular exercise rider. Scotty Schulhofer, who trains the colt for the Broadway music publisher Tommy Valando, reported that the countdown to the big race would be this: a half-mile workout Wednesday, some walking Thursday, galloping Friday, jogging Saturday.
"We had a little setback," Schulhofer said. "He jarred his shoulder a little in the Jim Dandy. But he's doing fine now. He's a tough horse. He's even a tough horse to gallop. Bob earns every penny when he gets on him. The Travers comes down to a matter of who gets the best trip. Whoever has the best luck will win the Travers."
Now, that's what you'd call a horse race. And, for one week, at least, the best of times at the race track.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Observer;
Not Half Likely

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Surely President Bush will not run for re-election. To do so would make little or no sense, and the President, like him or not, is eminently sensible.
He is far too sensible, for instance, to reveal such an explosive decision until the country's most formidable Democrats finish reading themselves out of the contest. When political opponents are busy knocking themselves out, why intervene? 
 Once these Democrats have all dropped out, they can of course drop right back in after Mr. Bush says he won't run either, but by then it will be too late. We have all heard these Democrats say they were not dropping out because they feared running against Mr. Bush. It wasn't fear of Bush that cooled their zeal. No siree.
They were dropping out because they had previous engagements, because they wanted to spend more quality time with the children, because they had to take the car to the shop, because the doctor had told them they needed another four years of fiber-rich diet and fresh air before running for President.
All America would laugh to see them rush back into the fray once Mr. Bush dropped out. Knowing how deadly such laughter can be would probably keep them permanently sidelined, guaranteeing Mr. Bush's hand-picked successor a romp to the White House, sealing his reputation for political genius and assuring him generous ink in the history books.
Why won't the President go for a second term? Four reasons:
1. Second-term curse:
Second terms usually become failures, if not catastrophes. Since 1900 only Theodore Roosevelt escaped the second-term curse. Woodrow Wilson's ended with the Versailles Treaty calamity and his Republican opposition triumphant. Franklin Roosevelt's was nearly ruined by his arrogant attempt to pack the Supreme Court and a deepening of the Great Depression. Truman's produced the Korean War. Eisenhower's produced the humiliation of the U-2 affair and spreading national ennui that contributed to the triumph of his Democratic opposition. Nixon's started and ended with Watergate. Reagan's is too recent to judge coolly, but despite triumphs Gorbachev gave him there is something terribly sad about those lingering last images of the tired old man so out of touch with his own job that an Oliver North could bring him close to ruin.
President Bush, who knows his history, must realize that he would be defying prohibitive odds by taking a second term.
2. Wisdom of Joseph P. Kennedy:
The founder of the Kennedy dynasty, when asked why he cleverly got his fortune safely out of Wall Street before the 1929 market crash, replied, "Only a fool holds out for top dollar." Going for a second term would for Mr. Bush be tantamount to holding out for top dollar. His first term with its historic successes in foreign policy and war has blessed him with a popularity and stature almost inconceivable for any President in his third year in office. To risk losing so much glory by defying the second-term curse would take a reckless, impetuous personality quite alien to Mr. Bush's solid conservative nature.
3. Lethal domesticity:
What President today wouldn't hate domestic policy? Everything needs to be done and there is no money to do anything, at least no money obtainable by Presidents loyal to the Reagan way of life. Prognosis: Society is likely to continue coming apart, continuing a trend that is already turning the country into angry, bickering tribal units defined by common economic, racial, age, sexual, regional and ethnic bonds. In 1988 Mr. Bush proved he knew the Pledge of Allegiance, but he hasn't shown much interest in saving us from becoming one nation highly divisible. Foreign, not domestic, policy is his bag. A second term would confront him with four years of domestic crises that might defeat Solomon, much less a Republican President with a surly Democratic Congress.
4. Age and health:
He is just the right age to enjoy his large, loving family in reasonably good health and bask for many years in the world's admiration of his statesmanship, but four years of the second-term curse offer only melodrama for his biography.
The President's choice to be next? Secretary of State Baker, provided of course that somebody has enough nerve to get his dander up by saying he's too wimpish to dump Dan Quayle.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New York Should Cap Hiring of City Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Every few years, New York City goes through such a budget crisis as we have now. The scenario seems the same. Recession sets in, therefore receipts to the city decrease, thereby causing layoffs of city workers. After the good times return, politicians hire workers back in greater numbers than before the crisis. In our recent crisis we have 50,000 more workers than we had at the end of the last crisis, in the late 1970's. 
 I would suggest that a cap be put on the number of workers in city government, with a small increase allowed when population increases. This would prevent politicians from hiring great numbers of unneeded workers and would protect the future population of the city from the whims of today's politicians. The city must be run in a businesslike fashion to stop the budget crises that reappear every 10 years.
 
PETER GIAIMO
New York, Aug. 2, 1991

HEADLINE: We Need a Single-Payer Health-Care System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You are mistaken in your July 22 editorial endorsing Alain Enthoven's "managed competition" plan as the fix for our broken health care system. Mr. Enthoven's plan would force all but the wealthy into an insurance company-run health maintenance organization chosen by the employer or government "sponsor." 
 Doctor-patient relations would be repeatedly disrupted as employers and sponsors switched H.M.O.'s in search of the cheapest rates. Insurers owning the H.M.O's would still selectively market to the healthy and shun the sick, despite safeguards you suggest. "Cream skimming" -- through gimmicks like offering free exercise club memberships to attract healthy subscribers or by not putting facilities near neighborhoods with high rates of expensive diseases like acquired immune deficiency syndrome -- would remain an easier way to prosper than improving efficiency.
While "managed competition" would perpetuate discrimination and maximize disruption, it probably would not slow health care inflation. According to the General Accounting Office, a Canadian-style national health program would save $67 billion on bureaucracy in the first year alone and hold down increases through enforceable budgetary limits.
Such administrative streamlining is characteristic of single-payer systems, whether Canadian or Swedish, where government pays virtually all health care bills. This eliminates the enormous overhead of insurance companies (15 percent of premiums in the United States, against 1 percent in Canada and 2 percent in Sweden) and relieves doctors and hospitals of most billing-related paperwork.
In contrast, Mr. Enthoven's plan would leave all the health bureaucracy and add another layer -- the government agencies that would buy group coverage from private insurers. No country has maintained a multiple-payer structure, as Mr. Enthoven envisions, while achieving single-payer efficiency. The H.M.O's Mr. Enthoven praises took 19 percent of total premiums for their administrative overhead in Medicare's managed-care demonstration project, an even higher level of inefficiency than traditional indemnity insurance plans. Moreover, the inflation rate in managed-care plans has been no less than for traditional indemnity plans.
A Canadian-style single-payer plan would contain costs, cover all the uninsured and improve coverage for most other Americans, while guaranteeing patients a free choice of doctors. Contrary to your assertions, Canada has pulled its weight (per capita) in medical research and surpasses us in efforts to weed out incompetent physicians. Modest waits for a few high-technology services are not caused by the Canadian payment system, but by Canada's lower expenditures for care -- almost $1,000 lower per capita than in the United States.
The G.A.O. concluded that our levels of spending with the Canadian system's efficiency would assure us of high-technology care, universal coverage and an end to the cost spiral. In short, the best health care in the world at an affordable price.
 
STEFFIE WOOLHANDLER, M.D.
DAVID U. HIMMELSTEIN, M.D.
SIDNEY M. WOLFE, M.D.
Cambridge, Mass., July 31, 1991
 
The first two writers are national coordinators of Physicians for a National Health Program, and the third is director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group.
