HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Coca Dreams, Cocaine Reality

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT is no surprise that Washington is sending the Green Berets to Peru: As Willie Sutton might have said, that is where the coca is.
What ought to surprise, say economists who study illegal markets, is the drug busters' faith that harassment of Peruvian coca farmers will affect the supply of cocaine in Miami or Modesto. At best, argues Peter Reuter of the Rand Corporation, intervention will push coca cultivation into other parts of the Andes. At worst, it will further enrich the Shining Path guerillas, who sell protection services to the coca farmers. 
 According to the State Department, some 70 percent of the world's coca is grown in Peru. The crop is currently worth some $500 million annually -- enough, says Melanie Tammen, a researcher at the Cato Insitute in Washington, to support one million people in the country's upland valleys.
While small amounts of cocaine are made and used in Peru -- it takes 500 pounds of the raw material to yield one pound of the finished product -- the bulk is concentrated as paste and sent to Colombia for manufacture and shipment to market.
Washington has been supporting Peru's coca eradication since 1980, but to little apparent effect: the total acreage in coca production grew over the decade. The Bush Administration is now turning up the heat, conditioning further aid to the Government of Alberto Fujimoro on the acceptance of American military trainers for the war on cocaine.
Drug experts scoff at their prospects. "There is no good argument for squeezing coca farmers," Mr. Reuter says flatly.
Increasing the risks of growing coca might raise the price needed to induce farmers to grow it, he explains. But at the mid-1990 price of about $350 for 500 pounds, the cost of Peruvian leaf represents a trivial percentage of the $45,000-a-pound street price of pure cocaine in America's cities. Thus raising the price of the leaf by any plausible amount would not make much difference in the total cost, most of which represents payment for risks in transporting and selling the drug.
If one could eradicate coca, there could not be any cocaine to sniff or smoke. But according to Paul Boeker, the president of the Institute of the Americas at the San Diego campus of the University of California, the land in the Andes suitable to grow this hardy plant is virtually unlimited. "Nibbling around the edges of the leaf market," he said, "is terribly inefficient."
Indeed, Mr. Boeker notes, aggressive eradication efforts in Bolivia have backfired. Rather than discouraging farmers, they have functioned like American farm support programs that stabilize prices by keeping marginal land out of use.
The unintended effects of burning coca fields could prove more grave in Peru, which is engaged in a bloody civil war. Pitting the Peruvian and American military against peasants who grow coca to survive could increase support for the Maoist Shining Path guerrillas. And as Mr. Reuter points out, "it raises the demand for protective services from the guerrillas," increasing the guerrilla take from what is reportedly already their primary source of income.
If attacking cocaine at its roots cannot work, what might? The Rand Corporation's research on drug smuggling convinced most people who were paying attention that interdiction at the United States border is an exercise in futility. But Mr. Boeker thinks the cocaine trade is vulnerable at intermediate points in the production and transport chain. As evidence he cites the simultaneous collapse in demand for coca leaf and the run-up in United States street prices after the Colombian Government smashed the Medellin cartel.
Mr. Reuter offers a less optimistic interpretation of the same events. The destruction of the Medellin traffic, he speculates, gave the traffickers in the Colombian city of Cali a temporary monopoly on the cocaine trade.
By this interpetation, the Cali cartel was able to raise cocaine profits by reducing production and exports. United States street prices have since fallen and coca leaf prices have recovered -- facts consistent with the idea that the Cali mob first gained and then lost a hammerlock on the trade.
The trouble with Mr. Reuter's analysis is that it does not provide much hope for a supply-side fix to the cocaine problem. That could explain why Washington, charged with making cocaine disappear, tends to go deaf and dumb whenever confronted with the illogic of calling in the Army.
But the doleful prospects of the Peruvian initiative do not bother Ms. Tammen at the libertarian Cato Institute. "Only an end to drug prohibition in the United States," she concludes, "can make substitute crops viable in Peru and unravel the web of drug-related terror in both nations."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Can Skim Milk Taste Like Whole Milk?

 BODY:
All that the scientists at the Electric Power Research Institute were trying to do was find a way to conserve power in the dairy industry. But, inadvertently, they may have developed a process that makes skim milk taste like whole milk.
Instead of heating milk to drive off water to produce concentrate or powder, as is usually done, institute researchers and representatives of the Dairy Research Foundation chilled it. Some of the water formed ice crystals, which were filtered out. The resulting concentrate was reconstituted by adding water. 
 The researchers were surprised to find that the resulting skim milk tasted better than normal skim milk. "We put the water back in, and it tasted like whole milk," said Robert D. Jeffress, a program manager at the Palo Alto, Calif., institute, which is supported by electric utilities.
"We are not sure why that is, but we have blindfolded taste tests that say so," he added. The difference could be that the milk proteins are preserved when frozen, but partly broken down when heated, changing the taste, he said.
Other advantages of freeze-concentrated milk include less volume, so it is cheaper to ship, and a longer shelf life in stores or home freezers. To test the economics of the process, the institute is backing a commercial-scale operation for removing 700 pounds of water an hour at the Galloway West Company in Fond du Lac, Wis., starting in the fall.
According to officials of the institute, freezing is a more energy-efficient means of concentrating milk and other dairy products than heat evaporation. The most common type of evaporator takes 118 kilowatt- hours to remove one metric ton, or 2,204 pounds, of water, compared with 65 kilowatt-hours for freezing. A typical dairy could save $100,000 a year in power costs by switching methods, they said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed In Continued Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against major currencies yesterday in another day of quiet trading as the market waited to see if German interest rates are headed up or down.
Gold prices were lower. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid for gold at $356.50 an ounce, down 95 cents from late Monday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell $1.20 an ounce, to a late bid of $356.30. 
 The dollar was helped early when the Commerce Department announced a five-tenths of a percent rise in retail sales in July, said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange with Paine Webber International Ltd. in New York.
The dollar often moves in the same direction as interest rates, and the retail sales report gave little indication that the Federal Reserve would nudge rates downward to spur the economy.
But trading was very light, Mr. Troni said.
"We're paralyzed awaiting the big news Thursday," he said. The Bundesbank's council is expected to review German interest rates at its meeting tomorrow.
Rumors circulated early yesterday that the Bundesbank would not raise rates, but the talk spurred little market activity, said Mike Ballow, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago.
"The dollar is basically consolidating right now," Mr. Ballow said.
In New York, the British pound finished at $1.6930, down from $1.6980 Monday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.6938, from $1.6975 late Monday.
In Tokyo, the dollar was unchanged from Monday at 136.40 yen. Later, in London, it closed at 136.50 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 136.45 yen, down from 136.55 yen Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.7325 German marks, up from 1.7245; 1.5145 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 5.8960 French francs, up from 5.8670; 1,300 Italian lire, up from 1,293, and 1.1462 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1463.
In gold trading earlier in London, the metal fell to a late bid price of $357.00 an ounce, from $358.25 bid late Monday, and to $356.80 an ounce in Zurich, from $358.25 late Monday.
In Hong Kong, gold fell 77 cents to close at a bid $358.26.
Silver for August delivery fell 2.8 cents an ounce, to $3.925, on New York's Comex. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $3.95 an ounce, from $3.98 bid late Monday.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Rose 0.5% in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Consumers continued a cautious pickup in spending in July, pushing retail sales up five-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said today. It was the first three-month string of increases in nearly a year.
But analysts, noting that the spending was far from robust, said the figures supported the view that the recovery would be much weaker than the average since World War II. The report also failed to dispel concerns about whether the economy could avoid a "double dip" recession, turning down after a period of growth. 
 "The bottom line is that there is a bit of a pickup, but some real question about whether it is sustainable," said David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York Government-securities dealer.
 
Need for Jobs
 Sandra Shaber, an economist at the Futures Group in Washington, suggested that the spending pace could be maintained "only if we have improvements in the job market and in earnings. Judging by recent trends, that hasn't happened yet."
On the sales report, bond prices fell initially on the belief that interest rates would stay high, but then recovered later. [Page D13.] The figures helped lift stock prices, with the Dow gaining 7.38, to 3,008.72, in heavy trading. [Page D6.]
The Commerce Department said the July sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $153.7 billion, up from $152.9 billion in June. It also revised its initial estimate for June to a one-tenth of 1 percent gain from a two-tenths of 1 percent decline.
 
Strong Upward Revisions
 Even May's revised 1.2 percent increase was stronger than the 1 percent first estimated. It was the first time sales had risen for three consecutive months since July through September 1990.
Most analysts say the economy resumed growing in the second quarter. But they caution that any recovery will quickly falter without consumer participation. Retail sales account for half of overall consumer spending, which itself represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Laurence H. Meyer, head of a St. Louis economic forecasting company, said that while the report "suggests that consumer spending has a fair amount of momentum going into the third quarter, it doesn't alter very much our views that over all the recovery is still struggling."
Still, Mr. Meyer said, the July report with its revisions "gives us some confidence we can avoid slipping back into recession."
Automobile sales, which represent about one-fifth of retail purchases, jumped 1.1 percent in July following gains of nine-tenths of 1 percent in June and five-tenths of 1 percent in May. It was the first three-month string of advances in this recession-battered sector since June through August 1989.
"Deep discounts and incentives in automobile sales are driving recent improvements in retail sales," said Richard W. Rahn, an economist with the United States Chamber of Commerce. He also questioned whether the pace could be maintained.
Excluding the auto category, sales were up three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Gain in Durables
 Sales of durable goods -- expected to last more than three months -- increased seven-tenths of 1 percent following a three-tenths of 1 percent gain a month earlier.
Customers increased purchases of furniture and other home furnishings by 1.9 percent, erasing an eight-tenths of 1 percent drop in June. But they continued to avoid building-material outlets, where sales fell eight-tenths of 1 percent after declining three-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier.
Sales of nondurable goods like food and fuel advanced four-tenths of 1 percent, after a one-tenth of 1 percent gain a month earlier.
Department-store sales jumped 2.8 percent, wiping out a 2 percent decline in June. Apparel sales inched up one-tenth of 1 percent after a six-tenths of 1 percent drop a month earlier. Drugstore sales posted a seven-tenths of 1 percent gain after a 1.1 percent increase the previous month.
Sales at restaurants and bars held steady after posting a 1.1 percent gain a month earlier. But grocery- store sales were off three-tenths of 1 percent after increasing six-tenths of 1 percent in June.

HEADLINE: Short-Term Rates Off Again; Further Drop Is Expected

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The recent decline in yields on short-term securities, both money market funds and certificates of deposit, gained momentum in the last week, and rates will likely drop even lower, said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla.
Commenting on what he called the very strong decline in the seven days that ended yesterday, Mr. Heady said: "The bottom of the down cycle is not yet in sight. The latest decline in savings yields follows last week's easing of the Federal funds rate and Monday's drops in Treasury bill rates." 
 He noted that a bit of history will be set by the lower yields on money market accounts effective tomorrow, in that for the first time in eight years and eight months the average money market account yield for New York commercial banks fell below the 5 percent level, to a 4.98 percent yield. It was that many years ago, in December 1982, that Congress first authorized the bank money market accounts. On average, the banks in the last seven days cut their money market account yields by 9 basis points, to the 4.98 percent level.
Among the major banks in the New York area, the largest change in the return on money market accounts was reported by three banks, where yields all fell 21 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. The banks were the Bank of New York, the European American Bank and the Republic National Bank of New York.
Both European American and Marine Midland reported that their yields on three-month certificates of deposit declined 21 basis points, the biggest drop among the New York banks. In six-month certificates, European American reported the biggest decline, with a drop of 26 basis points. Mr. Heady called all of these "pretty sharp declines."
New York commercial banks on average reduced their yields by 11 basis points on the six- and the three-month certifcates, to 5.42 percent and to 5.23 percent, respectively.
At savings institutions, the yields were down 4 basis points on average on both the six- and three-month certificates, to 5.94 percent and 5.66 percent, respectively, while the money market average yield was off 2 basis points, to 5.50 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Advance

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Bond prices advanced again and long-term interest rates fell in active trading yesterday, staging a turnaround from morning trading when prices fell after a Government report suggested that consumer spending in the third quarter might be picking up.
The retail sales report, which showed that sales rose by five-tenths of a percent in July, was slightly better than most analysts had expected. 
 Dealers initially interpreted the figures as suggesting the economy may in fact be recovering at a more vigorous clip than most Wall Street economists currently maintain, and sold securities. But big institutions were rumored to have bought after prices dipped, and the decline was reversed.
"It's been a busy day," one government bond trader said. "A lot of securities have been trading, and I think some of the bonds that were auctioned last week have moved off of dealers' books."
 
Gain in Retail Sales
 The retail sales gain was the third monthly gain in a row, the first time in nearly a year that has happened. Nevertheless, analysts said underlying employment and income trends offered scant evidence to support the view that consumers are in a position to provide much stimulus to the economy.
"The numbers were a tad stronger than expected, but I think consumers are struggling to get ahead at this point," said Joseph Carson, chief economist at Chemical Bank. "The lack of income growth makes it difficult to increase spending. And Corporate America is not making any money, which is being reflected in more layoffs."
Mr. Carson said he expected consumer spending to remain weak for the remainder of the year, but he added that the decline in interest rates should help set the stage for a rebound in early 1992.
The drop in interest rates "will allow consumers to reliquify their balance sheets," he said. "Hopefully, that will be enough to get us growing next year."
 
Yield Declines to 8.16%
 In the market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of August 2021 that were auctioned last week were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.16 percent, down from 8.20 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the new 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 7.90 percent, compared with 7.93 percent late Monday.
In the secondary Treasury note market, the 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at a price of 101 25/32, up 5/32, to yield 7.43 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 25/32, up 1/32, to yield 6.44 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates, which have fallen sharply recently, were little changed yesterday.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.28 percent in late trading, unchanged on the day. And six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 5.38 percent.
 
New-Issue Activity Up
 New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market remained heavy.
The Grand Metropolitan Investment Corporation, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the giant British-based food company, offered $900 million worth of securities through an underwriting group led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The securities, all guaranteed by Grand Met, were offered in maturities of 5 years, 10 years and 20 years.
The $300 million worth of 8 1/8 percent five-year notes were priced at $99.94 to yield 8.14 percent, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The 8 5/8 percent 10-year notes were priced at $99.70, to yield 8.67 percent, 76 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The final $300 million of 9 percent 20-year debentures were priced at $99.174, to yield 9.09 percent, 92 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
All three maturities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. All are noncallable for life.
 
Imperial Oil Bonds
 J. P. Morgan Securities acted as lead manager on an offering of $200 million worth of 10-year notes for the Imperial Oil Company.
The 8.30 percent notes, which mature Aug. 20, 2001, were priced at $99.80 to yield 8.33 percent, 41 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated AA-1 by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for an offering of $100 million worth of 15-year notes for the Eaton Corporation.
The 8.90 percent notes, which mature Aug. 15, 2006, are noncallable for life. They were priced at $99.625, to yield 8.946 percent, a percentage point over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate securities, traders said prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 point in active trading.

HEADLINE: EXPERTS WORRIED BY KUWAIT FIRES

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 13

 BODY:
Nearly six months after the Iraqis blew up hundreds of Kuwaiti oil wells, about 40 percent of the wells have been capped but the short- and long-term health effects still look grim.
At an international conference here on the Kuwaiti oil fires arranged by Harvard's School of Public Health and Center for Middle Eastern Studies, Prof. Richard Wilson, a Harvard physicist and specialist in risk analysis, estimated that 50,000 people in the Kuwait region "will have their lives shortened in some way" in the next several years because of the smoke. 
 The estimate, covering an area from Basra, Iraq, to Bahrain, assumes that there is no safe threshhold dose for pollutants that are known to be poisonous in high doses, like sulfur dioxide and small particles of soot.
 
Comparison to London Fogs
 But another speaker, George D. Thurston, of the New York University Institute of Environmental Medicine, said a preliminary analysis of average concentrations of pollutants indicated that their could be 1,000 extra deaths in Kuwait if the fires took a year to put out, a schedule that he noted was optimistic. He based his data on analysis of severe London fogs of 1952 and 1962; some of the components of the pollution in London, including soot and acid, are present in Kuwait.
Others were less willing to attach numbers to their health estimates, but many expressed frustration with gaps in knowledge about what is being emitted and how much most people are exposed to, in a situation with wide variability in air quality from place to place and time to time.
A French team and a Japanese team compared air quality in Kuwait with 24-hour average values in, respectively, Paris and Tokyo, and found that Kuwait was no worse. But the Kuwait average hides tremendous variations over periods of a few minutes, the researchers found. Short-lived high concentrations of sulfur dioxide can trigger asthma attacks in people who are susceptible, medical experts say, and the Middle East has a higher incidence of asthma than most of the world.
 
Impact of Short Doses
 But the significance of short, severe doses of other forms of pollution is not so clear. One question concerns the effects of chemicals called polyaromatic hydrocarbons, which are known to cause cancer over extended periods and appear in Kuwait at far higher-than-normal levels.
Much of the analysis contrasted with the early verdict of the Environmental Protection Agency, which said that there were no acute hazards. But James E. Makris, who lead the first E.P.A. mission to Kuwait City right after the war, said that his agency's assessment had been borne out. Early fears that wells would emit hydrogen sulfide gas or heavy metals, which can kill large numbers of people promptly, were unfounded, he said.
The conference was held at the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and was jointly sponsored by the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development and the United Nations Development Program, with participation by the World Health Organization and other international agencies.
 
A Shift in Winds
 In Kuwait itself the short-term outlook is worrisome. Natural weather patterns seem likely to make the living conditions in Kuwait City worse in coming months. The "shemal" winds, part of a counter-clockwise movement across southern Asia and the Indian ocean, had been blowing from the northwest in recent months, bringing clean air to Kuwait City and carrying the smoke from the biggest oilfield over the Persian Gulf or uninhabited desert. Now, however, the wind has died down, allowing smoke to collect.
Kuwait is still struggling to establish a system to predict particularly bad days and warn residents to stay inside. Health officials now hope to have such a system in place by October.
Progress on extinguishing the fires is slow. According to Dr. Faisal Al-Jassem, of the Kuwait Petroleum Company, between 740 and 750 wells were blown up, and as of Monday, 291 of those had been capped. Huge crusts of coke, a product of partial burning, have built up at some wells, and must be chipped away to expose the wellhead. Firefighters have recently called in tanks to shell the crusted wells.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Kansas City Fed Bank Names New President

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City yesterday named a career officer, Thomas M. Hoenig, as the bank's new president, succeeding Roger Guffey, who is retiring.
The 44-year-old Mr. Hoenig, who will take office on Oct. 1, has been with the bank since 1973, always in bank supervision and currently as senior vice president of the Bank Supervision and Structure division. As president of one of the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks, he will become one of the Fed's policy makers, a group that has the power to change the nation's short-term interest rates. 
 Mr. Hoenig has not spoken publicly on monetary policy. Mr. Guffey, who has served since 1976 as the Kansas City Fed's seventh chief executive, has had the reputation of being more concerned about inflationary pressures than some of the Fed's other policy makers. Besides the 12 regional bank presidents, the Fed's seven governors, headed by Alan Greenspan as chairman, sit on the policy-making body known as the Federal Open Market Committee.
Mr. Greenspan and the governors always sit as voting members of the committee, which meets in Washington every six weeks. The presidents rotate as voting members, with five having votes at a given time. Mr. Hoenig will become a voting member next Jan. 1, three months after he takes office.
Mr. Hoenig, born in Fort Madison, Iowa, joined the Kansas City Fed as an economist in the supervision division, having earned M.A. and Ph.d. degrees at Iowa State University. He was named a vice president in the supervision division in 1981 and senior vice president in 1986.
The bank's board of directors appointed him to his new job as president, with the board of governors in Washington confirming the appointment.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City has jurisdiction over an eight-state district containing more than 3,000 banks and savings and loan associations eligible for Fed services. Besides Kansas, the district includes Colorado, Nebraska, Oklahoma, Wyoming and parts of Missouri and New Mexico.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Plans to Scale Back Proposal for Adirondacks

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 13

 BODY:
In a scaled-down version of the broad recommendations made last year by his Commission on the Adirondacks, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is to propose measures to restrict development along many Adirondack lakes and preserve large tracts of back-country forest.
While less encompassing than called for by the commission that he had appointed, the Governor's package is still the most significant package of legislation affecting the Adirondacks in two decades, and it foreshadows what will likely be an intense legislative struggle next year during the centennial of Adirondack Park. 
 Mr. Cuomo's proposal, for instance, would reduce the number of houses that could be built along many Adirondack lake shorelines, while the commission plan would have prohibited shoreline construction on some lakes altogether.
And the Governor's package is expected to focus on tax breaks and other incentives to keep privately held plots of land out of development, while shying away from the costlier alternative of large-scale state purchases of land or the more stringent approach of prohibiting new construction.
No firm cost estimate was ever attached to the Cuomo commission's recommendations -- some officials said they would have cost a few hundred million dollars while others said all the land it urged the state to buy could cost $1 billion.
In any event, by focusing on tax breaks, the Governor's measure would be considerably less expensive, but also far-reaching. Mr. Cuomo is expected to issue a renewed call for passage of a dedicated state fund for environmental projects, which the Legislature resisted this year.
The Governor's plan also provides measures to insure greater representation of local Adirondack governments on the Adirondack Park Agency, the state agency that must approve any development project within the park.
Mr. Cuomo's plan will be formally unveiled in the next few weeks, and state lawmakers are not expected to consider it until next year's legislative session.
But several people familiar with his proposals said they focused on some of the most critical problems identified by the commission without adopting some of the strongest measures it advocated. The commission report, while supported by many environmental groups and park residents as a visionary document, was interpreted in some Adirondack communities as an economic death knell.
It has remained unaddressed in the last year and a half.
The panel, warning of a "last clear chance" to protect the wilderness character of the Adirondacks, called for massive state purchases of land and some of the most restrictive zoning measures affecting privately held land in the eastern United States.
The Governor has repeatedly pledged to offer legislation to aid both the park's spectacular natural heritage and its battered economic base. The Adirondacks, a patchwork of public and private land, represents the largest wilderness area east of the Mississippi. It is also home to some of the poorest communities in the state.
Mr. Cuomo appointed the commission in January 1989, warning of dangers of "unbridled land speculation" in the Adirondacks amid intense publicity about sales to developers of several large long-forested tracts.
 
Applications to Build
 Largely because of the recession, many of the more dire predictions have not yet materialized and some planned developments have been put on hold, although the Adirondack Park Agency has reported record numbers of applications for construction permits in recent years.
And while critics of the commission have cited the slowed pace of activity as proof that the commission's recommendations were excessive, many environmental groups have argued that a rebound in the economy could bring a burst of development in the park and that now is the time to head it off.
Many of these groups have also called on the state to buy up available land now, while prices are in decline. But with last fall's defeat of the $1.9 billion environmental bond act and the state's fiscal turmoil, Governor Cuomo has repeatedly stated that New York has no money to buy land anytime soon.
Late last month, Mr. Cuomo said confusion over the recommendations of the Adirondack commission, which was headed by Peter A. A. Berle, the National Audubon Society president, had caused the defeat of the bond act because many upstate residents feared that the state wanted to buy up too much land.
 
Berle Commission
 "The Berle Commission -- that killed it," Mr. Cuomo told a Plattsburgh newspaper. "I would not have chosen that concatenation of the bond issue and the Adirondack Commission. It was too confusing. This is my problem, my responsibility. It was my commission; it was my mistake."
Mr. Berle was traveling in the Soviet Union today and was unreachable, his office said.
Since the commission report was issued, the Governor has been under pressure from all sides on the Adirondack issue. Preservation groups have urged him to embrace the report in full, while many local government and business leaders have castigated it as big-brotherism and urged the Governor to leave them alone to regulate park affairs.
 
'Visionary Document'
 The interest in the issue has remained ardent: By one Adirondack resident's count earlier this year, no less than 14 groups have been formed in the last few years purporting to represent the true views of Adirondackers.
The Governor's chief adviser on environmental affairs, Francis Murray, declined to discuss specifics of the legislation. But he said the Governor wanted to issue it soon so that there would be plenty of time for public discussion of the proposals before the Legislature acts.
Mr. Murray described the committee's report as "a visionary document," but added, "I don't think that the people on the commission believed that all of their vision would be realized within the next few years."
The last major actions concerning the Adirondacks were taken by the Legislature in the early 1970's, under pressure from Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. That is when of many of the current zoning laws -- which the commission described as insufficient to preserve much of the park's shoreline and back country -- were put in place.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
British Air Cuts U.S. Fares To London and Rivals Join In

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
British Airways has introduced discounts of up to 15 percent on its flights between the United States and London this fall, and three carriers -- American, Continental and United -- have quickly matched them. Other carriers competing on the trans-Atlantic routes are expected to follow.
Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines said yesterday that they were studying the British Airways specials. "Everybody will match," said Edmund Greenslet, publisher of The Airline Monitor, a trade journal. 
 But analysts said the cuts on the London routes did not necessarily indicate that discounts on other routes to Europe were in the offing. On the other hand, autumn "is the time of year when you get more incentive pricing," Mr. Greenslet said.
 
Discounts on Hotels, Too
 In addition to the 15 percent discount on air fares, British Airways is offering savings of up to 35 percent on hotels and other travel costs. The specials apply to round trips to London that depart between Oct. 15 and Dec. 13 and return by Jan. 4, 1992.
The airline flies to London from 17 cities, including New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Its new round-trip New York-London fare, for example, will be $428 on weekdays.
British Airways, which saw its business drop between 20 percent and 30 percent in the first quarter because of the war in the Persian Gulf and the recession, customarily offers specials in the fall, when leisure travel slows.
But this year, the advance notice offered to fliers and the depth of the discounts are greater, said John Lampl, a spokesman for the airline. "They're a stimulator to get people traveling again," he added. The airline's market share on the United States-Britain routes is 39 percent.
 
International Travel Flat
 Industry data show that international travel was largely flat in May and June. Robert Decker, an airline analyst at Duff & Phelps/MCM, said he expected that newer data would show the pattern continuing through the summer.
"International travel seems to be coming back at a fairly steady pace," Mr. Decker said.
With increased competition on the routes to Britain, carriers are marketing London heavily as a tourist destination. The exposure, combined with the discounts, should encourage more vacationers to sign up for the specials, said Steven E. Heydt, senior vice president of Liberty Travel.

HEADLINE: Brown's Gospel: Community Policing

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
At 6-foot-3, in a dark suit and tie, Lee P. Brown was an imposing figure as he stood between murals of Jesus in the garden and Jesus weeping over Jerusalem. In the humid Harlem church, his sweating listeners hung on his words. He told them that their ministry was to be good parents. Teach moral discipline and spiritual idealism to their children, he said, and then go out and improve the community and city.
The message, sprinkled with biblical allusions and lines from spirituals, could have been delivered by a minister. Indeed, Mr. Brown confided, he once had given serious thought to becoming one. "But," he said with a wry smile, "you can see from my current position the Lord had other plans for me." 
 The other plans he spoke of included trying to make the city a safer place. "Even though I did not go into the ministry, I am reminded every day in the position I now occupy that you don't have to be a minister to be part of God's program," Mr. Brown said on a recent Sunday at the annual Men's Day ceremony of the Childs Memorial Temple Church of God in Christ, at Amsterdam Avenue and 147th Street.
Such talk is not what one expects from the Commissioner of an urban police department of about 27,400 uniformed members and 7,400 civilians, but it helps set Mr. Brown apart from other police leaders, especially as he goes around the city speaking to citizens and to police officers about his vision of modern-day policing.
 
More Officers on Foot Patrol
 In the year and a half since he came to New York from Houston, where he was the Chief of Police for eight years, Mr. Brown has spoken at hundreds of gatherings, many of them at churches. At each one, he has preached the gospel of community policing.
Thousands of new officers are to be added to foot-patrol duty so that when the department is fully staffed in 1994, Mr. Brown foresees each officer becoming familiar with a group of streets. With the help of residents, they are to try to solve recurring crime problems rather than just respond to crimes after they occur.
The reaction from the public has generally been enthusiastic. The reaction from the police has been more guarded, with the more cynical officers seeing his plans as unrealistic in light of the complexity of the city and the intricacies of the police bureaucracy.
"There is a lot of preacherman in him, no doubt about that," said Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a watchdog organization that monitors developments in crime and criminal justice.
Other commissioners have set a moralistic tone, Mr. Reppetto said, like Patrick V. Murphy, who took over during the Knapp Commission's investigation into police corruption in 1970. But he added, Mr. Brown "is something unusual."
 
'Something Unusual'
 The 53-year-old Mr. Brown, who grew up in a religious family in the African Methodist Episcopal Church tradition in Fowler, Calif., has said he most admires Jesus Christ, Mohandas Gandhi and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
And while Mr. Brown never chose the ministry, the eldest of his four children, Patrick, 31, did, and is a minister in Chicago.
Mr. Brown is a native Oklahoman whose family migrated to California, where his father was an agricultural worker and his mother a cook. He holds a master's and doctorate in criminology from the University of California at Berkeley and a master's in sociology from San Jose State University.
He got into criminology by chance. He won a football scholarship to Fresno State University, where he planned to major in physical education and become a football coach. But a friend who gave him a ride to registration chose to major in criminology and because "phys ed" was not available that day and Mr. Brown needed a ride home, he made the same choice.
In the 35 years since, Mr. Brown has held jobs ranging from foot patrolman to Public Safety Commissioner of Atlanta and has developed his theories of community policing. While some may view the concept as simply "putting the cop back on the beat," to Mr. Brown it is a philosophy, an ideal form of cooperative effort between the community and the police officer in preventing crime rather than just responding to it. And for Mr. Brown philosophy must be rooted in a value system.
At a promotion ceremony at Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan last month, he explained why officers needed such values.
"One of the great demands for any member of the Police Department is to be able to adhere to values in the face of the collapse of values all around us," he said. "To be a police officer in urban America today is to bear witness to that collapse. We witness it in the utter disregard for human life that begins at so early an age."
Mr. Brown created a set of values, the first to be committed to writing in the New York department's history. It reads: "In partnership with the community, we pledge to: protect the lives and property of fellow citizens and impartially enforce the law; fight crime both by preventing it and by aggressively pursuing violators of the law; maintain a higher standard of integrity than is generally expected of others because so much more is expected of us; and value human life, respect the dignity of each individual and render our services with courtesy and civility."
After reading the code at Childs Memorial Temple, he said, "As you can see, the values of the Police Department are not all that different than the values we learn about in church."
At the promotion ceremony, he said it was easy to pay lip service to such values.
 
Values to Live By
 "But it is quite another to live by them when as police officers you confront just the opposite every day," he said. "So why should the police be different? Because we know the difference between right and wrong. Because we know the difference between decency and indecency. Let me ask it another way: If we don't stand by values, who will? If we don't set an example, who will?
"Most people who live in the worst areas of this city are good people trapped there by their economic plight. On streets where the dealer or the mugger would rule, the cop may be the only powerful symbol of decency left."
The values have been sent to precincts and been incorporated in the training program at the Police Academy. Seminars dealing with their meaning will be held for every officer, he said.
In an interview, Mr. Brown said: "I have a role to determine the culture of this organization. That's the role of a leader in any organization."
 
Molding a Culture
 He added, "I happen to believe that values are a key element in terms of helping to mold that culture. If you don't know what you stand for, then you can't provide the guidance to the organization to go in the direction that you want to go."
Bishop Norman N. Quick, pastor of Childs Memorial, said he was pleased with Mr. Brown's approach. "Police officers are given by statute a lot of force and a great deal of authority," he said, "and I think it's very important that they have and hold it in proper perspective."
Acknowledging that Mr. Brown's view of the police and the community working together might be criticized as idealistic, Bishop Quick said: "We need that. Our people need to be inspired by idealism."
In other places, the reaction has been much the same.
Dr. Arthur Caliandro, senior minister of the Marble Collegiate Church, said he had known Mr. Brown's predecessor as Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, a tough administrator, and liked him. "But there's a different approach with Lee Brown," he said. "I didn't sense any hardness. It's easy in our city to get hard and cynical. I sensed a tremendous patience with humanity."
But police officers have reacted with more skepticism.
An officer in Brooklyn said: "I think he has a good heart and he means well, but I think he's a little naive to the needs of the city. He's got an unrealistic view. It may have worked in Texas, but it won't work in New York because there are just so many people here."
 
Too Idealistic?
 A veteran narcotics officer in Manhattan said most police officers did not object to the code of values.
"I think most cops become police officers because they want to do some good," he said. "Nobody objects to Brown's ideas of what the department should be. Where the problem comes is a lot of guys think it's very idealistic and not realistic."
Robert Harris, president of the senior choir at the Williams Institutional Christian Methodist Episcopal Church in Harlem, where Mr. Brown also has spoken, is a retired Bronx homicide detective.
He said that while many police officers would resist change, others were hungry for a value system. "Believe it or not, a lot of police on the street are religious," he said. "To walk the street you have to believe in a supreme being or you end up alcoholic, divorced or both or worse."
He agreed with Mr. Brown's philosophy of policing and felt others should give it a chance.
Mr. Harris had another thought. "You know, a lot of police executives retire and go on to work as executives in security firms," he said. "When he leaves the department, I predict he's going to become a minister, mark my words. That's going to be his second career."

HEADLINE: Clifford Resigning as Chairman Of Bank That Had Secret Links

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Clark M. Clifford, a towering figure at the intersection of law and politics in the capital for nearly half a century, resigned today as the chairman of Washington's largest bank holding company, apparently under pressure from Federal regulators and the board of the bank he led for nine years.
Federal regulators and investigators have said that First American Bankshares Inc. was secretly controlled by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, a loosely regulated international banking concern that was seized last month after auditors reported that the bank had a complex past that included bribery, money laundering and bank fraud. 
 Mr. Clifford's law partner and protege, Robert A. Altman, who was president of the First American Corporation, also resigned today. The corporation was one of several holding companies that form the First American group's intricate structure.
 
Temporary Chairman Named
 For now, First American said Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a former United States Attorney General and former general counsel of the International Business Machines Corporation, would serve as First American's chairman.
Banking officials said the Federal Reserve Board and Charles McC. Mathias, the former Republican Senator from Maryland who is on First American's board, helped force the resignations that commenced the latest chapter in the B.C.C.I. saga and precipitated the dizzying decline of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman from their highly lucrative bank posts.
Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman have consistently insisted that they were unaware that B.C.C.I. held any controlling interest in First American.
The resignations also crystallize how much Mr. Clifford's long relationship with First American and B.C.C.I. had tarnished his once-illustrious reputation in the twilight of his career as a lawyer, lobbyist, adviser to Democratic Presidents and an unchallenged symbol of rectitude in Washington.
Mr. Clifford, who is 84 years old, represented the Arab-owned, Pakistani-run B.C.C.I. when it first tried to acquire American banks in the late 1970's.
The crux of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman's problems is that law enforce- ors with B.C.C.I. money. If they were aware that B.C.C.I. controlled First American, and lied to regulators about it, they could be charged with fraud.
Neither man has been formally accused of any wrongdoing.
Last month, the Federal Reserve moved to fine B.C.C.I. a record $200 million for "secret arrangements" that allowed the foreign bank to acquire First American but were in violation of agreements with the Fed that barred B.C.C.I. from having any ownership interest in First American. Those commitments were made by Mr. Clifford.
Mr. Mathias, who had taken a leading role in managing the bank earlier this year when the B.C.C.I. connection was first discovered by the Fed, took the leading role in demanding the ouster of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman, banking officials said.
 
'The Fed Wanted Them Out'
 "The Fed wanted them out," one official said, "and Senator Mathias played the leading role."
Mr. Mathias declined through a spokesman to discuss the specifics of how the resignations came about.
Frank Mankiewicz, the bank's public relations counsel, disputed the assertion that the resignations of Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman had been forced. Rather, he said, they had chosen on their own to resign for the good of the company.
Mr. Katzenbach, the new chairman, is expected to attempt to extricate First American from B.C.C.I. and eventually to sell the bank to new owners. But those tasks will be complicated by the fact that B.C.C.I.'s shares in First American have been seized by foreign bank regulators and are tied up in court proceedings in London and New York.
Mr. Katzenbach said in a statement that the Fed had tentatively endorsed a plan for a trust to be established holding First American shares.
"Constructive ownership of the bank will be in the trust," Mr. Mathias said. He added that the legal issues might take a long time to resolve and that the trust would allow the bank to continue operations until that occurred.
An order freezing B.C.C.I.'s assets in the United States, including the First American holding, was extended last Friday by Federal Bankruptcy Judge James Garrity in New York. It would prevent the movement of any First American shares. But Harvey Miller, a bankruptcy lawyer representing a claim against B.C.C.I., said that if the Fed asked Judge Garrity to revise his order to permit such a transaction, it would likely be granted.
 
Three Inquiries Under Way
 The Fed, the District Attorney in Manhattan and a Federal grand jury here are investigating whether Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman knowingly misled regulators with their repeated assurances over the years that B.C.C.I. would not be involved with First American.
Robert M. Morgenthau Jr., the District Attorney in Manhattan, is investigating because First American has a branch in New York. Law enforcement officials have said that one of his objects is to see whether B.C.C.I. used First American to launder money.
In a statement issued late today, Michael Cherkasky, chief of the investigation division for District Attorney Morgenthau, said, "We have been informed of the resignations, and they will not impact on our ongoing investigation."
The officials said that Mr. Clifford had been interviewed extensively by New York City investigators, though he has not appeared before the New York grand jury. They said Mr. Altman had not yet been interviewed in New York.
 
Indictments in Manhattan
 So far, Mr. Morgenthau's investigation has yielded indictments against B.C.C.I. and two of its top executives for bribery, money laundering and fraud. The bank pleaded guilty in 1990 to money laundering charges in Tampa, Fla., and was fined $15 million.
First American officials said that neither Mr. Clifford nor Mr. Altman had received any special compensation for their resignations.
Over the years, Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman profited handsomely from their B.C.C.I. dealings. At one point, both men borrowed 100 percent of the purchase price of First American stock on highly favorable terms from B.C.C.I.
But the action that raised the issue most profoundly of whether Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman knew of the B.C.C.I. role in First American was a series of stock transactions in 1988 in which the two made a profit of $10 million in less than two years. A secretive subsidiary of B.C.C.I. in the Cayman Islands subsidized a buyer who officials have said was a small-time money-lender who purchased most of the stock at three times the price paid by Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman.
And B.C.C.I. is said to have made a $2.2 million commission on the deal.
 
Audit Earlier This Year
 An audit earlier this year showed that some First American shareholders used money from B.C.C.I. to buy their shares in First American in 1982 and never repaid the loans, making B.C.C.I. the secret owner.
Throughout the year, Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman said they were unaware that B.C.C.I. held a controlling interest in First American. In June 1981, Mr. Clifford, relying on his reputation, assured Federal regulators that B.C.C.I. would have no role in First American, an assertion he repeated several times in the ensuing years.
Mr. Clifford now contends that he was gulled by the founder and former head of B.C.C.I., Aga Hassan Abedi, a Pakistani who is at the center of the unfolding B.C.C.I. story.
But investigators and Federal regulators have said there is much evidence that makes the claim that they were unaware of B.C.C.I.'s involvement less plausible.
 
Dual Role as Lawyers
 Mr. Clifford and Mr. Altman, as lawyers, represented both B.C.C.I. and First American. The group of original stockholders in First American who were represented by the two lawyers were assembled by Mr. Abedi.
In his statement of resignation today, Mr. Clifford said that First American "has been operated honestly and without control from B.C.C.I." He added that he and Mr. Altman had resigned because the publicity about B.C.C.I. and First American could have an adverse impact on the bank.
"Mr. Altman and I must insure that this public attention does not adversely affect the company," Mr. Clifford said in a statement.
He also said he was gratified that First American customers had remained loyal throughout the affair.
But despite statements that the bank remains in strong condition, a confidential report from the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates nationally chartered banks, gave the bank a rating of "4" on a scale of 1 to 5, 5 meaning that a bank is about to fail. The bank has struggled recently with bad real estate loans reflecting the recession in the Washington area.
The Comptroller's office said an institution with a "4" rating was one in which "a high potential for failure is present but is not yet imminent or pronounced."
Jack W. Beddow, chief executive of the bank's holding company, said that there had been some impact on the bank as a result of the growing difficulties surrounding its association with B.C.C.I., but that it was "mild" and depositors were overwhelmingly remaining confident in the bank. "There have been phone calls, inquiries and some confusion, but that is all," he said.
Mr. Katzenbach, who now practices law in Morristown, N.J., said he was "honored to have the opportunity to help guide First American into a new chapter in its distinguished history."

HEADLINE: Breaking the Beirut Hostage Impasse: New Mideast Alignments Clear Way

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
A powerful confluence of national interests has contributed to the surprisingly abrupt progress toward freeing the Western hostages held in Lebanon, according to specialists inside and outside the Bush Administration.
In the long regional struggle that has brought hostage-taking to the fore as a widely condemned tactic, each of the major parties has either taken part in or witnessed military, political or economic turmoil that has changed national equations. 
 Years of bleak stalemate in efforts to release the hostages may have given way to a recognition by the disparate powers with influence and bargaining leverage that it is time to resolve the issue finally, thereby removing what has become a signficant barrier to economic progress and political development in the region, the specialists said.
As was demonstrated briefly last week with the abduction of the Frenchman Jerome Leyraud, hostage-taking is not likely to soon disappear from the region. But for Iran, Syria, Israel, Lebanon, the United States and some Western European nations, the time may have arrived for successfully closing out an ugly chapter of confrontation that has obsessed and dominated the region's conscience and haunted American politics.
 
A Self-Propelled Iran
 Trying to answer the question "why now?" Richard Murphy, the former Assistant Secretary of State who supervised United States policy in the Middle East for most of the 1980's, said that while Syria has been maneuvering for several years to win the release of the Western hostages, Iran's post-revolutionary leadership has not been able to make a clear-cut decision to press the pro-Iranian militants in Lebanon to release their captives.
"The Syrians have never wanted to push Iran," Mr. Murphy said, "and Iran wasn't interested for a long time. But now the Syrians don't have to push them, because the Iranians are self-propelled -- not that there still aren't divided councils in Teheran."
"Local politics" in Lebanon among the kidnapping groups is also a factor, an Administration official asserted. "They've held those people for six years and haven't gotten anything for the Islamic revolution," he said. "And hostages are only valuable if they are traded."
The precise change in Iran that helped set off the release of two hostages in the last week remains a mystery, but Mr. Murphy argues that in the multifactioned ruling environment of Teheran, events today probably represent the culmination of forces that have been building for years. And those forces are well known.
 
Culmination of Forces
 After its eight-year war with Iraq ended in 1988, Iran was devastated economically. Its agricultural base has declined as its population has soared. Even before the death in 1989 of the uncompromising revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Teheran was looking to marshal massive resources to rebuild a shattered economy. That could happen only with Western investment and technology.
"I think we are finally seeing it work out," said Mr. Murphy.
Did the final factors include United States relief flights to Iran last spring, when hundreds of thousands ofIraqi Kurds overwhelmed Iranian refugee centers? Mr. Murphy said that might have added to the momentum.
Another factor is that the United States, after a period of mixed signals that included the covert arms-for-hostages trading in the Iran-contra scandal, might have convinced Teheran's leaders that future trade, transfers of technology and financing cannot flow while Terry A. Anderson and his fellow hostages remain chained to radiators in Beirut's basement dungeons.
For Syria, the end of the cold war and the American-led struggle against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq provided an obvious pretext for President Hafez al-Assad to reposition himself as an ally of the West. But what began as a tactical and perhaps transitory realignment by Mr. Assad might be turning into a strategic transformation for the man who came to prominence in the Middle East as the chief rejectionist.
 
Fulfilling Assad's Interests
 "Ever since he came to power, Assad's interests have not been fulfilled by going the peaceful route," said Graham Fuller, a Rand Corporation analyst who served as a senior Middle East specialist in the Reagan Administration. "What Syria got out of being the leader of the hell-no crowd -- oil money, leadership of the Palestinian cause and Soviet arms -- made him a dominant force for 15 years.
"Now for the first time," Mr. Fuller continued, "Syria is benefiting more from peace than from controlled confrontation and to me that is the real revolution in Syrian thinking."
Thus, Syria's interests in Lebanon's hostage problem are far more subtle and vital to Mr. Assad's survival as a regional power.
Since Lebanon was destabilized with the outbreak of civil war in the mid-1970's, Mr. Assad has been engaged in a struggle with Israel for effective control of his western flank, Lebanon. After two major Syrian military incursions into Lebanon and the humiliation of the Israeli invasion in 1982, Syria has forcefully backed a new Government in Beirut and emerged the demonstrable victor; Lebanon's new leadership is and is likely to remain pointedly pro-Syrian.
 
Removing Threats to Israel
 To keep Israel from reasserting a major role in Lebanon through partial occupation and military incursions against guerrilla bases, Mr. Assad must remove the security threats that face his sworn enemy, some analysts argue.
One way to do that would be to win the freedom not only of the Western hostages, but of Israel's captive servicemen held by either pro-Iranian militiamen or Palestinian guerrillas. Once that is done, a Syrian-backed effort to demilitarize southern Lebanon and disarm the still independent militias there would, over time, remove Israel's pretext for continued occupation.
How Syria brings peace to Lebanon also has a direct effect on the Middle East peace process, which has reached the sensitive stage of convening an international peace conference for direct talks between Israel and its Arab enemies.
 
Fine Line for Israelis
 Mr. Assad's performance in bringing security to southern Lebanon will bear directly on any argument he makes that Israel should return to Damascus control over the Golan Heights, seized in 1967.
According to Willaim Quandt, Middle East specialist at the Brookings Institution who served in the Carter White House, Israel will have to walk a fine line in responding to the "good will" and momentum of the hostage releases last week while not giving away its leverage over the kidnappers.
Among its hundreds of Arab prisoners whose freedom is sought by the kidnappers, Israel's main leverage is Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, who Israel accuses of being a spiritual leader of the Party of God in South Lebanon. Israel abducted Sheik Obeid in 1989.
"If they go ahead and release Sheik Obeid and this leads to the release of American hostages, they are going to get some credit in the United States," Mr. Quandt said. "If it doesn't cost them too much, they will seek to get it."

HEADLINE: Future Looks Grim For Theater Center In Los Angeles

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13

 BODY:
When it opened in a converted Greek Revival bank building six years ago, hopes were high that the Los Angeles Theater Center would form the nucleus of a SoHo-like arts district to revive the seedy Spring Street area downtown. The city pumped more than $27 million into the experimental multi-cultural theater company.
But today the nearby storefronts are mostly vacant, petty drug dealers and homeless men gather in littered doorways and the daring young company teeters on the brink of financial collapse, a stark example of the risks in using the arts as a tool of urban redevelopment. The city has said no more money, and The Los Angeles Times has refused to run the company's advertisements for failure to pay. 
 By most accounts, the theater center, which has produced nearly 100 plays in its short, busy life, has been a considerable artistic success and a boon to the city's vibrant Hispanic, Asian and black theater scene. On Monday night, the cast of "The Phantom of the Opera" gave a special cabaret-type performance, raising $40,000, the center said. Combined with $175,000 raised earlier and an anonymous donation of $100,000 today, the group has $315,000 of the $500,000 needed by the end of the month, the center said today. The $500,000 would allow it to complete a season scaled back to just 7 plays from the 14 it used to produce.
 
'A Major Tragedy'
 But almost all those in the Los Angeles theatrical world agree that the money would provide only a temporary reprieve from the inevitable and that the company cannot survive much longer. Its probable demise has set off deep soul-searching among those in the arts about why the nation's second-largest city, ranking behind only New York City, and seat of the movie industry, cannot support a public theater or create a downtown arts district.
"This is a major tragedy for Los Angeles: its loss will not easily be repaired," said the president of the California Institute of the Arts, Steven D. Lavine, whom Mayor Tom Bradley appointed last year to lead a special study of the theater center.
"No other major American theater has such a diverse audience and diverse casting," Mr. Lavine said. "They pushed the edges of audience taste. Part of the problem is that L.A. has relatively new cultural institutions and less of a history of facing this kind of setback. We are not practiced at organizing ourselves to address an emergency, as New York has had to do often."
Under the leadership of William Bushnell, the 1,215-seat theater complex opened in 1985 and quickly became one of the largest of most productive nonprofit public theaters in the United States, comparable in many ways to Joseph Papp's Public Theater. It supports theater laboratories for Hispanic, black and Asian actors and playwrights. Its provocative, often iconoclastic productions, including "The Illusion" and "August 29," won critical acclaim.
"It was a much needed component of cultural life: it offered a lot of experimentation," said the director of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, Adolfo V. Nodal, who oversees the theater.
The center's current productions include Reza Abdoh's "Bogeyman," which blasts critics of public financing of the arts, and "Bowl of Beings" a biting satire by Culture Clash, a trio of Hispanic actors signed by Fox Television for a sitcom.
The theater was to have been the centerpiece of the city's efforts to breathe new life into Spring Street, once the center of Los Angeles business life but now full of low-price clothing stores, residential hotels and drug dealing. Despite an investment of $65 million in the area from the Community Redevelopment Agency, the revival has failed. The restaurants and nightclubs that opened soon after the theater center have all become bankrupt, and only two of the many planned developments -- a state office building and a condominium -- have opened. Though ticket sales are good, many Angelenos are frightened to enter the area after dark. In 1989, the center sold $3.5 million in tickets, according to the city's latest statistics. The center also earned $430,000 in other income, from such concessions as the bar and from rentals to other outfits.
The center has had a paid attendance of about 200,000 a year in recent years, and it plays to 67 percent capacity on average nights, below the attendance at comparable theaters elsewhere in the nation, which have had 80 to 90 percent capacity. The center has been quite successful in selling season subscriptions, deriving about a third of its income from such sales, which is higher than the industry average of 29 percent. But it lags in single-ticket sales, partly because residents here have been unwilling to "brave a trip to Spring Street," the Lavine report says.
The larger reasons for the center's troubles, though, have had to do with its financing and a 34-member board that has been unable to raise sufficient private funds.
"The real costs of operating a complex like that were not thought through from the beginning," said Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Center Theater Group, which operates the Mark Taper Forum theater at the Music Center of Los Angeles County. "There was aggressive producing, but not sufficiently diversified backing. At the same time, other things did not happen on Spring Street."
There was also the issue of Mr. Bushnell, a forceful, frequently abrasive figure who made as many enemies as friends for the theater. "He kind of runs over people in order to get what he wants, and in some cases, he has made enemies," said Daniel S. Lewin, a former stage manager for the Los Angeles Theater Center. "But the place wouldn't exist if he wasn't that way."
For his part, Mr. Bushnell cites a combination of factors, including the recession, which has left the city strapped. "If I were a better politician in the traditional American way of never really saying what you feel, I probably wouldn't have had some of the problems I've had," he said.
The turning point came last year when the theater center asked for a $32 million subsidy over 5 years. An infuriated Los Angeles City Council balked, but approved a plan by which the redevelopment agency transferred title of the theater center to the city's Department of Cultural Affairs and paid off $5.3 million in bonds. Mr. Nodal, the director of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, said efforts were being made to reorganize the operation so that a consortium of theater companies or another operator, possibly including local universities, may take over the center, with the company remaining only as a tenant.
The company's beleaguered board is to meet on Thursday evening to decide whether to stage more productions. The center's fate was unclear today, but Mr. Nodal said that whoever ultimately runs it, "the building is not going to get turned into a bowling alley."

HEADLINE: Taking Lessons From Restaurants That Still Fill Their Seats

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
NEW YORK snaps to attention in autumn, not just with school and Broadway openings, but with new restaurants. This fall, the list of restaurants to open is almost as brief as that of Democratic Presidential candidates. But where kitchens are being built, and menus conceived, there is optimism.
"I think I know what it takes," said Arnold Israel, a former advertising and promotional executive who is opening his first restaurant, a refurbished edition of the Art Deco One Fifth at Fifth Avenue and Washington Square in about a month. Paradoxically, the recession made it easier for him to open the restaurant now than during the boom years of the past decade because his initial investment was considerably less than it would have been then and it was easier to negotiate favorable terms for the space.
"The economics are good now but you still have to be prepared to work 16 hours a day to cater to your customers," he said last week. "By giving people excellent food, service and value you can sustain it beyond the initial flush of curiosity."
A sound philosophy does not guarantee success, of course, but now that much of the glamour in the New York restaurant business is gone, this year's crop of intrepid restaurateurs will try to follow the lead of establishments that are weathering the recession and transition from the free-spending 80's to the cautious 90's.
In New York and around the country, these perennial magnets continue to fill their tables night after night. In contrast to the hot spots that briefly attracted a feeding frenzy of fashionable crowds before closing down, these durable restaurants have in common a businesslike attitude of dedicated professionalism.
"Successful restaurants like the Gotham Bar and Grill are about fabulous consistency and constantly paying attention to detail," said Richard Lavin, who is working with Mr. Israel as a consultant. "We think we're all headed for Broadway, but we must be willing to edit all the time."
Like the Gotham Bar and Grill, there are other places known for top-notch food in relaxed but stylish settings that were established in the early 1980's and are still going strong. Union Square Cafe, Elio's and Provence are some notable examples. Some restaurants, ranging from formally elegant to brassy, like Le Cirque and Jim McMullen's on the Upper East Side, Cafe des Artistes on the West Side and Smith & Wollensky and the venerable Palm in midtown, have been enjoying even longer successful runs. Commander's Palace in New Orleans, Legal Seafood in Boston and Joe's Stone Crab in Miami are all examples of restaurants in other cities around the country that continue to succeed regardless of the economy.
A casual neighborhood spot like Isabella's, with its sidewalk cafe on the Upper West Side, which opened in late 1987, never enjoyed the high profile of some others but has become solidly established. Stephen Hanson, one of the owners, said that to date, business in 1991 is outpacing that in 1990 by about 6 percent.
A few newer places at various price levels, including Aureole, Trattoria dell'Arte and Zarela, have been around long enough for the novelty to have worn off, but are still packed with diners night after night.
"Business is up by 20 percent," said Sheldon Fireman, the owner of Trattoria dell'Arte. "There's no magic, it's all hard work and having a flexible attitude that doesn't dictate to the customers but keeps them happy and coming back."
And judging from the many customers who dine there week after week, Coco Pazzo, the busy Italian spot on the Upper East Side that is scarcely a year old, appears to fit the profile of a place settling in for a long run rather than one doomed to become a fashion victim. "People come in here, look around and asked, 'What recession?' " said John Fanning, the maitre d'hotel.
The key, of course, is nurturing repeat business. Successful restaurateurs say their regular customers make up anywhere from 40 to 90 percent of their business, which may explain why neighborhood restaurants that depend on a local clientele seem to be thriving. Eddie Schoenfeld, an owner of Vince and Eddie's near Lincoln Center, is opening another restaurant on the West Side in September, Fishin Eddie on West 71st Street.
"We hope we can continue to satisfy the needs of this neighborhood," he said. "It's very important to understand your marketplace."
It's not only the neighborhood places that hope to cultivate a local clientele. "We do not want to be that once-a-year special occasion sort of place," Peter W. Tischmann, vice president and general manager of the newly restored St. Regis, said of the hotel's luxuriously appointed restaurant, Lespinasse. "We want to be the kind of place people will come back to because they like the food and the service and because they can afford it."
"Having repeat customers makes a place recession proof," Mr. Tischmann said, "but to do that we must first establish ourselves." Lespinasse will open Sept. 10 with Gray Kunz, formerly of Adrienne in the Peninsula across the street, as chef.
Mr. Tischmann said a three-course lunch would cost $35, comparable to many of the top midtown restaurants. But the price of a three-course dinner, including extras like chocolates and petits fours, will be $50, $5 to $20 less than most of the competition.
But delivering value is not just about low prices. In the past few years a number of Manhattan restaurants like Hubert's and Rakel restructured their menus and cut prices but still went out of business. "New Yorkers are sophisticated and they understand about prices," said Sirio Maccioni, the owner of Le Cirque.
"It goes back to perceived value and that can happen at any price level," said Drew Nieporent, owner of Montrachet and an owner of TriBeCa Grill. Mr. Nieporent says that TriBeCa is extremely busy, and that Montrachet has "hung in there."
"Your customers have to buy what you're delivering," he said. "And it's not just the food. For some it's the room or the service or the greeting at the door. Maybe they really like just one dish."
Indeed, there is a host of elements that contribute to a restaurant's success. And unlike in the flush economic climate a few years ago when droves of people would show up at the latest multimillion-dollar cattle barn with sponged walls, halogen sconces and $25 grilled chicken, close attention must be paid to every one of them.
Mr. Hanson said that when he opened Coconut Grove, his first restaurant, in early 1987, it was meant to be trendy. "It was less well-conceived and that wasn't wise because trends pass," he said. "By the time I opened Isabella's I had a better understanding of how important it was to attract people from the community. You have to work much harder at service." Unlike Isabella's, Mr. Hanson said, business at Coconut Grove is off about 8 percent.
"Customers are much more demanding these days; they are very aware of prices and are very sensitive to the details on how they are treated -- on the phone, when they come in, by the waiter, everything," said Elio Guaitolini, co-owner of Elio's, which opened at Second Avenue and 84th Street in 1981 and where some customers dine as often as two or three times a week. "We have to be much more careful than we were three years ago when the mood was lighter," he said.
Marc Sarrazin, who runs an informal personnel agency for chefs in addition to being an owner of DeBragga & Spitler, wholesale meat purveyors to the restaurant industry, believes it is important for restaurants to deliver according to expectations. "There is room for great restaurants at every level, but there has to be harmony," he said. "Customers can sense when there is tension, when the kitchen and dining room are at odds. We should give them more credit."
Pretension is out and personalization is in. Even at Le Cirque, where the social and power scene makes it seem as if the 80's never went away, Mr. Maccioni can be seen patrolling the dining room with an eagle eye; he's not above aligning the salt and pepper shakers or instructing a waiter to remove plates.
Mr. Maccioni and others also pointed out how important it was to refresh a restaurant. At the Gotham Bar and Grill, for example, Jerome Kretchmer, an owner, and his chef, Alfred Portale, are developing a complete four- or five-course dinner for the first time. "It's just to give our steady customers the possibility of a new experience," Mr. Kretchmer said.
Charles Palmer, chef and co-owner of Aureole, said nothing can be taken for granted. "Business has been great, but if there is any lapse it could go the other way. This place is not cheap but I guess people perceive it as value." The complete dinner at Aureole is $55.
And just as chefs and owners are paying careful attention to the details of greeting and service as well as to the quality of food, they are forever fine-tuning costs so they do not have to increase prices in the face of higher expenses. "We no longer have the guys from Wall Street coming in and showing off with $400 bottles of port," Mr. Palmer said.
These former big spenders, it seems, are also going to bed earlier these days. Fashionably late no longer seems fashionable and many restaurants, even the highly successful ones, are trying to devise ways, like not closing for vacation, to compensate for the decline in business after 9:30 or 10 P.M. It's a situation the newcomers will have to face. These hours around the edges of the prime dining times can often make the difference between profit and loss.
Along with the high-rolling party atmosphere, out went the dilettantes who regarded having a stake in a restaurant as a way of nourishing their egos but who never wanted to do the hard work.
"When you think of the great restaurants of Europe, they're about the people who run them, not two-or-three-million-dollar installations," Mr. Sarrazin said. "In the past few years the restaurant business became distorted, a monster. Maybe now it's getting back on a better track."
