LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: When a Fellow Needs A Friend, Not Just a Buddy

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
"THERE is much about our experience as men that can only be shared with, and understood by, other men," Sam Keen, a writer and philosopher, says in his best-selling book on men, "Fire in the Belly." And he says, "Only men understand the secret fears that go with the territory of masculinity."
What's going on here? After listening for a generation to women's complaints that men should open themselves emotionally and be more vulnerable in their relationships, some men are heeding the advice, Mr. Keen says. But with a twist: They are increasingly confiding in other men about the nature of manhood and friendship itself. 
 There is, say Mr. Keen and others who track the progress of men in unsettling times, a growing sense of a need to restore respect for masculinity and male friendships in American society.
Whether it's a condition of aging members of the post-war generation, economic downturn, family relations broken by divorce or a loneliness bred by a corporate culture that rewards rootlessness, there are signs that thoughtful men are exploring ways to find one or two others with whom they can share their innermost feelings.
"The men's movement today, which is building all the time, is made up of men who went after success, got it, and now question its values," Mr.Keen said in a telephone interview from his Sonoma, Calif., home. Those who haven't yet made it, he said, "are still aspiring to get all those things Madison Avenue says will make them happy."
Evidence of the search is seen in what Americans are reading this year: Both "Fire in the Belly" (Bantam Books, $19.95) and "Iron John: A Book About Men" (Addison-Wesley Publishing, $18.95) by the poet Robert Bly, have been at the top of the best-seller lists for months. These two books, while quite different in style, suggest that contemporary American man spends most of his time reacting to the presence of women in his life and very little on sorting out the mysteries of his own identity. Both authors say they are not "women bashers." In fact, they say, they welcome the gains achieved by women. But they also wonder whether men have become confused, compromising their natural instincts in deference to women's legitimate complaints about sexism.
"Women are coming out into activity just as the men are passing them going the other way, into passivity," Mr. Bly writes. "During the last 30 years men have been asked to learn how to go with the flow, how to follow rather than lead, how to live in a nonhierarchical way, how to be vulnerable, how to adopt consensus decision-making. Some women want a passive man if they want a man at all."
A lot of ridicule has been directed at Mr. Bly's evocation of ancient myths of "hairy men" who guide boys through intitiation rites into manhood, and some researchers have dismissed the "maleness movement" as a fad.
"It's appealing on one level, but I frankly do not put much faith in its longevity," said Dr. Robert E. Gould, a New York Medical College psychiatrist, author and feminist. "Men can't just jump into the wilderness and beat some drums to find themselves."
But the books obviously touch a nerve: after a generation of complaints by the women's movement about men's vices, some champions of manhood are talking up its virtues and finding a receptive audience.
They tell men that happiness lies in responding to positive, even admirable, aspects of their nature like physical exuberance in youth and being a mentor in later years and not feeling guilty if they need close male friendship apart from female claims on their time and emotions. To turn one's back on biology and history, both authors seem to say, is not only folly but damaging to both sexes.
It is a summons that can be unsettling if men, mainly those past 35, respond only to find they are entering the second half of their lives without friends other than business acquaintances and neighborhood pals.
Strong, abiding friendships between men have been a bedrock strength in most cultures, past and present. But in the United States, the competitive drive for success, as well as, in some cases, a homophobia that is part of their social experience, has left many successful middle-aged men shorn of deep, trusting relationships with other men.
Dr. Robert S. Weiss, director of the Work and Family Research Bureau at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, says men differ in their friendships with other men more than in any other area of their lives. In "Staying the Course" (Free Press, 1990), Dr. Weiss observes that some successful men have dozens of friends while others are not sure they have any.
Some men who cannot confide in other men find it easy to confide in women, especially wives, Dr. Weiss said in an interview, and while many men may bare their inner feelings while drinking or under the guise of kidding, they are not taken seriously.
For most adult men, work and family dominate adult lives. If divorce, loss of employment or some other crisis coincides with midlife questions and disillusion, the man who is without valued friends to fall back on is set adrift in dangerous, uncharted waters, often beyond the reach of family and his weekend sports companions or drinking buddies.
Corporate men in particular, Mr. Keen said, "are the men most deprived of true male friends; friendship doesn't thrive in a social ecology that stresses speed, constant preoccupation and competition."
Men without enduring friends can either suffer alone or do something about it. The old answers are rent-a-friend: $100-an-hour psychoanalysts or, at less cost, group therapy sessions for men. Men who feel confident enough to reach out and trust someone are creating other alternatives.
In northwestern Ohio, for example, a group of eight business and professional men recently formed a group that meets every six weeks over dinner to discuss serious elements of their lives that range from critical bread-and-butter decisions to heterosexual intimacy to issues of middle age.
"As men, from the age of 5 we were taught to put our dukes up against each other and keep them there," said Barry Heermann of Yellow Springs, Ohio, a 47-year-old business consultant. "In the group we mentor each other, care about each other, and there is a kind of surrender that I don't think men are used to experiencing."
A Manhattan group, fed by somewhat different needs, was formed recently by six men enrolled in a noncustodial therapy class for fathers, conducted at the 92d Street Y. When the four-week course ended, the men continued to meet on an informal basis in their own homes.
"Going through divorce can be a very isolating experience for a man," said a group member, Kenneth Berk, a Manhattan optometrist. "He finds he is divorcing not just his wife but many of his friends. I discovered I didn't have the wide circle of friends I thought I had. Most were husbands of my wife's friends, and when we separated they all began to pussyfoot around me. I'm not a criminal, but I feel like an outcast."
Like divorce, loss of a job can be shattering if there are no close friends to help a man through the crisis of self-doubt.
John Mennell, 30, a business analyst in New York, suddenly found himself on the street last November when his department at Bankers Trust was closed
His code is that a man takes the hard knocks "and keeps plugging away." He admits to feeling a need for a friend's comforting words and advice, but "you don't want to have to ask; there's an understanding among men, it's wrong to ask."
Breaking down those kinds of barriers, says Chuck Layer, a 56-year-old native of Kentucky who lives in Short Hills, N.J., was what led him to strike up a friendship with Tom Walker, of Edison. They met through their wives, both Wall Street executives, and hit it off on several levels. Both men once held top financial jobs and both now work out of their homes as consultants.
"When you work at home the computer, telephone and fax machine can isolate you socially," Mr. Walker, a gregarious 49-year-old Texan, said with a smile. But what brought him and Mr. Layer together was something more than companionship.
"Since turning 50," Mr. Layer explained, "for the first time in my life, I wanted to really talk to another man. I didn't want to chat about the weather, sex or night baseball. I wanted to learn more about my feelings and what makes me behave the way I do."
This spring the two met for lunch. "We skipped all the slick things we men use to sell ourselves -- what big deals we had pulled off, our golf handicaps -- and talked about meaningful subjects," Mr. Layer said. "What our parents were like, our relations to our fathers. We shared parts of our lives that were musty and deep."
Mr. Walker agreed. His neighbor Richard Kulbis, 46, is a front-porch pal and fishing buddy. But his talks with Mr. Layer helped him realize "there is a lot more to life than beating last year's income." "We are all looking for some way to talk, but getting across that bridge the first time is the hard part," Mr. Layer said. "Once across, it's marvelous how much unbundling we can do if you accept another man as a non-threat. He's not invading my little sandbox. I can let my guard down a little bit. He can be my close friend."

HEADLINE: The Swamp President

 BODY:
George Bush coupled his 1988 campaign pledge to be the "environment President" with a promise to resist further erosion of the nation's valuable wetlands. "My position on wetlands is straightforward," he said. "All existing wetlands, no matter how small, should be preserved."
Mr. Bush's latest proposal for managing wetlands, however, will certainly result in wetland loss, at least by present Federal standards. Shaped more by politics than science, it represents a grievous disappointment to conservationists. And it plunges wetlands policy into a swamp of controversy that's sure to grow when the proposal is offered for a 60-day public review later this week. 
 But this much can be said for his plan: It may have defused a far more dangerous threat to wetlands being hatched in Congress.
"Wetlands" is a broad term applied to ecosystems ranging from prairie potholes to vast tidal marshes. Until the 1970's, wetlands were treated with contempt -- as mosquito-filled swamps to be diked, drained and turned into cropland, shopping malls and subdivisions.
Scientists finally persuaded Congress that wetlands are remarkable biological systems deserving protection. They filter pollutants, replenish water supplies, nourish organisms essential to the food chain and provide habitat for wildlife. The result was the Clean Water Act of 1972, which requires anyone seeking to fill a wetland to obtain a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers and submit to review by the Environmental Protection Agency.
The law slowed the loss of wetlands. But it suffered from indifferent enforcement by the Corps and the failure of various agencies to agree on what a wetland was. In 1989, Government experts finally arrived at a common definition: A wetland is any ground that has mucky or peat-based soils, nourishes specific plant life and is saturated for at least seven straight days per year.
The new definition brought more acres under protection. It also brought howls from farmers and developers who discovered they had been plowing or building on land previously thought to be "dry." Led by oil and gas interests, which hope to drill on protected land, they have lobbied fiercely for changes.
Two weeks ago the Administration caved in. Overriding the strenuous objections of Environmental Administrator William Reilly, the President's Council on Competitiveness invented a much looser definition of wetlands -- 21 days of saturation instead of 7. The change will surely lead to the exploitation of wetlands now protected by the stringent 1989 regulations. But will it violate Mr. Bush's 1988 campaign pledge for no "net loss" of wetlands?
It's hard to say. When Mr. Bush made his pledge, environmentalists generally agreed that there were perhaps 100 million wetland acres genuinely worth saving. The White House insists that the new policy will leave those acres intact. Conservationists disagree -- violently.
In any case, the Bush proposal is preferable to Senate and House bills that would also ease the definition of a wetland and, worse, would eliminate the E.P.A.'s veto power over permits and its authority to establish environmental standards.
Alarmingly, the House version, drafted by oil and gas interests, has already picked up 170 co-sponsors. Instead of seizing on something truly destructive, Congress would be well advised to let Mr. Bush try working his way out of the wetlands swamp and strike a sensible balance between wetlands protection and economic growth.

HEADLINE: Peace-Weary Iraqis Flee for Jordan, to Rest or to Head West

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The 34-year-old Iraqi Christian had a close family, good friends, a Ph.D. and a well-paying engineering job in Iraq.
But when Baghdad lifted travel restrictions on Iraqis in May, for the first time in nearly a decade, he decided like thousands of others to risk it all: he headed to Jordan in search of a scarce visa to the West and a new start in life, far from the hardship of postwar Iraq. 
 "We are fed up with wars," he said. "We want a better life." Like many newly arrived Iraqis, he said bitterly that he had spent nearly a decade in the army, first in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war and then in the Persian Gulf war.
Like others, he would not give his name for fear of reprisals by the Iraqi authorities against relatives in Iraq.
Since reaching Amman a month ago, the Iraqi said, he has lived in two rooms with nine others, hoping that relatives in Europe will help him get a visa before his money runs out. He said he was determined not to go back.
Officials say that 130,000 Iraqis have come to Jordan since the war, but that most have left; about 20,000 remain.
Many Iraqis come simply to unwind from the war and conditions at home, to stock up on cheaper food and medicine, or to gain access to international phone service to make their first calls to relatives abroad since communications were knocked out in the gulf war.
"They are coming here, settling down, waiting to find out what the situation in Iraq will be like" and whether economic sanctions on Iraq will be eased, said Wahil Aljabari, co-owner of Abdun Real Estate, which like other real estate agencies here has been flooded by requests for rentals.
Most of the Iraqis, particularly Assyrians, Chaldeans and other Christians who have relatives abroad, have flocked to Western embassies in search of entry to favored destinations like the United States, Canada or West Europe.
Others wind up at the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. About 1,500 have sought refugee status, said the office's head, Carl Von Seth; 110 have qualified.
For some, it is the last hope of starting a new life. A 32-year-old Assyrian Christian who says he deserted the Iraqi Army during the Iran-Iraq war and helped smuggle others to Iran was turned down for refugee status.
But he shows up at the United Nations office most days, hoping officials will reconsider because he has a family to support and it too afraid of arrest to return to Iraq. "I don't know what I can do," he said, "where I can go."

HEADLINE: Hints of an Ouster Strain Bhutto's Successor

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 12

 BODY:
A year after the abrupt ouster of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, her successor, Nawaz Sharif, is widely believed to be under threat of an equally sudden and unceremonious exit.
Mr. Sharif is spending much of his time this week forcing a smile for photographers and trying to reassure political allies and his opponents that he expects to retain his post for some time. 
 There is no hard evidence to suggest that Mr. Sharif is facing an immediate challenge to his leadership. But that has not stopped Pakistani politicians and journalists from circulating rumors of an imminent military coup tied to the retirement this weekend of the nation's army chief, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, and the furor created by Mr. Sharif's draconian response to a national crime wave.
The response, a constitutional amendment that if adopted in its original form would have given the Prime Minister broad authority to suspend civil rights, was seen as a grab for power at the expense of the military and President Ghulam Ishaq Khan.
The President's influence is never to be underestimated. It was Mr. Khan who took his constitutional authority to the limit last August and dismissed Ms. Bhutto, and it was his allies in Parliament who this year helped to drastically water down the constitutional amendment offered by Mr. Sharif.
While Western and Asian diplomats scoff at the suggestion of an imminent coup -- this is a nation prone to conspiracy theories, they point out -- many agree that Mr. Sharif, whose political prospects seemed bright just a few weeks ago, will not serve out his five-year term.
"I don't think the Prime Minister will fall any time soon," said a Western diplomat in Islamabad, the Pakistani capital. "But if I were him, I certainly would keep looking over my shoulder. The atmospherics now are similar in some ways to what we had in the days before Ms. Bhutto was forced out."
Political figures say Mr. Sharif's future may also be determined by his handling of the scandal surrounding the Pakistani-run Bank of Credit and Commerce International -- specifically, of suggestions of illegal deals between the bank and senior Pakistani military officers.
Aides to the Prime Minister are reported to be advising Mr. Sharif to limit Pakistan's cooperation with investigators in the United States and Britain if only to avoid offending military leaders with close ties to B.C.C.I.
Ms. Bhutto, who is now the opposition leader in Parliament, has seized on the Prime Minister's troubles, accusing the Government of trying to impose "civilian martial law" in the guise of an anti-crime crackdown.
In an interview, Ms. Bhutto said followers of her Pakistan People's Party in the southern province of Sind were being subjected to a harassment campaign by Mr. Sharif's allies that included detention without charge and threats of violence.
On Aug. 4 she led a well-publicized, daylong hunger strike in front of Parliament House in Islamabad to protest the "repression" of the Sharif Government. Her followers sponsored similar hunger strikes in cities across Pakistan.
The scion of a large Pakistani business family and, by most accounts, an able and amiable politician, Mr. Sharif was elected Prime Minister in October and has won praise from the diplomatic corps and business community for a series of ambitious economic changes, including proposals for the privatization of large industries.
His troubles began in late June, when 19 members of 2 families were found slain, their throats cut, in their homes in Punjab Province, where Mr. Sharif had previously been the Chief Minister. No one has suggested any involvement by anyone associated with Mr. Sharif.
The killings remain unsolved and were shocking not only for their savagery -- the victims included nine children -- but also because they occurred in the relatively affluent and peaceful Punjab. The killings came in the midst of a surge in lawlessness in the country and especially in Sind, where scores of people, including Western business executives, have been killed or kidnapped this year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher Amid Speculation on Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher yesterday against most major currencies, as investors weighed the Federal Government's report of a small rise in consumer prices against an expected rise in German interest rates.
Gold prices also moved higher. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid of $357.60 a troy ounce, up $1.10 from late Tuesday. 
 The dollar rose despite speculation that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates after a report that the Consumer Price Index rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in July, keeping the annual inflation rate to just 2.7 percent.
Expectations of lower rates would normally depress the dollar because they make investments in dollar-demoninated securities less attractive to foreign investors.
"I'm a little bit surprised that it's holding up as well as it has," Peter Iversen, a vice president with Shawmut Bank of Boston, said of the dollar. "The numbers this morning would be a good environment for a rate cut in America."
Most attention remained focused on the Bundesbank's council meeting today, at which it will review interest rates.
In New York, the British pound finished at $1.6860, down from $1.6930 Tuesday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.6860, from $1.6938 late Tuesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar was unchanged from Tuesday, closing at 136.40 yen. Later in London, it rose to 136.60 yen, and in New York to 136.50 yen, up from 136.45 yen Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.7375 German marks, up from 1.7325; 1.5222 Swiss francs, up from 1.5145; 5.9095 French francs, up from 5.8960; 1,301.25 Italian lire, up from 1,300, and 1.1432 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1462.
In precious-metals trading, gold for current delivery rose $1.50 a troy ounce, to a late bid of $357.80 on New York's Commodity Exchange. Earlier in London, gold fell to a late bid price of $356.90 a troy ounce, down from $357.00 bid late Tuesday.
Silver for August delivery rose 2.9 cents an ounce, to $3.954 on New York's Comex.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bell Atlantic Plans Early Retirements

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it would offer early retirement to 3,500 employees in a cost-cutting move. The action is similar to one taken earlier this week by the Atlanta-based BellSouth Corporation, which said that 3,100 of its managers would take early retirement. BellSouth said Tuesday that the action would result in a charge of 18 cents a share against third-quarter earnings. 
 The weak economy has hurt the nation's phone companies by cutting the number of new service connections, forcing them to reduce operating costs. Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said employees would be entitled to a full package of increased benefits if they retire by Dec. 15. Others who retired after that date would still receive some increased benefits. Bell Atlantic said 6,300 employees would be eligible to apply for the retirement incentives, and the 3,500 applicants with the most seniority would be selected, Bell Atlantic shares fell 37.5 cents today, to $47.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Business Inventories Decline 0.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Business inventories fell three-tenths of a percent in June, the fifth straight decline, the Government said today in a report that analysts said should mean increased production and jobs as soon as consumers resume spending.
"The minute demand picks up, we will have a spurt in production," said Evelina Tainer, an economist with the First National Bank of Chicago. 
 Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said increased orders would force manufacturers to produce more because not enough goods were stockpiled to satisfy the demand.
The increased production, he added, will benefit the economy because "that will mean more people employed, making more money and spending more money" and thereby stimulating further production.
The Commerce Department report showed that demand was beginning to pick up. Business sales inched up two-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $536.9 billion in June, their third consecutive monthly advance. There were gains of 1.0 percent in May and 1.5 percent in April.
 
Long Stretch of Declines
 The inventory liquidation through June marks the longest stretch of declines since inventories dropped for eight months -- from August 1982 through March 1983 -- as the economy emerged from the 1981-82 recession.
Today's report showed inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $808.9 billion, down from $811.7 billion a month earlier. May's six-tenths of 1 percent shrinkage was even more than the five-tenths of 1 percent reported in the department's initial estimate last month.
The combination of inventory cuts and sales increases resulted in a 1.51 inventory-to-sales ratio, meaning it would take 1.51 months to exhaust the backlog at the June sales pace. The ratio was unchanged from May.
"The 1.51 ratio is considered very comfortable when compared to previous business cycles when it was much higher," Mr. Benz said.
The ratio had jumped to 1.75 during the 1974-75 recession and to 1.74 during the 1981-82 downturn. It averaged 1.49 in 1990.
 
Retail Inventories Off
 Retail inventories in June declined two-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month. Manufacturers trimmed their stockpiles by four-tenths of 1 percent after cutting them by eight-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier. Wholesale inventories dropped four-tenths of 1 percent following a seven-tenths of 1 percent decrease the previous month.
Retail sales, on the other hand, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in June, a much slower pace than the 1.2 percent rate in May. But the Commerce Department said earlier this week that retail sales were up five-tenths of 1 percent in July, for the first three-month string of increases in nearly a year.
Manufacturers' sales also slowed in June, rising three-tenths of 1 percent after a 1.4 percent gain a month earlier. Sales on the wholesale level were flat after slipping one-tenth of 1 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Further Decline Is Expected For Money Market Yields

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
A further decline in short-term money rates is expected by Walter S. Frank, chief economist for the IBC/ Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
"One should expect that because of the Federal Reserve's actions in encouraging lower rates recently, money market yields will decline somewhat further," he said. "The whole bond market is strong, with higher prices and resultant declining yields." 
 Mr. Frank said that in the case of tax-free funds, "there has been very little change over the past week." The supply of municipal issues available to investors has slowed after a deluge a few weeks ago. "The market now is relatively stable," he said.
 
Newcomers Join List
 Total assets of the tax-exempt funds covered by the Money Fund Report rose by $383 million, to $88.4 billion, for the week that ended on Monday. But Mr. Frank said, "Actually, there was an outflow because we added 10 new funds to our list." With the newcomers excluded, there was an outflow from tax-exempt funds of about $80 million.
For tax-exempt funds, the average seven-day simple yield was 3.95 percent, while the seven-day compound yield was 4.03 percent. The 30-day simple yield was 3.89, and the 30-day compound yield was 3.97.
Two New York funds tied in terms of highest yields. They were the Boston Company New York Tax-Free Money Fund and Salomon New York Municipal Money Market, both with a seven-day compound yield of 4.46 percent.
Among Connecticut funds, the highest was reported by the Dreyfus Connecticut Municipal Money Market Fund, with a 4.23 percent yield. In New Jersey, the top-yielding fund continued to be the Calvert Tax-Free Reserve New Jersey Fund, with a 4.88 percent compounded seven-day yield.
For the 15th week, the top-yielding tax-free fund was the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund of Milwaukee, with a seven-day compound yield of 5.03 percent.
 
Taxable Assets Rise
 Assets of the taxable funds rose by $2.7 billion, to $454 billion, in the week. Funds that are newly reporting to Donoghue's accounted for $900 million of that increase. The net comparable inflow, therefore, was $1.8 billion, Mr. Frank said. The average maturity of securities held by the taxable funds rose to 58 days, from 56 days, which he called "a very long maturity."
The seven-day average simple yield for taxable funds dropped by 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.40 percent, and the seven-day compound yield dropped 5 basis points, to 5.54 percent.
For the 30-day period, the simple yield dropped 2 basis points, to 5.44 percent; the 30-day compound yield was also down 2 basis points, to 5.59 percent.
The yield leader among the taxable funds was Merrill Lynch C.M.A. Money Fund, with a compound yield of 6.82 percent for the seven-day period. Mr. Frank said the fund used a different accounting method from that of most other funds reporting to Donoghue's.
Nationwide, The Bank Rate Monitor said that average yields on money-market accounts was 5.18 percent, down from 5.20 percent a week ago, while the average yield of six-month certificates was 5.67 percent, down from 5.76 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Newsprint Mill Given To Workers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company will give their Spruce Falls newsprint mill in northern Ontario to an employee-led group of investors as part of an agreement announced today by the Ontario government.
The agreement also requires Ontario Hydro, the state-owned power company, to buy the mill's hydroelectric power plant for $140 million (Canadian). 
 The two American companies promised to lend the new mill owners $60 million at low interest rates. Ontario Hydro will provide the mill owners 103 megawatts of power for 10 years and $34 million. And Tembec Inc., a Montreal-based paper company, will inject $25 million in equity and loans and $15 million for investment in upgrading the mill in return for a 40 percent stake in the mill.
The agreement came after months of tense negotiations over the fate of the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company Ltd., the joint venture through which the American companies owned the mill and power plant. The mill is the only large employer in Kapuskasing, the market center for the vast but thinly populated region some 500 miles north of Toronto. The power plant is at Smoky Falls on the Mattagami River, about 50 miles farther north.
 
Two-Part Deal
 Kimberly-Clark, which owns 50.1 percent of Spruce Falls and has represented both American companies in the negotiations, proposed last March to give the aging mill to the employees if its previously negotiated preliminary agreement to sell the power plant to Ontario Hydro could be quickly completed. That preliminary argreement included 80 years of free power for the mill.
Darwin E. Smith, Kimberly-Clark's chairman and chief executive, made the proposal as an alternative to his plans to shut down all but the mill's most profitable operations so that it could be easily sold. The cutback would have eliminated 1,200 of the 1,450 jobs by the end of this year.
The deal announced yesterday will also eliminate hundreds of jobs, but it will do so gradually. The business plan worked out by the employee group and Tembec projects a total employment of 800 next year and 670 after 1994. An additional 200 workers will be temporarily employed in construction to modernize the mill.
"I am pleased that the government has been able to bring about a new partnership between business and labor to maintain jobs at the mill," Ontario's Premier, Bob Rae, said in a statement.
Neither Kimberly-Clark nor the Times Company had any comment. The deal will not affect either company financially as both had previously taken write-downs to cover their anticipated costs in disposing of Spruce Falls.
The main sticking point in Mr. Smith's original proposal had been the unwillingness of Ontario Hydro to complete the purchase of the power plant without assurances from the Government that it would receive environmental permits to expand the plant. The utility's only interest in the Smoky Falls plant is as part of broader plans to develop a number of hydroelectric sites on the Mattagami and other northern rivers.
Government officials pressed Mr. Smith to accept partial payment for Smoky Falls, with additional sums to be paid if the environmental reviews approved its expansion. But Mr. Smith refused, saying the original deal was fair. Faced with economic decimation of one of the province's key northern settlements and fierce protests from northern Ontario residents who have contended that their interests were frequently overlooked in Toronto, government officials finally worked out an arrangement that included a promise to pay the utility up to $247 million (Canadian) if the expansion was not approved.
Although unable to put pressure on Mr. Smith to share Ontario Hydro's environmental risk, government officials did persuade Kimberly-Clark and the Times Company to increase their loans for upgrading the mill to $60 million from the $40 million the companies originally offered.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices on Bonds Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Bond prices soared and long-term interest rates fell yesterday to levels not seen since early February, driven by good news on inflation and another sign that the economic recovery may be stalling out.
The two-tenths of a percent increase in the July Consumer Price Index was in line with market expectations, as was the four-tenths of a percent rise in prices excluding food and energy. 
 What encouraged analysts was the fact that when compared to a year ago, inflation is almost certain to decelerate even more over the balance of 1991.
The year-over-year comparisons are expected to be favorable because last year was affected sharply by the surge in oil prices that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August, which caused consumer and wholesale prices to climb.
"The key to this whole situation is that for the 12 months ended in July inflation is up 4.4 percent," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Co. "But by the end of the year, we will be at 3.5 percent. It's not going to be hard to get an improvement from last year."
Richard B. Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said an improvement in inflation is "baked in the cake. You can't help but get good numbers."
 
Consumer Price Outlook
 While consumer prices will come down compared to where they were a year ago, Mr. Berner said the 2.7 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index since the start of 1991 is probably not sustainable.
"But I am not looking for any appreciable increase" from that level, he added.
Sagging 10-day auto sales, which came in at a seasonally adjusted rate of 6.2 million units for early August, also helped to lift bond prices. For the last two reporting periods, vehicle sales had averaged about 6.6 million units.
"The car sales numbers give you a further indication that what we are seeing is not a typical recovery from recession," one bond trader said.
The combination of good inflation news and weak economic data increases the odds that the Federal Reserve Board will move again soon to lower short-term interest rates, analysts said.
"I think the Fed will move again, sometime in early September," Mr. Liro said.
The only way the central bank might not choose to lower the overnight federal funds rate by another quarter point, to 5.25 percent, and to cut its discount rate by half a point, to 5 percent, would be if the August employment report is unusually strong, he said. That report is expected to be released on Sept. 6.
As has been the case for much of the week, market participants said that trading activity was brisk.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the new 8 1/8 percent bonds of August 2021 were offered at a price of 100 22/32 late yesterday, up more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 worth of securities, to yield 8.06 percent, down from 8.16 percent late Tuesday. It is the lowest yield on the benchmark issue since early February.
"You can't rule out bond yields falling below 8 percent," Mr. Berner said. "The tougher question is if yields can fall through the lows we saw when the economy was clearly in recession."
In late February bond yields fell as low as 7.96 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 15/32 late yesterday, up 5/8 of a point, to yield 7.80 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 31/32, up 6/32, to yield 6.33 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates also fell.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.28 percent in late trading, unchanged on the day. But six-month bill rates fell by five basis points, or five one-hundredths of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 5.33 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 10 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.34 percent.
 
Investment-Grade Bonds
 Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a two-part global offering of $1.40 billion worth of securities backed by receipts due on Citicorp credit cards.
The bulk of the issue consists of $1.25 billion worth of five-year notes. The 8 percent securities were priced at $99.48, to yield 8.132 percent, 72.5 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing. These securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The remaining $155 million worth of securities carry an 8.25 percent coupon and were priced at $99.14, to yield 8.465 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 7 7/8 percent five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
UBS Securities Inc. acted as lead manager for the transaction. It is the first time the Swiss-based firm has acted as lead underwriter on an asset-backed transaction.
In other developments, Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager on an offering of $125 million worth of 10-year first mortgage bonds for Baltimore Gas & Electric.
The non-callable securities, which mature Aug. 15, 2001, carry a coupon of 8 3/8 percent and were priced at $99.50, to yield 8.45 percent, 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most long-term issues rose by as much as 3/4 of a point, traders said. Prices of most shorter-term maturities rose by about 1/4 of a point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/4 of a point.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Route Sales Put T.W.A. in Black

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it earned $336.9 million in the second quarter, mainly because its sale of prized London routes erased what otherwise would have been a loss.
T.W.A. said its $53 million operating loss was more than offset when the carrier sold London routes out of New York, Los Angeles and Boston to American Airlines for $445 million. 
 T.W.A.'s earnings for the quarter compared with net profits of $103.4 million for the period a year earlier.
The privately owned airline is considered one of the weakest and most heavily indebted United States carriers. T.W.A.'s owner, the financier Carl C. Icahn, recently struck a deal with creditors that gave the airline more time to get its finances in order.
T.W.A. said revenues were $926.9 million in the second quarter of 1991 and $1.23 billion a year earlier. For the first six months of 1991, T.W.A. reported revenues of $1.75 billion, down from $2.24 billion for that period in 1990.
T.W.A., based in Mount Kisco, N.Y., attributed its most recent troubles to the Persian Gulf crisis and the recession, which cut deeply into passenger traffic. Airlines have since lured many travelers back, but they did so by cutting some ticket prices so low it has been difficult to show much of a profit.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Valuing Stocks In Terms of Gold

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE American stock market finally reached a new high this year, breaking the record set 15 years ago. But even now, prices are only 11 percent above the peak in 1976.
If that paragraph sounds absurd, it is because you are no doubt used to thinking of stock prices in terms of dollars. In terms of gold, it is true. 
 As measured in gold terms, stocks set their previous record on Aug. 31, 1976, when an ounce of gold would buy just a bit more than the dollar value of the Standard & Poor's 500. On that date, the S.& P. stood at 102.91, while gold was at $104.38 an ounce.
That record stood for nearly 15 years, until it fell in February and an ounce of gold was no longer enough to buy the S.& P. 500, a relationship that had not existed since the ownership of gold by Americans became legal at the end of 1974. Yesterday, the S.& P. 500 stood at 389.90, while gold was just $357.80.
The S.& P. 500 is cited in the above example because it is the broadest of the standard market indexes. The relationship is even more stark in terms of the Dow Jones industrial average. Because that average has risen less than the S.& P. 500 in the last 15 years, it remains, in gold terms, 10 percent below its level of August 1976.
Whether that is at all relevant depends on whether the idea that gold is money has died. It is certainly on the rocks, as the death of gold as an investment has been widely heralded. To hear those most bearish on gold tell it, gold is just another commodity, one with production in excess of real demand for uses in jewelry and industrial processes. To make matters worse, better mining techniques threaten to expand the gold supply.
But gold still has its adherents, even if markets have not been friendly to them. To J. David Edwards, the chief investment officer for United Services Advisors, a mutual fund company whose largest funds specialize in gold stocks, the high value of stocks in relation to gold shows just how undervalued gold has become.
"You can very easily say that gold has not kept up its purchasing power," he said yesterday. "But I take the contrarian approach, that there is a tremendous catch-up potential in the value of bullion."
Gold prices surged in the late 1970's amid concern about inflation, then stagnated in the 1980's, when the threat of inflation receded. Stock prices suffered in the inflationary times and boomed in the 1980's.
Now, with the biggest problem facing the financial system appearing to be declining values, there would seem to be no need for a hedge against inflation. But William H. Tehan, a money manager for P. R. Herzig & Company and a man with a good record on gold, argues the opposite.
"We are now in a credit and asset deflation," he said yesterday. "It will be more bullish for gold than was the period of inflation. When capital flees from credit, it seeks the protection of real money."
James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, is a bull on gold and a bear on stocks. Both opinions, he readily acknowledges, have been wrong of late.
"It seems to me that the low price of gold is symptomatic of a state of mind in financial markets," he said yesterday. "If caution were a stock, it would be making new lows. If speculation were a stock, it would be making new highs."
To Mr. Grant, that is an unhealthy situation. But he concedes that even when fear rises these days, gold does not seem to benefit.
"For a bull on gold, it is quite demoralizing to see what happened in Hong Kong," he said, referring to the brief run on several banks last week, in the wake of the worldwide seizure of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. "They had a run on banks, but they did not buy enough gold to run the price up."

HEADLINE: Helping Hands Await Immigrants in Ontario

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Toronto Welcome House, an Ontario agency helping 40,000 immigrants a year get jobs and settle into this city's ethnic enclaves, is something of a family enterprise for the Xus, formerly of Beijing.
Both Xu Huilian, who holds a doctorate in plant science, and his wife, Xu Liwei, who has a master's in economics, are using it to improve their English and learn computer skills. 
 While they attend classes in a four-story building in downtown Toronto, their 3-year-old daughter, Xu Xianhuizi, nicknamed Chieko, romps in the nursery, getting her first exposure to English.
Mr. Xu, Mrs. Xu and other classmates, including Zerihun Tensa, who worked as an accountant in his native Ethiopia, Susana Arenas, a former industrial production superviser in Peru, and Mathavan Nallalingan, a bookbinder from Sri Lanka, are all hoping to be able to send off their first English resumes soon.
Forty years ago, three-quarters of the people who lived in metropolitan Toronto were of British origin. Today, 40 percent of the population are immigrants, and more than a quarter can speak neither English nor French. About 20 percent are what Canadians call visible minorities.
The liberalization of immigration policies since the 1960's has not only transformed cities like Toronto, often called Canada's New York, but also challenged Government policies of trying to absorb hundreds of thousands of new citizens a year with a miminum of friction.
Toronto's claim to one of the best records on race relations of any major North American city is owed in large measure to creative absorption programs like Welcome House, which have been studied by American municipalities, including New York City, and by representatives of the Governments of France, Britain, Sweden and Norway.
For the newcomers, the 40 Welcome House settlement officers in downtown Toronto and 55 other mainly contract employees at four other sites in the metropolitan area offer a variety of counseling services, like advice on housing, the job market and schools and on how to set up a business, cope with taxes, and obtain welfare or a driver's license. In addition, there are the language and computer-training classes and the day-care center.
The settlement officers work closely with organizations in the local ethnic communities to help the new arrivals assimilate.
"It's an example of a government-community partnership working well, for everyone's benefit," said Shamira Madhany, senior manager of the program, herself from India by way of Uganda.
Ethnic community organizations are a much more important part of local life here than in the United States. Canada has always maintained greater emphasis on maintaining the cultural distinctiveness of its immigrant groups, whereas people of various nationalities entering the United States tend to be absorbed more quickly into the great American personality. It is what demographers call the "salad bowl" as opposed to the "melting pot."
While apparently effective, the Toronto Welcome House network is not cheap. The Ontario provincial government is spending $2.2 million on its administration this year, up from $1.9 million last year.
But Elaine Ziemba, the official in charge of the entire program, makes no apologies. She is a 49-year-old former social worker brought into Ontario's first Socialist government last year by Premier Bob Rae.
As Minister of Citizenship with Responsibility for Human Rights, Disability Issues, Senior Citizens and Race Relations, Mrs. Ziemba has the longest official title of any of the 30 provincial ministers.
"Compared with what the new citizens will eventually give back to this country in terms of living up to their full potential, that money is really very little," she said.
Mrs. Ziemba added that the agency's programs "are helping people become extremely good citizens, giving them the tools to participate fully in Ontario life."

HEADLINE: Will Diversity Subvert Vision In a New York City District?

SERIES: Neighborhood Politics: Choosing the Council -- An occasional look at the races for New York's new City Council.

BYLINE: By E. R. SHIPP

 BODY:
As much as any of New York City's 51 new Council seats, the five miles and many neighborhoods of District 7 illustrate the difficulty of mandating diversity and matching a seat to a particular racial or ethnic group.
The complexities come in the form of more than 66,000 registered voters of all stripes -- poor blacks in the public housing projects of Manhattan Valley; upper-middle-class blacks and whites who own homes in a historic section of Harlem; Irish and Jewish New Yorkers who fled to Inwood when blacks began moving into the area in the 1950's and 60's, and a relatively recent wave of immigrants, primarily Hispanic, in Washington Heights.
 
New Yorkers of All Persuasions
 When the New York City Districting Commission created District 7, its members expected that it would be represented by a black who would replace the white incumbent whose district was being folded into the new tuning-forked shape creation. 
 But now that the campaign has begun, many are not so sure. The very diversity of the neighborhoods the commission linked together may undermine its vision of a Council on which New Yorkers of all persuasions -- but especially black, Hispanic and Asian residents -- would be able to elect someone who looked like them.
"You have a lot of Dominicans in the Seventh," said Selwyn Carter, a political analyst for the Community Service Society, a nonprofit advocacy organization. "They could be feeling that Seven is also theirs, just as the blacks in Harlem feel that Seven is theirs and the whites in the northern part feel it's theirs. And each of them, you could argue, has a legitimate claim."
In district after district, neighborhood after neighborhood, the way the diversity translates into ballots cast is proving to be more complicated than was foreseen even by the commission. How the varying groups within District 7 come together or compete in the new setting will make a major statement about how politics is being practiced in the city.
District 7 is a particularly pointed example. Forty-two percent of its 151,428 inhabitants are black, 38 percent Hispanic, 17 percent white and 2 percent Asian.
Eight men and women have announced their intentions to run, including Republican and Conservative Party candidates who are unopposed. In the Democratic primary, scheduled for Sept. 12, there could be one white man -- Stanley E. Michels; one Hispanic man -- Jaime T. Garcia; two black men -- C. Vernon Mason and Keith S. Mitchell; and two black women -- Peggy M. Shepard and Frankye Graves. It is a situation that could so splinter the vote that many politicians and residents see it leading to the election of Mr. Michels.
Mr. Michels represented much of the district for years in the old District 6, and many white and Hispanic residents who are following the race say they are happy with him.
But many blacks, previously part of the old District 8, have been represented by blacks and would see it as a step backward if a white won the seat. Dominicans, who are growing more politically astute, are demanding a voice. "We have nothing in common, absolutely nothing -- except that we are human, of course," one resident, Michael Adams, said of District 7.
Ask residents about what pulls their neighborhoods together. The first reaction of a black man living in a residential hotel on 126th Street, a Dominican woman living on 150th Street and a white man living in an Irish stronghold near 215th Street is that not much does.
 
From Odors to Stolen Flowers
 What is on their minds ranges from the stop sign that everyone ignores at 126th and Broadway to the overcrowded schools in Inwood; from the unreliable A train once celebrated by Duke Ellington to the store of empty apartments that some landlords hold on to in hopes of converting their buildings to cooperatives or condominiums. They are concerned about foul odors emanating from a sewage-treatment plant on the Hudson River and a crematorium on Riverside Drive. And, of course, the flowers being stolen from window boxes in Hamilton Heights.
Blacks, especially, complain that when the area changed, stores went from white ownership to Dominican and Korean, bypassing them.
For all their differences, there is at least one common concern: drugs and crime that drive many of the law-abiding citizens off the streets and behind locked doors at sundown.
"I couldn't see any other issue that's bigger than that," said John Galvin, an Irishman who has lived his entire life in Inwood. He was born on Post Avenue.
"At nighttime I wouldn't walk down Post Avenue now if you paid me," he said the other day as he drank beer in a neighborhood bar. "It's a bad neighborhood. It's drugs down there. Anytime there's drugs, there's crime. They go together hand and foot. I'm afraid."
Until 30 years ago, this part of upper Manhattan was predominantly white -- Irish and Jewish, in the main. Blacks remember the pride they had in moving up the hill from central Harlem into neighborhoods like Sugar Hill and Washington Heights.
Calvin Copeland, who owns one of the area's most popular restaurants, on 145th Street, remembers moving to 150th Street more than 35 years ago. His was the second black family in a building of 64 apartments.
"I would say that after a matter of a year, there was only one white family left," he said. "Everybody moved out like we had leprosy."
As newer waves of immigrants, most of them Dominican, move into the area, the older residents feel squeezed. The streets teem with people all hours of the day and night: some of them seeking a respite from apartments in which families live doubled and tripled up, others involved in drugs.
Ybelice Simancas's family moved to Washington Heights from the Dominican Republic 19 years ago. Now, Ms. Simancas, who works in a luncheonette in a bingo parlor on 181st Street, said: "It's not a good neighborhood. I'm planning to move soon."
Tom Mullany, who has lived in Inwood since 1963, is also thinking of leaving.
"That's the big question for the first time in my life," Mr. Mullany, a telephone company executive, said. "I've lived in New York City since I was born, never left, never lived any other place. And in the last year, year and a half, I've never seen my city change as much. Just a general letting things get out of control."
 
One Problem: Name Recognition
 Though the campaign season has just begun, it is already evident that any candidate will have an enormous task trying to appeal to everyone in the district. Name recognition alone can be a problem.
Democrats outnumber Republicans 50 to 1, according to the Republican candidate for the seat, Ronald Perry. But nearly half the voting-age population never even bothers to vote -- people like Michael Layton, who lives in the Grant housing project on Broadway at 125th Street.
"The system is not working as far as I'm concerned," said Mr. Layton, a Vietnam veteran and unemployed construction worker, as he played cards with neighbors in a city park. "People lose hope when they don't see nothing changing."
Up in Inwood, Mr. Mullany, a former candidate for public office himself, was surprised to know that there were more than two candidates in the race: Mr. Michels and Mr. Mason, a lawyer who often takes on controversial causes, from the Tawana Brawley case to the defense of a City College professor under fire for racially charged remarks he made in a recent speech.
"Who is Peggy Shepard?" Mr. Mullany asked.
On 145th Street, Crosby Barnes, a man who seems to be a walking encyclopedia on the area, could barely place Mr. Michels. "His name, I've heard it once or twice," he said.
But everyone, he and Mr. Mullany agreed, has heard of Mr. Mason, a man whose very name frightens many whites. Ms. Shepard, a state housing official who has been active in local community affairs for years and is a Democratic district leader, said that Mr. Mason had become "the Willie Horton in the race" -- a black figure viewed as menacing by whites who will vote for the candidate most likely to keep him from obtaining office. Neither Mr. Mason nor Mr. Michels responded to messages left with their offices.
Still, Mr. Barnes said, many blacks see Mr. Mason as a champion of blacks facing all kinds of injustice.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rose 0.2% in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Held in check by the sharpest drop in grocery costs in nearly four decades, consumer prices rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today.
The slight rise helped to hold the 1991 inflation rate so far to 2.7 percent, less than half last year's pace of 6.1 percent. 
 The small, seasonally adjusted rise in the Consumer Price Index was viewed as both a symptom of the recession and a necessary ingredient of a sustained recovery. It followed an identical rise in June.
The financial markets, which expected good news on inflation, were encouraged, and bond prices soared to levels not seen since early February. [Page D17.] The Dow Jones industrial average rose sharply early in the day when the data came out, although it fell back later to close 3.35 points down. [Page D10.]
 
1.2% Drop in Grocery Prices
 The July data largely reflected a 1.2 percent drop in grocery prices, the largest one-month decline since 1953. The grocery numbers included a 12.7 percent drop in prices for fresh vegetables as crops rebounded from earlier weather problems.
In addition, energy prices fell for the seventh time in eight months.
Prices excluding the volatile food and energy items -- considered a good measure of core inflation -- rose four-tenths of 1 percent, the same rate as in June.
A senior Bush Administration official said subdued inflation would revive consumer spending and lower interest rates, but some private forecasters warn that the economy could suffer a relapse.
"Inflation prospects are terrific," said Robert Brusca, an economist at Nikko Securities Company International Inc. But he added, "We do not have a recovery in the bag."
Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher said: "Very low inflation is a welcome development for consumer purchasing power. This news creates the right environment for possible additional reductions in market interest rates."
 
Fed Would Have Leeway
 Dampened inflation gives policy makers at the Federal Reserve, who are scheduled to meet privately Tuesday, leeway to stimulate economic growth with lower interest rates if necessary, economists said. The last move by the Fed to push short-term interest rates down came Aug. 6, with a quarter of a percentage point cut in the Federal Funds rate.
Despite subdued price rises, the Labor Department also said today that Americans' purchasing power -- as measured by inflation-adjusted average weekly earnings -- slipped 1.4 percent in July after rising nine-tenths of 1 percent in June. The drop came from a large decrease in average hours worked and a slight dip in average hourly earnings.
In another report, the Commerce Department said business sales in June rose a weak two-tenths of 1 percent. Businesses still managed to shrink their inventories by three-tenths of 1 percent. That should pave the way for new orders, increased production and job gains when consumer demand strengthens.
Two private surveys showed business executives were not becoming more optimistic about the economy.
The United States Chamber of Commerce said only 40 percent of 7,057 businesses surveyed in August believed the economy is headed up, compared with 46 percent in June.
 
Optimism Index Slips
 The National Federation of Independent Business, which represents smaller businesses, said its optimism index slipped to 100 in July from 101 three months earlier.
The July inflation report reflected improving fruit and vegetable crops following severe weather earlier in the year. The price of both lettuce and tomatoes fell more than 20 percent for the month.
The various changes left the Consumer Price Index, before adjusting for seasonal variations, at 136.2 in July, compared with 130.4 a year earlier. That means a market basket of goods and services costing $136.20 last month would have cost $130.40 in July 1990.

HEADLINE: Domestic Auto Sales Fall 9.4%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The recovering United States automotive market stumbled in early August, as sales of cars and trucks made in North America fell 9.4 percent from levels a year earlier.
Moreover, the seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales from Aug. 1 to 10 was 6.2 million, down from 6.7 million in late July and 6.9 million for all of July. The rate for the year so far has been 6.2 million, including the dismal sales of late winter and early spring. 
 Analysts said the expiration of aggressive sales incentives in late July might have contributed to the decline. Scott Merlis, an automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, also noted that relatively weak July payroll statistics might have been reflected in the decline in automotive buying.
Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, called early August sales a disappointment. "The latest sales pace only confirms that this will be a slow and bumpy recovery for the auto sector," he said in a statement.
 
'Steeper Than Expected'
 Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, said that after two months of stronger results, "we've all been expecting a down-draft, but this was a little steeper than expected."
Mr. Heinbach speculated that the Big Three's sales to daily rental fleets in June and July had bolstered total vehicle sales during that period, but that the fleets had now completed their purchases of 1991 models, so overall sales became weaker.
Because auto makers have been building cars and trucks at a conservative pace, dealer inventories are at a six-year low, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry newsletter. Thus, some sales may have been lost because of shortages of specific vehicles, Mr. Merlis said. Still, auto makers should have less trouble than in previous years in clearing the way for new models. The 1992 cars are already being shipped.
In any case, the latest 10-day results do not necessarily portend a trend, analysts said.
In the first 10 days of August, the three United States and six Japanese auto makers assembling vehicles in North America posted sales of 223,494, down 9.4 percent from 246,708 a year earlier. Car sales were 139,643, down 7.4 percent from last year's 150,877, and light-truck sales, which include mini-vans and sport utility vehicles, were 83,851, down 12.5 percent from last year's 95,831.
The General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, sold 59,935 cars in the 10-day period, or 8.7 percent fewer than a year earlier, and 34,790 light trucks, a drop of 16.7 percent. G.M.'s Buick and Oldsmobile divisions posted higher sales, however, partly because of strong demand for two redesigned, higher-priced models, the Buick Park Avenue and Oldsmobile 98. G.M.'s Pontiac division showed the biggest sales decline.
The Ford Motor Company sold 40,318 cars, a drop of 16.6 percent, and 27,564 light trucks, a drop of 19.5 percent. Ford's Tempo compact car, Club Wagon van and Explorer sport-utility vehicle were among the very few models to post gains.
Sales for the Chrysler Corporation were estimated by Ward's at 14,300 cars and 18,200 light trucks. Chrysler discloses its sales on a monthly basis.
The Honda Motor Company was the only member of the Japanese Big Three to show an increase over last year. Honda's car sales rose 60.8 percent, to 12,245 cars, in early August. Honda said the increase might reflect pent-up demand for the Accord model, which was in short supply in July.
The Nissan Motor Company's car sales fell 13.4 percent, to 1,704, while truck sales rose 3.3 percent, to 2,372. The Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales fell 13.8 percent, to 7,391.
The Mazda Motor Corporation's car sales fell 31.4 percent, to 1,114. Meanwhile, the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's car sales more than doubled, to 1,814, and sales of Subaru cars, which are made by Fuji Heavy Industries, rose 47.6 percent, to 822.

HEADLINE: BANKS IN U.S. SHUN A LOAN TO MOSCOW

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
American banks have not put up any money to finance Soviet purchases of American grain, despite the Bush Administration's efforts to facilitate such loans.
No American banks participated last month in a $600 million loan to the Soviet Union for grain purchases, even though the United States guaranteed repayment of almost all of the principal and half of the interest, banking and grain industry executives said. 
 Despite the Government loan guarantees, American bankers said that they were worried about the declining ability of the Soviet Union to pay its bills and that their own financial problems had limited their ability to make loans to anyone. Eventually four European banks stepped forward to make the loans, reportedly under pressure from their governments. The loans have an adjustable interest rate that is initially set slightly below 7 percent.
 
Believed to Be a First
 Agriculture Department and banking officials said they could not recall a previous instance in which a major guaranteed agricultural-export loan had been claimed entirely by foreign banks.
The absence of American banks is likely to embarrass the Administration, which certified the Soviet Union as creditworthy when it arranged the guarantee. It also spells further trouble for the crippled and shrinking Soviet economy, which desperately needs foreign loans and investment to try to make itself competitive in world markets. In essence, the European banks are charging the Soviets the equivalent of an interest rate exceeding 20 percent on the very small portion of the loan that is not guaranteed by the United States.
The situation could be a vicious circle for the Soviet Union if a disappearance of loans deprives it of the foreign currency needed for imports, which are needed to keep the economy running and creditworthy.
"Declining industrial imports feed back into declining output," said Joseph S. Berliner, a professor emeritus of economics at Brandeis University who has been studying the Soviet economy since 1950.
Some American banks did discuss the loans with Soviet officials, but the Americans wanted even higher interest rates than what the Europeans got, bank executives said. Now, if the Soviet Union defaults on these loans, American taxpayers will end up reimbursing the European banks.
 
A Sharp Increase
 Banking officials said that for a $1 billion guaranteed loan last year the Soviets paid three-eighths of a percentage point above the short-term rate at which banks borrow from each other. For the $600 million this summer, the margin increased to almost one percentage point, so that the profit margin for banks between their rough cost of borrowing money and the interest rate they charge has nearly doubled. The six-month international interbank lending rate is currently at 5.94 percent, and the Soviet loans carry an interest rate adjusted every six months to account for changes in this rate.
The higher rates reflect a calculation by the banks that the Soviets might not repay the loans. If the return on the guaranteed portion of the loan is calculated at the current rate for comparable borrowing by the United States Government and if the considerable extra processing costs of agricultural loans are excluded, then the Soviet Union is paying an interest rate of more than 20 percent on the 2 percent of principal and several percentage points of interest that it is obtaining on the strength of its own creditworthiness.
Government-guaranteed loans for countries buying American agricultural products are not new; nor is allowing the Soviet Union to use this financing mechanism when it buys American corn and wheat.
But after the United States found itself stuck in recent years with $2 billion in guaranteed agricultural loans to Iraq, Congress imposed tighter rules last year on who was eligible for such guarantees. The new rules require that the President certify the creditworthiness of any nation before it can qualify for the borrowing program, but the rules set no guidelines for determining creditworthiness.
Therein lies a problem. Although the Soviet Union has paid back other such grain loans, its fast-deteriorating economy has led many in Congress and outside to see it as a problem credit. But the Bush Administration wants dearly to promote continued Soviet purchases of American agricultural products. In the weeks leading up to last month's economic summit meeting, the Administration was also seeking ways to help the Soviet Union even while opposing any program of direct government aid from the leading industrial nations.
 
Giving Guarantees
 Over some opposition, President Bush granted a Soviet request for $1.5 billion in loan guarantees on June 11, certifying at the time that the Soviet Union was creditworthy.
The first $600 million worth of guarantees was given to Moscow immediately, with another $500 million scheduled for October and a final installment of $400 million planned for February. The guarantees state that if the Soviet Union defaults on a loan covered by the program, the United States will repay 98 percent of the principal plus the first 4.5 percentage points of interest on that 98 percent of the principal.
But American banking and Agriculture Department officials say the Soviets quickly ran into difficulties in finding banks willing to lend.
"There is significant risk that's uncovered" by the government guarantee, which includes only half of the interest payments on such a deal, said a top trade-finance executive at a large American bank. "None of us want to smash our balance sheets."
 
Request Reportedly Denied
 
 
Soviet officials asked for the guarantee to be raised from 98 percent, which is the standard for countries with credit problems, to 100 percent, said an Agriculture Department official who insisted on anonymity.
The Administration turned down the request. "As long as you're able to place those loans, albeit with European banks in this case, there's no inclination to raise it," the senior Administration official said.
Executives at several American banks said they were reluctant to lend not only because of concerns about creditworthiness, but also because of the heavy paperwork involved in government guaranteed loans, their own weak capital bases, and a desire to limit their already considerable holdings of similar loans to other countries.
American banks lent money to the Soviet Union under a $1 billion export loan guarantee last year. But continued upheaval in the Soviet Union has led to growing worries about a possible default. "Nobody would like to explain to anyone, including your own kids, why you didn't anticipate something drastic would happen," an American bank official said.
The American branches of four European banks agreed to lend the money instead. The Banque Nationale de Paris agreed to lend nearly $300 million; London-based Barclays Bank, $150 million; Rabobank Nederland of Utrecht, the Netherlands, $100 million; and Paris-based Banque Indosuez promised about $60 million, officials at those banks said.
 
Paid Out Periodically
 The loans have a maturity of three years and are disbursed periodically as each shipment of American agricultural products is sent. Because pieces of these loans are often resold to other banks, American banks could later participate in the loans indirectly if they change their minds.
The Agriculture Department does not receive the paperwork from banks until after the grain is actually shipped, and department officials said they did not know who had made the loans.
American bankers contend that the European banks came under pressure from their governments to make the loans. Western European governments have been more worried than Washington about the potential for civil disorder and large-scale emigration from the Soviet Union, and have been lending the nation huge sums at concessionary rates.
European bankers mostly deny that political considerations played a role. "This was an independent assessment," said Sharon C. Delezenski, the senior vice president in charge of trade finance and commodities and Wall Street lending at Banque Nationale de Paris, which is owned by the French Government.
But another European banker took a different view. "I was mildly surprised that anybody would take Soviet risk," said the banker, who insisted on anonymity. "It's not an obvious risk to take."
The United States loan guarantees also have the unusual effect of subsidizing European banks in their efforts to establish relationships with American exporters, he added.
Finding lenders for the remaining $900 million may prove difficult if conditions in the Soviet Union do not improve, an American bank official said. Ms. Delezenski said her bank had agreed to lend no more than $300 million of the entire $1.5 billion package, only to find that Moscow wanted to use almost all of this money for the first installment.
Some Latin American countries had trouble borrowing even with guarantees from the United States when their debt problems were most severe in the early 1980's.
Some members of Congress were critical of the guarantees before they were given in June, and the role of the European banks is likely to draw criticism when Congress returns next month from its recess.
"This shows what we were saying all along -- they're not creditworthy, and this is a giveaway to the Soviet Government and a taking away from the American taxpayer," said an aide to Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey.
But a senior Administration official responded that the participation of European banks showed that the Soviet Union could still borrow if it paid a high enough interest rate.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Awaiting the Next Big Bank Merger

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
WITH the BankAmerica Corporation having agreed to buy the Security Pacific Corporation, attention in California banking circles is shifting to a deal that has not yet happened: an acquisition of First Interstate Bancorp by Wells Fargo & Company.
Wells Fargo and First Interstate have not given any firm indication that they are interested in a merger, and it is unclear whether the two companies have even held any discussions. But many analysts, investors and industry executives say a deal is almost a sure thing, if not immediately then in the long run, in response to BankAmerica's agreement, announced Monday, to buy Security Pacific for $4.4 billion in stock. 
 Wells Fargo and First Interstate, California's third- and fourth-largest banking companies, need the economies of scale that would come from a merger in order to compete with the combination of BankAmerica and Security Pacific, the state's two largest banks. That, at least, is the reasoning offered by proponents of such a deal.
But any deal would hold perils as well as opportunities for both Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, and First Interstate, based in Los Angeles.
First Interstate has been plagued for years by a staggering level of troubled loans, and despite vigorous efforts by the company to identify and work out the problems, it is far from certain that there are not more nasty surprises lurking in its portfolio. Last month First Interstate reported a loss for the second quarter of $80.3 million, in contrast to a profit of $95.1 million in the 1990 period. The loss was caused primarily by a $295 million provision for loan losses, $159.8 million more than the company was forced to set aside for loan losses in the first quarter.
Wells Fargo is stronger financially and is considered to be better managed. But there have been troubling signs in the last few months that its loan portfolio, too, could hold some big problems. In the second quarter, the company had a sharp rise in problem loans, many of them to companies that did leveraged buyouts in recent years, and it also remains vulnerable to further weakening in the California commercial real estate market.
As a result of the loan problems, Wells Fargo's earnings fell sharply in the second quarter, to $14 million, or 21 cents a share, from $232 million, or $4.40 a share, in the second quarter of 1990.
Still, analysts think the logic of a deal will ultimately propel the companies together.
"It's a transaction that makes a tremendous amount of sense," said Thaddeus W. Paluszek, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company.
The main impetus to a transaction would be the chance to cut operating costs by reducing corporate staffs and eliminating redundant branches and back-office operations like data processing. The merger of BankAmerica and Security Pacific, for example, would allow the banks to cut $1 billion a year from operating expenses over the next three years, the companies projected; the savings in a Wells Fargo-First Interstate combination would be lower but still substantial, analysts said.
 Carl E. Reichardt, Wells Fargo's chairman and chief executive, has a reputation as the industry's most aggressive cost-cutter. (He once eliminated the budget for the Christmas tree on an executive floor at the company's headquarters.) First Interstate, despite considerable progress in the last year under its chairman, Edward M. Carson, remains highly inefficient by comparsion.
Wells Fargo, with assets of $55 billion, spent $940 million on general and administrative expenses in the first six months of the year, said James Hanbury, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company. First Interstate, with assets of $50 billion, spent $1.3 billion in the same period.
A deal in which Wells Fargo bought First Interstate would also give Wells Fargo First Interstate's 14-state, 1,051-branch network throughout the West and Southwest, instantly making the combined institution a dominant player not just in California, but in Texas, Arizona, Nevada, Washington, Oregon and other states. Big banking companies increasingly believe they must have huge regional networks to compete as banking slowly becomes a national business.
Unless it is battered by loan losses, something most analysts do not expect, Wells Fargo would have little trouble financing an acquisition. Its stock, which closed yesterday at $77.625, up $1.125, is well above the book value of $58 a share, meaning that buying First Interstate with stock would be financially attractive to Wells Fargo. First Interstate closed yesterday at $35, a share, down 12.5 cents;at that price the company would be valued at about $2.1 billion.
What remains unclear to outsiders is the chemistry between the companies, and in particular between Mr. Reichardt at Wells Fargo and Mr. Carson at First Interstate. Mr. Carson seems to admire Mr. Reichardt's style, at least as far as it entails running an efficient operation. But more than one bank merger has failed to come off when the top executives involved could not agree on their respective roles or on the roles of their respective management teams.
