HEADLINE: Salomon Violations Detailed

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Salomon Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it had provided the Government with evidence that it had violated rules governing bids for Treasury bonds at the April auction. The disclosure followed its report last week of transgressions at three other auctions.
The firm also said that it had routinely overstated the quantities of Treasury securities it traded so that it could increase its chance of being allocated enough of each new issue to satisfy all its customers. It pledged to discontinue the practice. 
 Salomon also said a committee of independent members of its board would be appointed shortly to review the situation.
 
Facing Lawsuits
 Salomon already faces private lawsuits from traders in securities markets who contend that the leverage Salomon had over bond prices as a result of its activities cost them money.
Salomon noted yesterday that it and various employees also faced possible criminal fines and sanctions. Under the securities laws, the sanctions might include suspending or banning Salomon from acting as a broker-dealer or primary dealer in Treasury securities, but there is no indication that the Government currently plans such a step.
Salomon is one of the three largest firms in the Treasury securities market, where $115 billion worth of issues are traded daily. At the end of last year, $2.2 trillion in Treasury securities were outstanding.
 
$1 Billion Practical Joke
 The announcement included surprising details on the extent of the previously disclosed violations, including an admission that a managing director whom it did not name caused the firm to make an unauthorized $1 billion bid in the name of a customer at the February auction as part of a practical joke on a fellow employee. Salomon said the managing director had been suspended.
Four men were suspended last week. They were reported to be Paul Mozer, the head of government bond trading; Thomas Murphy, a top deputy; Christopher Fitzmaurice, a trader, and Henry Epstein, a clerk. A Salomon spokesman declined last night to confirm the names of the suspended employees, but said that no new suspensions had taken place.
Yesterday's disclosures came on a day when Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told reporters in Washington that the actions of Salomon's powerful bond trading unit demonstrated that the "honor system" was not an adequate method of policing securities markets. The government securities market is far more lightly regulated than the stock market or commodities markets.
Some of the details in yesterday's announcement indicated that Salomon's bidding violations did not leave the firm controlling as large a percentage of the securities sold at the recent auctions as had been rumored. For example, although some reports suggested the company ended up with as much as 85 percent of the two-year notes sold at the May auction, Salomon said yesterday that the firm acquired 44 percent of the issue, just nine percentage points more than the allowable limit.
Salomon said two actions put it over the 35 percent limit in May. It bid $2 billion for a customer and then repurchased $500 million of the notes at the auction price; also, it held $497 million of the notes on a when-issued basis before the auction began. Those purchases came on top of its routine bid for the maximum 35 percent.
 
Questions on May Auction
 That part of the report did not address one of the most persistent rumors surrounding the May auction, namely that Salomon acted in concert with outside investors to control a much larger percentage of the notes and squeeze prices upward. Dealers said the price impact of Salomon's activity seemed more evident in May than in the other months in which, according to yesterday's report, Salomon actually went further over the 35 percent limit.
In December 1990, for example, Salomon bid the maximum 35 percent for its own account and, without authorization, $1 billion using a customer's name, leaving it with 46 percent of the four-year notes.
In February, Salomon submitted three bids for 35 percent of the five-year notes, two of which were unauthorized bids in customers' names. Salomon said yesterday it ended up with 57 percent of the notes. Salomon said that it ended up with 30.2 percent of the 30-year bonds that were involved in the practical-joke incident.
In the April auction of five-year notes, the firm exceeded the 35 percent limit by bidding the full amount for its own account and repurchasing $600 million worth of notes from a customer who wanted $1.9 billion of them. Salomon had bid for $2.5 billion in the customer's name to make sure that it would be allocated enough to fill the order.
Following Salomon's announcement, Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance, likened the firm's actions to "high-stakes games of 'Jeopardy' being played with investors' and taxpayers' money." His subcommittee will be drafting proposed changes in securities laws this fall, which may include tighter rules for the auction and trading of government securities.
Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. W. Wrightson & Associates, said, "That kind of arrangement sounds almost Japanese," referring to recent scandals at Japanese securities houses.
Indeed, Wall Street is wondering whether the Government's desire to have Japan do more to regulate its markets may encourage it to come down harder on Salomon than it might otherwise have.
Questions about how far up the chain of command the problems ran remain unanswered. Salomon conceded in yesterday's announcement that John H. Gutfreund, its chairman and chief executive; Thomas W. Strauss, its president, and John W. Meriwether, a vice chairman, had all been informed by April of at least one transgression -- an unauthorized bid in February. But a decision to tell the Government was not carried out. Indeed, the Government was not told about that or any other rule violation until Aug. 9, when the Government was also told about the delay in reporting, Salomon said yesterday.

HEADLINE: Banking's Ultimate Goal;
Mergers Set Stage for National Operations And Perhaps a Healthier Financial System

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The recent spate of bank mergers, involving 5 of the country's 10 largest banks, has done little to correct one of the American banking system's greatest weaknesses -- the lack of geographic diversification that leaves banking companies vulnerable to regional economic downturns.
The weakness of New England's banking system and the problems before that in Texas have been widely attributed to a patchwork of state and Federal laws that limited banks in those areas to their local markets. If those banks had been part of a larger company, the losses from a local economic downturn could have been absorbed by other parts of the company, and the damage to the banking system would have been much less. The problems of New England and Texas are among the reasons the Treasury Department's banking-overhaul proposals would allow nationwide branching. 
 The largest American banks have long wanted a system similar to those in countries like Britain and Japan, with unlimited nationwide branching that allows banks to become much larger. In recent years that desire has come closer to being fulfilled as some states allowed out-of-state banks to buy local banks, and as Federal laws allowed out-of-state buyers to take over troubled institutions.
While bankers involved in the recently announced mergers say that diversification and nationwide banking are their goals, their immediate plans are more limited, aimed at solving today's problems.
Large banks are concentrating on their local markets, where the opportunity to cut duplicated branches, employees and computer centers can bring savings that quickly bolster profits. The BankAmerica Corporation, for example, sees $1 billiion in annual cost savings resulting from merging its operations with those of the Security Pacific Corporation.
But BankAmerica officials say the merger with a former California competitor does not mean they have abandoned their goal of becoming a truly national bank -- a goal they pursued unsuccessfully earlier this year when they tried to leapfrog across the country and buy the Bank of New England. But Fleet/Norstar Financial Group of Rhode Island submitted the winning bid for the bank.
Executives at the Chemical Banking Corporation, which acquired the troubled Texas Commerce Bank in the late 1980's, have said they will consider national banking plans, but only after they have put their own house in order following Chemical's merger with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation early next year.
For NCNB, based in Charlotte, N.C., plans for a national bank are clear from the new name -- Nationsbank -- that it announced at the time it disclosed plans to acquire Atlanta-based C&S/Sovran, whose scope of operations is not much greater than NCNB's existing business.
 
A View From Newark
 "The quickest, most dependable savings for banks come from mergers within their own or contiguous markets," said Anthony Terraciano, chairman of the First Fidelity Bancorporation of Newark. Mr. Terraciano, who has been acquiring branches and deposits of failed savings insitutions in New Jersey and raising capital from a Spanish bank while First Fidelity heals its wounds, added that "over a reasonable period of time the consolidation trend will lead to diversification."
"But there will be an interim period," he continued, "when the consolidation appears to result in increased concentration."
Edward E. Furash, a Washington bank consultant, said, "What we are seeing now is just the first stage of merger mania, where large institutions use cost savings to strengthen themselves so they can better withstand the economic shocks in the regions they operate."
The diversification so far, Mr. Furash said, has been by product lines not geography. For example, NCNB becomes a bit more consumer-oriented with the acquisiton of C&S/Sovran, while BankAmerica becomes stronger in corporate-processing businesses like cash management, where Security Pacific does well.
 
A Matter of Efficiency
 Geoffrey Nicholson, a director at the Boston Consulting Group, said that when banks began creating national branch systems, they would be looking for new kinds of benefits, not the quick cost savings that come from merging with neighbors. Outside their local markets, he said, "the efficient banks will be looking for less-efficient banks which can be improved and operated more profitably with a change in ownership."
Some analysts have estimated that mergers of banks in different markets could still produce cost savings equal to 10 percent to 20 percent of the non-interest expenses of the acquired bank. These would include less spending for top executives, legal advisers and advertising.
Also, they noted, advances in communications and computers foster consolidation of operations. NCNB, for example, has shifted back-office processing to a low-cost site in Dallas far removed from its banks in the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida, but close to its large Texas bank subsidiary.
With about 10,000 banking companies and 12,300 banks, the merger trend clearly has far to go. Only a handful of companies have managed to spread a significant part of their business outside their region, and their efforts to expand are still opposed by thousands of banks in small towns that see little opportunity in diversification. For them, the lack of diversification is a penalty they willingly accept for the privilege of keeping other banks out of their market.

HEADLINE: It's Thursday in the Park With Paul

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
This is what Ken Harlin did at lunchtime yesterday: Checked the weather forecast for today. (Humid, with a chance of thundershowers.) Looked at the sky. (Hazier by the minute.) Changed his mind about spending last night in Central Park. (Some New Yorkers will consider doing anything for a good seat at tonight's Paul Simon concert.)
Almost anything, anyway, which is why Mr. Harlin set his alarm clock for 6 A.M. and planned to head for the park as soon as he got up. Mr. Harlin -- who is 44 years old and says he has attended "every single New York Philharmonic concert and Metropolitan Opera performance in the park for the last 15 years, even when it rained" -- said he would stake out his territory and plant the red-and-yellow flag he made during Mr. Simon's last concert in the park, with Art Garfunkel, in 1981. 
 "This is a New York event," said Mr. Harlan, the supervisor of the circulation and reserve section at the Columbia University East Asian Library, "and it's free."
Like so many New York events, the logistics defy logic, or what passes for logic in mind-slowing midsummer. For the Simon concert, scheduled to start between 7:15 and 7:45 P.M. on the Great Lawn, there will be 150 extra cellular phones in the park, not to mention 160 portable toilets, a portable hospital and a 50-foot tower for television cameras that also has an observation deck for the police.
There will also be the biggest backstage setup the Parks Department says it has ever seen and, above the stage, a 15-by-30-foot television monitor so the crowd can see what Mr. Simon and his 17-piece band from seven countries are up to.
Cable-television viewers can see what that are up to, live, beginning at 7 P.M., on HBO. Radio listeners can hear them on more than 200 stations from coast to coast, adding millions to the inevitable crowd estimates. Mr. Simon will have no opening act, but he will be introduced, by Mayor David N. Dinkins. The concert is expected to last two and a half hours, a spokesman for Mr. Simon said.
Already, the suspense is building among municipal record-keepers: Will more people turn out than turned out for the New York Philharmonic (800,000 on July 5, 1986)? Will the throng match the one that heard Simon and Garfunkel (400,000 on Sept. 19, 1981)?
 
Even Rehearsals Draw
 "That was the most amount of people I'd ever seen," Mr. Simon said before a rehearsal last night. Even his rehearsals are well-attended: more than 1,000 people lolled on blankets and settled into folding chairs.
The figures do not include the only-in-New-York attempts at demonstrating influence. "Everybody and his and her grandmother is calling me for tickets," said the Parks Commissioner, Betsy Gotbaum. "It's a free concert. I'm not a ticket agent. They say, 'What, the Parks Commissioner doesn't have tickets?' It's a nightmare."
There were 675 V.I.P. tickets, fewer than used to be set aside for previous concerts because the big backstage setup gobbled up the space for 325 V.I.P. seats. The 675 have long since been given away, but Mrs. Gotbaum's phone is still ringing. "I hate it," she said.
Economists preach that there is no such thing as a free lunch, and even a free concert has a price. Stewart Desmond, a Parks Department spokesman, said HBO was paying the costs of the production. He said the company was donating $400,000 to the Parks Foundation to cover the city's expenses, estimated at about $150,000 on overtime for police, sanitation and parks workers. The rest will be spent on parks programs around the city.
Mr. Simon will be taking his music to the park tonight. (The rain date is tomorrow.) The Parks Department, the Emergency Medical Service and the police will be taking their cellular phones, and there are also 20 emergency call boxes in the park that use cellular hookups. Nynex Mobile Communications, which provides cellular service, installed a special antenna on Belvedere Castle so the phones can all get dial tones at once if necessary.
The police say additional officers will be assigned to the park, and city officials hope their presence will keep the evening from turning into a rerun of a Diana Ross concert in July 1983. Bands of young people robbed fans leaving the performance. More than 30 people were arrested and at least 40 were hurt.
Mr. Simon said before last night's rehearsal that he expected no problems tonight. "The city is so conscious of the black eye we all took because of that," he said, referring to the 1983 concert. "That's part of what the $400,000 goes for."
For some, the only worry was getting a seat. David Randall, a 19-year-old college student, showed up last night with an inflatable mattress and 40 sheets. The mattress was to sleep on, though he ended up taking it to a friend's apartment nearby rather than sleeping in the park. The 40 sheets were placeholders for friends who wanted to attend the concert.
"I like Paul Simon," he said. "I just haven't memorized all his lyrics yet."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Television workers preparing equipment near the stage of tonight's Paul Simon concert in Central Park. (Edward Keating for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: White Canarsie Resident Charged In Group Attack on a Black Man

 BODY:
A white unemployed mover was charged yesterday in the slashing of a black man in a playground in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn earlier this month. The attack was one of 14 bias-related incidents in Canarsie since July 1, the police said.
The suspect, Richard Ferrente of 2125 Rockaway Parkway in Canarsie, was identified by the victim from a police lineup yesterday evening, the police said. 
 Mr. Ferrente, 26 years old, was charged with second-degree assault, aggravated harassment and violation of the city's civil rights law. He will be arraigned today in Brooklyn Criminal Court, the police said.
Detective Capt. Richard A. Ward said the police were looking for three other men in the incident. He said Mr. Ferrente did not wield the knife in the slashing but had pushed the victim, Michael Mark, to the ground and yelled racial epithets at him while Mr. Mark was with his 4-year-old daughter.
Captain Ward said Mr. Ferrente and his companions had attacked Mr. Mark "because he was black."
Mr. Ferrente and the three other men had spent the evening of July 31 drinking beer in the playground of Public School 272 in Canarsie, Captain Ward said. About 3:25 A.M. on Aug. 1, he said, Mr. Mark -- who lives in the East New York section of Brooklyn but was visiting his mother in Canarsie -- and his daughter passed by the playground at Seaview Avenue between East 99th and East 100th Street.
Captain Ward said the four men began "yelling racial slurs" at Mr. Mark until they reached East 102d Street near Avenue N, where Mr. Ferrente pushed Mr. Mark to the ground. Then, Captain Ward said, another man cut Mr. Mark with a razor. His daughter was unharmed.
Mr. Mark was treated at Kings County Hospital Center for a six-inch gash on his arm.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Ferrente, accused in a bias-related slashing, being led out of 69th Precinct station house. (Edward Keating for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Perils With a New Folk Hero

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
JOHN DALY, the new glittering golfer, may be hazardous to your health, and to his own, and with dangerous ramifications that could reach even into our gross national product.
John Daly is now hailed as a folk hero because he performed a kind of miracle by winning the Professional Golfers Association Championship on Sunday. 
 He is Cinderella Man: he was the last player entered in the tournament -- in fact, he was originally the ninth alternate, as the world now knows, and got into the field of 151 only when another golfer dropped out at the last moment because his wife was going into labor. So Wednesday night John Daly (Arkansas-born) jumped into his car in Memphis and drove fast for seven and a half hours and found himself Thursday afternoon playing on a formidable course in Indiana he had never seen before, and shot 69.
Daly is 25 years old and a rookie on the PGA Tour, and now he is being linked with people like Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino -- whose first tournament victories were, like Daly, in a major championship -- and Jack Fleck, another former miracle worker, who as an unknown beat Ben Hogan in a playoff for the 1955 United States Open championship (and was rarely heard from again).
Few people had known of Daly before last week, when he took the lead on the second day of the P.G.A. Championship and kept it to the final, tearful, Mother Goose end.
Just last month, in fact, he said he was nearly broke. "I'm young and I'm hungry," he said. "Basically, I'm starving."
At the P.G.A. Championship, in which there was a $230,000 first prize, he was walloping the ball for cosmic distances. And he played so fast that on Sunday one of his drives nearly hit the score-bearer in the group ahead of him. He plays like Mike Tyson fights -- Tyson is so eager to do damage that he runs into the ring without even putting on socks. (Daly wears socks, but at the P.G.A. he didn't appear to have time to tie his shoe laces properly, and retied them at almost every tee.)
But now to the really dangerous aspects about Daly. For one thing, there's the swing, a huge, powerful thing that subverts the adage of "hit it easy." Ray Floyd, a former P.G.A. winner himself, said: "My back got sore just watching him."
Golfers are odd people. As soon as they see something that may work for someone else, they start fooling around with it, too; pros and amateurs alike.
"On Monday, a woman who I give lessons to started swinging with her elbow higher than normal," said Don McDougall, the club pro at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton, L.I. "I asked what she was doing. She said, 'I want to hit the ball like John Daly.' I said, 'Please, let's get that elbow back down a little, O.K.?' "
Not only can a new swing begin to throw everyone off their game -- golfers are forever studying the intricacies of every muscle twitch in their stroke -- but it can throw their necks and backs and hips out of whack, too. Even John Daly is vulnerable: What happens when he really starts to age and becomes, say, 28?
So we have medical reasons for not copying John Daly's style, as well as psychological ones. Golfers ponder too much, anyway, and golf has probably put more people on the couch than even, as we say in the love game, relationships.
Daly also distorts the genteel elements of the old game. Daly gave his caddie, Jeff (Squeaky) Medlen, an assignment in the P.G.A. Each time he handed Daly a driver, Squeaky was instructed to squeak, "Kill!" This inspired Daly. He is known to his peers as Wild Thing and Macho Man and, naturally, Killer.
And what a hazard Daly-imitated play would present for those who own homes along the golf course. Golf balls, as in a P. G. Wodehouse story, would crash through their windows like never before. Picture the consternation at a tea party: "Excuse me, madam, but I'm bunkered in your piano."
Daly, born in Dardanelle, Ark., is a self-taught golfer. A few years ago a pro suggested that he modify his swing. Daly looked at the man with the disdain you save for someone who moves his shadow across your putting path. Absolutely not, Daly told the pro. Yet if everyone who waggles a golf stick stopped seeking advice, imagine the effect on the economy.
Golf pros, golf videos, golf books and magazines -- an entire instructional industry would unravel like a cheap suit. People would be jobless. Crime might increase. There would be a general drain on everyone.
Sure, John Daly's a great rags-to-riches story, and yes there's a refreshing joy to his big, bold game. But there are also the potential dangers to society of this exciting noncomformist. From here on, he must be watched very closely.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Daly (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Checketts Counting On Ewing Back at Center

BYLINE: By SAM GOLDAPER

 BODY:
Forget the talk of Patrick Ewing's possible escape from New York via the trade route.
Dave Checketts, the Knicks' president, said yesterday that he expected Ewing to be the starting center when New York opens its National Basketball Association season on Nov. 1 against the Magic in Orlando, Fla. 
 "Patrick is a Knick and we expected it would be that way before he filed for arbitration and after it," said Checketts, speaking at a basketball charity event in Manhattan. "It's not like everyone is waiting around outside the teepee to see if the peace pipe has been smoked. Life goes on. He's our center. In all our talks, he has never given me any indications that he wants to be traded, not before the arbitration and not after it."
 
Silence From Ewing
 Ewing has remained silent on whether he wants to stay a Knick since an arbitrator ruled on July 29 that he was one of the league's four highest-paid players as of June 1 and thus ineligible to become a restricted free agent. After the arbitrator found in the Knicks' favor, Checketts said that if Ewing wanted to be traded, he would try to accommodate him. But after Checketts's latest statement, it matters little since Ewing has four years remaining on his contract. The important thing now is whether Ewing comes back as a happy or an unhappy Knick.
Checketts can make him a happy Knick by re-opening negotiations for a contract extension. He did that before Ewing filed his arbitration grievance on June 21. He offered to add two years to Ewing's contract and rocket his salary to an average of $5.4 million a year, making him the highest-paid player in team sports.
Ewing rejected the deal and the offer was withdrawn when Ewing filed for arbitration. Negotiations could start again. They might even be going on now during Ewing's silence.
"Checketts and I have maintained an open dialogue since he became the Knicks' president in March," David Falk, Ewing's lawyer-agent, said yesterday. "Patrick is the New York franchise and we're working behind the scenes to resolve the issues in a way that will be beneficial to both parties."
Checketts confirmed that he had spoken with Falk several times, even as late as yesterday morning. Although both sides presented their cases to Daniel Collins, the arbitrator, Checketts said he had "dropped Patrick a note."
"At some point we will have a conversation when Patrick is ready," Checketts said. "Meanwhile, we're getting on with life and I hope he is."
Asked if he was concerned about Ewing's image being soured because of the issues over the last several months, Checketts said: "Yes, but people tend to forget. This has been a summer of discontentment with the recession and unemployment and people find it difficult to understand why Patrick turned down so much money."

"Every team is so tight under the salary cap," he said, "and the agents know how much money there is out there for a team to spend." . . . "Mr. Edwards is under contract through the 1991-92 season."

HEADLINE: Alaska Offers Californians An Additional Water Spigot

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14

 BODY:
California gets two-thirds of its gasoline from Alaska, so why not water also?
That, in essence, is the proposal Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska brought to Southern California today to solve this parched region's water problems. "We have an awful lot of fresh water," he said. "Can we get it down cheap enough? That depends on how thirsty you get." 
 Governor Hickel wants to build a pipeline to pump water 2,000 miles down the Pacific Coast, supplying nearly 10 percent of California's current water use. It has drawn fire from environmentalists, who maintain that it would not only cause environmental damage in Alaska but also encourage California to continue to waste water.
 
'A Thirsty Vampire'
 "For years, California has acted like a thirsty vampire," said Robert Hattoy, regional director for the Sierra Club. "Building a pipeline would be like putting a faucet in a blood bank."
Still, few water experts have entirely dismissed the notion. The Office of Technology Assessment, a research arm of Congress, has begun a preliminary study of the pipeline's feasibility at the behest of two lawmakers from California and one from Alaska, and held a workshop here today at the Los Angeles County Hall of Administration.
One of the lawmakers, Representative Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California, is sponsoring a bill to authorize a more thorough study.
If ever undertaken, the project would be an engineering feat comparable in ways to digging the Panama Canal.
The pipeline would carry water from the mouths of one or two of Alaska's great rivers, the Stikine and the Copper, which disgorge billions of gallons of fresh water annually into the Pacific Ocean, and funnel it down the coast and then overland to Lake Shasta in Northern California. From there, the water would flow through the State Water Project to Southern California and possibly to other states as well.
 
Cost Estimate: $110 Billion
 According to a preliminary study prepared by Fluor Daniel, the California-based engineering firm, the project would require four undersea aqueducts and land-based pumping stations every 150 miles along the coast. It would cost $110 billion and take 15 years to build.
Most at today's session agreed that the plan was technically feasible, but there was much doubt its economic or political feasibility. It would probably require substantial Federal aid, changes in Federal and state laws and agreements with Canada.
After all that it could then fail if Californians find a cheaper way to obtain additional water. The staff of the Office of Technology Assessment found that the pipeline was neither needed nor economically feasible.
Though not new, the notion gained new life recently after conversations between Governor Hickel and Kenneth Hahn, a veteran Los Angeles County Supervisor. "The big question is what will happen to California if we do not have water," Mr. Hahn said. "Will it become a desert again?"
 
Trillion Gallons a Year
 Harold C. Heinze, Alaska's Commissioner of Natural Resources, said the pipeline would carry about a trillion gallons a year, a little less than a tenth California's current demand.
He and Mr. Hickel said the project's environmental effects would be minimal because the water would be drawn only at the rivers' mouths and would constitute only half a percent of the water discharged in southeast Alaska.
Mr. Heinze said that for its part Alaska would gain jobs for building and maintaining the pipeline and money that would be used in part to provide safe water supplies and sewerage to 30,000 to 50,000 rural Alaskans. He cited no specific income figures.
Many at the workshop doubted that California needed to import water.
The five-year drought has forced new thinking about water allocation, with many arguing that California has plenty of water if it makes more efficient use of it. Already, efforts are under way to store more water, to reclaim waste water, to conserve, to desalinate and to shift more water away from farming to urban uses.
"I do not believe we need to divert more water from other states," said Christine E. Reed of Santa Monica, a member of the board of the Metropolitan Water District, the politically powerful agency that distributes water to 15 million people in Southern California.
 
Call for Conservation
 Both Mr. Hattoy of the Sierra Club and Tom Cassidy of American Rivers, a Washington-based environmental group that focuses on rivers, said California should concentrate on conservation. They asserted that the estuaries and wetlands at the mouths of Alaskan rivers were prime fishing grounds that might suffer from changes in salinity caused by the project.
"The Copper River delta is one of the most productive waterfowl habitats in the world," Mr. Cassidy said in an interview, adding that it was "offensive" to sell this river water "to the highest bidder."
Mr. Hattoy said the pipeline would bring roads, housing and other industrialization associated with its construction through hundreds of miles of mostly undeveloped coastline. "We are not just downhill from Alaska," he said.
But economic rather than environmental realities are probably the greater threat. While California's population continues to grow, the question is how can pipeline water compete with local water that studies suggest could cost 10 times less for urban users.
Mr. Hickel said new technology, along with economies of scale, could reduce the cost. "We are here saying this might be a solution," he said.

HEADLINE: Richard A. Snelling, 64, Is Dead; Governor of Vermont for 9 Years

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, a Republican who blended fiscal conservatism and concern for the environment during nearly nine years in office, died Tuesday night at his home in Shelburne, Vt., just south of Burlington. He was 64 years old.
 Mr. Snelling's body was found by his state police driver near his pool about 8 A.M. yesterday. 
 Dr. Paul Morrow, the State Medical Examiner, performed an autopsy yesterday afternoon and later reported that the Governor had died of cardiac arrest resulting from hardening of the arteries. Mr. Snelling died about 12 hours before his body was found, Dr. Morrow said.
The Governor's chief of staff, Elizabeth Edwards, said Mr. Snelling's associates did not think he had suffered any previous heart problems.
At 3 P.M. yesterday, Lieut. Gov. Howard Dean, 42, was sworn in to fill the rest of Mr. Snelling's term, which ends in January 1993. Dr. Dean, a Democrat who teaches medicine at the University of Vermont, had been Lieutenant Governor since 1987. In Vermont, the governor and the lieutenant governor are elected independently, and the lieutenant governor's position is part time.
 
Death Termed 'a Real Shocker'
 Among those mourning Mr. Snelling was a Democratic predecessor, Philip Hoff, who said: "His governorship in the last year came at a propitious time. We needed a person in that office who was a fiscal conservative while at the same time recognizing human need."
In an appearance in Pittsburgh with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, President Bush said: "It's a real shocker. He was a good man and a good Governor of his state."
Mr. Snelling, a self-made millionaire, had barely begun his fifth two-year term. He had served four terms from 1977 to 1985, and decided to run again last year because of concern for the state's economic health.
Most of his energy in the last five months was devoted to balancing the budget. At his urging, the Legislature passed the largest tax increase in Vermont's history, more than $90 million, while imposing deep cuts in programs.
 
'Constantly on the Move'
 "Mr. Snelling is not the kind of Vermonter who waits for the sap to start running in the maple trees," a reporter for The New York Times once wrote of the Governor. "He is constantly on the move. He flies his own plane and plays tennis aggressively, despite a knee injury he got while playing football at Harvard."
Richard Arkwright Snelling was born on Feb. 18, 1927, in Allentown, Pa. After attending the University of Havana and Lehigh University, he served in the Army in 1945 and 1946. In 1948 he earned a bachelor's degree from Harvard University.
Mr. Snelling moved to Vermont in 1953, settling in Shelburne, where he founded Shelburne Industries, a manufacturer of ski equipment that made him wealthy. In 1959 and 1960 and again from 1973 to 1976, he served in the Vermont House of Representatives.
He was elected Governor in November 1976. Admirers praised his record of attracting industry to the state.
In 1978, after a large court award against a ski resort, Mr. Snelling signed a bill establishing in law what had long been believed in a state where the ski industry is vital: skiers are responsible for their own safety.
 
Concern for the Environment
 And in a state where land use and the environment are also constant concerns, he opposed a plan to allow mining for uranium and barred the sale of phosphate detergents, which pollute water by fostering the growth of algae.
In 1981 and 1982, Mr. Snelling served as president of the National Governors' Association. In that role, he tried to cooperate with President Ronald Reagan's New Federalism, under which about 35 Federal programs were to be turned over to the states. The concept, Mr. Snelling said, was akin to the New England town meeting, making sure government stays close to the people.
But he forcefully objected when Mr. Reagan did not offer Federal financing to support those programs and imposed budget cuts placing additional burdens on the states. He called the President's approach to cities and states "an economic Bay of Pigs."
Mr. Snelling is survived by his wife, Barbara; two daughters, Diane, of Hinesburg, Vt., and Jacqueline Mansfield of Washington; two sons, Mark, of Richmond, Vt., and Andrew, of Sterling, Ill., and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: The Stick Congress Gave Castro

 BODY:
Once again Fidel Castro has caught Washington off guard, lowering the minimum age for foreign travel from 60 to 20 years. This has opened floodgates for an illegal exodus of Cubans -- and created a painful dilemma for Americans:
Having regularly censured him for reining Cubans in, how can critics now condemn him for letting them out? 
 The game has a further twist. Cuba's new boat people, lancheros in Spanish, automatically obtain the right to settle and work in the United States under a special law that applies only to Cubans.
The newcomers merely need to make themselves known to the Immigration Service to obtain a right for which other foreigners must wait years. And the same Cuban Adjustment Act also applies to as many as 30,000 Cubans who have illegally overstayed their tourist visas. Thus Mr. Castro is beating on America with a stick Congress gave him -- meanwhile ridding his island of potential troublemakers.
Efforts to repeal this dated law have been torpedoed by lawmakers from Florida who are moved by concern for the state's large Cuban community. But if Congress does not quickly plug this hole, a million Cubans may well sail right through it.
Cuba's desperate economic situation drives this new migration. Typically, Cubans are allowed only two bread rolls a day and barely a pound of meat a week. This is the result of wretched planning, loss of trade with no-longer-Communist Eastern Europe and dwindling aid from a Soviet Union whose leader Mr. Castro despises.
There is some truth to claims that Mr. Castro's revolution has provided low-cost housing, free medical care and schooling. But so has democratic Costa Rica. With fewer resources, it has made comparable social gains and done so without enduring a one-party tyranny under a dictator for life. Rather than generate wealth, Cuba rations poverty.
Small wonder that requests for tourist visas have swamped the U.S. Interests Section in Havana, forcing it to suspend further applications after issuing 40,000 visas. Small wonder, too, that Cuban youngsters, endlessly exhorted to choose Socialism or death, respond by braving shark-infested waters in little boats.
The result is the biggest exodus since the Mariel boatlift in 1980 that sent 125,000 Cubans to southern Florida, including felons spitefully released from prison. Most of the Marielitos have resettled successfully but it took years of frustrating negotiations to repatriate the criminal remnant. One such trauma is enough.
The Cuban Adjustment Act makes America turn an unjust face to the rest of the world, giving Cubans preference over Haitians, Salvadorans or people from all other countries. And it gives Fidel Castro the power to push, send or dump whomever he wishes to the United States. Such a law is difficult to explain and impossible to defend. Its repeal will be an early order of business when Congress comes back to work.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Broad Impact Of the Gulf War

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IT'S been a year since Iraq invaded Kuwait -- and half a year since the United States and its coalition partners defeated Iraq in a land war that lasted 100 hours. This seems like a good time to assess the effects of the Persian Gulf war on the American economy.
This was a unique war in American history in terms of its effect on the budget and the economy, both because it was fought out of inventories and because America's allies paid for the war, at least in the short run. Indeed, the United States made a "profit" on the war during the fiscal year 1991, which ends on Oct. 1. 
 Total pledges from coalition partners to the United States came to $54 billion. Thus far, the amount received has been $46.6 billion, of which $41.8 billion was in cash and $5.4 billion in kind, especially fuel. The Office of Management and Budget expects that by the end of this year, cash contributions will reach $48.2 billion, bringing the combined cash-and-kind grants to the $54 billion pledged.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that United States incremental costs for Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm came to $15 billion. Hence, with cash receipts expected to total $48 billion this year, it says the United States will have received $33 billion more than the incremental costs of the war this year.
However, Richard G. Darman, director of O.M.B., has testified that the total costs to the United States of stopping Iraq were $61 billion, implying that American outlays exceeded foreign contributions by at least $7 billion. But the Darman figure includes transfers from already budgeted military outlays to the gulf operations plus estimated future costs of replacing equipment lost in the war.
One issue is how much lost equipment should be replaced, given American plans to scale back military expenditures. The inflow of foreign capital not only offset America's budget costs but also helped reduce the United States balance-of-payments deficits. America's foreign balance swung from a $23.4 billion deficit in the fourth quarter of 1990 to a $10.2 billion surplus in the first quarter of 1991.
The gulf crisis either triggered or aggravated the American recession. Just before the invasion, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned of the dangers of recession and said the Fed was prepared to ease credit, if necessary, to prevent a recession. But other economists said, before the crisis erupted, that the Fed had been too tight and was endangering a weak economy.
But when Iraq's invasion came, the Fed did not ease off, caught between uncertainties of whether to fight the looming recession or an inflation aggravated by climbing oil prices. The oil shock of 1990 proved much less severe than the two oil shocks of the 1970's. After the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies, oil prices initially soared from a pre-invasion average price around $18 a barrel to slightly above $40 by the late fall. But they fell back to roughly $21, as greater shipments came in from other producers, and world oil demand lagged.
Still, some industries were hard hit. The airlines saw the cost of jet fuel, which had been 60 cents a gallon before the invasion, soar to $1.40 a gallon by mid-October. Even after fuel prices began to ease, the outbreak of a ground and air war created a severe reenue problem for the airlines because traffic fell. Trans-Atlantic traffic dropped 50 percent.
The gulf crisis hurt consumer confidence and snagged business spending on new plant and equipment. The slide into recession, together with the steep costs of bailing out the savings and loan associations, deepened the Federal budget deficit. The Congressional Budget Office this week estimated that the budget deficit in the coming fiscal year would reach $362 billion, up from $279 billion in the fiscal year 1991. The ballooning deficit will come down painfully slowly, and it aggravates the nation's savings, investment and growth problems.
Symmetrically, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, says, as the gulf crisis tipped the economy into recession, its end helped stop the recession and start the recovery. The council is forecasting 3.6 percent real economic growth in 1992. The Congressional Budget Office puts next year's growth rate at 3.3 percent, and the consensus of private economists polled by Blue Chip Economic Indicators sees 2.7 percent growth next year.
Even with a slower-than-usual recovery, the expected swing in inventories from an annual rate of decline of $30 billion in the final quarter of 1990 and the first half of 1991 to a positive rate of $20 billion in inventory building, required to maintain existing inventory-to-sales ratios, would give the economy a $50 billion lift. And, with the gulf war fading into memory, and fears of inflation shrinking, the Fed is freer to nourish the recovery with easier money and credit.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Rose 3.7% in July

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The housing industry continued its slow but steady recovery in July, with construction of new homes and apartments rising for the fourth straight month, the Commerce Department said today.
Housing starts rose 3.7 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.07 million units. The increase, which was better than analysts had expected, followed revised gains of 5 percent in June and six-tenths of 1 percent in May. Starts rose 7.7 percent in April. 
 In addition, applications for permits to build new houses -- a measure of future activity -- rose for the sixth month in a row.
 
A Lackluster Recovery
 The housing industry, which has been in a long and painful slump, has been leading the economy out of a recession that began in July 1990, analysts say. But the housing recovery, like that of the overall economy, is far less vigorous than the rebounds from other recessions.
"It's great to have a recovery, but this is not a really robust one," said Dave Seiders, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders.
Underscoring that point, the regional pattern of housing starts was mixed, with construction dropping in both the Northeast and the Midwest.
Nevertheless, the last time housing starts nationally rose for four straight months was more than a decade ago, from July to October 1980.
"These numbers are a good sign that the housing sector is still on track," said Tom Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association.
"That's particularly important at this juncture because the overall economic recovery has been fragile at best, and it needs all the help it can get from the housing sector," he said.
 
A Forecast of Weakness
 The weakness of the economy was underscored by a report today from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, which said that the recession probably ended between April and June but that unemployment would remain high, averaging 6.7 percent this year and 6.2 percent in 1992. The unemployment rate in July was 6.8 percent.
The forecast raises the question of whether there will be enough job opportunities to insure sufficient income growth to create a durable economic revival.
Since January, when housing starts sank to an annual rate of 847,000, their lowest level since 1982, the monthly pace of construction has bounced back 26 percent, encouraged by lower interest rates and stronger consumer confidence.
But Mr. Seiders of the home builders group said that for all of 1991 he anticipates only about 1.05 million new houses will be started. That would be the weakest performance in 45 years, since 1.02 million starts in 1946. Housing starts peaked in 1986 at about 1.8 million units.
Rates for 30-year mortgages are now down to about 9.25 percent while adjustable-rate mortgages can be found as low as 7 percent, Mr. Seiders said. Most of the strength in housing is in single-family homes, he added.
 
One Indicator Is Up
 Applications for building permits increased in July by three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of one million units, after a 3.4 percent rise in June, pointing to more increases in construction activity ahead.
Permits for single-family homes were up 1.5 percent, to an annual rate of 792,000 units in July. Permits for apartments fell by 4.1 percent, to a rate of 210,000 units.
The last time permit applications rose for six straight months was between February and July 1983, as the economy was emerging from the 1981-82 recession.
Construction dropped 27 percent in the Northeast, to a rate of 106,000 new houses a year, and also fell in the Midwest, by 4.5 percent, to a rate of 235,000. The decline in the Northeast, however, followed gains of 27.2 percent in June and 22.6 percent in May, and analysts said a pullback from those levels was not surprising. They added that the May and June increases were a better reflection of the general improvement in the market.
In the big Southern market, starts climbed a solid 15 percent, to a rate of 448,000, and were up 11.5 percent in the West, to 281,000 units a year.
The actual number of new houses that contractors started in July was 105,400, up from 103,200 in June but fewer than the 111,200 that were started in July 1990, just as the economy was entering recession.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Holding a Library in Your Hands

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
If the Sony Corporation has its way, handheld computers will no longer be novelties. Sony, in its aggressive search for new markets, is preparing to introduce its own handheld computer, the Data Discman, that plays disks containing a shelf full of reference works. The company wants millions of consumers to punch these devices for, say, an encyclopedia entry on asteroids, the proper spelling of accommodate, or the right wine to serve with veal.
Several much smaller companies have tried for years to build a market for such products, with only limited success. The Franklin Electronic Publishing Company of Mount Holly, N.J., has sold more than four million palm-sized computers, but is still struggling to make a profit. The entrance of a company with the technical and marketing prowess of Sony will provide the first real test of the consumer's appetite for portable information devices. 
 The introduction of the Data Discman will also be the first big test for the new Sony Electronic Publishing Company and its 29-year-old president, Olaf Olaffson. The group, formed in April, is under pressure to insure that a compelling selection of electronic books will be ready in time to insure the Discman's successful introduction for the Christmas season.
 
Disputes Over the Disks
 But the company is still squabbling over contracts with the outside developers who will create the reference material for disks. Some developers say the contract delays are likely to push the introduction of the Data Discman back until next year, although Mr. Olaffson said the project was on track. Contracts for 20 titles have now been signed, he said.
Sony's product does have a distinct advantage over the single-purpose devices on the market. Like a compact disk music player, the Data Discman can play different disks, allowing a single machine to serve as encyclopedia, dictionary and wine guide. But the electronic Bible made by Franklin, for example, delivers only the Scripture; you cannot pop in a cartridge that lists baseball statistics. Franklin and other competitors are planning to introduce models that will play different cartridges.
Several advances have made the palmtop computers possible. Engineers continue to shrink electronic components. The price of computer memory chips has fallen dramatically in recent years. Morton E. David, chief executive of Franklin, said the cost of memory in Franklin machines was declining by about 30 percent a year, to $7.50 for each machine, from $48 a few years ago.
Franklin's products range in price from $39 for a spell checker to nearly $400 for an electronic encyclopedia. Sony has been selling a $450 Data Discman in Japan for about a year, and the product is expected to cost about that much in the United States. The disks are likely to cost $30 to $50.
The devices are far easier to use than personal computers and require no technical expertise. The machines are operated by miniature keyboards with simple command keys. Can't recall the name of one of mythology's worst scoundrels? Type the phrase "Norse god of evil" into the Franklin encyclopedia and press the enter key. The name Loki, and a short description of his treacheries, pops up on the screen in a fraction of a second.
To keep the machines portable, the screens are fairly small. Franklin's encyclopedia displays about 50 words of text at a time. Many schools are buying the devices as learning aids.
The handheld computers are currently intended for consumers, but both Franklin and Sony are contemplating business uses. A stock analyst could have volumes of Standard & Poor's reports on one of the machines. An accountant could carry volumes of regulations in a pocket.
For some uses, the electronic devices will replace books, Mr. David of Franklin said. "In five years, the paper dictionary will be the anomaly," he said.
Franklin has fended off assaults from other large consumer electronics makers. In 1989, the Smith Corona Company brought out a poorly designed product that sold slowly. The company quietly retreated from the market.
 
Created the Market
 Franklin has transformed itself from a bankrupt maker of Apple computer clones into the leader of the small but growing $140 million market for handheld reference devices. Franklin effectively created the market in 1986 with a spelling corrector.
In the fiscal year ended March 1991, Franklin had sales of $54 million and lost $5 million. Mr. David and analysts attribute the loss to weak economic conditions and the price cutting necessary when Smith Corona liquidated its inventory to leave the business. Analysts predict the company will be profitable this year.
Franklin now has nearly 20 different models of computers. Its most sophisticated offering, an electronic encyclopedia introduced this year, costs about $400.
 
Sony's Move Called Helpful
 After withstanding the competition from Smith Corona, Mr. David maintains that Sony's looming presence does not concern him. "There is this perception that it is a great threat to Franklin, but I see it a great boon," Mr. David said.
He explained that retailers who will have prominent displays for the Sony product will surround them with cheaper Franklin devices. "I think it will result in the sale of a lot of Franklin products," he said.
Paul Elliot, an analyst with Cowen & Company in New York, said Sony's entry would lend the entire category legitimacy, aiding Franklin. Franklin, he added, already has plenty of material to install on the machines. "Sony doesn't sell these products yet and Sony has to get the data bases," he said.
The flexibility of Sony's product is expected to give it an important edge. But Mr. David of Franklin said that within 18 months his company would introduce its own device to play multiple titles. In a recent interview, Mr. David showed off the prototype of a device that will hold separate, removable cartridges containing different programs.
Without such flexibility, Franklin and other electronic publishers, like Selectronics Inc. in Pittsford, N.Y., "will go the way of the dinosaur," said one publishing executive. Selectonics, which is under financial pressure, sharply scaled back its operations last month.
Texas Instruments and Seiko also offer spell checkers and similar devices, but appear to have far less ambitious plans than Sony.
 
Bumpy Road to Market
 Sony has sold 70,000 to 100,000 of its palm-sized computers in Japan in little more than a year, industry executives said. Sony will say only that sales have been better then expected.
Despite Sony's size and sophistication, there are signs that the Data Discman's road to market has not been smooth. Mr. David of Franklin said his friends at Sony had told him that the company was divided over the wisdom of introducing the Data Discman. For Sony, the technology is relatively dated. The Discman is powered by an 8-bit chip -- less powerful than the chips used to drive the latest video games. Sony executives have privately demonstrated a more advanced version of the product, dubbed the Bookman, which has a bigger screen, animation and audio capabilities.
For Sony, the danger is that what the electronics industry calls "pro-sumers," the eager consumers who rush out to buy new technology, will be upset if their Data Discmans are outdated in 18 months. Sony executives say that the market has room for both machines, and that the Data Discman will pave the way for more advanced portable information devices.
 
Signs of Tension Seen
 Publishing executives, who asked not to be identified, said they also saw signs of tension between Sony's hardware and software executives. One publisher said that if Data Disc faltered because of a lack of good software from Mr. Olaffson's group, "there would be fireworks and celebration at Park Ridge," the site of Sony's hardware group.
Mr. Olaffson and Mike Vitelli, president of personal audio products, the Sony unit handling the hardware, denied reports of internal strife. Mr. Olaffson also played down the pressure on his group, saying, "I sleep at night."

HEADLINE: Dow Slips From Early Gain, Losing 6.94

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market yesterday repeated its pattern of recent days, scoring impressive gains in the morning but sliding back at the close.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been perched just above 3,000, closed below that barrier, and even secondary stocks, which had shown strength throughout the week, finally fell. 
 "You have to expect some profit taking, especially after the run they had," Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research for Gruntal & Company in Stamford, Conn., said of the secondary issues.
The Dow, after jumping 16 points in early trading, traded in a narrow range most of the rest of the day before finishing at 2,998.43, off 6.94. Weakness was also felt on the broader market, as the New York Stock Exchange composite of all Big Board stocks fell 0.25, to 213.38.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.57, to 389.33, while the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues declined by 2.01 points, to 515.67. Traders on the American Stock Exchange fared better, as the composite index rose 0.21, to 367.99.
 
Moderately Heavy Volume
 Volume on the Big Board was a moderately heavy 174.7 million shares, down from 212.7 million yesterday. Advances led declines by a slim margin, 792 to 782.
Mr. Seagle noted that yesterday's market lacked leadership and was affected by several factors. One, he said, was dealers adjusting their positions ahead of today's "double witching hour," the simultaneous expiration of stock-index futures and options contracts.
"Then there is the Salomon Brothers situtation, which has affected the market psychologically," he continued. "There was the afternoon disruption of program trading and not much coming from bank stocks, which had been one of the cores of this week's strength. A modest increase in housing starts for the month of July had no apparent impact."
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trades, said three of the day's four program sells came in the afternoon, with the net effect being a decline of 15.67 in the Dow.
 
Pressure on Salomon
 Shares of Salomon Brothers, which have been under pressure since last week over disclosures of irregularities involving bids at certain Treasury auctions, fell 4 3/4, to 26 7/8, in heavy trading. Other brokerage stocks fell yesterday, including Merrill Lynch, down 3/8, to 41 7/8.
Black & Decker rose 3/4, to 16 7/8, after the toolmaker said it would privately sell 150,000 shares of convertible preferred stock to the Newell Company, a consumer hardware concern, for $150 million. Shares of Newell fell 1 1/8, to 38,
General Electric, accused by the Justice Department of defrauding the Pentagon of more than $30 million on the sale of jet engines to Israel, fell 3/8, to 72 5/8.
Motorola rose 3/8, to 68 3/8, as Lawrence Hassis, a Kemper Securities analyst, rated the company a long-term buy based on a pickup in profitability by the fourth quarter and 1992.
 
New T2 Medical Shares
 T2 Medical fell 2 7/8, to 61 7/8, as 390,000 shares of previously restricted stock became available on Wednesday. The company said the stock was used two years ago to buy a physician-owned medical center.
Storage Technology, which has a merger pending with XL/Datacomp, fell 2 3/4, to 44 1/4, as it received a downgrade from Stephen Cohen, an analyst with the Soundview Financial Corporation.
UAL, where flight attendants for United Airlines are about to vote on a tentative labor contract, rose by 2, to 139 1/2.
Ricky Harrington, director of equity investments for Marion Bass Securities in Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that stocks and bonds, which have been rising in tandem lately, were likely to go their separate ways shortly, leaving stocks in a difficult position.
"If the economy continues to grow at a mild pace, there may be a short decoupling where both markets go off in different directions," he said. "But if the economy begins to slip back under, the decoupling would be a long one. The verdict may come in the fall."
Right now, he added, the market seems to be saying that it believes the economy will make the recovery.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Report on Starts of Housing Helps to Push Dollar Ahead

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher yesterday against most major currencies as an encouraging report on United States housing starts outweighed the effects of a long-awaited rise in German interest rates.
The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, increased the nation's discount rate a full point, to 7.5 percent, and the Lombard rate a quarter-point, to 9.25 percent. 
 The rate rise would tend to weaken the dollar against the German mark as investors seek more marks to buy higher-yielding German securities. But traders said that while the dollar stalled somewhat in the morning, it improved later.
"All this rate hike business has been built into the price the past week or so," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston. Against the German currency, the dollar rose more than a pfennig in New York yesterday to close at 1.7490 marks, up from 1.7375.
On the other hand, the Labor Department's housing starts report was "remarkably better than expected, so the dollar started to stabilize a bit," Mr. Lawrie said.
The 3.7 percent increase was the fourth consecutive monthly advance -- the longest string of monthly advances since July-October 1980, the Government said. The report suggested a slow but steady recovery from the recession.
The housing news and the dollar's rise could indicate a shift in investor attitudes toward lower United States interest rates, which could tend to weaken the dollar, said Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company.
"I think people are beginning to think that maybe lower interest rates mean a better chance for a better recovery, therefore a stronger dollar," he said.
He predicted the dollar would continue gaining strength over the next eight months or so, as the economy strengthens.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 136.59 yen, up 0.19 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 136.08 yen, while in New York, it was quoted at 137.05 yen, up from 136.50 yen.
In New York, the British pound finished at $1.6720, down from $1.6860 Wednesday. Earlier in London, the pound rose to $1.6870, up slightly from $1.6860 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.5355 Swiss francs, up from 1.5222; 5.9490 French francs, up from 5.9095; 1,310.75 Italian lire, up from 1,301.25, and 1.1436 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1432.
In precious metals trading, gold for current delivery in New York fell 80 cents a troy ounce to a late bid of $357.00 on the Commodity Exchange. And the Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $357 a troy ounce, down 60 cents from late Wednesday.
Earlier in London, gold prices rose to a closing $358.35 an ounce, from $356.90 an ounce late Wednesday, and to $357.80 in Zurich, up from $356.50 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Security Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday, as traders took profits by selling long-term bonds but continued to buy shorter-term issues.
Prices, which have risen for the better part of two weeks, continued to rise during overnight trading in Asia and later in Europe, but selling began after the Government announced that housing starts rose by a stronger-than-expected 3.7 percent in July. The rise was the fourth in a row in a sector that in the past has been an important element in previous economic recoveries. 
 A report from the Labor Department that initial unemployment claims edged up in the week ended Aug. 3 softened the impact of the housing data somewhat. But with a weekend approaching, dealers were in a mood to pare their positions.
"The housing starts data were a reminder that things don't point universally in the direction of lower interest rates," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "And once bond yields get in the vicinity of 8 percent, the market seems to get tired. That is basically what happened today."
The announcement late Wednesday that provided further details about Salomon Brothers' activities in the government securities market was a major topic of conversation yesterday.
 
Reviewing Salomon Relationship
 Based on the most recent disclosures, some money management firms said they were reviewing their relationship with Salomon.
"Anybody who works in Treasury securities is going to have some contact with Salomon at some point, and we have been dealing with them since the firm was founded in 1971," said Randy Merk, a vice president at Benham Capital Management in Mountain View, Calif., a firm with around $5 billion in Treasury securities under management.
"What has happened on the Treasury side is unfortunate," Mr. Merk added, "and we have decided to review whether or not we will cut back our Treasury business with them."
Bloomberg News Service reported that the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif., a firm with $32 billion in fixed income assets under management, was also reviewing its relationship with Salomon.
But others said they expected to continue doing business with the firm.
"What happened is astounding, shocking, unbelievable," said Marshall B. Front, an executive vice president at Stein, Roe & Farnham, a Chicago-based investment advisory firm with close to $10 billion in fixed income assets under management.
"But as misguided as their behavior appears to have been, they have been and continue to be a firm with unusual expertise in the Government bond market. Unless they are stopped from doing business, which I doubt, we will continue to do business with them."
Traders said the selling pressure that appeared yesterday had nothing to do with worries about Salomon's future in the Government securities business.
 
Secondary Securities Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 14/32, down 10/32, to yield 8.08 percent, up from 8.06 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered late yesterday at 100 10/32, down 5/32, to yield 7.82 percent. But demand for the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes remained strong, and the issue rose by 1/8 point, to a late offered price of 101 3/32, to yield 6.27 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.27 percent, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.31 percent.
Issuance of new investment-grade corporate debt remained heavy yesterday.
Among the issuers was the Tenneco Credit Corporation, which offered $250 million worth of 10-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 9 5/8 percent notes were priced at $99.566, to yield 9.693 percent, 1.90 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The notes, which are noncallable for life, are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Capital Cities/ABC Inc. offered $250 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 8.75 percent securities, which mature Aug. 15, 2021, were priced at $99.10, to yield 8.836 percent, 75 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Aug. 5.
M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely monitored by the Fed, posted a modest $1.2 billion increase during the week. Still, the rise was enough to prevent the aggregate from falling below the 2.5 percent rate of growth the Fed has set as the low end of its target growth range for M-2 this year.
The money report had no impact on prices in the credit markets. Analysts said the numbers were not likely to provide any additional weight to speculation that the Fed may decide to ease monetary policy further when members of its policy-making Open Market Committee meet in Washington on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: On a March to Hartford, Jackson Rallies Crowds

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 15

 BODY:
It had taken two days to cover the 20 miles from New Haven, 20 miles of hot pavement lined with factories and warehouses, car dealerships and fast-food restaurants, tire stores, tanning salons and kung fu schools.
People had come out to watch: A half-dozen salesmen and yard workers from Colony Lumber in Wallingford. The salesmen and mechanics from Century Toyota. Construction workers. An elderly couple in front of their house on hot, straight Route 5, which had not seen so much excitement, they said, since the neighborhood store had a big lottery winner. 
 Coming into this city of 59,500 on Wednesday afternoon, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the more than 200 marchers behind him found crowds along the streets. The pace picked up. New people stepped in line. The chanting rang louder: "Rebuild America! Keep hope alive!"
Small, low-key, but curiously in tune with the unsettled state of Connecticut, Mr. Jackson's "Rebuild America" march from Bridgeport to Hartford began its fifth day today as he and his group set off for a nine-mile hike through rural Berlin into the city of New Britain.
 
A Friendly Reception
 Except for the drivers trapped in the traffic behind the marchers, the reception is friendly and welcoming for the marchers, whose goal is to call attention to the social and economic ills in this wealthy state's cities and towns. People are not sure why Mr. Jackson is here, but he seems to be doing something. And these are times when they think someone should, indeed, be doing something.
On the steps of City Hall here, Mayor James L. Pellegrini stood next to Mr. Jackson and said, "This is the one person in the country right now who is championing the cause of the city."
Drawn by the distress signal that Bridgeport sent up when it tried to file for bankruptcy protection, Mr. Jackson's National Rainbow Coalition has found in Connecticut a handy-sized demonstration project. The state's economy is deep in recession, with real estate, banking and insurance badly wounded, and its large military contractors threatened with thousands of layoffs.
Its three largest cities, Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven, are among the nation's poorest, but their budget problems are shared to some extent by the rest of the state's cities and suburbs, rich and poor. The state government is without a budget, six weeks into its fiscal year.
 
'A Piece of America'
 "If this is the wealthiest state, with a manageable-size population," Mr. Jackson said, "think of those states with more population and fewer resources."
"This is a kind of biopsy, a piece of America."
The immediate goal is unlikely to bear fruit: On Saturday a final rally at the State Capitol in Hartford will call on the legislature to convene a special session to address the needs of cities and towns on issues from affordable housing to tax relief to education. The General Assembly has been in special session since June 6, trying unsuccessfully to reach agreement on a budget.
But the longer-term goal is almost by definition vague, embracing and, in a time of economic uncertainty, always appealing: "The purpose of our march is to mobilize the people to fight for change," Mr. Jackson told a rally in Meriden.
 
'Educate Our People'
 In a populist appeal to common-sense fairness, Mr. Jackson asked the crowd at day's end: "If we can fight a $50 billion war to bail out Kuwait City, what about New Haven?"
If sending someone to Yale costs less than sending him to jail, "We choose Yale over jail. Educate our people."
And so people have come out to watch as the police motorcycles and patrol cars clear the way. A lumber salesman said, "He's trying to do something." A Toyota salesman: "The state definitely needs the help Jesse can give."
Bob Weug, who had walked the entire way from Bridgeport with a group of homeless veterans from Stamford, said, "Those other countries have their problems, but good grief, don't we have our own?"
 
Chant as the Message
 Asked the marchers' message, Dorothy Durgan of Meriden gave a typical response, repeating the chant, "Rebuild America!" Her daughter, Melanie, gave another common answer: "We don't get a lot of things here, so this is exciting."
Sasha Natapoff, a member of Mr. Jackson's policy staff who helped organize the march, said: "If we march by and people really don't know what's going on, that's O.K. That's what the march is for. That's why we have signs. That's why we have chants."
But most people said the issue was jobs, and they were all for anything Mr. Jackson or anyone else could do about that. Passing some construction workers today, Mr. Jackson waved to them and said: "These people do not fit the stereotype of who identifies with us. These guys are Joe Sixpacks."
"A lot of people in towns and cities look at their problems and think it's just them," said Chris Donovan, a union representative with the Congress of Connecticut Community Colleges who helped organize the stop in Meriden. "This shows it's not an individual problem. It may be structural."

HEADLINE: Weekly Jobless Claims Show a Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose in the week ended Aug. 3, after two weeks of declines, the Labor Department said today.
Some analysts said the rise confirmed a return to a sluggish economy after a brief spurt of activity in the wake of the Persian Gulf war. 
 A total of 408,000 people filed first-time claims for unemployment benefits in the week, the latest period for which data were available. That was a rise of 8,000 from the week before. Economists had expected about 401,000 new claims for the period.
Until the latest report, unemployment-claims numbers had generally been falling since they reached a peak in late March of 543,000, analysts said. "Labor market conditions are backsliding," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities Company International.
The latest four-week average was 409,250, up from 406,000 in the prior four-week period.
"We've seen the four-week average running between 403,000 and 409,000 for the past five weeks," said Stephen Slifer, senior economist at Lehman Government Securities Inc. "It looks like, after a rebound following the gulf war, suddenly it has plateaued."
The number of people actually receiving benefits under regular state programs rose to 3,315,000 in the week ended July 27, the latest period for which that figure was available. That was an increase of 30,000 from the prior week's seasonally adjusted revised level of 3,285,000, the department said.
