HEADLINE: Quick Rebuff for New Weicker Tax Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. gave the state some new budget and income tax proposals today that were almost immediately dismissed by lawmakers as unpassable. The plan broke a record for having the shortest lifespan yet -- about half a day -- among the dozens put forward over the last six months.
And the fiscal pace shows every sign of quickening. Legislative leaders said late in the day after a meeting in the Governor's office that Mr. Weicker had promised to veto any further attempts to keep the state running temporarily. Connecticut, now the only state without a budget in place, has been meeting its obligations since the July 1 start of the fiscal year by passing two-week resolutions while lawmakers struggled to reach a compromise over Mr. Weicker's effort to create an income tax.
 
3 Budgets, 3 Vetoes
 The leaders said that the threatened veto, which the General Assembly could probably not override, would force a vote on a full-year budget as early as Monday, though no one was at all sure what kind of budget lawmakers might be called to vote upon and whether forcing a vote would actually end the crisis. The current extension expires at 12:01 A.M. Monday, but Mr. Weicker has said he will keep the government running that day. 
 Since May the House and Senate have passed three budgets that would have resolved the state's revenue problems primarily by an expansion of the 8 percent sales tax. All were vetoed by Mr. Weicker, a third-party Governor who has insisted on overhauling the state's revenue system, saying he wanted to lower business taxes, stimulate the economy and make the tax rates more fair to the poor.
Mr. Weicker's new proposal was for a "piggyback" income tax, under which taxpayers would pay the state 21 percent of whatever they paid the Federal Government.
 
Marathon on Monday
 But even those legislators who support an income tax said yesterday that they do not support the new plan.
The Senate President, John B. Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford, said he be lieved there would be a push in his chamber instead for a plan that would tax the incomes of only the wealthiest residents, with the vast majority of taxpayers exempt. Such a tax has already been condemned by Democrats in the House.
Mr. Larson said that he expects a marathon session as early as Monday in which the Senate would take up one of the various budget bills that have already been drafted -- perhaps Mr. Weicker's, perhaps some other plan -- and propose amendments around the clock until some combination of good sense or exhaustion allows a budget to pass.
Both Mr. Larson and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington, said they strongly disliked the proposal made by Mr. Weicker today. And even the Governor seemed lukewarm about it in a morning news conference in his office.
"What is dangerous to the process is to have anyone go ahead and say, 'This is my plan, take it or leave it,' " Mr. Weicker said. "It's not my plan, it's a proposal."
The proposal would impose an income tax that would exactly mirror the Federal tax code, but with a smaller bite. The sales tax, now the highest statewide rate in the nation, would be lowered to 6 percent from 8 percent. The corporate profits tax would be lowered over two years from 13.8 percent, also the highest rate in the nation, to 10.5 percent.
The income tax formula would translate into a 1.6 percent state income tax for a family earning $23,800 in adjusted gross income, rising to 6.5 percent for the very wealthiest filers. Mr. Weicker initially proposed in February a flat 6 percent tax on adjusted gross income, which he modified in June to a progressive plan with a top rate of 6.75 percent.
Mr. Balducci said he favored a plan now before the House that would impose a 4 percent flat-rate income tax, with a 6 percent sales tax and slightly lower corporate taxes. Mr. Larson said he remains unconvinced about the wisdom of any income tax.
One of the handful of Republicans who have broken ranks with the party to support the concept of a wage tax, Senator Lawrence J. Bettencourt, a Republican from Waterford, also said he would likely oppose Mr. Weicker's most recent offering. But he said he remained open to other ideas that might be proposed on Monday.

HEADLINE: More Airlines Reduce Fares

 BODY:
Pan American Airways and Virgin Atlantic Airways yesterday announced lower fares on some international flights.
The announcements follow fare cuts by British Airways, American Airlines, United Airlines, Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines. 
 In response to a British Airways offer of 15 percent off some tickets, Virgin Atlantic said it would cut economy fares on trans-Atlantic flights by about 12 percent. Virgin Atlantic said fares from the United States to London would cost $449, down from $539, starting Sept. 15, and $359, down from $459, starting Oct. 15.
United Airlines said it would probably match Virgin Atlantic's new fares.
Pan Am is offering 25 percent off on flights to most of its destinations this fall. For those flights, passengers are required to buy tickets by Aug. 31 for travel between Sept. 1 and Oct. 26.
Pan Am, based in New York, said travel on those flights must originate in the United States and Europe to destinations in the United States, Europe, the Caribbean, Mexico and South America. The airline said the lower fares did not apply to the Pan Am Shuttle, which operates between New York, Boston and Washington.

HEADLINE: Soviet-Chevron Oil Venture Mired In Fears of Capitalist Exploitation

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The largest Soviet-American business venture ever, a Chevron Corporation plan to develop huge oilfields in Kazakhstan, has become enmeshed in this nation's traditional fear of capitalism and the new muckraking of its free press, leaving President Mikhail S. Gorbachev pressing to get the deal back on track to reassure skeptical foreign investors.
The proposed 25-year, multibillion-dollar venture between Chevron and its Soviet partners in the rich Tengiz oilfields is being restudied and renegotiated at the highest levels of the Gorbachev Government after a series of critical newspaper articles that warn of capitalist greed exploiting Soviet resources under the guise of perestroika, Mr. Gorbachev's program of economic restructuring. 
 And people like former Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze are cautioning that the proposal for the oilfields near the Caspian Sea is being misunderstood at home while the world's business leaders follow it closely as a major test of whether the Government can stifle the old Communist bureaucray and make foreign investment inviting.
"It is no secret that the United States will judge our readiness to cooperate by the success or failure of this project," Mr. Shevardnadze wrote in a newspaper essay. He said that in his most recent trip to the United States, he found political and business leaders pointing to the proposed Chevron deal as a test of Soviet resolve to move toward market capitalism.
In endorsing the Chevron venture, Mr. Shevardnadze said Soviet skepticism was understandable since "it has been dinned into our heads since childhood that capitalists do nothing but rob other states by buying up their wealth for peanuts." But he wrote that the Soviet Government had invested two billion rubles in developing the Tengiz fields since 1979 "with no payoff at all" under a Communist system notorious for wasting resources and abusing the environment.
"Should we continue to 'develop' our natural resources in the same barbaric way or should we turn for help to knowledgable and skillful people equipped with advance technology and experience in running business and making profit?" he wrote, raising the Chevron deal to a prime test case of Mr. Gorbachev's vows to shed the past and find maximum profit in the nation's resources.
 
'Dirty Deal' Asserted
 His warning was carried this week in Moscow News, the freewheeling independent newspaper that has also focused on the privacy of the negotiations over the oil proposal, calling it a "dirty deal" that would mean a hundred-billion-dollar windfall for Chevron with the nation being "plundered and sold for a mere song."
Among other things, the controversy has apparently featured an odd tandem of opponents in the Kremlin bureaucracy disclosing critical internal documents to news reporters in an attempt to stop the plan. Chief among the documents were two Internal Ministry studies recommending against the proposal. President Gorbachev reportedly overruled those traditional ministry views in his determination to push the bureaucracy toward capitalist innovation.
A critical question is how foreign investors will fare as the nation tries to create a new union treaty and redefine power sharing between the republics and the central Government. Kazakhstan's authorities already are openly mistrustful of Kremlin officials in the Chevron deal and are vowing to take greater control of it.
Chevron officials, after gingerly complaining about press distortions and denying accusations that bribes had been paid to clear the way for the plan, have been declining to make further comments.
[A Chevron spokesman, Larry Shushan, said in a telephone interview from the company's San Francisco headquarters, "Because we are currently in negotiations, and negotiations are in something of a sensitive stage, we don't feel it's appropriate to comment on the status of the joint venture."
[In an interview published Aug. 5 by an industry trade magazine, the Oil and Gas Journal, the president of Chevron Overseas Petroleum Inc., Richard Matzke, said: "It would be a terrible mistake to imply that this thing has fallen apart. We've been hunkered down in the trenches the past month until the dust settled over events we don't think were really directly related to our project."
 
Dated Oilfield Techniques
 The proposed joint venture is generating attention not only for its large scope and potential profits but also for its attempt to create a pioneer business venture even as the Soviet economic rules are being rewritten in an environment of the greatest political flux.
One economic goal in this period is to decentralize authority to the republics, including Kazakhstan, yet leave the central Government in Moscow in a position to encourage credibility among outside investors. Still unknown is precisely how the central Government and the Kazakhstan Government might share in the Soviet profits from the proposal.
The Tengiz resources, which some specialists say could produce profits well in excess of $100 billion, beckon as the Soviet Government suffers increasing shortages of hard currency export profits, in part because of dated oilfield techniques that leave it unable to compete in the world market.
The deal may be no less important for the United States as an additional hedge against the power of the OPEC oil cartel in the volatile Middle East.
The latest negotiations involve Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir I. Shcherbakov, Mr. Gorbachev's chief executive for economic change. He said in an interview that, prompted by the Soviet leader's personal order to deal with the controversy, progress was again being made on a deal that has been pursued for four years across the prized Tengiz fields, which cover 8,900 square miles.
Mr. Shcherbakov said ministry opponents who had been quietly leaking their concerns to curious reporters were summoned to air grievances in negotiating fashion before Soviet supporters and Chevron officials in recent weeks, with a delegation sent to negotiate further with Chevron in the United States.
In one apparent result of the newspaper scrutiny, Mr. Shcherbakov said Mr. Gorbachev's Government now wanted "independent evaluators" to estimate the value of the Soviet investment in the joint venture, known as Tengizchevroil, whose oil extractions would be split 50-50. Chevron executives have said the Tengiz field holds two and a half times as much oil as Prudhoe Bay in Alaska.
Nursultan Nazarbayev, President of Kazakhstan, has been looking to the Chevron plan as the key to some elaborate marketeering plans. He said through his office that his "trust in Chevron remains complete," but that he, too, wants "independent evaluators" because he does not trust Moscow's experts.
While the details of the proposal have never been officially released, Moscow News quoted its sources as saying that the promised 50-50 split of development expenses and profits would prove "lopsided," with the Soviet partner contributing $850 million in equipment and expenses to make the fields work, and Chevron only $20 million, expertise and a $150 million loan.
But Kommersant, another independent weekly respected for its business coverage, reported the deal would involve more than $1 billion in foreign infrastructure investments in Tengiz within the first three years. The paper said Mr. Gorbachev ordered a feasibility study of the project in January 1990, and then four months later, shortly before meeting with President Bush, rejected a letter opposing the project from the Oil and Gas Ministry, the Government's traditional oil monopoly.
A protocol of intentions was signed in June 1990 to have Chevron be the partner in developing the Tengiz reserves, but the plan has not yet proceeded to registry with the Government. The deal includes the possibility of elaborate related development in Kazakhstan through the American Trade Consortium to use some of the hard currency profits to open medicine and food processing plants.
The consortium, which pursues joint ventures as a group, includes Chevron, Archer-Daniels-Midland, Eastman Kodak, Johnson & Johnson, RJR Nabisco and the Mercator Corporation, a New York merchant bank.
Mr. Shcherbakov said the latest negotiations were also re-evaluating the deal's potential profits and the ways of exporting this money, always a critical issue in joint ventures, as well as on the rather complicated refining methods required in the Tengiz fields, which some experts say might be twice as productive of the Siberian oil fields.
"We're dealing with a classic moving target," said one Western official familiar with the Chevron proposal. "The Soviets' learning requirements about capitalism is an enormous task after all the decades of fear and ignorance, and this is being amplified by the press demanding to know details of ongoing business negotiations."
The official also noted the difficulties of trying to work out a multilevel deal amid the assorted rivalries of two governments -- the center and sovereignty-hungry Kazakhstan -- and of Chevron's own home office, where basic concerns include the question of whether there will be enough political stability for long-term profits.
